"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7539"	"6-hydroxymethyl-dihydropterin diphosphate biosynthesis III (Chlamydia)"	"PWY-7539"	"|FRAME: DIHYDROPTERIN-CH2OH-PP| (6-hydroxymethyl-dihydropterin diphosphate) is the pterin precursor for the biosynthesis of several important cofactors, including |FRAME:THF-GLU-N tetrahydrofolate|, |FRAME: CPD-10763| and |FRAME: CPD-10764|.
The compound is always synthesized from GTP, but the enzymes involved may differ among organisms.

This pathway variant has been characterized from |FRAME: TAX-810|, obligate intracellular bacteria that cause a wide variety of infectious diseases in humans and animals. Unlike other intracellular bacteria that salvage |FRAME:THF-GLU-N tetrahydrofolate| or its precursors from their hosts, many Chlamydia species have retained the ability to synthesize folate.

While the |FRAME: PWY-6147 \"cannonical pathway\"|, which is found in most bactreria and in eukaryotes, starts with |FRAME: EC-3.5.4.16|, the Chlamydial pathway variant starts with |FRAME: EC-3.5.4.25|, an enzyme that usually functions in flavin biosynthesis |CITS: [25006229]|.

The product is then isomerized to |FRAME: DIHYDRONEOPTERIN-P| by a unique Chlamydial isomerase, encoded by the |FRAME: G-34499| gene. In most organisms this enzyme only catalyzes |FRAME: EC-5.3.1.24|. However, in |FRAME: TAX-810| the enzyme has evolved to afford the additional activity seen in this pathway |CITS: [25006229]|.

The last two steps are identical to the cannonical pathway - the resulting |FRAME: DIHYDRO-NEO-PTERIN| is converted to |FRAME: AMINO-OH-HYDROXYMETHYL-DIHYDROPTERIDINE| by |FRAME: EC-4.1.2.25|, and the last reaction is catalyzed by |FRAME: EC-2.7.6.3|, which in |FRAME: TAX-810| is a bifunctional enzyme that also catalyzes |FRAME: EC-2.5.1.15|.

The unusual pathway is probably a result of a loss of the |FRAME: EG11375| and |FRAME: G-10191| genes, which encode the enzymes that catalyze the first two steps in the cannonical pathway, and the evolution of other enzymes to fulfill the missing roles."				"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=6-HM-Dihydropterin-PP-Biosynthesis"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7852" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6147" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7853" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6797" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7539"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Folate-Biosynthesis"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Vitamin-Biosynthesis"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6147"	"6-hydroxymethyl-dihydropterin diphosphate biosynthesis I"	"PWY-6147"	"|FRAME: DIHYDROPTERIN-CH2OH-PP| (6-hydroxymethyl-dihydropterin diphosphate) is the pterin precursor for the biosynthesis of several important cofactors, including |FRAME:THF|, |FRAME: CPD-10763| and |FRAME: CPD-10764|.
The compound is always synthesized from GTP, but the enzymes involve may differ among organisms.


This pathway, which is found in bacteria, fungi and plants, starts with |FRAME: FOLE-CPLX|, an enzyme that converts GTP into |FRAME: DIHYDRONEOPTERIN-P3|. The triphosphate motif is removed in a process that is still not completely understood, and the resulting |FRAME: DIHYDRO-NEO-PTERIN| is converted to |FRAME: AMINO-OH-HYDROXYMETHYL-DIHYDROPTERIDINE| by |FRAME: CPLX0-3936| (FolB).

In plants the pterin moiety is formed from GTP in the cytosol."	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6612"			"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=6-HM-Dihydropterin-PP-Biosynthesis"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7852" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6147" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7853" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6797" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7539"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Folate-Biosynthesis"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Vitamin-Biosynthesis"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=UDPNAGSYN-PWY"	"UDP-<i>N</i>-acetyl-D-glucosamine biosynthesis I"	"UDPNAGSYN-PWY"	"|FRAME: UDP-N-ACETYL-D-GLUCOSAMINE| (UDP-GlcNAc) is an essential precursor of cell wall peptidoglycan,
lipopolysaccharide and enterobacterial common antigen.  This situates UDP-GlcNAc at a branch point in metabolism,
each fork leading to synthesis of a major envelope component of the cell |CITS: [ColiSalII]|.  The enzymes of these
pathways are targets for development of novel antibacterial compounds (reviewed in |CITS: [17692001]|).

|FRAME: L-GLN-FRUCT-6-P-AMINOTRANS-CPLX|, or GFAT, catalyzes the first committed step in UDP-GlcNAc
biosynthesis from fructose-6-phosphate.  The product of this first reaction, |FRAME: D-GLUCOSAMINE-6-P|, can
also be transported into the cell and utilized as a source of carbon; thus, expression of GFAT is controlled at several
levels.  For details on regulation and the mechanism of uncoupling it from the regulation of |FRAME: EG11198|
expression, please see the protein page: |FRAME: L-GLN-FRUCT-6-P-AMINOTRANS-CPLX|.

|FRAME: D-GLUCOSAMINE-6-P| is then converted to |FRAME: GLUCOSAMINE-1P| by
|FRAME: PHOSGLUCOSAMINEMUT-MONOMER|.  The two final reactions of the pathway, transfer of an acetyl group
from acetyl-CoA to form |FRAME: N-ACETYL-D-GLUCOSAMINE-1-P| and transfer of a uridyl group to form the
final product, UDP-GlcNAc, are carried out by a bifunctional enzyme, GlmU, which contains two domains that carry out
each reaction independently.

"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7332" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6404" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=OANTIGEN-PWY"		"UDP-<i>N</i>-acetyl-D-glucosamine biosynthesis"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=UDP-NAc-Glucosamine-Biosynthesis"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=UDPNACETYLGALSYN-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=UDPNAGSYN-PWY"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=UDP-Sugar-Biosynthesis"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=SUGAR-NUCLEOTIDES"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-1269"	"CMP-3-deoxy-D-<I>manno</I>-octulosonate biosynthesis"	"PWY-1269"	"<b>General Background</b>

The acid sugar |FRAME: KDO| (known as Kdo for ketodeoxyoctonate) is a component of bacterial |FRAME: Lipopolysaccharides lipopolysaccharides| (LPS) and of the |FRAME: CPD-14581 \"rhamnogalacturonan II\"| (RG-II) pectin fraction of the primary cell walls of most higher plants, including dicots, monocots and gymnosperms |CITS:[York85][7958328][shin97][9779594]|.

The number of Kdo units in bacterial polysaccharides vary, depending on the species, but the majority of Gram-negative bacteria contain at least one Kdo molecule in their LPS.
To date, the specific contribution of Kdo to RG-II function in plants remains largely unknown. 

Kdo needs to be activated prior to its incorporation into the polymers. This activation occurs through the unusual coupling of Kdo to the monophosphonucleotide CMP |CITS:[11050325]|.

<b>About This Pathway</b>

Despite incorporating Kdo into very different macromolecules, the Kdo biosynthesis and activation pathway is almost completely conserved between plants and bacteria |CITS: [23974348]|. 

The pathway starts with the isomerization of |FRAME: RIBULOSE-5P| to |FRAME: ARABINOSE-5P|, followed by its conversion to |FRAME: KDO-8P| (KDOP), which is catalyzed by a family of enzymes called |FRAME: EC-2.5.1.55|| (KDOPS). The bacterial KDOPSs have been grouped in two classes, and plant KDOPSs belong to a third class |CITS:[15070398]|.

In the next step the phosphate group is removed from |FRAME: KDO-8P|, generating Kdo. This is catalyzed by the enzyme |FRAME: EC-3.1.3.45|. It should be noted that the plant enzyme responsible for this dephosphorylation has not been identified yet.

The last step of the pathway is the activation of Kdo to |FRAME: CMP-KDO|, which is catalyzed by |FRAME: EC-2.7.7.38|."	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=LPSSYN-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=KDO-NAGLIPASYN-PWY"		"CMP-Kdo biosynthesis I"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=CMP-KDO-Biosynthesis" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=CMP-Sugar-Biosynthesis"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7674" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-1269" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=CMP-N-Acetylneuraminate-Biosynthesis" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=CMP-Legionaminate-Biosynthesis" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=CMP-KDO-Biosynthesis" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6138" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6139" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7131" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6749" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7719" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7529" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6145" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6144" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6143" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6140"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=CMP-Sugar-Biosynthesis" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=SUGAR-NUCLEOTIDES"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=SUGAR-NUCLEOTIDES" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=CARBO-BIOSYNTHESIS"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5659"	"GDP-mannose biosynthesis"	"PWY-5659"	"|FRAME: GDP-MANNOSE| is a key substrate in glycoprotein formation.
In eukaryotes, |FRAME:MANNOSE| is a key monosaccharide for the glycosylation of proteins and lipids.

Mannose-containing glycoconjugates, such as protein <i>N-</i> and <i>C-</i>glycans, some
<i>O</i>-glycans, glycosylphosphatidylinositol (GPI) protein membrane anchors, and some glycolipids,
have a variety of important functions. These functions include the promotion of correct folding, solubility,
stability and intracellular sorting of proteins, promoting the enzymatic, hormonal or receptor activity of
many proteins, and the formation of cell surface glycocalyces, extracellular matrices and protective cell
walls. In addition, glycoproteins are known to play major roles in cell-cell interactions
(see |FRAME: MANNOSYL-CHITO-DOLICHOL-BIOSYNTHESIS|) |CITS: [11447107]|.

|FRAME: GDP-MANNOSE| is the critical metabolite of the mannose activation pathway for
glycoconjugate synthesis in eukaryotes, as it is utilized directly or indirectly as a mannose donor for all
mannosylation reactions.

In addition, |FRAME: GDP-MANNOSE| is a precursor for the biosynthesis of several important
compounds, including |FRAME: GUANOSINE_DIPHOSPHATE_FUCOSE| (see |FRAME: PWY-66|)
|FRAME: ASCORBATE| (see |FRAME: PWY-882|), |FRAME: 2-O-ALPHA-MANNOSYL-D-GLYCERATE|
(see |FRAME: PWY-5656|) and |FRAME: CPD-353| (see |FRAME: GDPRHAMSYN-PWY|).

The crucial role of |FRAME: GDP-MANNOSE| is supported by the finding that deletion of certain genes
in this pathway are lethal in |FRAME: TAX-4932| and |FRAME: TAX-5476| |CITS:[9195935][10844699]
[3288631][3053713]|."	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=COLANSYN-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7323"			"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=GDP-Sugar-Biosynthesis"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5740" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5661" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=GDPRHAMSYN-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7613" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7323" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5738" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5115" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7573" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6478" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5739" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5659" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7610" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-66"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=SUGAR-NUCLEOTIDES"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=CARBO-BIOSYNTHESIS"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7323"	"superpathway of GDP-mannose-derived O-antigen building blocks biosynthesis"	"PWY-7323"	"<b>General Background</b>

|FRAME: Lipopolysaccharides Lipopolysaccharides| (LPS) are a major component of the outer membrane of Gram-negative bacteria. While they are protecting the membrane from certain kinds of chemical attacks, they also induce a strong response from animal immune systems. Lipopolysaccharides can be conceptually divided into three parts: |FRAME: Lipid-A \"lipid A\"|, which anchors LPS into the membrane; core oligosaccharide, which contributes to membrane stability; and the |FRAME: O-Antigens O-antigen|, which is a polysaccharide that extends away from the cell surface.

The composition of the O-antigen varies among different strains, but in general it consists of repeating oligosaccharide subunits made up of three to five sugars. At least 20 different sugars are known to occur, and many of these sugars are unique dideoxyhexoses that are rarely found elsewhere in nature. The variations in sugar content of the O-antigens contribute to the wide variety of antigenic types between species and even strains of Gram-negative bacteria.

Gram-positive bacteria and Archaea do not have a lipopolysaccharide. Instead they possess the S-layer (surface layer) as a component of the cell envelope |CITS: [11742749][1938891]|. The S-layer is composed of a single layer of identical proteins or glycoproteins that form a two-dimensional, monomolecular crystalline array |CITS:[7934867]|. Structurally, S-layer glycoproteins from Gram-positive bacteria resemble the O-antigens of Gram-negative organisms, and often contain similar modified sugar building blocks |CITS: [11741945]|.

<b>About This Pathway</b>

A group of 6-deoxyhexoses, including |FRAME: CPD-13559|, |FRAME: CPD-15612|, |FRAME: CPD-13829|, |FRAME: CPD-9388|, |FRAME: CPD0-1107| and |FRAME: CPD-15615| are used as components of the O-anigen repeating units in lipopolysaccharides of certain Gram-negative bacteria and of the S-layer of some Gram-positive bacteria.

All of these modified sugar residues are synthesized in a GDP nucleotide-activated form from |FRAME: GLC-6-P| via |FRAME: GDP-MANNOSE|. 

Mannose is produced in its 6-phosphate form by the isomerization of |FRAME:GLC-6-P| via |FRAME: FRUCTOSE-6P| This is achieved by the action of the ubiquitous |FRAME: EC-5.3.1.9|, which also participates in glycolysis, and the more specific |FRAME: EC-5.3.1.8| |CITS: [1846611]|. In order to produce the activated mannose donor |FRAME: GDP-MANNOSE| the 6-phosphate is first reconstructed as a 1-phosphate form, followed by the action of |FRAME: EC-2.7.7.13| |CITS:[GaoIntJMassSpec05] [8922954]|.

Before |FRAME: GDP-MANNOSE| can be converted to the other sugars, it loses the the hydroxyl group connected to carbon 6 by the action of |FRAME: EC-4.2.1.47|, producing |FRAME: GDP-4-DEHYDRO-6-DEOXY-D-MANNOSE| |CITS: [14739333]|. This compound is the substrate for several different enzymes, including dehydrogenases, aminotransferases, and dehydratases, resulting in the production of the different modified 6-deoxysugars shown in this pathway." "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Pathways"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=CARBO-BIOSYNTHESIS" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=DTDPRHAMSYN-PWY"	"dTDP-L-rhamnose biosynthesis"	"DTDPRHAMSYN-PWY"	"|FRAME: CPD0-1112| is a deoxysugar that functions as a building block of the glycan component of the lipopolysaccharide present in ECA, the enterobacterial common antigen, and of the O-antigens of many bacterial species |CITS: [11114506][14670712]|. |FRAME: L-rhamnose| is also a component of the plant cell wall pectic polysaccharides |FRAME: Rhamnogalacturonans-I \"rhamnogalacturonan type I\"| and |FRAME: CPD-14581 \"rhamnogalacturonan type II\"| and is present in diverse plant secondary metabolites including anthocyanins, flavonoids and triterpenoids. |FRAME: L-rhamnose| has also been observed in archaebacteria. For example, it is the terminal saccharide of the tetrasaccharide attached to the surface (S)-layer glycoprotein Asn-498 of the halophilic archaeon |FRAME: TAX-2246| |CITS: [22029420][24194539][24831810]|.
Some bacteria such as the actinomycete |FRAME: TAX-60894| also utilize |FRAME: CPD0-1112| as a component of secondary metabolites (see |FRAME: PWY-7100| for an example) |CITS: [11544225 ]| |CITS: [19126547]|.

Like most deoxysugars, |FRAME: CPD0-1112| is synthesized in the activated form of a nucleotide sugar - |FRAME: DTDP-RHAMNOSE|. However, at least in some plants, such as mung bean (|FRAME: TAX-157791|), both |FRAME: DTDP-RHAMNOSE| and |FRAME: UDP-L-RHAMNOSE| act as sugar donors for the rhamnosylation of flavonoids |CITS: [13864832 ]|.

Biosynthesis starts with |FRAME: GLC-1-P|, which is activated by |FRAME: TTP| and converted to |FRAME: DTDP-DEOH-DEOXY-GLUCOSE| in two steps. The first enzyme of the pathway, RmlA (RfbA) (|FRAME: EC-2.7.7.24 \"EC 2.7.7.24\"|), catalyzes the transfer of a thymidylmonophosphate nucleotide to |FRAME: GLC-1-P| |CITS: [11053865]|. The second enzyme, RmlB (|FRAME: EC-4.2.1.46 \"EC 4.2.1.46\"|), catalyzes the oxidation of the C4 hydroxyl group of the sugar, followed by dehydration |CITS: [10666612][11243820]|. These two steps are common in the synthesis of many modified sugars used for O-antigen synthesis (see |FRAME: PWY-7317|).

|FRAME: DTDP-DEOH-DEOXY-GLUCOSE| is then converted to |FRAME:DTDP-DEOH-DEOXY-MANNOSE| by the action of  RmlC (|FRAME: EC-5.1.3.13 \"EC 5.1.3.13\"|) |CITS: [10089454][10802738]|. In most organisms this enzyme only participates in |FRAME: CPD0-1112| production, although in some streptomyces species it also participates in synthesis of |FRAME: CPD-15496| (see |FRAME: PWY-7301|) |CITS: [15752721]|.

The final enzyme of this pathway, |FRAME: EC-1.1.1.133|, reduces the carbon at the 4th position, resulting in |FRAME: CPD0-1112| |CITS: [10666586]|.

The pathway is ubiquitous and highly conserved in both Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria. It is also found in plants, fungi, and lower eukaryotes |CITS: [27009306]|. The last two enzymatic activities (epimerase and reductase) are performed in plants by one bifunctional enzyme, NRS/ER |CITS: [15020741]|."	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7317" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6404" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=OANTIGEN-PWY"			"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=dTDP-Sugar-Biosynthesis"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6953" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7318" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7315" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7438" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7104" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7317" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7688" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6973" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7439" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=DTDPRHAMSYN-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7413" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7316" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7301" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7814" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6974" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7440" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6942" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7414" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7312" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6976" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7657"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=SUGAR-NUCLEOTIDES"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=CARBO-BIOSYNTHESIS"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY0-1261"	"anhydromuropeptides recycling I"	"PWY0-1261"	"|FRAME: Peptidoglycans Peptidoglycan|, the bacterial bag-shaped envelope, is best described as a fisherman net. The net is made of parallel, rather inextensible glycan threads consisting of alternating |FRAME: N-ACETYL-D-GLUCOSAMINE| (GlcNAc) and |FRAME: CPD-19950| (MurNAc) sugars, which are held together by small elastic peptide crosslinks allowing the net to expand or shrink |CITS: [10532377]|.

Gram-negative bacteria recycle a very large proportion of the peptidoglycan polymer during normal growth in a process termed cell wall recycling. For example, the Gram-negative bacterium |FRAME: TAX-562| recycles about half of its cell wall within one generation |CITS: [18535144][23163477]|.

During this process anhydromuropeptides (mainly |FRAME: CPD0-1080|), which are steadily released during growth by lytic transglycosylases and endopeptidases, are imported back into the cytoplasm by the |FRAME: EG12183|-encoded |FRAME: AMPG-MONOMER|.
Once inside the cytoplasm, the anhydromuropeptides are hydrolyzed by |FRAME: EC-3.5.1.28| (|FRAME: EG10041|), |FRAME: EC-3.2.1.52| (|FRAME: G6567|) and |FRAME: EC-3.4.17.13| (|FRAME: G6621|), yielding |FRAME: N-ACETYL-D-GLUCOSAMINE|, |FRAME: CPD0-882|, |FRAME: L-ALA-GAMMA-D-GLU-DAP| and |FRAME: D-ALANINE| |CITS: [    3891732]|.

|FRAME: CPD0-882| is phosphorylated by |FRAME: EC-2.7.1.170| (|FRAME: G6880|) and then converted into |FRAME: N-ACETYL-D-GLUCOSAMINE-6-P| by |FRAME: EC-4.2.1.126| (|FRAME: G7263|). This is a branch point, as this compound could be directed either for further degradation (see pathways of |FRAME: N-Acetylglucosamine-Degradation|) or for recycling into new peptidoglycan monomers, as described in this pathway |CITS: [15901686][15983044]|.
The final product of this pathway, |FRAME: UDP-N-ACETYLMURAMATE|, is one of the precursors for peptidoglycan biosynthesis.

The tripeptide |FRAME: L-ALA-GAMMA-D-GLU-DAP|, which is generated by |FRAME: EC-3.4.17.13|, can be degraded further, as described in |FRAME: PWY0-1546|. However, the vast majority is recycled by muropeptide ligase (|FRAME: EG12440|). This enzyme is a dedicated recycling enzyme that attaches the recovered Ala-Glu-DAP tripeptide to |FRAME: UDP-N-ACETYLMURAMATE|, thereby substituting three amino acid ligases of the peptidoglycan <i>de novo</i> biosynthetic pathway |CITS: [8808921]|.

Although exogenously provided |FRAME: CPD0-882| can be taken up by |FRAME:TAX-562|, it can not serve as the sole source of carbon for growth, suggesting that it may be toxic to the cell |CITS: [16452451]|."			"1,6-anhydro-<i>N</i>-acetylmuramic acid recycling I" // "cell wall recycling I"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Anhydromuropeptides-Recycling"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7883" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY0-1261"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Sugar-Derivatives"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=SECONDARY-METABOLITE-DEGRADATION"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5121"	"superpathway of geranylgeranyl diphosphate biosynthesis II (via MEP)"	"PWY-5121"	"<b>General Background</b>


|FRAME: GERANYLGERANYL-PP| (also known as geranylgeranyl pyrophosphate, or GGPP) is a
crucial compound involved in the biosynthesis of a variety of terpenes and terpenoids, including
central compounds such as ubiquinones and menaquinones.

In plants, |FRAME: GERANYLGERANYL-PP| is an intermediate in the biosynthesis of essentail
compounds such as chlorophylls, carotenoids, tocopherols, plastoquinones, and gibberellins
|CITS:[12427975]|, as well as a variety of secondary metabolites.

In addition, GGPP is also used in posttranslational modifications of proteins (geranylgeranylation) which
is important for membrane adhesion as well as the function of some proteins |CITS:[11500541][16183844]|.

GGPP is synthesized from |FRAME: FARNESYL-PP| either by dedicated enzymes,
such as the |FRAME: YPL069C-MONOMER| of |FRAME: TAX-4932|, or by the action of polyprenyl
transferases such as the |FRAME: MONOMER-13766| from |FRAME: TAX-1061| or
|FRAME: CPLX0-7426| from |FRAME: TAX-83333|.
It should be noted that the building blocks for |FRAME: FARNESYL-PP|
are synthesized in different organisms by different pathways. While most eukaryotes and some
bacteria use the |FRAME: PWY-922|, most bacteria, as well as green algae utilize the
|FRAME: NONMEVIPP-PWY| (as described in the two superpathways |FRAME: PWY-5910| and
|FRAME: PWY-5121|).

In plants, GGPP is synthesized using both routes - in the cytosol using the |FRAME: PWY-922|,
and in the plastids using the |FRAME: NONMEVIPP-PWY|.

This superpathway describes the production of GGPP via the |FRAME:NONMEVIPP-PWY|.

In plants, plastidic GGPP is a central metabolite, involved in the biosythesis of a variety of compounds
(see list given above)." "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Pathways"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=SECONDARY-METABOLITE-BIOSYNTHESIS" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Cofactor-Biosynthesis" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=NIL&object=Generalized-Reactions"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5861"	"superpathway of demethylmenaquinol-8 biosynthesis I"	"PWY-5861"	"<b>General Background</b>

Menaquinones (MK) and demethylmenaquinones (DMK) are low-molecular weight lipophilic components of the cytoplasmic membrane, found in many bacterial species.  These quinones function as a reversible redox component of the electron transfer chain, mediating electron transfer between hydrogenases and cytochromes.
Menaquinones have also been implicated in regulation, as they are necessary for sporulation and proper regulation of cytochrome formation in some Gram-positive bacteria |CITS: [4353869][4202999]|.

Most aerobic Gram-negative bacteria contain ubiquinone as the sole quinone, while most aerobic Gram-positive bacteria contain menaquinone and/or demethylmenaquinones as the main quinone. However, most of the anaerobic bacteria, regardless whether they are Gram-negative or Gram-positive, contain menaquinone or demethylmenaquinone as their main quinones. Some facultatively anaerobic bacteria, such as |FRAME:TAX-562|, contain ubiquinone, menaquinone, and demethylmenaquinone, which they use under different growth conditions |CITS: [11153266]|. The main difference between
these quinone molecules is their redox potential. For example, the redox potential for ubiquinone, demethylmenaquinone, and menaquinone has been measured as +112 mv, +36 mv, and -74 mv, respectively, in the bacterium |FRAME: TAX-729| |CITS: [187454]|.

Menaquinones are considered a vitamin (vitamin K<sub>2</sub>), since they are essential for animals, mostly for the posttranslational modification of certain proteins required for blood coagulation. Animals can not synthesize menaquinones, but usually receive a sufficient amount from bacteria growing in their intestines. In the absence of menaquinone or the related compound |FRAME: 2-METHYL-3-PHYTYL-14-NAPHTHOQUINONE| (vitamin K<sub>1</sub>) which is synthesized in plants, animals suffer from hemorrhage |CITS: [Dam35]|. Menaquinone was first isolated from putrefied fish meal by McKee in 1939 |CITS: [17783315]|, and its structure resolved in 1958 |CITS: [Isler58]|.

The biosynthesis of menaquinones is essentially identical to that of demethylmenaquinones, with one additional step, comprising the addition of a methyl group to the naphthoquinone ring. Many bacterial species do not have this methylase and produce demethylmenaquinone as their sole quinone |CITS: [7022156]|.

All three quinones are synthesized from |FRAME: CHORISMATE|, an intermediate of aromatic amino acid biosynthesis. However, the pathways of (demethyl)menaquinone synthesis diverts from that for ubiquinones early on.
Most organisms synthesize their menaquinones via |FRAME: ISOCHORISMATE|, although some organisms, including |FRAME: TAX-210|, |FRAME: TAX-197|, |FRAME: TAX-1902| and |FRAME: TAX-274|, synthesize menaquinones in alternative pathways, via |FRAME: CPD-10477| or |FRAME: CPD-13324| |CITS: [18801996][21489995][23972005]|.

<b>About This Pathway</b>

In this pathway menaquinone is synthesized from chorismate via |FRAME: ISOCHORISMATE|. In a series of reactions, |FRAME: ISOCHORISMATE| is converted to the two-ring compound |FRAME: DIHYDROXYNAPHTHOATE| via several intermediates that include |FRAME: O-SUCCINYLBENZOATE|. At this point a prenyltransferase enzyme attaches a polyprenyl tail to form |FRAME: Demethylmenaquinones|, which can be converted to |FRAME: Menaquinones| by a
dedicated methylase.

Demethylmenaquinones with a side chain of 8 isoprenyl units (DMK-8) have been detected mainly in facultatively anaerobic Gram-negative bacteria, mostly belonging to the |FRAME: TAX-91347| order (|FRAME: TAX-83333|, |FRAME: TAX-548|, |FRAME: TAX-554|, |FRAME: TAX-584|, and |FRAME: TAX-585|) |CITS:[11945333][4886765][4900998][4100202][4148761]|, but also outside that group, as in the case of |FRAME: TAX-644| |CITS: [4886765]|. However, DMK-8 has also been reported from the Gram-positive bacterium |FRAME: TAX-1351| |CITS: [14321383][118232 ][11722738]|.

Interestingly, most of these organisms produce not only DMK-8 but also |FRAME: UBIQUINONE-8| and |FRAME: CPD-9728|. Since their redox potential is different, each of these electron transfer agents appear to be best suited for specific growth conditions, and having all three maximizes the ability of the organism to adjust to available substrates. It has been suggested that DMK-8 is used for nitrate and |FRAME: TRIMETHYLAMINE-N-O| (TMAO) respiration |CITS: [2849923]|, but its role in nitrate respiration has been contested |CITS: [2204318][1444716][7601837]|." "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Pathways"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Quinone-Biosynthesis" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=NIL&object=Generalized-Reactions"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5686"	"UMP biosynthesis I"	"PWY-5686"	"<b>General Background</b>

Pyrimidine and purine nucleoside triphosphates are the activated precursors of DNA and RNA. The pyrimidine deoxyribonucleoside triphosphates |FRAME: DCTP| and |FRAME: TTP| are incorporated into DNA while the pyrimidine ribonucleoside triphosphates |FRAME: CTP| and |FRAME: UTP| are incorporated into RNA. In addition, mono- or diphosphorylated forms of pyrimidine nucleotides activate other molecules, as in |FRAME: CMP-KDO|, |FRAME: CPD-12575|, and |FRAME: DTDP-D-FUCOSE|, for use in biosynthesis of polysaccharides, glycoproteins and phospholipids |CITS: [9576794][12369616][16024685][16669783]|.

The <i>de novo</i> biosynthetic pathways of pyrimidine nucleotides consume relatively large amounts of high energy phosphate and reducing power, and thus organisms prefer to use salvage pathways when possible. Salvage pathways reutilize exogenous free bases and nucleosides, and some of the resulting pyrimidine nucleotides can enter the <i>de novo</i> biosynthesis pathways to form other nucleotides (see |FRAME: PWY-7193|, |FRAME: PWY-7183| and |FRAME: PWY-7199|).However, the <i>de novo</i> biosynthetic pathways are necessary when exogenous precursors are limiting. In order to conserve resources, the <i>de novo</i> pathways are regulated both by allosteric enzymes and at the gene expression level. These essential, evolutionarily conserved biosynthetic and salvage pathways are found in both prokaryotes and eukaryotes.

|FRAME: L-ASPARTATE|, a precursor of pyrimidine ribonucleotides, is derived from |FRAME: OXALACETIC_ACID|, which is generated in the |FRAME: TCA \"TCA cycle\"|.

<b>About This Pathway</b>

The <i>de novo</i> pyrimidine nucleotide biosynthetic pathway converts |FRAME: HCO3|, |FRAME: GLN|,
|FRAME: L-ASPARTATE| and |FRAME: PRPP| (PRPP) to |FRAME: UMP| (uridine 5'-monophosphate), a pyrimidine nucleotide that can be subsequently converted to all other pyrimidine nucleotides (see |FRAME: PWY-7176|).

The first enzyme, |FRAME: EC-6.3.5.5|, forms |FRAME: CARBAMOYL-P|, which is not only an intermediate of pyrimidine synthesis but also a precursor for the synthesis of amino acids such as |FRAME: ARG|, |FRAME: L-CITRULLINE| and |FRAME: CANAVANINE|. The pathway continues with the condensation of |FRAME: CARBAMOYL-P| with |FRAME: L-ASPARTATE| to form |FRAME: CARBAMYUL-L-ASPARTATE| |CITS: [8041358]|. The products is cyclized to
|FRAME: DI-H-OROTATE|, the first intermediate that contains a pyrimidine ring.

The next step, the oxidation of |FRAME: DI-H-OROTATE| to |FRAME: OROTATE| is carried out by different enzymes in different organisms. In general, Gram-positive bacteria and fungi contain class 1  enzymes, which are cytosolic, include |FRAME: FMN| cofators, and use |FRAME: FUM| or NAD(P)+ as electron acceptors (|FRAME: EC-1.3.98.1|, |FRAME: EC-1.3.1.14|, or |FRAME: EC-1.3.1.15|). Gram-negative bacteria and eukaryotes possess class 2 enzymes, which are membrane bound and use |FRAME: Quinones| as electron acceptor (|FRAME: EC-1.3.5.2 \"EC 1.3.5.2\"|) |CITS: [Jensen98]|.

The final two steps, the condensation of |FRAME: OROTATE| with PRPP forming |FRAME: OROTIDINE-5-PHOSPHATE|
(OMP) followed by the decarboylation of OMP to UMP, are carried out by the enzymes |FRAME: EC-2.4.2.10|
and |FRAME: EC-4.1.1.23|. The last step is considered the rate-limiting step of the overall <i>de novo</i> biosynthesis of pyrimidine nucleotides |CITS: [7579161]|.

In plants, the two initial enzymatic reactions of this pathway occur in the plastids, while all of the remaining reactions occur in the cytosol and mitochondria |CITS: [22474184]|. This implies that |FRAME: CARBAMYUL-L-ASPARTATE| must be exported from the plastids. A plastidic nucleobase transporter specific for uracil (a precursor for pyrimidine salvage pathways) has been reported |CITS: [22474184]|. Since the reaction catalyzed by |FRAME: DIHYDROOROTOX-MONOMER \"dihydroorotate dehydrogenase\"| occurs in the mitochondria, transporters for both |FRAME: DI-H-OROTATE| and |FRAME: OROTATE| must exist, although they have not been identified yet.

The <i>de novo</i> biosynthesis of pyrimidine nucleotides appears to be one of the most ancient biochemical pathways
as it is evolutionary conserved in all species. Although the enzymatic steps in this pathway are conserved throughout all organisms (with the exception of the oxidation of |FRAME: DI-H-OROTATE| to |FRAME: OROTATE|), some differences in the enzymes do exist. For example, in plants and bacteria the three steps leading from |FRAME: CARBAMOYL-P| to |FRAME: OROTATE| are catalyzed by three different proteins, while in mammals they are catalyzed by the single multifunctional |FRAME: CPLX-6703| |CITS: [8619816]|.
Similarly, the last two steps of the pathway are carried out by a bi-functional enzyme (|FRAME: AT3G54470-MONOMER|) in plants and animals |CITS: [2876681][7579161][9878395]| whereas bacteria express two separate proteins for that purpose."	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7211" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY0-162"		"uridine-5'-phosphate biosynthesis I" // "<i>de novo</i> biosynthesis of uridine-5'-phosphate I" // "<i>de novo</i> biosynthesis of uridine-5'-monophosphate I"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=UMP-Biosynthesis"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7791" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5686" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7790"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Pyrimid-Ribonucleot-De-Novo-Biosyn"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Pyrimidine-De-Novo-Biosyn"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY0-162"	"superpathway of pyrimidine ribonucleotides <i>de novo</i> biosynthesis"	"PWY0-162"	"<b>General Background</b>

Pyrimidine and purine nucleoside triphosphates are the activated precursors of DNA and RNA. The pyrimidine deoxyribonucleoside triphosphates |FRAME: DCTP| and |FRAME: TTP| are incorporated into DNA while the ribonucleoside triphosphates |FRAME: CTP| and |FRAME: UTP| are incorporated into RNA. In addition, their diphosphates form activated derivatives of other molecules, such as |FRAME: CPD-12575|, |FRAME: CMP-KDO| and |FRAME: DTDP-D-FUCOSE|, for use in biosynthesis of polysaccharides, glycoproteins and phospholipids |CITS: [9576794][12369616][16024685][16669783]|.

In addition to <i>de novo</i> biosynthesis, salvage pathways reutilize exogenous free bases and nucleosides and some of the resulting pyrimidine nucleotides can enter the <i>de novo</i> biosynthesis pathways (see |FRAME: PWY-7193|, |FRAME: PWY-7183| and |FRAME: PWY-7199|). The <i>de novo</i> biosynthetic pathways consume relatively large amounts of high energy phosphate and reducing power, and thus organisms prefer to use salvage pathways when possible. However, the <i>de novo</i> biosynthetic pathways are necessary when exogenous precursors are limiting. In order to conserve resources, the <i>de novo</i> pathways are regulated both by allosteric enzymes and at the gene expression level.
These essential, evolutionarily conserved biosynthetic and salvage pathways are found in both prokaryotes and eukaryotes.

The pyrimidine nucleotide <i>de novo</i> biosynthetic pathway derives in part from the central metabolic precursors |FRAME: OXALACETIC_ACID| and |FRAME: RIBOSE-5P|. |FRAME: L-ASPARTATE|, a precursor of pyrimidine ribonucleotides, is derived from oxaloacetate, which is generated in the |FRAME: TCA \"TCA cycle\"|.

<b>About This Pathway</b>

The <i>de novo</i> biosynthesis of UMP appears to be one of the most ancient biochemical pathways
as it is evolutionary conserved in all species. The pathway converts |FRAME: HCO3|, |FRAME: GLN|,
|FRAME: L-ASPARTATE| and |FRAME: PRPP| (PRPP) to |FRAME: UMP| (UMP), a pyrimidine nucleotide that can be subsequently converted to all other pyrimidine nucleotides.

The enzyme |FRAME: UMPKI-CPLX| catalyzes the phosphorylation of UMP to form UDP. The eukaryotic enzyme also catalyzes the phosphorylation of CMP to CDP, and was thus named |FRAME: AT5G26667-MONOMER| |CITS: [15604701]|.

The penultimate enzyme in this pathway, |FRAME: NUCLEOSIDE-DIP-KIN-CPLX| (NDK), catalyzes a reaction in which the terminal phosphate of a nucleoside triphosphate is transferred to a nucleoside diphosphate - in this case, the
transfer of a phosphate from the purine ATP to the pyrimidine UDP, forming UTP. The enzyme has a broad substrate specificity, and is involved in the biosynthesis of several nucleoside-triphosphates, including formation of CTP from CDP.

Interconversion between thymidine and cytidine nucleotides is possible only at the level of nucleoside triphosphates, by the glutamine (or ammonia)-dependent enzyme |FRAME: CTPSYN-CPLX|."	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PRPP-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7211"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7176" // // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6937" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5005" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY66-341" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=GLYCINE-SYN2-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=BIOTIN-BIOSYNTHESIS-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6284" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY66-5"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Pyrimidine-De-Novo-Biosyn" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Pathways"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PYR-NUC-SYN" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=NIL&object=Generalized-Reactions"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6123"	"inosine-5'-phosphate biosynthesis I"	"PWY-6123"	"<i>De novo</i> biosynthesis of purines starts with the synthesis of |FRAME: IMP|, which can be converted to all
other purines.

In bacteria and archaea |FRAME:IMP| is synthesized from |FRAME: 5-PHOSPHORIBOSYL-5-AMINOIMIDAZOLE| in 6 steps, while in eukarya the first two steps are replaced by a single reaction (see |FRAME: PWY-6124|).

The first 4 steps of the bacterial pathway are catalyzed by individual enzymes, and the last two steps are catalyzed by a single multifunctional enzyme, |FRAME: AICARTRANSIMPCYCLO-CPLX|, which is encoded by the |FRAME: EG10795| gene.

In archaea the last two steps are catalyzes by two different enzymes (see |FRAME: PWY-7234|).

Genetic studies indicate that in bacterial systems the majority <i>of de</i> novo purine biosynthetic genes are unlinked, but may act as a single unit of regulation controlled by the `purR' repressor protein."	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=DENOVOPURINE2-PWY"		"IMP biosynthesis I"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=IMP-Biosynthesis"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6123" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6124" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7234"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Purine-Ribonuc-De-Novo-Biosynthesis"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Purine-Nucleotide-De-Novo-Biosynthesis"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7234"	"inosine-5'-phosphate biosynthesis III"	"PWY-7234"	"<i>De novo</i> biosynthesis of purines starts with the synthesis of |FRAME: IMP|, which can be converted to all
other purines.

In bacteria and archaea |FRAME:IMP| is synthesized from |FRAME: 5-PHOSPHORIBOSYL-5-AMINOIMIDAZOLE| in 6 steps, while in eukarya the first two steps are replaced by a single reaction (see |FRAME: PWY-6124|).

In bacteria the last two steps are catalyzed by a single multifunctional enzyme encoded by the |FRAME: EG10795| gene (see |FRAME: PWY-6123|).
In archaea, on the other hand, the last two steps are catalyzes by two different enzymes. The penultimate step is catalyzed by the archaeal PurP enzyme, which is format-dependent and does not require folate |CITS: [9150241]| and the last step is catalyzed by PurO. No homology exists between PurH and either PurO or PurP |CITS: [15623504]|."			"IMP biosynthesis I"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=IMP-Biosynthesis"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6123" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6124" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7234"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Purine-Ribonuc-De-Novo-Biosynthesis"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Purine-Nucleotide-De-Novo-Biosynthesis"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7219"	"adenosine ribonucleotides <i>de novo</i> biosynthesis"	"PWY-7219"	"The first purine nucleotide that is synthesized <i>de novo</i> is |FRAME: IMP| (IMP). IMP is converted to |FRAME: ADENYLOSUCC| by the enzyme |FRAME: EC-6.3.4.4|, and the latter is converted to the first adenosine nucleotide, |FRAME: AMP \"adenosine 5'-monophosphate\"| (AMP) by the action of |FRAME: EC-4.3.2.2|.

AMP is phosphorylated to ADP and subsequently to ATP. The first reaction is catalyzed by |FRAME: EC-2.7.4.3|. 

Reactions that convert ADP to ATP are numerous and found in multiple pathways, including fueling pathways such as anaerobic respiration, TCA-cycle based aerobic respiration, fermentation, and glycolysis, and thus this conversion is not included in this pathway. A major source for this conversion is the |FRAME: CPLX490-3510 ATP synthase| complex (|FRAME: EC-3.6.3.14 \"EC 3.6.3.14\"|), which is membrane bound and utilizes the proton gradient across membranes to phosphorylate ADP. That enzyme is described in pathway |FRAME: PWY-7980|.

In some bacteria ADP can also be converted to the deoxy form |FRAME: DATP| (see |FRAME:PWY-7220|).

Genetic studies indicate that in bacterial systems the majority of <i>de novo</i> purine biosynthetic genes are unlinked but may act as a single unit of regulation controlled by the |FRAME: PC00033| |CITS:[2404765]|."	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY66-409" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7229" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-841" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6126"			"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Purine-Ribonuc-De-Novo-Biosynthesis"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=IMP-Biosynthesis" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6123" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6124" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7234" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7219" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7221"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Purine-Nucleotide-De-Novo-Biosynthesis"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PUR-NUC-SYN"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7221"	"guanosine ribonucleotides <i>de novo</i> biosynthesis"	"PWY-7221"	"The first purine nucleotide that is synthesized <i>de novo</i> is |FRAME: IMP|. IMP is converted to |FRAME: XANTHOSINE-5-PHOSPHATE| by the enzyme |FRAME: IMP-DEHYDROG-CPLX|, and the latter is converted to the first guanosine nucleotide, |FRAME: GMP|, by the action of |FRAME: GMP-SYN-CPLX|, an enzyme that can use either glutamine or ammonia as substrate.

GMP is phosphorylated to |FRAME: GDP| and subsequently to |FRAME: GTP| by the enzymes
|FRAME: GUANYL-KIN-CPLX| and |FRAME: NUCLEOSIDE-DIP-KIN-CPLX|, respectively.

In bacterial systems genetic studies indicate that the majority of <i>de novo</i> purine biosynthetic genes are unlinked but may act as a single unit of regulation controlled by the `purR' repressor protein |CITS: [2404765]|."	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY66-409" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-841" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7228" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6125"			"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Purine-Ribonuc-De-Novo-Biosynthesis"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=IMP-Biosynthesis" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6123" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6124" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7234" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7219" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7221"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Purine-Nucleotide-De-Novo-Biosynthesis"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PUR-NUC-SYN"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6609"	"adenine and adenosine salvage III"	"PWY-6609"	"Adenosine nucleotides can be synthesized <i>de novo</i>. In that route |FRAME: AMP| (AMP) is synthesized via |FRAME: IMP| (IMP) and |FRAME: ADENYLOSUCC| , which is converted to AMP by the action of
|FRAME: ASL-MONOMER| (see |FRAME: PWY-6126|). Note that the free base |FRAME: ADENINE| or the ribonucleoside |FRAME: ADENOSINE| are not produced via the <i>de novo</i> pathway.

Many organisms can also recycle adenosine nucleotides by a combination of degradation and salvage pathways. The degradation pathways are responsible for the conversion of the nucleotides to the nucleoside (|FRAME: ADENOSINE|) and  free base form (|FRAME: ADENINE|), and further degradation to compounds that can be catabolized to basic building blocks (for example, see |FRAME: SALVADEHYPOX-PWY|).

The distinction between nucleoside degradation and recycling is not always straight forward.
This pathway shares several steps with the pathway |FRAME: SALVADEHYPOX-PWY|. However, this salvage pathway starts with |FRAME: ADENINE| (which is often transported into the organism) and ends with |FRAME: IMP|, leading to biosynthesis of nucleotides, while the degradation pathway starts with the nucleotide form (|FRAME: AMP|) and ends with |FRAME: URATE|, which in most organisms is degraded further.

A key enzyme in this pathway is adenosine deaminase, which converts |FRAME: ADENOSINE| to |FRAME: INOSINE|. This has been shown to be the main form of adenosine degradation by the fungi |FRAME: TAX-36642| |CITS: [7551735]| and |FRAME:TAX-293373| |CITS: [15812856]|."			"adenosine nucleotides salvage III"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Adenine-Adenosine-Salvage"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6605" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6619" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6609" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6610" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=P121-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6611"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Purine-Nucleotides-Salvage"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PUR-NUC-SYN"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=HSERMETANA-PWY"	"L-methionine biosynthesis III"	"HSERMETANA-PWY"	"<b>General Background</b>

|FRAME: MET| (Met) is one of the proteinogenic amino acids. In addition to its role in protein biosynthesis, L-methionine is required for a number of important cellular functions, including the initiation of protein synthesis, the methylation of DNA, rRNA and xenobiotics, and the biosynthesis of cysteine, phospholipids and polyamines. In all metzoa |FRAME: MET| is an essential amino acid (an indispensable amino acid that cannot be synthesized <i>de novo</i>) and must be supplied in the diet.

Some bacteria can synthesize methionine using organic sulfur through transsulfuration of |FRAME: O-SUCCINYL-L-HOMOSERINE| with |FRAME: CYS| to form |FRAME: L-CYSTATHIONINE|. Cystathionine is then cleaved to |FRAME: HOMO-CYS|, which is methylated to methionine (see |FRAME: HOMOSER-METSYN-PWY|) |CITS: [3309561]|. Plants use a modification of this pathway, where |FRAME: O-PHOSPHO-L-HOMOSERINE|, instead of |FRAME: O-SUCCINYL-L-HOMOSERINE|, is the intermediate converting homoserine to cystathionine (see |FRAME: PWY-702|).

Other bacteria, as well as yeast and fungi, can use a different route in which they directly assimilate inorganic sulfur by a sulfhydrylation (this pathway). In this route |FRAME: HS|, the final product of microbial sulfate reduction (see MetaCyc pathway |FRAME: SO4ASSIM-PWY|) reacts with <i>O</i>-acetylated homoserine, with replacement of the acetyl group by sulfide to form |FRAME: HOMO-CYS|, which is once again methylated to methionine (see |FRAME: PWY-5344|).

Most methanogenic archaea utilize yet a different pathway. While these organisms also use |FRAME: HS| as the sulfur source, the other precursor for |FRAME: HOMO-CYS| production is |FRAME: L-ASPARTATE-SEMIALDEHYDE|, produced from |FRAME: L-ASPARTATE| (see |FRAME: PWY-7977|).

Methylation of |FRAME: HOMO-CYS| is catalyzed by either a cobalamin-independent enzyme (|FRAME: EC-2.1.1.13 \"EC 2.1.1.13\"|) or a cobalamin-dependent enzyme (|FRAME: EC-2.1.1.14 \"EC 2.1.1.14\"|), depending upon the species or growth conditions |CITS: [9409150][12948640]|.


<b>About This Pathway</b>

Organisms for which there is evidence for the existence of a direct sulfhydrylation pathway for methionine biosynthesis include |FRAME:TAX-4932| (reviewed in |CITS: [9409150]|), the spirochete |FRAME: TAX-29508| |CITS: [9440513], [12951250]|, |FRAME:TAX-1423| |CITS: [11832514]|, |FRAME:TAX-92706| |CITS: [7096282], [7275950]|, |FRAME:TAX-1718|
|CITS: [11844756]|, |FRAME:TAX-287| |CITS: [10482527]|, and |FRAME:TAX-303| |CITS: [10482527]|. In these organisms, there is also evidence for the transsulfuration pathway, and the use of one pathway may predominate over the other.
In |FRAME:TAX-562| and other enteric bacteria only the transsulfuration pathway is used (Greene, R.C. in |CITS: [COLISAL]| pp. 542-560).  

The presence of |FRAME: EC-2.5.1.49|, is considered indicative of the presence of a direct sulfhydrylation pathway.

Note that all bacterial methionine biosynthetic pathways involve acylated homoserine. However, the <i>O</i>-acyl group is an acetyl group in fungi, yeast, and most Gram-positive bacteria (see |FRAME: HSERMETANA-PWY|) but a succinyl group in enteric bacteria and some other Gram-negative bacteria, such as |FRAME:TAX-287| and |FRAME:TAX-303| (this pathway) (|CITS: [10482527][3309561][9409150]|)." "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY66-5"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=METHIONINE-SYN" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Pathways"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=IND-AMINO-ACID-SYN" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=NIL&object=Generalized-Reactions"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5345"	"superpathway of L-methionine biosynthesis (by sulfhydrylation)"	"PWY-5345"	"|FRAME: MET| (met) is one of the proteinogenic amino acids. In addition to its role in proteins, L-methionine is required for a number of important cellular functions, including the initiation of protein synthesis, the methylation of DNA, rRNA and xenobiotics, and the biosynthesis of cysteine, phospholipids and polyamines.

In all metzoa |FRAME: MET| is an essential amino acid (an indispensable amino acid that cannot be synthesized <i>de novo</i>) and must be supplied in the diet.

Most bacteria, yeast and fungi can directly assimilate inorganic sulfur for the biosynthesis of sulfur-containing amino acids.  This pathway depicts such a direct sulfhydrylation pathway for the biosynthesis of |FRAME: MET|.

|FRAME:HOMO-SER| is biosynthesized from |FRAME: L-ASPARTATE|, which is synthesized from |FRAME:OXALACETIC_ACID|, a TCA cycle intermediate. Homoserine is then activated through esterification to form the <i>O</i>-acetyl ester. In most organisms |FRAME: HS|, the final product of sulfate reduction (see |FRAME: SO4ASSIM-PWY|), reacts with |FRAME:ACETYLSERINE| generating |FRAME: CYS| (see |FRAME:CYSTSYN-PWY|).
However, in certain organisms, including the yeast |FRAME: TAX-4932| and certain bacteria, |FRAME: HS| reacts with |FRAME:CPD-667|, replacing the acetyl group and forming |FRAME:HOMO-CYS|. Homocysteine is then methylated to |FRAME: MET| via either a cobalamin-independent enzyme or a cobalamin-dependent enzyme, depending upon the species and growth conditions |CITS: [12948640][9409150]|.

The other route of microbial methionine biosynthesis involves the use of organic sulfur through transsulfuration of <i>O</i>-acylated homoserine with cysteine to form cystathionine (see MetaCyc pathway |FRAME: PWY-5347|). Cystathionine is then cleaved to homocysteine, and methylated to methionine |CITS: [3309561]|.

Organisms for which there is evidence for the existence of a direct sulfhydrylation pathway for methionine biosynthesis include  |FRAME: TAX-4932| |CITS: [9409150]|, the spirochete |FRAME: TAX-29508| |CITS: [9440513][12951250]|, |FRAME: TAX-1423| |CITS: [11832514]|, |FRAME: TAX-92706| |CITS: [7096282][7275950]|, |FRAME: TAX-1718| |CITS: [11844756]|, |FRAME: TAX-287| |CITS: [10482527]|, and |FRAME: TAX-303| |CITS: [10482527]|.
In most of these organisms, there is also evidence for the transsulfuration pathway, and the use of one pathway may predominate over the other.  In |FRAME: TAX-83333| and other enteric bacteria, only the transsulfuration pathway is used (Greene, R.C. in |CITS: [COLISAL]| pp. 542-560).

The <i>O</i>-acyl group of homoserine is an acetyl group in fungi, yeast and most Gram positive bacteria, or a succinyl group in enteric bacteria, as well as |FRAME: TAX-287| and |FRAME: TAX-303| |CITS:[10482527][3309561][9409150]|."		"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=SO4ASSIM-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=HSERMETANA-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5344" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=HOMOSERSYN-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=ASPARTATESYN-PWY"		"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Methionine-De-novo-Biosynthesis" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Super-Pathways"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5345" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=HOMOSER-METSYN-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5347" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Pathways"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=IND-AMINO-ACID-SYN" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=NIL&object=Generalized-Reactions"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5347"	"superpathway of L-methionine biosynthesis (transsulfuration)"	"PWY-5347"	"|FRAME: MET| (met) is one of the proteinogenic amino acids. In addition to its role in proteins, L-methionine is required for a number of important cellular functions, including the initiation of protein synthesis, the methylation of DNA, rRNA and xenobiotics, and the biosynthesis of cysteine, phospholipids and polyamines.

In all metzoa |FRAME: MET| is an essential amino acid (an indispensable amino acid that cannot be synthesized <i>de novo</i>) and must be supplied in the diet.

This superpathway describes the biosynthesis of the amino acid |FRAME: MET| via the transsulfuration pathway.

|FRAME:HOMO-SER| is biosynthesized from |FRAME: L-ASPARTATE|, which is synthesized from |FRAME:OXALACETIC_ACID|, a TCA cycle intermediate. Homoserine is then activated through esterification to form the <i>O</i>-succinyl ester. In the next step, the enzyme |FRAME:O-SUCCHOMOSERLYASE-ENZRXN| catalyzes a transsulfuration of  |FRAME:O-SUCCINYL-L-HOMOSERINE| with |FRAME:CYS| forming |FRAME:L-CYSTATHIONINE|,
which is then cleaved to |FRAME:HOMO-CYS| and methylated to |FRAME: MET| |CITS: [3309561]|. The methylation can be catalyzed by either a cobalamin-independent enzyme or a cobalamin-dependent enzyme, depending upon the species and growth conditions |CITS: [12948640][9409150]|.

The other route of microbial methionine biosynthesis involves the use of inorganic sulfur via sulfhydrylation of |FRAME:CPD-667| with |FRAME: HS|, forming |FRAME:HOMO-CYS| which is methylated to |FRAME: MET| (see |FRAME:PWY-5345|).

The <i>O</i>-acyl group of homoserine is an acetyl group in fungi, yeast and most Gram positive bacteria, or a succinyl group in enteric bacteria, as well as |FRAME: TAX-287| and |FRAME: TAX-303| |CITS:[10482527][3309561][9409150]|." "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY66-5"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=METHIONINE-SYN" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Pathways"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=IND-AMINO-ACID-SYN" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=HOMOSER-METSYN-PWY"	"L-methionine biosynthesis I"	"HOMOSER-METSYN-PWY"	"<b>General Background</b>

|FRAME: MET| (Met) is one of the proteinogenic amino acids. In addition to its role in protein biosynthesis, L-methionine is required for a number of important cellular functions, including the initiation of protein synthesis, the methylation of DNA, rRNA and xenobiotics, and the biosynthesis of cysteine, phospholipids and polyamines. In all metzoa |FRAME: MET| is an essential amino acid (an indispensable amino acid that cannot be synthesized <i>de novo</i>) and must be supplied in the diet.

Some bacteria can synthesize methionine using organic sulfur through transsulfuration of |FRAME: O-SUCCINYL-L-HOMOSERINE| with |FRAME: CYS| to form |FRAME: L-CYSTATHIONINE|. Cystathionine is then cleaved to |FRAME: HOMO-CYS|, which is methylated to methionine (this pathway) |CITS: [3309561]|. Plants use a modification of this pathway, where |FRAME: O-PHOSPHO-L-HOMOSERINE|, instead of |FRAME: O-SUCCINYL-L-HOMOSERINE|, is the intermediate converting homoserine to cystathionine (see |FRAME: PWY-702|).

Other bacteria, as well as yeast and fungi, can use a different route in which they directly assimilate inorganic sulfur by a sulfhydrylation (see |FRAME:HSERMETANA-PWY|). In that route |FRAME: HS|, the final product of microbial sulfate reduction (see MetaCyc pathway |FRAME: SO4ASSIM-PWY|) reacts with <i>O</i>-acetylated homoserine, with replacement of the acetyl group by sulfide to form |FRAME: HOMO-CYS|, which is once again methylated to methionine (see |FRAME: PWY-5344|).

Most methanogenic archaea utilize yet a different pathway. While these organisms also use |FRAME: HS| as the sulfur source, the other precursor for |FRAME: HOMO-CYS| production is |FRAME: L-ASPARTATE-SEMIALDEHYDE|, produced from |FRAME: L-ASPARTATE| (see |FRAME: PWY-7977|).

Methylation of |FRAME: HOMO-CYS| is catalyzed by either a cobalamin-independent enzyme (|FRAME: EC-2.1.1.13 \"EC 2.1.1.13\"|) or a cobalamin-dependent enzyme (|FRAME: EC-2.1.1.14 \"EC 2.1.1.14\"|), depending upon the species or growth conditions |CITS: [9409150][12948640]|.

<b>About This Pathway</b>

While many organisms seem to contain both routes for methionine biosynthesis, in |FRAME:TAX-562| and other enteric bacteria only the transsulfuration pathway is used (Greene, R.C. in |CITS: [COLISAL]| pp. 542-560).  Published evidence for these pathways includes gene identification; complementation of known mutants; analysis of mutant phenotypes; and gene cloning, expression, and enzyme activity assays.
The presence of |FRAME: EC-2.5.1.49| was considered indicative of the presence of a direct sulfhydrylation pathway.

Note that all bacterial methionine biosynthetic pathways involve acylated homoserine. However, the <i>O</i>-acyl group is an acetyl group in fungi, yeast, and most Gram-positive bacteria (see |FRAME: HSERMETANA-PWY|) but a succinyl group in enteric bacteria and some other Gram-negative bacteria, such as |FRAME:TAX-287| and |FRAME:TAX-303| (this pathway) (|CITS: [10482527][3309561][9409150]|)."	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=METSYN-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5347" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=P4-PWY"		"L-methionine biosynthesis from L-homoserine" // "L-methionine biosynthesis by transsulfuration"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Methionine-De-novo-Biosynthesis"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5345" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=HOMOSER-METSYN-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5347" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=HSERMETANA-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-702" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=METSYN-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7977"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=METHIONINE-SYN"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=IND-AMINO-ACID-SYN"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=HEMESYN2-PWY"	"heme <i>b</i> biosynthesis II (anaerobic)"	"HEMESYN2-PWY"	"Heme (protoheme, heme <i>b</i>) is an iron-containing prosthetic group found in many essential proteins including cytochromes and heme-containing globins.  It is a porphyrin member of the cyclic tetrapyrroles. It is biosynthesized as protoheme, but different derivatives of protoheme can be formed that differ in modifications to the porphyrin ring, including how it is bound to the protein, such as |FRAME: HEME_O|, |FRAME: HEME_A|, |FRAME: HEME_C|, and |FRAME: HEME_D|.

The main difference between this protoheme biosynthetic pathway and the one shown at |FRAME: HEME-BIOSYNTHESIS-II| is the presence of the enzyme |FRAME: EC-1.3.98.3|, which catalyzes the transition from |FRAME: COPROPORPHYRINOGEN_III| to |FRAME: PROTOPORPHYRINOGEN| without the need for molecular oxygen. In addition, |FRAME: EC-1.3.3.4|, which under aerobic conditions catalyzes the oxidation of |FRAME: PROTOPORPHYRINOGEN| to |FRAME: PROTOPORPHYRIN_IX| using molecular oxygen, is replaced under anaerobic conditions with |FRAME: EC-1.3.5.3|, which uses a quinone instead of molecular oxygen.

|FRAME: EC-1.3.98.3|, is found in many bacteria, but does not appear to be present in archaea or eukarya (the only reference for its presence in a eukaryote is in the organism |FRAME: TAX-5911|, but this finding is based on sequence analysis alone, and has not been verified biochemically).

Important branch points within this pathway lead to biosynthesis of other important compounds such as vitamin B<sub>12</sub> (cobalamin) (see |FRAME: P381-PWY|), |FRAME: CPD-7425| (see |FRAME: PWY-5196|), |FRAME: SIROHEME| (see |FRAME: PWY-5194|), heme D biosynthesis, and bacteriochlorophyll (see |FRAME: CHLOROPHYLL-SYN|).

This topic has been reviewed in |CITS: [13680202], [12177321], [16093570]|."	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY0-1415"			"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Heme-b-Biosynthesis"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=HEMESYN2-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7766" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5918" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY0-1415" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5920" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=HEME-BIOSYNTHESIS-II" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7552"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=HEME-SYN"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Porphyrin-Compounds-Biosynthesis"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=HEME-BIOSYNTHESIS-II"	"heme <i>b</i> biosynthesis I (aerobic)"	"HEME-BIOSYNTHESIS-II"	"<b>General Background</b>

|FRAME: Hemes Heme| (protoheme, heme <i>b</i>) is an iron-containing prosthetic group found in many essential proteins including cytochromes and heme-containing globins. In addition to its role in oxidative metabolism, heme also functions as a regulatory molecule in transcription, translation, protein targeting, protein stability, and cellular differentiation.

Heme is a porphyrin member of the cyclic tetrapyrroles. Even though it is biosynthesized as |FRAME: Heme-b|, different derivatives of protoheme can be formed that differ in modifications to the porphyrin ring, including how it is bound to the protein, such as |FRAME: HEME_O|, |FRAME: HEME_A|, |FRAME: HEME_C|, and |FRAME: HEME_D|.

<b>About This Pathway</b>

This pathway describes the common aerobic route for |FRAME: Heme-b| biosynthesis. This pathway involves the enzymes |FRAME: COPROGENOXI-MONOMER| and |FRAME: MONOMER-17460|, which require moelecular oxygen for their respective reactions.

There are several types of protoporphyrinogen oxidases: in most eukaryotes and many aerobic or facultative bacteria, such as Firmicutes, the enzyme is a FAD-dependent ~55 kDa protein encoded by the |FRAME: BSU10140| gene. A number of &gamma;-proteobacteria, including |FRAME:TAX-562|, have another type of oxidase, a 21 kDa protein encoded by the |FRAME: EG11485| gene. Most archaea and many other bacteria, including the majority of cyanobacteria, have a third version of the enzyme, a 24 kDa protein encoded by |FRAME: G-15222| |CITS: [20823222]|."	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5920" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5918"			"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Heme-b-Biosynthesis"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=HEMESYN2-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7766" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5918" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY0-1415" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5920" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=HEME-BIOSYNTHESIS-II" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7552"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=HEME-SYN"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Porphyrin-Compounds-Biosynthesis"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5918"	"superpathay of heme <i>b</i> biosynthesis from glutamate"	"PWY-5918"	"Heme (protoheme, heme <i>b</i>) is an iron-containing prosthetic group found in many essential proteins
including cytochromes and heme-containing globins. 
In addition to its role in oxidative metabolism, heme also functions as a regulatory molecule in
transcription, translation, protein targeting, protein stability, and cellular differentiation.

Heme is a porphyrin member of the cyclic tetrapyrroles. Even though it is biosynthesized as
|FRAME: Heme-b|, different derivatives of protoheme can be formed that differ in
modifications to the porphyrin ring, including how it is bound to the protein, such as |FRAME: HEME_O|,
|FRAME: HEME_A|, |FRAME: HEME_C|, and |FRAME: HEME_D|.

The protoheme biosynthetic pathway shown here is found in some bacteria (including
|FRAME: TAX-83333|), archaea, and plants. In these organisms the tetrapyrrole biosynthesis pathway
starts with glutamate (see |FRAME: PWY-5188|).

In many other organisms, including animals, fungi, apicomplexan protozoa (such as the malaria parasite
|FRAME: TAX-5833| |CITS: [15144063]|), and members of the &alpha;-proteobacteria, the tetrapyrrole
biosynthesis pathway starts with glycine and succinyl-CoA (see |FRAME:PWY-5189|).
Both the glycine and glutamate pathways are present in the chloroplast-containing |FRAME: TAX-3039|
(reviewed in |CITS: [13680202], [15576047], [12051904], [16093570]|).

Both tetrapyrrole biosynthetic pathways merge at the intermediate |FRAME: 5-AMINO-LEVULINATE|.
However, a branch point at |FRAME: UROPORPHYRINOGEN-III| leads to biosynthesis of different
compounds such as vitamin B<sub>12</sub> (cobalamin) (see |FRAME: P381-PWY|),
|FRAME: CPD-7425| (see |FRAME: PWY-5196|), |FRAME: SIROHEME| (see |FRAME: PWY-5194|),
and heme D biosynthesis.
A second branch point at |FRAME: PROTOPORPHYRIN_IX| leads to biosynthesis of chlorophyll
in plants and bacteriochlorophyll in photosynthetic bacteria (see |FRAME: CHLOROPHYLL-SYN|).
In eukaryotes, heme biosynthesis spans the mitochondrial (or plastid) and cytosol compartments.

This topic has been reviewed in |CITS: [13680202], [12177321], [16093570]|." "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY0-381" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7237" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-3282" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6595" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6963" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Pathways"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Porphyrin-Compounds-Biosynthesis" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=NIL&object=Generalized-Reactions"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5920"	"superpathway of <i>b</i> heme biosynthesis from glycine"	"PWY-5920"	"<b>General Background</b>

Heme (protoheme, heme <i>b</i>) is an iron-containing prosthetic group found in many essential proteins
including cytochromes and heme-containing globins. 
In addition to its role in oxidative metabolism, heme also functions as a regulatory molecule in
transcription, translation, protein targeting, protein stability, and cellular differentiation.

Heme is a porphyrin member of the cyclic tetrapyrroles. Even though it is biosynthesized as
|FRAME: Heme-b|, different derivatives of protoheme can be formed that differ in
modifications to the porphyrin ring, including how it is bound to the protein, such as |FRAME: HEME_O|,
|FRAME: HEME_A|, |FRAME: HEME_C|, and |FRAME: HEME_D|.

The protoheme biosynthetic pathway shown here is found in animals, fungi, apicomplexan protozoa
(such as the malaria parasite |FRAME: TAX-5833| |CITS: [15144063]|), and members of the
&alpha;-proteobacteria.  In these organisms the tetrapyrrole biosynthesis pathway starts with glycine
and succinyl-CoA (see |FRAME:PWY-5189|).
In other bacteria (including |FRAME:TAX-562|) and archaea, tetrapyrrole biosynthesis begins with
glutamate instead of glycine (see |FRAME:PWY-5188|). Plants also biosynthesize heme via
glutamate for use in cytochromes and compounds derived from heme. Both the glycine and glutamate pathways are present in the chloroplast-containing |FRAME: TAX-3039| (reviewed in |CITS: [13680202], [15576047], [12051904], [16093570]|).

Both tetrapyrrole biosynthetic pathways merge at the intermediate |FRAME: 5-AMINO-LEVULINATE|.
however, a branch point at |FRAME: UROPORPHYRINOGEN-III| leads to biosynthesis of different
compounds such as vitamin B<sub>12</sub> (cobalamin) (see |FRAME: P381-PWY|),
|FRAME: CPD-7425| (see |FRAME: PWY-5196|), |FRAME: SIROHEME| (see |FRAME: PWY-5194|),
and heme D biosynthesis.

A second branch point at |FRAME: PROTOPORPHYRIN_IX| leads to biosynthesis of chlorophyll
in plants and bacteriochlorophyll in photosynthetic bacteria (see |FRAME: CHLOROPHYLL-SYN|).
In eukaryotes, heme biosynthesis spans the mitochondrial (or plastid) and cytosol compartments.

This topic has been reviewed in |CITS: [13680202], [12177321], [16093570]|.    

<b>About This Pathway</b>

This MetaCyc pathway shows many enzymes and genes for heme biosynthesis in |FRAME: TAX-9606| and the photosynthetic purple nonsulfur &alpha;-proteobacterium |FRAME: TAX-1063|.

|FRAME: TAX-1063| possesses two chromosomes and five additional replicons. Two genes encoding 5-aminolevulinate synthase, <i>hemA</i> and <i>hemT</i>, are present on chromosomes 1 and 2, respectively. Biosynthesis of the tetrapyrrole cofactors heme, bacteriochlorophyll, siroheme and cobalamin in this organism is highly regulated and is dependent upon expression of these two isozymes (in |CITS: [7592416], [10491185]|). The <i>hemA</i> gene product is expressed under normal aerobic and photosynthetic conditions, under which the <i>hemT</i> gene product is not expressed. No activity could be demonstrated for the purified, recombinant <i>hemT</i> gene product <i>in vitro</i> |CITS: [10491185]|. 

In |FRAME: TAX-1063|, no <i>hemD</i> gene encoding uroporphyrinogen III synthase has been identified. A 
gene encoding coproporphyrinogen III oxidase (oxygen-dependent) has been identified as <i>hemF</i> and has amino acid sequence similarities to the eukaryotic enzyme. However, oxygen-independent 
(anaerobic) <i>hemN</i> and <i>hemZ</i> encoded forms of the enzyme also exist in this organism, and there is 
evidence that these two alleles were duplicated |CITS: [15028685]|. In |FRAME: TAX-1063| and many other 
prokaryotes, no gene encoding protoporphyrinogen IX oxidase (EC 1.3.3.4) has been definitively identified, 
although the gene has been identified as <i>hemG</i> in |FRAME:TAX-562| and <i>hemY</i> 
in |FRAME: TAX-1423|. Reviewed in |CITS: [12177321]|.    

The ferrochelatase reaction involves incorporation of ferrous iron. In bacteria the mechanisms for acquisition of 
ferrous and ferric iron depend upon which form is available in the environment and its abundance. The source 
of ferrous iron for this reaction in bacteria may involve direct import by divalent metal ion transporters, more 
complex mechanisms involving siderophores, other transport systems, and extracellular reductases |CITS: [12054438]|. Reviewed in |CITS: [12829269]|.

In humans, the eight steps of the pathway are divided between the cytosol and the mitochondria, with the final product heme, being synthesized in the mitochondria. The pathway occurs in many cell types and is regulated in a tissue and cell specific manner. The first reaction of the pathway catalyzed by |FRAME: CPLX66-342| or |FRAME: CPLX66-342| is considered the rate-limiting step |CITS: [23471474]|. Defects in any of the enzymes in humans, leads to a group of inherited disorders called porphyrias."
