// "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Pathways"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Porphyrin-Compounds-Biosynthesis" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=NIL&object=Generalized-Reactions"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY0-1415"	"superpathway of heme <i>b</i> biosynthesis from uroporphyrinogen-III"	"PWY0-1415"	"Heme (protoheme, heme <i>b</i>) is an iron-containing prosthetic group found in many essential proteins including cytochromes and heme-containing globins.  It is a porphyrin member of the cyclic tetrapyrroles.
It is biosynthesized as protoheme, but different derivatives of protoheme can be formed that differ in modifications to the porphyrin ring, including how it is bound to the protein, such as |FRAME: HEME_O|, |FRAME: HEME_A|, |FRAME: HEME_C|, and |FRAME: HEME_D|.

This superpathway shows the two routes of synthesis found in the facultative anaerobe |FRAME:TAX-562|. Under aerobic conditions, the transition from |FRAME: COPROPORPHYRINOGEN_III| to |FRAME: PROTOPORPHYRINOGEN| is catalyzed by the oxygen -dependent |FRAME: COPROGENOXI-MONOMER| (EC 1.3.3.3). However, when oxygen is not available, the organism is still able to catalyze this transition, using the readical-SAM enzyme |FRAME: HEMN-MONOMER| (EC 1.3.99.22), which can catalyze the transition without the need for molecular oxygen. This enzyme, which contains an iron-sulfur cluster, is able to break SAM into |FRAME: MET| and a 5'-deoxyadenosineyl radical. This radical can attack |FRAME: COPROPORPHYRINOGEN_III| and bring about the conversion to |FRAME: PROTOPORPHYRINOGEN|.

This enzyme is found in many bacteria, but does not appear to be present in archaea or eukarya (the only reference for the enzyme in a eukaryote is in the organism |FRAME: TAX-5911|, but this finding is based on sequence analysis alone, and has not been verified biochemically).

Important branch points within this pathway lead to biosynthesis of other important compounds such as vitamin B<sub>12</sub> (cobalamin) (see |FRAME: P381-PWY|), |FRAME: CPD-7425| (see |FRAME: PWY-5196|), |FRAME: SIROHEME| (see |FRAME: PWY-5194|), heme D biosynthesis, and bacteriochlorophyll (see |FRAME: CHLOROPHYLL-SYN|)." "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=ARGORNPROST-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5863" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=ARGDEG-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY66-5"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=HEME-SYN" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Pathways"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Porphyrin-Compounds-Biosynthesis" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=NIL&object=Generalized-Reactions"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=TCA"	"TCA cycle I (prokaryotic)"	"TCA"	"<b>General Background</b>

The TCA pathway is a catabolic pathway of aerobic respiration that generates both energy and reducing power. In addition, it is also the first step in generating precursors for biosynthesis. The pathway is very common, and a variation of it exists in practically all aerobic living organisms |CITS: [16746397][16746585][16747930]|.

The input to the cycle is |FRAME: ACETYL-COA|, an activated form of |FRAME: ACET| that is generated by the degradation of carbohydrates, fats and proteins. A common source of acetyl-coA is |FRAME: PYRUVATE|, which is generated by |FRAME: GLYCOLYSIS glycolysis| and converted to acetyl-CoA by the |FRAME: PYRUVDEHYD-PWY \"pyruvate dehydrogenase complex\"|.

In every turn the TCA cycle converts one molecule of acetyl-CoA into two |FRAME: CARBON-DIOXIDE| molecules, reduces a total of four molecules of either |FRAME: NAD|, |FRAME: NADP|, or |FRAME: Quinones quinone| to |FRAME: NADH|, |FRAME: NADPH| and |FRAME: Reduced-Quinones quinol|, respectively, and phosphorylates one molecule of GDP to GTP.

The reduced molecules of NADH/NADPH/quinol that are formed by the TCA cycle serve as electron donors for oxidative phosphorylation (see for example |FRAME: PWY-3781|). In that process the electrons flow to a terminal acceptor, powering on their way proton pumps that trasport protons across the cytoplasmic or mitochondrial membranes, generating a proton motive force (PMF). As the protons return to their original location, they power ATPase enzymes that phosphorylate ADP molecules to ATP. The total energy gained from the complete breakdown of one molecule of glucose by glycolysis, the TCA cycle, and oxidative phosphorylation equals about 30 ATP molecules in eukaryotes.

The name of the TCA (short for tricarboxylic acid) cycle is derived from the fact that the first step in the pathway is attachment of acetyl-coA to |FRAME: CIT|, an acid with three carboxylate groups. The pathway is also known as the citric acid cycle, and as the Szent-Gyorgyi-Krebs cycle (or just the Krebs cycle), named after the scientists who described it.

Some organisms possess a truncated version of the TCA cycle, known as the |FRAME: GLYOXYLATE-BYPASS \"glyoxylate cycle\"|, that converts |FRAME:ACETYL-COA| to biosynthetic intermediates without the loss of |FRAME: CARBON-DIOXIDE| |CITS:[6378912][3333001][3332993]|.

<b>About This Pathway</b>

This is a common variation of the pathway that occurs in many bacteria and archaea.
There are a few small differences between this prokaryotic version of the cycle and the version found in most eukaryotes (see |FRAME: PWY-5690|). In this pathway, an NADP-dependent enzyme (|FRAME: ISOCITDEH-RXN \"EC 1.1.1.42\"|) catalyzes the dehydrogenation of |FRAME: THREO-DS-ISO-CITRATE| to |FRAME: 2-KETOGLUTARATE|, while eukaryotes employ an NAD+-dependent enzyme (|FRAME: ISOCITRATE-DEHYDROGENASE-NAD+-RXN \"EC 1.1.1.41\"|). Another difference is that while in most eukaryotes the conversion of |FRAME: MAL| to |FRAME: OXALACETIC_ACID| is catalyzed only by an NAD-dependent enzyme (|FRAME: HS07366-MONOMER \"EC 1.1.1.37\"|), prokaryotes that employ this variation of the TCA cycle possess an alternative quinone-dependent enzyme (|FRAME: RXNI-3 \"EC 1.1.5.4\"|). 

While the pathway is most common in heterotrophic bacteria and arachaea, there is evidence for its presence in some facultatively autotrophic archaea when growing under heterotrophic conditions.

In |FRAME: TAX-562|, when acetate is the carbon source, citrate synthase is rate-limiting for the TCA cycle |CITS: [3889909][3332995]|."	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=TCA-GLYOX-BYPASS"		"tricarboxylic acid cycle" // "citric acid cycle" // "Krebs cycle" // "Szent-Gyorgyi-Krebs cycle"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=TCA-VARIANTS"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=TCA-GLYOX-BYPASS" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7254" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5690" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY66-398" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5913" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=REDCITCYC" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6969" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=P105-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=TCA"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Energy-Metabolism"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Pathways"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5913"	"partial TCA cycle (obligate autotrophs)"	"PWY-5913"	"<b>General Background</b>

The TCA pathway is a catabolic pathway of aerobic respiration that generates both energy and reducing power. In addition, it is also the first step in generating precursors for biosynthesis. The pathway is very common, and a variation of it exists in practically all aerobic living organisms |CITS: [16746397][16746585][16747930]|.

The input to the cycle is |FRAME: ACETYL-COA|, an activated form of |FRAME: ACET| that is generated by the degradation of carbohydrates, fats and proteins. A common source of acetyl-coA is |FRAME: PYRUVATE|, which is generated by |FRAME: GLYCOLYSIS glycolysis| and converted to acetyl-CoA by the |FRAME: PYRUVDEHYD-PWY \"pyruvate dehydrogenase complex\"|.

In every turn the TCA cycle converts one molecule of acetyl-CoA into two |FRAME: CARBON-DIOXIDE| molecules, reduces a total of four molecules of either |FRAME: NAD|, |FRAME: NADP|, or |FRAME: Quinones quinone| to |FRAME: NADH|, |FRAME: NADPH| and |FRAME: Reduced-Quinones quinol|, respectively, and phosphorylates one molecule of GDP to GTP.

The reduced molecules of NADH/NADPH/quinol that are formed by the TCA cycle serve as electron donors for oxidative phosphorylation (see for example |FRAME: PWY-3781|). In that process the electrons flow to a terminal acceptor, powering on their way proton pumps that transport protons across the cytoplasmic or mitochondrial membranes, generating a proton motive force (PMF). As the protons return to their original location, they power ATPase enzymes that phosphorylate ADP molecules to ATP. The total energy gained from the complete breakdown of one molecule of glucose by glycolysis, the TCA cycle, and oxidative phosphorylation equals about 30 ATP molecules in eukaryotes.

The name of the TCA (short for tricarboxylic acid) cycle is derived from the fact that the first step in the pathway is attachment of acetyl-coA to |FRAME: CIT|, an acid with three carboxylate groups. The pathway is also known as the citric acid cycle, and as the Szent-Gyorgyi-Krebs cycle (or just the Krebs cycle), named after the scientists who described it.

Some organisms possess a truncated version of the TCA cycle, known as the |FRAME: GLYOXYLATE-BYPASS \"glyoxylate cycle\"|, that converts |FRAME:ACETYL-COA| to biosynthetic intermediates without the loss of |FRAME: CARBON-DIOXIDE| |CITS:[6378912][3333001][3332993]|.

<b>About This Pathway</b>

In obligate autotrophs exogenously furnished organic compounds make a very small contribution to cellular carbon |CITS: [4963789]|. In a study conducted with obligate autotrophic |FRAME: TAX-919| strains, as well as several species of |FRAME: TAX-1117|, acetate, which was the most readily incorporated compound of those studied, contributed only about 10% of newly synthesized cellular carbon.

The carbon from pyruvate, acetate, and glutamate provided exogenously was incorporated into restricted groups of cellular amino acids. In addition, the enzymes |FRAME: EC-1.2.1.M9| or |FRAME: EC-4.1.1.71| are missing from the obligate autotrophs that were studied, and activities of malic enzyme and succinate dehydrogenase had extremely low levels.

The authors concluded that the tricarboxylic acid cycle in these organisms is blocked at the level of |FRAME: 2-KETOGLUTARATE| oxidation |CITS: [4963789]|. A later study showed that while most cyanobacteria do posses the enzymes required for a full TCA cycle (see |FRAME: P105-PWY|), cyanobacteria of the |FRAME: TAX-1218| and marine |FRAME: TAX-1129| genera lack |FRAME: G185E-5419-MONOMER \"2-oxoglutarate decarboxylase\"| and thus are likely to operate the pathway described here |CITS: [Zhang11]|."			"TCA cycle VI (obligate autotrophs)"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=TCA-VARIANTS"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=TCA-GLYOX-BYPASS" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7254" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5690" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY66-398" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5913" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=REDCITCYC" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6969" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=P105-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=TCA"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Energy-Metabolism"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Pathways"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6969"	"TCA cycle V (2-oxoglutarate:ferredoxin oxidoreductase)"	"PWY-6969"	"<b>General Background</b>

The TCA pathway is a catabolic pathway of aerobic respiration that generates both energy and reducing power. In addition, it is also the first step in generating precursors for biosynthesis. The pathway is very common, and a variation of it exists in practically all aerobic living organisms |CITS: [16746397][16746585][16747930]|.

The input to the cycle is |FRAME: ACETYL-COA|, an activated form of |FRAME: ACET| that is generated by the degradation of carbohydrates, fats and proteins. A common source of acetyl-coA is |FRAME: PYRUVATE|, which is generated by |FRAME: GLYCOLYSIS glycolysis| and converted to acetyl-CoA by the |FRAME: PYRUVDEHYD-PWY \"pyruvate dehydrogenase complex\"|.

In every turn the TCA cycle converts one molecule of acetyl-CoA into two |FRAME: CARBON-DIOXIDE| molecules, reduces a total of four molecules of either |FRAME: NAD|, |FRAME: NADP|, or |FRAME: Quinones quinone| to |FRAME: NADH|, |FRAME: NADPH| and |FRAME: Reduced-Quinones quinol|, respectively, and phosphorylates one molecule of GDP to GTP.

The reduced molecules of NADH/NADPH/quinol that are formed by the TCA cycle serve as electron donors for oxidative phosphorylation (see for example |FRAME: PWY-3781|). In that process the electrons flow to a terminal acceptor, powering on their way proton pumps that trasport protons across the cytoplasmic or mitochondrial membranes, generating a proton motive force (PMF). As the protons return to their original location, they power ATPase enzymes that phosphorylate ADP molecules to ATP. The total energy gained from the complete breakdown of one molecule of glucose by glycolysis, the TCA cycle, and oxidative phosphorylation equals about 30 ATP molecules in eukaryotes.

The name of the TCA (short for tricarboxylic acid) cycle is derived from the fact that the first step in the pathway is attachment of acetyl-coA to |FRAME: CIT|, an acid with three carboxylate groups. The pathway is also known as the citric acid cycle, and as the Szent-Gyorgyi-Krebs cycle (or just the Krebs cycle), named after the scientists who described it.

Some organisms possess a truncated version of the TCA cycle, known as the |FRAME: GLYOXYLATE-BYPASS \"glyoxylate cycle\"|, that converts |FRAME:ACETYL-COA| to biosynthetic intermediates without the loss of |FRAME: CARBON-DIOXIDE| |CITS:[6378912][3333001][3332993]|.

<b>About This Pathway</b>

The enzyme |FRAME: 2OXOGLUTARATEDEH-RXN \"2-oxoglutarate dehydrogenase\"|, a key member of the \"standard\" TCA cycle that converts |FRAME: 2-KETOGLUTARATE| to |FRAME: SUC-COA|, is absent, or not expressed, in many organisms, including obligately autotrophic and methanotrophic bacteria and archaea |CITS: [15449607]|, as well as mycobacteria |CITS: [16045627]|. Most cyanobacteria also lack a gene encoding the enzyme |CITS: [4963789][15449607][21282404]|.

The absence of this enzyme could in theory result in incomplete oxidative or reductive TCA cycles that supply biosynthetic intermediates in response to growth conditions (see MetaCyc pathway |FRAME: P42-PWY|). However, in some cases other enzymes substitute for the missing activity and complete the cycle. For example, some archaea and the bacterium |FRAME: TAX-210| possess the enzyme |FRAME: 2-OXOGLUTARATE-SYNTHASE-RXN \"2-oxoglutarate synthase\"| (see |FRAME: REDCITCYC|) |CITS: [10091606]|.  

In the pathway described here, the role of 2-oxoglutarate dehydorgenase is replaced by |FRAME: CPLX-8408| |CITS: [Zhang11]|. Succinate can also be formed by a reductive TCA half-cycle, or by the glyoxylate bypass found in this organism, as shown here (in |CITS: [16027371]|) (see |FRAME: GLYOXYLATE-BYPASS|).  

The pathway is believed to operate in several types of mycobacteria, including |FRAME: TAX-1773|, |FRAME: TAX-1772| and |FRAME: TAX-1765| |CITS: [16027371][19936047][21561773]|. A similar, yet somewhat different pathway occurs in helicobacteria (see |FRAME: REDCITCYC|)"			"citric acid cycle" // "tricarboxylic acid cycle" // "Szent-Gyorgyi-Krebs cycle" // "Krebs cycle"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=TCA-VARIANTS"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=TCA-GLYOX-BYPASS" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7254" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5690" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY66-398" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5913" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=REDCITCYC" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6969" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=P105-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=TCA"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Energy-Metabolism"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Pathways"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=REDCITCYC"	"TCA cycle VIII (Helicobacter)"	"REDCITCYC"	"<b>General Background</b>

The TCA pathway is a catabolic pathway of aerobic respiration that generates both energy and reducing power. In addition, it is also the first step in generating precursors for biosynthesis. The pathway is very common, and a variation of it exists in practically all aerobic living organisms |CITS: [16746397][16746585][16747930]|.

The input to the cycle is |FRAME: ACETYL-COA|, an activated form of |FRAME: ACET| that is generated by the degradation of carbohydrates, fats and proteins. A common source of acetyl-coA is |FRAME: PYRUVATE|, which is generated by |FRAME: GLYCOLYSIS glycolysis| and converted to acetyl-CoA by the |FRAME: PYRUVDEHYD-PWY \"pyruvate dehydrogenase complex\"|.

In every turn the TCA cycle converts one molecule of acetyl-CoA into two |FRAME: CARBON-DIOXIDE| molecules, reduces a total of four molecules of either |FRAME: NAD|, |FRAME: NADP|, or |FRAME: Quinones quinone| to |FRAME: NADH|, |FRAME: NADPH| and |FRAME: Reduced-Quinones quinol|, respectively, and phosphorylates one molecule of GDP to GTP.

The reduced molecules of NADH/NADPH/quinol that are formed by the TCA cycle serve as electron donors for oxidative phosphorylation (see for example |FRAME: PWY-3781|). In that process the electrons flow to a terminal acceptor, powering on their way proton pumps that trasport protons across the cytoplasmic or mitochondrial membranes, generating a proton motive force (PMF). As the protons return to their original location, they power ATPase enzymes that phosphorylate ADP molecules to ATP. The total energy gained from the complete breakdown of one molecule of glucose by glycolysis, the TCA cycle, and oxidative phosphorylation equals about 30 ATP molecules in eukaryotes.

The name of the TCA (short for tricarboxylic acid) cycle is derived from the fact that the first step in the pathway is attachment of acetyl-coA to |FRAME: CIT|, an acid with three carboxylate groups. The pathway is also known as the citric acid cycle, and as the Szent-Gyorgyi-Krebs cycle (or just the Krebs cycle), named after the scientists who described it.

Some organisms possess a truncated version of the TCA cycle, known as the |FRAME: GLYOXYLATE-BYPASS \"glyoxylate cycle\"|, that converts |FRAME:ACETYL-COA| to biosynthetic intermediates without the loss of |FRAME: CARBON-DIOXIDE| |CITS:[6378912][3333001][3332993]|.

<b>About This Pathway</b>

There has been considerable debate over whether |FRAME: TAX-210| has a complete oxidative citric acid cycle as shown here or a branched modified form of a citric acid cycle, similar to that of |FRAME:TAX-562| under anaerobic conditions. Since the original genomic sequence of |FRAME: TAX-210| lacked open reading frames (ORFs) for three of the typical citric acid cycle enzymes, |FRAME: TAX-210| initially was believed to contain a noncyclic branched pathway whereby one branch operates in an oxidative direction converting oxaloacetate to &alpha;-ketoglutarate via citrate and isocitrate, while the other operates in a reductive direction converting oxaloacetate to succinate via malate and fumarate |CITS: [10091606][10477311][10477312]|. 

However, it was later discovered that the organism contains alternative enzymes for the three missing citric acid cycle enzymes, suggesting that it may have a complete citric acid cycle after all.  Biochemical studies demonstrated that |FRAME: TAX-210| has a ferredoxin-dependent |FRAME: EC-1.2.7.3| instead of the NAD+-dependent 2-oxoglutarate dehydrogenase |CITS: [9495749]| , |FRAME: EC-2.8.3.5| instead of succinyl-CoA synthetase |CITS: [9495749]|, and |FRAME: EC-1.1.5.4| instead of an NAD+-dependent malate dehydrogenase |CITS: [10809701]|.

There is still some debate over whether the fumarate reductase of |FRAME: TAX-210| can operate as a succinate dehydrogenase as proposed in this pathway. Although several authors detected succinate dehydrogenase activity in biochemical assays |CITS: [7781988][10809701]|, Pitson et al. detected no such activity |CITS: [10091606]|. The enzyme has been shown to function <i>in vitro</i> using benzyl viologen as the electron donor|CITS: [9434188]|."			"Krebs cycle" // "tricarboxylic acid cycle" // "TCA cycle" // "citric acid cycle"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=TCA-VARIANTS"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=TCA-GLYOX-BYPASS" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7254" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5690" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY66-398" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5913" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=REDCITCYC" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6969" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=P105-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=TCA"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Energy-Metabolism"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Pathways"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7254"	"TCA cycle VII (acetate-producers)"	"PWY-7254"	"<b>General Background</b>

The TCA pathway is a catabolic pathway of aerobic respiration that generates both energy and reducing power. In addition, it is also the first step in generating precursors for biosynthesis. The pathway is very common, and a variation of it exists in practically all aerobic living organisms |CITS: [16746397][16746585][16747930]|.

The input to the cycle is |FRAME: ACETYL-COA|, an activated form of |FRAME: ACET| that is generated by the degradation of carbohydrates, fats and proteins. A common source of acetyl-coA is |FRAME: PYRUVATE|, which is generated by |FRAME: GLYCOLYSIS glycolysis| and converted to acetyl-CoA by the |FRAME: PYRUVDEHYD-PWY \"pyruvate dehydrogenase complex\"|.

In every turn the TCA cycle converts one molecule of acetyl-CoA into two |FRAME: CARBON-DIOXIDE| molecules, reduces a total of four molecules of either |FRAME: NAD|, |FRAME: NADP|, or |FRAME: Quinones quinone| to |FRAME: NADH|, |FRAME: NADPH| and |FRAME: Reduced-Quinones quinol|, respectively, and phosphorylates one molecule of GDP to GTP.

The reduced molecules of NADH/NADPH/quinol that are formed by the TCA cycle serve as electron donors for oxidative phosphorylation (see for example |FRAME: PWY-3781|). In that process the electrons flow to a terminal acceptor, powering on their way proton pumps that trasport protons across the cytoplasmic or mitochondrial membranes, generating a proton motive force (PMF). As the protons return to their original location, they power ATPase enzymes that phosphorylate ADP molecules to ATP. The total energy gained from the complete breakdown of one molecule of glucose by glycolysis, the TCA cycle, and oxidative phosphorylation equals about 30 ATP molecules in eukaryotes.

The name of the TCA (short for tricarboxylic acid) cycle is derived from the fact that the first step in the pathway is attachment of acetyl-coA to |FRAME: CIT|, an acid with three carboxylate groups. The pathway is also known as the citric acid cycle, and as the Szent-Gyorgyi-Krebs cycle (or just the Krebs cycle), named after the scientists who described it.

Some organisms possess a truncated version of the TCA cycle, known as the |FRAME: GLYOXYLATE-BYPASS \"glyoxylate cycle\"|, that converts |FRAME:ACETYL-COA| to biosynthetic intermediates without the loss of |FRAME: CARBON-DIOXIDE| |CITS:[6378912][3333001][3332993]|.

<b>About This Pathway</b>

Acetic acid bacteria are Gram-negative acidophilic &alpha;-proteobacteria that oxidize ethanol to acetate. These bacteria are highly resistant to high levels of both of these membrane-permeable compounds. The citric acid cycle of these organisms has been shown to converts acetate to CO<sub>2</sub>.

Studies of the the vinegar producing bacterium |FRAME: TAX-435| have shown that instead of the |FRAME: SUCCCOASYN| enzyme, which catalyzes the conversion of |FRAME: SUC-COA| to |FRAME: SUC| in most bacteria, this organism possesses a |FRAME: CPLX-8672|, an enzyme that links acetate metabolism with the TCA cycle |CITS: [18502856]|. The enzyme couples the conversion of |FRAME: SUC-COA| to |FRAME: SUC| to the conversion of acetate to acetyl-CoA, and thus simultaneously reduces the acetate concentration and reduces the metabolic demand for free |FRAME: CO-A|. The enzyme is essential for survival in high acetate concentrations |CITS: [2156811]|.

Another enzyme of the TCA cycle, |FRAME: CPLX-8671|, has also been found to be essential for acetate resistance |CITS: [2156811]|."			"tricarboxylic acid cycle" // "citric acid cycle" // "Krebs cycle" // "Szent-Gyorgyi-Krebs cycle" // "TCA cycle VII (acetic acid-producers)"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=TCA-VARIANTS"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=TCA-GLYOX-BYPASS" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7254" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5690" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY66-398" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5913" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=REDCITCYC" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6969" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=P105-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=TCA"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Energy-Metabolism"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Pathways"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=P105-PWY"	"TCA cycle IV (2-oxoglutarate decarboxylase)"	"P105-PWY"	"<b>General Background</b>

The TCA pathway is a catabolic pathway of aerobic respiration that generates both energy and reducing power. In addition, it is also the first step in generating precursors for biosynthesis. The pathway is very common, and a variation of it exists in practically all aerobic living organisms |CITS: [16746397][16746585][16747930]|.

The input to the cycle is |FRAME: ACETYL-COA|, an activated form of |FRAME: ACET| that is generated by the degradation of carbohydrates, fats and proteins. A common source of acetyl-coA is |FRAME: PYRUVATE|, which is generated by |FRAME: GLYCOLYSIS glycolysis| and converted to acetyl-CoA by the |FRAME: PYRUVDEHYD-PWY \"pyruvate dehydrogenase complex\"|.

In every turn the TCA cycle converts one molecule of acetyl-CoA into two |FRAME: CARBON-DIOXIDE| molecules, reduces a total of four molecules of either |FRAME: NAD|, |FRAME: NADP|, or |FRAME: Quinones quinone| to |FRAME: NADH|, |FRAME: NADPH| and |FRAME: Reduced-Quinones quinol|, respectively, and phosphorylates one molecule of GDP to GTP.

The reduced molecules of NADH/NADPH/quinol that are formed by the TCA cycle serve as electron donors for oxidative phosphorylation (see for example |FRAME: PWY-3781|). In that process the electrons flow to a terminal acceptor, powering on their way proton pumps that trasport protons across the cytoplasmic or mitochondrial membranes, generating a proton motive force (PMF). As the protons return to their original location, they power ATPase enzymes that phosphorylate ADP molecules to ATP. The total energy gained from the complete breakdown of one molecule of glucose by glycolysis, the TCA cycle, and oxidative phosphorylation equals about 30 ATP molecules in eukaryotes.

The name of the TCA (short for tricarboxylic acid) cycle is derived from the fact that the first step in the pathway is attachment of acetyl-coA to |FRAME: CIT|, an acid with three carboxylate groups. The pathway is also known as the citric acid cycle, and as the Szent-Gyorgyi-Krebs cycle (or just the Krebs cycle), named after the scientists who described it.

Some organisms possess a truncated version of the TCA cycle, known as the |FRAME: GLYOXYLATE-BYPASS \"glyoxylate cycle\"|, that converts |FRAME:ACETYL-COA| to biosynthetic intermediates without the loss of |FRAME: CARBON-DIOXIDE| |CITS:[6378912][3333001][3332993]|.

<b>About This Pathway</b>

The |FRAME: 2OXOGLUTARATEDEH-RXN \"2-oxoglutarate dehydrogenase complex\"|, a key member of the \"standard\" TCA cycle that converts |FRAME: 2-KETOGLUTARATE| to |FRAME: SUC-COA|, is absent, or not expressed, in many organisms, including obligately autotrophic and methanotrophic bacteria and archaea |CITS: [15449607]| as well as mycobacteria |CITS: [16045627]|. Most cyanobacteria also lack a gene encoding the enzyme |CITS: [4963789][15449607][21282404]|.

The absence of this enzyme could theoretically result in incomplete oxidative or reductive TCA cycles that supply biosynthetic intermediates in response to growth conditions (see MetaCyc pathway |FRAME: P42-PWY|). However, in some cases other enzymes substitute for the missing activity and complete the cycle. For example, some archaea and the bacterium |FRAME: TAX-210| possess the enzyme |FRAME: EC-1.2.7.3| (see |FRAME: REDCITCYC|) |CITS: [10091606]|.  

In the pathway described here, the role of the 2-oxoglutarate dehydrogenase complex is replaced by two enzymes, |FRAME: EC-4.1.1.71|| and |FRAME: EC-1.2.1.79 \"EC 1.2.1.79, succinate-semialdehyde dehydrogenase\"| | |CITS: [Zhang11]|. Similarly to the glyoxylate shunt, this pathway bypasses the synthesis of ATP via succinate thiokinase. Note that by avoiding the generation of ATP, this variant of the TCA cycle is not inhibited by high ATP concentration, which is typical in photosynthetic organisms.

Since succinyl-CoA  is not produced by the pathway, pools of succinyl-CoA for synthesis of methionine, diaminopimelate, sulfolipids and heme have to be derived in an energy-dependent manner, either from succinate at the expense of ATP (by succinyl-CoA synthetase) or from methylmalonyl-CoA via methylmalonyl-CoA mutase |CITS: [16027371][Munoz-Elias06]|.
Succinate can also be formed by a reductive TCA half-cycle, or by the glyoxylate bypass found in this organism, as shown here (in |CITS: [16027371]|) (see |FRAME: GLYOXYLATE-BYPASS|).

The 2-oxoglutarate decarboxylase and succinate semialdehyde dehydrogenase reactions have been shown in |FRAME: TAX-3039| |CITS: [SHIGEOKA86][1910306]|, in some rhizobia |CITS: [10781553]|, and in cyanobacteria |CITS: [Zhang11]|. The pathway was also thought to exist in mycobacteria |CITS: [16027371]|, but it was later shown that the key enzyme  |FRAME: MONOMER-17040| is missing from those organisms |CITS: [20416504]|, and that they operate a different variation instead (see |FRAME: PWY-6969|)."			"citric acid cycle" // "tricarboxylic acid cycle" // "Szent-Gyorgyi-Krebs cycle" // "Krebs cycle"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=TCA-VARIANTS"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=TCA-GLYOX-BYPASS" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7254" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5690" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY66-398" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5913" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=REDCITCYC" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6969" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=P105-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=TCA"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Energy-Metabolism"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Pathways"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6703"	"preQ<sub>0</sub> biosynthesis"	"PWY-6703"	"|FRAME: 7-Deazapurines 7-Deazapurines\"| are compounds that contain pyrrolopyrimidine functional groups (similar to purines, but lacking one of the nitrogens in the pentameric ring). These compounds form a structurally diverse class of nucleoside analogues that often possess antibiotic, antineoplastic, or antiviral activities.

Various species of Streptomyces produce 7-Deazapurine nucleoside antibiotics, such as |FRAME: CPD-13056|, |FRAME: CPD-13052|, |FRAME: CPD-13054|, and |FRAME: CPD-13055|.

An important |FRAME: 7-Deazapurines 7-deazapurine\"| compound is |FRAME: CPD-13053|, a modified nucleoside that is present in certain tRNAs in bacteria and most eukaryotes (with the exception of mycoplasmas and yeast) but not in the archaea |CITS: [ 12697167]|. The pathway describing the biosynthesis of |FRAME: CPD-13053| can be found at |FRAME: PWY-6700|.

The biosynthesis of all 7-deazapurines proceeds via the common intermediate |FRAME: 7-CYANO-7-DEAZAGUANINE|, which is produced in four steps from the nucleotide |FRAME:GTP|. The pathway starts with the conversion of GTP to |FRAME: DIHYDRONEOPTERIN-P3| by |FRAME: FOLE-CPLX|, an enzyme that is also involved in the biosynthesis of |FRAME: THF|. |FRAME: DIHYDRONEOPTERIN-P3| is converted to |FRAME: CPD0-1699| by the action of |FRAME: G7431-MONOMER| (|FRAME: G7431|). This intermediate is converted to |FRAME: CPD-13043| by an unusual transformation catalyzed by |FRAME: BSU13740-MONOMER| (|FRAME: BSU13740|), a member of the radical SAM enzyme superfamily. 
Finally, the carboxylate moiety of the latter is converted subsequently to a nitrile in an ATP-dependent reaction, in which ammonia serves as the nitrogen source, catalyzed by |FRAME: BSU13720-MONOMER| (|FRAME: BSU13720|), generating  the final product, |FRAME: 7-CYANO-7-DEAZAGUANINE| |CITS: [19354300]|.

"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6975"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Biosynthesis"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Pathways"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=NONOXIPENT-PWY"	"pentose phosphate pathway (non-oxidative branch)"	"NONOXIPENT-PWY"	"<b>General Background</b>

The |FRAME: PENTOSE-P-PWY \"pentose phosphate pathway\"| is an alternative way of oxidizing glucose, and in this pathway the oxidation is coupled to NADPH synthesis.  As a result, the pentose phosphate pathway is a major source of reducing equivalents for biosynthesis reactions. The pentose phosphate pathway is also important for the conversion of hexoses to pentoses  |CITS: [zubay1983]| .

<b>About This Pathway</b>

The pentose phosphate pathway is one of the three essential pathways of central metabolism. It supplies three of |FRAME:TAX-562|'s 13 precursor metabolites (compounds needed for the biosyntheses): |FRAME: RIBOSE-5P|,
|FRAME: D-SEDOHEPTULOSE-7-P|, and |FRAME: ERYTHROSE-4P|. Regardless of the carbon source upon which
|FRAME:TAX-562| is growing, some carbon must flow through the pentose phosphate pathway to meet the cell's requirements for these metabolites.
In addition this pathway is an important source of NADPH, which is also needed for biosyntheses. The pathway begins with one intermediate of glycolysis, |FRAME: GLC-6-P|, and ends with the formation of two others, |FRAME: FRUCTOSE-6P| and |FRAME: GAP|. 

For convenience, the pentose phosphate pathway is commonly divided into its preliminary |FRAME: OXIDATIVEPENT-PWY \"oxidative portion\"|, in which |FRAME: GLC-6-P| is oxidized to |FRAME: RIBULOSE-5P|, and its subsequent |FRAME: NONOXIPENT-PWY \"non-oxidative portion\"| in which through a series of transaldolase and transketolase reactions, |FRAME: RIBULOSE-5P| is converted into |FRAME: FRUCTOSE-6P| and |FRAME: GAP|."	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PENTOSE-P-PWY"			"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Pentose-Phosphate-Cycle"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7796" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=OXIDATIVEPENT-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=P21-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PENTOSE-P-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=NONOXIPENT-PWY"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Energy-Metabolism"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Pathways"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY0-1297"	"superpathway of purine deoxyribonucleosides degradation"	"PWY0-1297"	"|FRAME:TAX-562| can use all three naturally occurring purine deoxyribonucleosides (deoadenosine, deoxyguanosine, and
deoxyinosine) as total sources of carbon and energy.  All are cleaved by the same <i>deoD</i>-encoded
phosphorylase, yielding the corresponding bases (adenine, guanine and hypoxanthine) and
D-deoxyribose-1-phosphate, which is converted to D-deoxyribose-5-phosphate by a mutase that also can utilize
D-ribose-1-phosphate as a substrate.  A specific aldolase splits D-deoxyribose-5-phosphate, yielding
D-glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate, which enters central metabolism through the glycolytic pathway, and acetaldehyde,
which must be converted to acetyl-CoA before it can enter central metabolism. 

Although |FRAME:TAX-562| is able to utilize the deoxyribose moiety of deoxyribonucleosides, it is unable to utilize
exogenously supplied deoxyribose; however, the closely related organism |FRAME:TAX-90371| can.

The amino nitrogen of adenine and guanine but not the nitrogen atoms in the purine bases can serve as total
sources of nitrogen for |FRAME:TAX-562|.  

Review: Linn, E.C.C. Dissimilatory Pathways for Sugars, Polyols, and Carboxylates. |FRAME:TAX-562| and |FRAME:TAX-590|,
F.C. Neidhardt, Ed. |CITS:[COLISALII]|

"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6700"	"queuosine biosynthesis"	"PWY-6700"	"|FRAME: CPD-13053 Queuosine| is an important |FRAME: 7-Deazapurines 7-deazapurine\"| modified nucleoside that is present in certain tRNAs in bacteria and most eukaryotes (with the exception of mycoplasmas and yeast). It is not found in the archaea |CITS: [ 12697167]|. Prokaryotes can synthesize queuosine <i>de novo</i> by a complex biosynthetic pathway, whereas eukaryotes are unable to synthesize it, and utilize a salvage system, acquiring the |FRAME: QUEUINE| base as a nutrient factor from their diet or from intestinal microflora |CITS: [19925456 ]|.

Queuosine and its derivatives occur exclusively at position 34 (the wobble position) in the anticodons of tRNAs coding for the amino acids |FRAME: HIS|, |FRAME:L-ASPARTATE|, |FRAME: ASN| and |FRAME: TYR| |CITS: [ 4550561]|. Each of these tRNAs posses the anticodon sequence GUN (positions 3436), where N can be any nucleotide. Queuosine improves accuracy of translation |CITS: [ 2988936][11532950]|. These tRNAs of the 'Q-family' originally contain guanine in the first position of anticodon, which is post-transcriptionally modified with |FRAME: QUEUINE| by an irreversible insertion during maturation. 

Beside the 7-deazaguanosine core, quenosine possesses an additional adaptation - a cyclopentendiol ring attached to an aminomethyl group at position 7. In in some mammalian species the cyclopentendiol ring is further modified by glycosylation with galactose (on |FRAME: ASP-tRNAs|) or mannose (on |FRAME: TYR-tRNAs|) at the C5'' hydroxyl (see |FRAME: 2.4.1.110-RXN \"EC 2.4.1.110\"|) |CITS: [190593]|. In bacteria |FRAME: ASP-tRNAs| appears to be glutamylated at the same position (see |FRAME: EG11362-MONOMER|) |CITS: [16164993]|.

The first part of the pathway leading to formation of queuosine, up to the intermediate |FRAME: 7-CYANO-7-DEAZAGUANINE|, is described in the pathway |FRAME: PWY-6703|. 

|FRAME: 7-CYANO-7-DEAZAGUANINE \"PreQ<sub>0</sub>\"| is a common intermediate, and is also found in the pathways leading to the biosynthesis of several 7-deazapurine antibiotics produced by Streptomyces species. Before it can be inserted into a tRNA it is converted into |FRAME: 7-AMINOMETHYL-7-DEAZAGUANINE| by the enzyme |FRAME: EC-1.7.1.13| (|FRAME: G7452|). This enzyme uses 2 NADPH molecules to reduce the nitrile group of |FRAME: 7-CYANO-7-DEAZAGUANINE| to an amino group |CITS: [15767583]|. The next enzyme, |FRAME: EC-2.4.2.29| (|FRAME: EG10996|) catalyzes a complex reaction in which |FRAME: 7-AMINOMETHYL-7-DEAZAGUANINE| is transferred into a target tRNA molecule, replacing the guanine base, and generating a 7-aminomethyl-7-deazaguanine nucleoside at position 34 |CITS: [8323579]|. The enzyme recognizes the anticodon region of its substrate, and only acts on tRNAs that contain a GUN sequence |CITS: [8494901]|.
The third enzyme, |FRAME: EC-2.4.99.17| (|FRAME: EG10812|) transfers a ribose moiety from |FRAME: S-ADENOSYLMETHIONINE| to the tRNA, resulting in the formation of the 2,3-epoxy-4,5-dihydroxycyclopentane ring of epoxyqueuosine and releasing |FRAME: ADENINE| and |FRAME: MET| |CITS: [8347586][7849103]|. In the last step of the pathway, catalyzed by |FRAME: EC-1.17.99.6|, the eopxy bonds are reduced, generating the final queuosine residue. Two different enzymes, not related to each other, have been found to catalyze the last step, encoded by the |FRAME: G7843| and |FRAME: HP0100| genes, respectively. Some organisms possess both genes, but most contain only one form |CITS: [21502530][28128549]|."				"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Nucleic-Acid-Processing"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=tRNA-Splicing" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7379" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7285" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6711" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7888" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY0-1479" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7286" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7803" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6829" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6689" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7892" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY0-1554" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7904" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7889" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7375" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7283" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY0-1587" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6700" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7923" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7891"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Macromolecule-Modification"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Pathways"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PPGPPMET-PWY"	"ppGpp biosynthesis"	"PPGPPMET-PWY"	"<b>General Background</b>

The nucleotides |FRAME: GUANOSINE-5DP-3DP| (guanosine 3'-diphosphate 5'-diphosphate) and |FRAME: GDP-TP| (guanosine 3'-diphosphate 5'-triphosphate), referred to collectively as (p)ppGpp, have been shown to regulate gene expression during the stringent response in some bacteria.  Their levels become elevated during this response and they are key indicators and regulators of it.  The stringent response is a global regulatory system that operates under conditions of nutrient or energy starvation or other environmental stress.  It has varying effects on gene expression and metabolism |CITS: [18039766] [18430135]|.  In addition to bacteria, there is evidence that (p)ppGpp may regulate transcription by plastid-encoded RNA polymerase in plant chloroplasts |CITS: [19308923]|.

Due to its role as an effector molecule in the stringent response in bacteria, (p)ppGpp has been described as a bacterial alarmone.  It can contribute to the regulation of various cellular processes that are affected by nutritional stress such as growth, cell division, motility, adaptation and virulence.  Its effect on the pathogenicity of some bacteria has led to the development of |FRAME: GUANOSINE-5DP-3DP| analogs as possible antibacterial compounds |CITS: [18776539]| and new <i>in vitro</i> synthesis |CITS: [18789883]| and detection |CITS: [18166051]| methods for |FRAME: GUANOSINE-5DP-3DP|.  Different bacteria have different ways of synthesizing and responding to (p)ppGpp, many of which are still being discovered.  Even in the well-studied |FRAME:TAX-562| many details of |FRAME: GUANOSINE-5DP-3DP| action remain to be elucidated.  Reviewed in |CITS: [18454629] [15866041] [18359660]|.

In the |FRAME:TAX-562| stringent response transcription, translation and DNA replication are affected by (p)ppGpp levels.  Transcription is redirected from genes related to growth to genes involved in survival under starvation and stress conditions.  The regulation of transcription by (p)ppGpp occurs at the transcription initiation stage and affects promoter use.  However, the mechanism remains unclear and direct and indirect models for regulation have been proposed.  It has been shown that |FRAME: GUANOSINE-5DP-3DP| and a cofactor protein DksA bind to RNA polymerase and modulate its activity at promoters |CITS: [15294157] [15899978]|, although the exact |FRAME: GUANOSINE-5DP-3DP| binding site(s) responsible for regulation are undefined |CITS: [18272182]|.  Transcription of many &sigma;<sup>70</sup>-dependent genes and genes dependent upon alternative sigma factors is negatively or positively regulated by |FRAME: GUANOSINE-5DP-3DP|.  In direct models for regulation, |FRAME: GUANOSINE-5DP-3DP| affects the RNA polymerase-promoter interaction via stabilization, or destabilization of the RNA polymerase-promoter open complex.  Indirect models include changes in the availability of RNA polymerase, and a role for |FRAME: GUANOSINE-5DP-3DP| in regulating differential binding of sigma factors to core RNA polymerase.  Transcriptional alterations resulting from these mechanisms include repression of tRNA and rRNA synthesis (a key event in limiting the growth rate), induction of stress response factors, and induction of genes involved in amino acid biosynthesis and transport.  Reviewed in |CITS: [16554711] [15686546] [18359660]|.

In |FRAME:TAX-562| the regulation of translation by (p)ppGpp involves its repression of transcription of rRNA, tRNA and ribosomal proteins, as well as its interaction with initiation factor IF2 and possibly with elongation factors.  The regulation of DNA replication by (p)ppGpp in |FRAME:TAX-562| involves inhibition of the initiation step.  The demonstration that the |FRAME:TAX-562| DnaG primase is inhibited by |FRAME: GUANOSINE-5DP-3DP| <i>in vitro</i> also suggests inhibition of the elongation step |CITS: [19945481]|.  Reviewed in |CITS: [18359660]|.

In |FRAME:TAX-562| the products of genes <i>relA</i> and <i>spoT</i> have prominent roles in (p)ppGpp metabolism.  This was shown by the absence of |FRAME: GUANOSINE-5DP-3DP| in <i>relA</i>/<i>spoT</i> null mutants under stringent conditions |CITS: [2005134]|.  RelA functions as a synthetase and SpoT mainly as a hydrolase, although it also has synthetase activity.  Regulation of these opposing activities is critical for the ability of bacteria to respond to nutritional stress and to avoid a futile cycle of synthesis and hydrolysis of (p)ppGpp..  Homologous variants of the RelA and SpoT genes encoding Rsh proteins (Rel Spo homologs) are found in some bacteria and plants.  The &beta;- and &gamma;-proteobacteria have proteins homologous to RelA and SpoT, while most other bacteria have a bifunctional protein designated Rel.  Reviewed in |CITS: [18454629]|.

Experiments have shown that regulation of (p)ppGpp levels by RelA in response to amino acid starvation occurs at the level of translation on the ribosome.  Ribosome-associated RelA produces |FRAME: GUANOSINE-5DP-3DP| in response to the presence of uncharged tRNA in the ribosomal A-site which results in a stalled ribosome.  Regulation of (p)ppGpp levels by SpoT is less well understood, but involves sensing other sources of nutrient stress, such as a limitation in fatty acid synthesis |CITS: [17078815]|.  SpoT also senses phosphate starvation |CITS: [17640895]| and iron limitation |CITS: [15853883]|.  Reviewed in |CITS: [18454629] [16554711]|.

<b>About This Pathway</b>

The pathway shown here for the biosynthesis and metabolism of (p)ppGpp is based upon that shown in Cashel et. al. in |CITS: [ColiSalII]| (see reference below) except as noted.  Early kinetic studies established the overall pathway of |FRAME: GUANOSINE-5DP-3DP| metabolism.  The first product of the stringent response to amino acid starvation is |FRAME: GDP-TP| which is quickly converted to the more stable compound |FRAME: GUANOSINE-5DP-3DP|.  |FRAME: GUANOSINE-5DP-3DP| is then hydrolyzed to |FRAME: GDP| |CITS: [782536] [321933]|.  A role for a kinase in converting |FRAME: ENTEROBACTIN| back to |FRAME: GTP| to complete a cycle was proposed early (in |CITS: [321933] [365225]|) and nucleoside diphosphate kinase, the product of gene <i>ndk</i>, was suggested as a likely candidate.  This was supported by mutant studies in |FRAME:TAX-28901| serovar Typhimurium (|FRAME:TAX-90371|) although there is no direct evidence for a unique effect of Ndk on (p)ppGpp levels in |FRAME:TAX-562| or <i>S. typhimurium</i> (reviewed in Cashel et. al. in |CITS: [ColiSalII]|, see below).

RelA can catalyze the conversion of both |FRAME: GTP| to |FRAME: GDP-TP|, and |FRAME: GDP| to |FRAME: GUANOSINE-5DP-3DP| with similar <i>S</i><sub>0.5</sub> values derived from the Hill equation.  These values are well below the intracellular pool concentrations of |FRAME: GTP| and |FRAME: ATP|, but are similar to the intracellular pool concentration of |FRAME: GDP| |CITS: [3015258]|.  Therefore |FRAME: GDP-TP| is probably the main RelA product, although both reactions are shown here (reviewed in Cashel et. al. in |CITS: [ColiSalII]|, see below).  In addition to a synthetase (PSI) domain, RelA also contains an inactive hydrolase domain (in |CITS: [18454629]|).  RelA is responsible for ppGpp synthesis during the stringent response to amino acid starvation.

<i>In vivo</i> |FRAME: GDP-TP| is rapidly converted to |FRAME: GUANOSINE-5DP-3DP| by Gpp (reviewed in |CITS: [15590778]|).  It is the major route of |FRAME: GDP-TP| degradation, although minor routes via enzymes with similar activity may also exist (Cashel et. al. in |CITS: [ColiSalII]|, see below).

SpoT is a bifunctional enzyme with both a hydrolase activity and a weak synthetase activity (designated PSII) |CITS: [2005135] [8730877]|.  The SpoT |FRAME: GUANOSINE-5DP-3DP| hydrolase activity is inhibited under conditions of physiological stress and has a major role in |FRAME: GUANOSINE-5DP-3DP| degradation.  The role of the SpoT synthetase (PSII) activity is less clear.  It has been proposed to have a role in maintaining the basal level of |FRAME: GUANOSINE-5DP-3DP| during exponential growth (in |CITS: [8648647]|).  SpoT also has pppGpp hydrolase activity |CITS: [365225]| and possibly pppGpp synthetase activity.  The putative SpoT |FRAME: GDP-TP| synthetase activity is based on mutant phenotype.  In &Delta;<i>relA</i>/&Delta;<i>gpp</i> mutants starved for glucose |FRAME: GDP-TP| accumulates which suggests phosphoryl group transfer to |FRAME: GTP| as well as |FRAME: GDP|, although the phsophoryl donor is not known (cited as unpublished data in Cashel et. al. in |CITS: [ColiSalII]|, see below).  This reaction is not shown here.

Reviewed in Cashel, M., D.R. Gentry, V. J. Hernandez and D. Vinella (1996) \"The Stringent Response\", chapter 92, pp. 1458-1496, in |CITS: [ColiSalII]|.

"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PPGPPMET-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7535" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5983"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Biosynthesis"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Pathways"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=ANAGLYCOLYSIS-PWY"	"glycolysis III (from glucose)"	"ANAGLYCOLYSIS-PWY"	"<b>General Background</b>

Glycolysis, which was first studied as a pathway for the utilization of glucose, is one of the major pathways of central metabolism, the other two being the |FRAME:PENTOSE-P-PWY| and the |FRAME:TCA \"TCA cycle\"|. Glycolysis is essential under all conditions of growth, because it produces six of the 13 precursor metabolites that are the starting materials for the biosynthesis of building blocks for macromolecules and other needed small molecules (the six compounds are |FRAME:GLC-6-P|, |FRAME:FRUCTOSE-6P|, |FRAME:DIHYDROXY-ACETONE-PHOSPHATE|, |FRAME:G3P|, |FRAME:PHOSPHO-ENOL-PYRUVATE|, and |FRAME: PYRUVATE|). Glycolysis can be found, if at least in part, in almost all organisms.

Even though glycolysis is often described starting with glucose, other hexoses (e.g. fructose) can also serve as input (as its name implies - glycose is a general term for simple sugars).

Glycolysis has evolved to fulfill two essential functions:

i) it oxidizes hexoses to generate |FRAME:ATP|, reductants and |FRAME:PYRUVATE|, and

ii) being an amphibolic pathway (pathway that involves both catabolism and anabolism), it can reversibly produce hexoses from various low-molecular weight molecules.

Because various degradation pathways feed into glycolysis at many different points, glycolysis or portions of it run in the forward or reverse direction, depending on the carbon source being utilized, in order to satisfy the cell's need for precursor metabolites and energy.
This switching of direction is possible because all but two of the enzymatic reactions comprising glycolysis are reversible, and the conversions catalyzed by the two exceptions are rendered functionally reversible by other enzymes (|FRAME:F16B-CPLX \"fructose-1,6-bisphosphatase\"| and |FRAME:PEPSYNTH-CPLX|) that catalyze different irreversible reactions flowing in the opposite direction.

<b>About This Pathway</b>

The difference between this pathway and the one described in |FRAME: GLYCOLYSIS| is that glucose is phosphorylated not by a PTS transporter but intracellularly by |FRAME:CPLX-4241|. This reaction can be catalyzed by a general |FRAME: EC-2.7.1.1 \"hexokinase\"| (EC 2.7.1.1) |CITS: [ArchMicr161-460] [9075622]|, but some organisms have a highly specific |FRAME: EC-2.7.1.2 \"glucokinase\"| (EC 2.7.1.2) |CITS: [14553940]|.

In mammals, glycolysis always begins with the phosphorylation of glucose by hexokinase to form glucose 6-phosphate |CITS: [1637300]|. This ensures that the intracellular glucose concentration is kept low and promotes the continuous transport of glucose into the cell. In mammalian liver this reaction is carried out by glucokinase, an isozyme of hexokinase which has a much lower affinity (high Km) for glucose so it is effective only when glucose is abundant |CITS: [3902008]|. Its role is to provide glucose 6-phosphate for the synthesis of glycogen.

Glucose 6-phosphate is then isomerized to fructose 6-phosphate in a reversible reaction whose direction is driven by the concentration of fructose 6-phosphate |CITS: [12573240]|. A second phosphorylation event converts fructose 6-phosphate to fructose 1,6 bisphosphate in a rate limiting irreversible step |CITS: [16742819]|. The formation of two charged groups prevents the diffusion of substrates out of the cell. This six-carbon sugar is then cleaved into two three-carbon sugars that are interconvertible |CITS: [999838]|. 

Glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate enters the second stage of the pathway that results in the production of 4 ATP and 2 NADH molecules with a net gain of 2 ATP and 4 NADH |CITS: [6188151][BERG02]|. The two substrate-level phosphorylation steps that produce ATP are catalyzed by phosphoglycerate kinase and pyruvate kinase respectively, and are important regulatory points in the glycolytic pathway |CITS: [BERG02]|.

Glycolysis from internal glucose is also found in many prokaryotes. For example, |FRAME: TAX-2336| is a hyperthermophilic anaerobic eubacterium that can utilize various sugars or complex organic substrates as carbon and energy sources. With glucose as a substrate, |FRAME: TAX-2336| produces lactate, acetate, carbon dioxide and hydrogen as the main fermentation products (see |FRAME: PWY-5100|).

The organism has a highly specific |FRAME:CPLX-4241| and a periplasmic, high-affinity glucose-binding protein, suggesting the use of an ATP-binding casette (ABC) transporter for glucose entry into the cell |CITS: [12427944]|. The rest of the pathway occurs via the conventional Embden-Meyerhof pathway |CITS: [ArchMicr161-460][8791626][9075622][2318202]|."	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=ANAEROFRUCAT-PWY"		"anaerobic glycolysis" // "Embden-Meyerhof-Parnas pathway" // "EMP pathway" // "glycolysis III (glucokinase)"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=GLYCOLYSIS-VARIANTS"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-1042" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=ANAGLYCOLYSIS-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5484" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=GLYCOLYSIS" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=P341-PWY"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Energy-Metabolism"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Pathways"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5484"	"glycolysis II (from fructose 6-phosphate)"	"PWY-5484"	"<b>General Background</b>

Glycolysis, which was first studied as a pathway for the utilization of glucose, is one of the major pathways of central metabolism, the other two being the |FRAME:PENTOSE-P-PWY| and the |FRAME:TCA \"TCA cycle\"|. Glycolysis is essential under all conditions of growth, because it produces six of the 13 precursor metabolites that are the starting materials for the biosynthesis of building blocks for macromolecules and other needed small molecules (the six compounds are |FRAME:GLC-6-P|, |FRAME:FRUCTOSE-6P|, |FRAME:DIHYDROXY-ACETONE-PHOSPHATE|, |FRAME:G3P|, |FRAME:PHOSPHO-ENOL-PYRUVATE|, and |FRAME: PYRUVATE|). Glycolysis can be found, if at least in part, in almost all organisms.

Even though glycolysis is often described starting with glucose, other hexoses (e.g. fructose) can also serve as input (as its name implies - glycose is a general term for simple sugars).

Glycolysis has evolved to fulfill two essential functions:

i) it oxidizes hexoses to generate |FRAME:ATP|, reductants and |FRAME:PYRUVATE|, and

ii) being an amphibolic pathway (pathway that involves both catabolism and anabolism), it can reversibly produce hexoses from various low-molecular weight molecules.

Because various degradation pathways feed into glycolysis at many different points, glycolysis or portions of it run in the forward or reverse direction, depending on the carbon source being utilized, in order to satisfy the cell's need for precursor metabolites and energy.
This switching of direction is possible because all but two of the enzymatic reactions comprising glycolysis are reversible, and the conversions catalyzed by the two exceptions are rendered functionally reversible by other enzymes (|FRAME:F16B-CPLX \"fructose-1,6-bisphosphatase\"| and |FRAME:PEPSYNTH-CPLX|) that catalyze different irreversible reactions flowing in the opposite direction.

<b>About This Pathway</b>

The standard glycolysis pathway (|FRAME: GLYCOLYSIS|) depicts the sugar input into the pathway as glucose. However, the glycolysis pathway is utilized for the degradation of many different types of sugars.

This partial depiction of the glycolysis pathway is used with substrates other than glucose, such as |FRAME: ALLOSE|,
|FRAME: CPD-9569| , |FRAME: MANNITOL| , |FRAME: SORBITOL| , |FRAME: MANNOSE| and |FRAME: SUCROSE|,
which are processed into |FRAME: FRUCTOSE-6P|.
D-fructose 6-phosphate enters glycolysis and is processed to the end product pyruvate, which is often fermented
further into fermentation products such as |FRAME: ETOH|, |FRAME: Lactate| and |FRAME: ACET|."	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=HEXITOLDEGSUPER-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=P441-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=P461-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7345"			"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=GLYCOLYSIS-VARIANTS"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-1042" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=ANAGLYCOLYSIS-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5484" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=GLYCOLYSIS" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=P341-PWY"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Energy-Metabolism"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Pathways"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=GLYCOCAT-PWY"	"glycogen degradation I"	"GLYCOCAT-PWY"	"<b>General Background</b>

In many bacteria |FRAME: Glycogens \"glycogen\"| is the primary carbon and energy storage compound. Evidence suggests that it may play a role in the long-term survival of the cell.

In |FRAME: TAX-562| glycogen is stored in granules in the cytosol |CITS: [16816199]|. It is biosynthesized in a highly regulated manner when carbon is plentiful but other nutrients are limiting (see pathway |FRAME: GLYCOGENSYNTH-PWY|). The glycogen is broken down and utilized when carbon sources become limiting |CITS: [21421758][22750467]|.

|FRAME: Glycogens \"Glycogen\"|, |FRAME: Starch|, or |FRAME: Pullulans| are too large to be imported into the cell, and bacteria that do not have extracellualr enzymes that can break it outside the cell are not able to grow on exogenous polymers, although they are able to grow on smaller linear &alpha;-1,4-linked |FRAME: Maltodextrins \"maltodextrins\"| ranging in size from maltose up to about 20 glucose units in length (in Mayer and Boos |CITS: [ecosal]|).

<b>About This Pathway</b>

During endogenous glycogen degradation, |FRAME: EC-2.4.1.1| (encoded by |FRAME: EG10380|) progressively releases |FRAME: GLC-1-P| from the non-reducing ends of linear &alpha;-(1,4)-glycan chains, but is not able to break bonds that are close to &alpha;(1,6)-branch linkages, leaving tails of 4 &alpha;-1,4-linked residues next to branching points. The highly-branched, short-chained product formed by exhaustive hydrolysis by |FRAME: GLYCOPHOSPHORYL-CPLX| has been named |FRAME: CPD0-971|, since it is the limit of what this enzyme is able to achieve on its own.

This pathway is defined by the next enzyme, a type of debranching enzyme encoded by the |FRAME: EG10381| gene, which is unique to bacteria. This enzyme can remove &alpha;-1,6-linked branches that are up to four glucosyl residues in length, to produce a debranched limit dextrin (also called a debranched glycogen phosphorylase limit dextrin) and shorter |FRAME: MALTOTETRAOSE| molecules |CITS: [15687211][16816199]|. Note that this enzyme is different from the debranching system composed of |FRAME: EC-2.4.1.25| and |FRAME: EC-3.2.1.33|, which releases monosaccharides (see |FRAME: PWY-5941|).

Maltodextrin phosphorylase, encoded by |FRAME: EG10560|, phosphorylytically cleaves glucosyl residues from the nonreducing end of the resulting maltodextrins producing &alpha;-D-glucose-1-phosphate and a shortened maltodextrin. Maltotetraose is the smallest acceptable substrate, and thus the ultimate product of MalP is maltotriose, an endogenous inducer of the maltose system (see below) |CITS: [16816199][16321936]|.

Further breakdown of the maltodextrin intermediates, |FRAME: MALTOTRIOSE| and |FRAME: MALTOSE|, involves the products of the maltose utilization genes |FRAME: EG10565| and |FRAME: EG10561|. In |FRAME: TAX-562| the expression of these genes, as well as |FRAME: EG10560|, is activated by |FRAME: MALTOTRIOSE| |CITS: [16321936][16816199][19028900]|.

Maltodextrin glucosidase, encoded by |FRAME: EG10565|, can cleave an &alpha;-D-glucose residue from maltotriose, producing maltose |CITS: [16816199][19028900]|.

Amylomaltase, encoded by |FRAME: EG10561|, is a 4-&alpha;-glucanotransferase that is essential for maltose degradation in |FRAME: TAX-562|. Amylomaltase preferentially removes glucose from the reducing ends of maltose and small maltodextrins, transferring the enzyme-bound dextrinyl residue to the nonreducing ends of other maltodextrins, thereby forming longer maltodextrins (in |CITS: [21421758]|). In this process the number of glucosidic linkages remains constant. Therefore MalQ can both degrade and synthesize the inducer maltotriose, allowing induction when the bacteria are grown on maltodextrins |CITS: [16816199]|. 

The two products of this degradation pathway are |FRAME: Glucopyranose| and |FRAME: GLC-1-P|. Both products are converted to |FRAME: D-glucopyranose-6-phosphate|, whose &beta;-epimer enters |FRAME: GLYCOLYSIS glycolysis|." "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=NAGLIPASYN-PWY"	"lipid IV<sub>A</sub> biosynthesis"	"NAGLIPASYN-PWY"	"|FRAME: Lipopolysaccharides \"Lipopolysaccharide\"| (LPS), a major outer membrane component, is composed of three
domains: |FRAME: Lipid-A \"Lipid A\"|, the core, which is an oligosaccharide consisting of an inner and outer region; and a distal repeating unit known as the |FRAME: O-Antigens \"O-antigen\"|. Lipid A is linked to a &beta;-1,6-linked glucosamine disaccharide. Attached to this is the inner core containing at least two |FRAME: KDO \"3-deoxy-D-<I>manno</I>-octulosonate\"| (KDO) units followed by two units of heptose. The outer core region and the O-antigen are attached to one of the heptose units. 

This pathway includes the steps that lie between |FRAME: UDP-N-ACETYL-D-GLUCOSAMINE| and the immediate lipid A precursor |FRAME: LIPID-IV-A|. Most of the genes encoding the enzymes involved in this pathway are highly conserved. One exception is |FRAME: EC-3.6.1.54|, which is known to be catalyzed by three completely different types of enzymes, encoded by the |FRAME: EG12666| |CITS: [12000770]|, |FRAME: G-55034| |CITS: [20608695]|, and |FRAME: G-55035| |CITS: [27006461]| genes.

There is some evidence that lipid A or its precursors are synthesized in plants |CITS: [16935939][21709257]|." "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=P221-PWY"	"octane oxidation"	"P221-PWY"	"Studies have shown that the capacity to use hydrocarbons as sole carbon and energy source
is very common, and not restricted to any particular group of microorganisms.
Examples were found in a wide range of prokaryotic and eukaryotic genera including Gram-negative
and Gram-positive bacteria, yeasts, fungi, and even some achlorophyllous algae |CITS: [7532480]|.
One of these organisms is the Gram negative bacterium |FRAME: TAX-301|,  isolated from
machine shop cutting oil |CITS: [16560407]|, which can grow on intermediate chain length n-alkanes
(C<sub>6</sub> to C<sub>12</sub>). 
This pathway describes the oxidation of |FRAME: CPD-148| by this organism.

The key enzyme in this pathway is the |FRAME: CPLX-3202|, which is encoded by the OCT plasmid
|CITS: [4515610]|. The |FRAME: CPLX-3202| system introduces molecular oxygen in the terminal carbon
atom of the hydrocarbons at the expense of NADH |CITS: [4403503]| to yield primary alcohols
|CITS: [7592483]|. It is composed of three components - a |FRAME: MONOMER-3842|, a
|FRAME: MONOMER-3844|,  and a |FRAME: MONOMER-1021|.
The NADH-dependent |FRAME: MONOMER-1021| transfers the electrons from NADH, via the electron
carrier |FRAME: MONOMER-3844|, to the monooxygenase, which reduces the other oxygen atom.


The product of the hydroxylase system, |FRAME: OCTANOL|, is then further catabolized by an
|FRAME: MONOMER-1081|, an |FRAME: MONOMER-1082| and an |FRAME: MONOMER-1083|.
The final product, |FRAME: CPD-196|, enters the &beta;-oxidation-cycle, and can be utilized
as a carbon and energy source |CITS: [1453953][7532480]|." // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7978" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6377" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5336" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=P201-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7926" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-8000" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-1164" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-723" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5355"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Degradation"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Pathways"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6471"	"peptidoglycan biosynthesis IV (Enterococcus faecium)"	"PWY-6471"	"<b>General Background</b>

The bacterial bag-shaped envelope (sacculus) can resist turgor pressures of 2-5 atmospheres in Gram-negative bacteria, and up to 20 atm in Gram-positive bacteria.
This remarkable tensile strength, combined with elasticity, is achieved by the structure of the cell wall's main component, peptidoglycan (also known as \"basal structure\", \"mucopeptide\", \"glycopeptide\", \"glycosaminopeptide\" and \"murein\"). Peptidoglycan is found on the outside of the cytoplasmic membrane of almost all eubacteria, and is unique to these organisms.

Peptidoglycan is best described as a fisherman net. The mesh of the net is made of two segments of parallel, rather inextensible glycan threads, held together by two small elastic peptide crosslinks allowing the net to expand or shrink |CITS: [10532377]|.
The glycan moiety of the peptidoglycan is remarkably uniform among all bacteria, and is made up of alternating &beta;-1,4-linked <i>N</i>-acetylglucosamine and <i>N</i>-acetyl muramate residues, with an average chain length (in different organisms) of 10 to 65 disaccharide units (although it is about 5000 in |FRAME: TAX-1423|). The peptide moiety is less uniform, as described in |FRAME: PWY-5265|.

<b>About This Pathway</b>

This pathway describes the biosynthesis of the peptidoglycan found in Gram-positive Enterococci , including |FRAME: TAX-1352| and |FRAME: TAX-1354|. The peptidoglycan of these organisms is characterized by having |FRAME:LYS| at position 3 of the pentapeptide, and by including a |FRAME: CPD-302| or |FRAME: CPD-3633| bridge in the crosslinks between glycan strands.

Six cytoplasmic steps catalyze the formation of the |FRAME:UDP-NAcMur-Peptides| precursor. This precursor is attached to the memberane acceptor |FRAME:UNDECAPRENYL-P|, generating |FRAME:NAcMur-Peptide-Undecaprenols|, also known as lipid I.
Another transferase adds |FRAME:UDP-N-ACETYL-D-GLUCOSAMINE|, yielding lipid II, which carries the full monomer unit, |FRAME:NAcMur-Peptide-NAcGlc-Undecaprenols |.

The next step of the pathway describes the amidation of the |FRAME: D-GLT| at the second position of the pentapeptide. 
In most of the organisms which have been examined, including |FRAME: TAX-1352|, the &alpha;-carboxyl group of |FRAME: D-GLT| is present as an amide; i.e. the second amino acid in the peptide sequence is |FRAME: CPD-12296| |CITS: [5219821][6025572][5968582]|. Some characterization of the reaction has been carried out, although the identity of the enzyme that catalyzes it in |FRAME: TAX-1352| is still unknown |CITS: [5638594]|.
Following amidation, the final lipid intermediate is transferred by an as yet unknown mechanism through the membrane.

The peptidoglycan monomers are polymerized on the outside surface by glycosyltransferases, which form the linear glycan chains, and transpeptidases, which catalyze the formation of peptide crosslinks |CITS: [11320055]|. While some of these enzymes are mono-functional, the main enzymes are bifunctional proteins possessing both glycosyltransferase and transpeptidase activities |CITS: [9791115]|.

Peptide cross-links form between different parts of the peptides depending on the organism. In |FRAME: TAX-1352| the crosslinks includes an interpeptide bridge of a single |FRAME: CPD-302| or |FRAME: CPD-3633| residue (see |FRAME: PWY-6461|). |FRAME: CPD-302| is added to lipid II by a reaction catalyzed by |FRAME: MONOMER-15487| (encoded by the |FRAME: G-11868| gene) |CITS: [16510449]| and is subsequently amidated to |FRAME: CPD-3633| by the |FRAME: G-11898|-encoded |FRAME: MONOMER-15525|. The crosslinks are formed between the carboxyl group of the penultimate |FRAME: D-ALANINE| (residue 4) of one peptide and the amino group of the |FRAME: CPD-3633| of a peptide in a second glycan chain.

The crosslinking reaction is catalyzed by D-D transpeptidases, a group of enzymes that belong to the |FRAME: Penicillin-Binding-Proteins \"penicillin-binding proteins\"| (PBPs), and involves the cleavage of the D-alanyl-D-alanine bond of the pentapeptides, which provides the energy to drive the reaction. As a result, the peptides in the peptidoglycan polymers are one amino acid shorter than the peptides in the monomers. These crosslinking enzymes are the target of &beta;-lactam antibiotics.

<b>Penicillin Resistance</b>

Some Enterococci, including |FRAME: TAX-1352|, are intrinsically resistant to moderate levels of |FRAME: CPD-9195|, with MICs typically ranging from 1 to 16 &mu;g/ml.
Studies performed with |FRAME: TAX-1354| showed that one such enzyme in particular, |FRAME: MONOMER-15537|, is responsible for the resistance in this strain. This enzyme, which has a a low-affinity towards penicillin, can substitute the functions of the other PBPs which become inactive in the presence of the antibiotic.

While the |FRAME: G-11910| gene is located on a plasmid in |FRAME: TAX-1354|, it is chromosomally located in |FRAME: TAX-1352|, and is considered to be intrinsic to the species, although it can be treansferred among strains by chromosome-to-chromosome transfer |CITS: [16304165]|.

Recently, an increase in ampicillin resistance has been observed in clinical |FRAME: TAX-1352| isolates. 
Studies showed that increased resistance results from two mechanisms - over-production of |FRAME: MONOMER-15537| (expression of the enzyme is controlled by a regulator that is encoded upstream by the <i>psr</i> gene), and mutation of the enzyme to become less sensitive to the antibiotics |CITS: [7811006][9158761][8759860]|.

A 2001 study reported that |FRAME: G-11910| is responsible for intrinsic resistance only to moderate levels of ampicillin, and by itself cannot confer high-level resistance |CITS: [11502534]|. However, this conclusion has been disputed |CITS: [18676222]|." "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Cell-Structure-Biosynthesis" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=NIL&object=Generalized-Reactions"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6470"	"peptidoglycan biosynthesis V (&beta;-lactam resistance)"	"PWY-6470"	"For description of the regular peptidoglycan biosynthesis pathway in Gram-positive bacteria, please see |FRAME: PWY-5265|.

Two main classes of drugs that are used to treat severe infections due to Gram-positive bacteria, the &beta;-lactams and the glycopeptides antibiotics, are targeting this pathway. The mechanism of glycopeptides activity and resistance are described in the pathways of |FRAME: Vancomycin-Resistnace|.

The &beta;-lactams are the first and still the most frequently used class of antibacterial agents. The structure of these compounds contain a D,D linkage that is very similar to the D-Ala-D-Ala bond in the peptidoglycan pentapeptide. The D,D-transpeptidase catalytic domains of the penicillin-binding proteins (PBPs) that are responsible for cross-linking the peptidoglycan threads (see |FRAME: MONOMER-15471| for an example) recognize this strucutre and bind the &beta;-lactam antibiotics in an irreversible manner, resulting in inactivation of the enzymes.

&beta;-Lactam resistance in pathogenic bacteria is due to production of low-affinity PBPs (for example, methicillin resistance in |FRAME: TAX-1280| caused by the |FRAME: MONOMER-15469| protein, and ampicillin resistance in enterococci which results from the |FRAME: MONOMER-15537| protein), drug detoxification by production of &beta;-lactamases, and decreased permeability. Recently a new mechanism for resistance has been described.
In some strains, such as the case of |FRAME: TAX-1352| D344M512, resistance is a result of a complete bypass of the D,D transpeptidases by an |FRAME: MONOMER-15534 \"L,D transpeptidase\"| |CITS: [10748168]|.

The regular cross-links in Enterococci are formed between the |FRAME: D-ALANINE| residue at position 4 of one peptide and the |FRAME: CPD-302| or |FRAME: CPD-3633| which are attached to the |FRAME:LYS| at position 3 of a second peptide (see |FRAME: PWY-6461|). The D,D-transpeptidase that catalyzes this linkage requires an intact D-Ala-D-Ala bond in the first peptide. This bond is hydrolyzed, providing the energy to drive the reaction.

It has been shown that in the resistant strain a VanY-type |FRAME: CPLX-8039 \"carboxypeptidase\"| is constitutively active |CITS: [20025663]|. This carboxypeptidase, which is resistant to glycopeptide antibiotics such as vancomycin, removes the terminal |FRAME: D-ALANINE| residue from all pentapeptides, resulting in peptidoglycan precursors that exclusively include a tetrapeptide. These precursors are not a substrate for the D,D-transpeptidases, but form an excellent substrate for the |FRAME: MONOMER-15534 \"L,D-transpeptidase\"|, encoded by the |FRAME: G-11907| gene, which catalyzes the formation of cross-links between |FRAME: LYS| of the first peptide and the |FRAME: CPD-302| or |FRAME: CPD-3633| residue of the second peptide |CITS:[16144833][16647082]|.

The L,D-transpeptidase is present &beta;-lactam-sensitive strains of |FRAME: TAX-1352|, but is usually inactive due to lack of its substrate - the tetrapeptide form of the peptidoglycan precursor, |FRAME: CPD-12258|. A mutated two-component regulatory system (DdcRS) in the resistant strains is responsible for the activation of the |FRAME: CPLX-8039|, which prepares the substrates for the transpeptidase |CITS: [20025663]|.

By \"by-passing\" the D,D-transpeptidases the enzyme confers resistance towards most &beta;-lactam antibiotics on the organism |CITS: [10748168]|. The enzyme was thought to be completely insensitive to &beta;-lactam antibiotics, but recently it has been shown that it is very sensitive to |FRAME: CPD-9231|, a &beta;-lactam of the carbapenem class |CITS: [17646161]|. The discovery indicated that the spectrum of activity of &beta;-lactams is not restricted to transpeptidases of the DD-specificity, as previously thought."
