"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=SER-GLYSYN-PWY"	"superpathway of L-serine and glycine biosynthesis I"	"SER-GLYSYN-PWY"	"This superpathway shows the production of both |FRAME: SER| and |FRAME: GLY|, as the biosynthesis of each these two compounds is tightly affected by the other, via the action of |FRAME: EC-2.1.2.1|.

Serine biosynthesis is a major metabolic pathway in many organisms. |FRAME: SER| is not only used in protein synthesis, but also as a precursor for the biosynthesis of glycine, cysteine, tryptophan, and phospholipids. In the pathway shown here, which operates in bacteria, yeast, and animals, serine is derived from |FRAME: G3P|, an intermediate of glycolysis. 

|FRAME: EC-2.1.2.1|, converts serine to glycine, transferring a methyl group to |FRAME: THF-GLU-N tetrahydrofolate|, thus forming |FRAME: METHYLENE-THF-GLU-N 5,10-methylene-tetrahydrofolate|, the major source of one-carbon units in many organisms, making serine hydroxymethyltransferase a key enzyme in the biosynthesis of many compounds that require a one-carbon unit, such as purines, thymidine, methionine, choline and lipids.

"		"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=SERSYN-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=COMPLETE-ARO-PWY"	"superpathway of aromatic amino acid biosynthesis"	"COMPLETE-ARO-PWY"	"The aromatic amino acids |FRAME: PHE|, |FRAME: TYR| and |FRAME: TRP| are biosynthesized from the principal common precursor |FRAME: CHORISMATE|.  The conversion of |FRAME: CHORISMATE| to |FRAME: PREPHENATE| leads to the terminal pathways of |FRAME: PHE| and |FRAME: TYR| biosynthesis.  The conversion of |FRAME: CHORISMATE| to |FRAME: ANTHRANILATE| leads to the biosynthesis of |FRAME: TRP|.  |FRAME: CHORISMATE| is also the precursor for biosynthesis of other essential compunds, as shown in the |FRAME: ALL-CHORISMATE-PWY|.  Reviewed in Pittard, J. and J. Yang (2008) \"Biosynthesis of the Aromatic Aminio Acids.\" EcoSal 3.6.1.8 |CITS: [ecosal]|." "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=ASPASN-PWY"	"superpathway of L-aspartate and L-asparagine biosynthesis"	"ASPASN-PWY"	"Aspartate undergoes a number of reactions that are not in any linear order.  One reaction converts the TCA intermediate fumarate to aspartate.  Another reaction irreversibly converts aspartate to asparagine. A third reaction facilitates reversible interconversion of aspartate and asparargine.

In |FRAME:TAX-562| aspartase participates in at least two metabolic processes: the regeneration of oxaloacetate as amino-acceptor for enabling growth on glutamate, and the formation of fumarate and succinate during anaerobic growth on glucose |CITS: [6088667] [2853974]|." "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=P4-PWY"	"superpathway of L-lysine, L-threonine and L-methionine biosynthesis I"	"P4-PWY"	"This superpathway integrates the biosynthesis of the amino acids |FRAME: L-ASPARTATE|, |FRAME: LYS|, |FRAME: THR|, and |FRAME: MET|, all of which are derived from the central metabolite |FRAME: OXALACETIC_ACID|, an intermediate of the |FRAME:TCA \"TCA cycle\"|. The specific pathways shown here are those used by the bacterium |FRAME: TAX-562|.

The pathway starts by the reversible transamination of |FRAME:OXALACETIC_ACID| to |FRAME: L-ASPARTATE|, which is catalyzed by |FRAME: EC-2.6.1.1|, providing a link between carbohydrate and amino acid metabolism. |FRAME:OXALACETIC_ACID Oxaloacetate|, which is consumed in this pathway, is replenished from the |FRAME:TCA \"TCA cycle\"|, by |FRAME: EC-6.4.1.1|, and in some bacteria also by |FRAME: EC-4.1.1.31| |CITS: [Gottschalk1986]|.

|FRAME: L-ASPARTATE| is converted in two steps to |FRAME: L-ASPARTATE-SEMIALDEHYDE|, which is the first branch point in this pathway. One branch leads toward |FRAME: LYS| biosynthesis, while the other continues towards the biosynthesis of the other amino acids included in this superpathway |CITS: [14929228]|. Because this step is common to all of the subsequent biosynthetic pathways, |FRAME: TAX-562| has three different enzymes that catalyze it (|FRAME: ASPKINIHOMOSERDEHYDROGI-CPLX \"aspartate kinase I\"|, |FRAME: ASPKINIIHOMOSERDEHYDROGII-CPLX \"aspartate kinase II\"|, and |FRAME: ASPKINIII-CPLX \"aspartate kinase III\"|), which are controlled by the available supply of |FRAME: THR|, |FRAME: MET| and |FRAME: LYS|, respectively |CITS: [4148765]|.
The L-lysine pathway shown here belongs to the diaminopimelate (DAP) group of Lysine pathways, and is known as the succinylase variant (see |FRAME: DAPLYSINESYN-PWY|, as it involves succinylated intermediates.

The rest of the |FRAME: L-ASPARTATE-SEMIALDEHYDE| is converted to |FRAME: HOMO-SER| by |FRAME: EC-1.1.1.3|. Once again, |FRAME: TAX-562| has two different enzymes catalyzing this reaction, which are controlled by the availability of |FRAME: THR| and |FRAME: MET|, respectively |CITS: [4551091][4889171]|.
|FRAME: HOMO-SER| can be isomerized to |FRAME: THR| in two steps that involved phosphorylation and de-phosphorylation |CITS: [11368768]|, or alternatively can lead to the formation of |FRAME: MET| in a 4-step pathway. 

For |FRAME: MET| biosynthesis, homoserine is first activated by <i>O</i>-succinylation, and the product is combined with |FRAME: CYS| to form cystathionine. This compound is cleaved to homocysteine, which is subsequently methylated to produce methionine. The last reaction is catalyzed in |FRAME: TAX-562| by two different enzymes, |FRAME: EC-2.1.1.13| and |FRAME: EC-2.1.1.14|. Both enzymes use |FRAME: 5-METHYL-THF-GLU-N| as the methyl donor. However, the former requires cobalamin (vitamin B<sub>12</sub>), while the latter does not |CITS: [1339288]|." "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6562"	"norspermidine biosynthesis"	"PWY-6562"	"<b>General Background</b>

Polyamines are found in bacteria, archaea and eukaryotes and are necessary for normal cellular physiology.  They include the diamine |FRAME: PUTRESCINE|, the triamines |FRAME: SPERMIDINE|, |FRAME: NORSPERMIDINE| (<i>sym</i>-norspermidine) and |FRAME: CPD-1821| (homospermidine) and the tetraamine |FRAME: SPERMINE| (in |CITS: [20194510]| and in |CITS: [19196710]|).  Links to their biosynthetic pathways can be found by clicking on these compounds links.  See also |FRAME: POLYAMSYN-PWY|, |FRAME: POLYAMINSYN3-PWY| and |FRAME: PWY-6565|.  In members of the genus |FRAME:TAX-662|, |FRAME: NORSPERMIDINE| is a major polyamine (in |CITS: [19196710]|.

<b>About This Pathway</b>

In this pathway |FRAME: L-ASPARTATE-SEMIALDEHYDE| donates a carboxyaminopropyl group to |FRAME: CPD-313| to form |FRAME: CPD-9995| in a reaction catalyzed by carboxynorspermidine/carboxyspermidine dehydrogenase (CANSDH).  Decarboxylation of |FRAME: CPD-9995| catalyzed by carboxynorspermidine/carboxyspermidine decarboxylase (CANSDC) produces |FRAME: NORSPERMIDINE|.  |FRAME: L-ASPARTATE-SEMIALDEHYDE| is also a precursor for |FRAME: CPD-313| biosynthesis from |FRAME: CPD-470| which is catalyzed by a bifunctional fusion protein L-2,4-diaminobutyrate aminotransferase/decarboxylase (DABA AT/DC) (|CITS: [3697846] [19196710]|  and in |CITS: [20194510]|).

This |FRAME: L-ASPARTATE-SEMIALDEHYDE| based pathway has been experimentally demonstrated <i>in vivo</i> in |FRAME: TAX-666| including a branch of this pathway that leads to the biosynthesis of |FRAME: SPERMIDINE| as shown in the pathway link.  Both pathways are shown together in |FRAME: PWY-6565|.

Heterologous expression in |FRAME:TAX-562| of the genes encoding the enzymes in this pathway resulted in accumulation of |FRAME: CPD-313| and |FRAME: NORSPERMIDINE| (which are inactive polyamines in |FRAME:TAX-562|).  Deletion of the gene encoding CANSDC in |FRAME: TAX-666| resulted in accumulation of |FRAME: CPD-9995|.  Deletion of the genes encoding either CANSDC or CANSDH led to loss of |FRAME: NORSPERMIDINE| and |FRAME: SPERMIDINE|, thus identifying the gene encoding CANSDH.  Interestingly,  deletion of the |FRAME: TAX-666| genes encoding either CANSDH or CANSDC reduced the growth rate of planktonic cells by approximately 50% and severely reduced biofilm formation.  Biofilm formation could be rescued by adding exogenous |FRAME: NORSPERMIDINE|, but not |FRAME: SPERMIDINE| .  The pathway did not appear to be related to the infectivity of |FRAME: TAX-666|, using a mouse model |CITS: [19196710]|.  Earlier work also suggested a role for |FRAME: NORSPERMIDINE| in biofilm formation in |FRAME: TAX-666| |CITS: [16237027]|.

Bioinformatic analysis suggested that DABA AT/DC fusion proteins and their clustering with CANSDH and CANSDC were found only in the family |FRAME: TAX-641|, giving support to their role in both |FRAME: SPERMIDINE| and |FRAME: NORSPERMIDINE| biosynthesis in these organisms.    However, a clustered pair of CANSDH and CANSDC genes was widespread in the &alpha;-, &beta;-, &gamma;-, &delta;- and &epsilon;-proteobacteria, firmicutes and a candidate division TG-1, suggesting that the pathway for |FRAME: SPERMIDINE| biosynthesis may be more widely used.  However, this conclusion could not be extended to |FRAME: NORSPERMIDINE| biosynthesis without experimental support due to the use of |FRAME: CPD-470| in other pathways (see |FRAME: P101-PWY|, |FRAME: PWY-6409| and |FRAME: PWY-761|) |CITS: [19196710]|.

"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6562" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-3385" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6158" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-3542" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=POLYAMSYN-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-43" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-3561" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=GLYCGREAT-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-46" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=TRYPANOSYN-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6305" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6565" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-40" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6173" "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-4121"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Biosynthesis"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Pathways"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6608"	"guanosine nucleotides degradation III"	"PWY-6608"	"<b>General Background</b>

The distinction between nucleoside degradation and salvage is not always straight forward.
A general rule is that degradation pathways start with the nucleotide forms and convert them to simpler forms, eventually leading to complete mineralization, while salvage pathways start with either the nucleoside or the free base form, and convert those to the nucleotide forms.

Nucleotide recycling is achieved by a combination of both types - a nucleotide is partially degraded via a degradation pathway, but the products are shuttled into a salvage pathway rather then towrds complete mineralization.

<b>About This Pathway</b>

This pathway of guanosine nucleotides degradation begins with the conversion of GMP to |FRAME: GUANOSINE|, which is then converted to the free base |FRAME: GUANINE| by the enzyme |FRAME: CPLX-6181| (EC 2.4.2.1). |FRAME: GUANINE \"Guanine\"| is converted to |FRAME:URATE| via |FRAME: XANTHINE| by the enzymes |FRAME: MONOMER-11785| and |FRAME: XANTHINE-OXIDASE| |CITS: [14726515]|.

This pathway is very similar to a pathway that occurs in plants and fungi (|FRAME: PWY-6606|). However, in this pathway  |FRAME: GUANOSINE| is converted to |FRAME: GUANINE| by the enzyme |FRAME: CPLX-6181| (EC 2.4.2.1) while in plants this conversion is catalyzed by the enzyme |FRAME: MONOMER-15864| (EC 3.5.4.15) |CITS: [14725335]|."	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6353"			"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Guanosine-Nucleotides-Degradation"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6606" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6607" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6608" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6595"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Purine-Degradation"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=NUCLEO-DEG"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=SALVADEHYPOX-PWY"	"adenosine nucleotides degradation II"	"SALVADEHYPOX-PWY"	"<b>General Background</b>

The distinction between nucleoside degradation and salvage is not always straight forward.
A general rule is that degradation pathways start with the nucleotide forms and convert them to simpler forms, eventually leading to complete mineralization, while salvage pathways start with either the nucleoside or the free base form, and convert those to the nucleotide forms.

Nucleotide recycling is achieved by a combination of both types - a nucleotide is partially degraded via a degradation pathway, but the products are shuttled into a salvage pathway rather then towrds complete mineralization.

<b>About This Pathway</b>

This pathway shares several steps with the pathway |FRAME: PWY-6609|. However, the salvage pathway starts with the free base |FRAME: ADENINE| (which is often transported into the organism) and ends with the nucleotide |FRAME: IMP|, leading to biosynthesis of nucleotides, while this degradation pathway starts with the nucleotide form (|FRAME: AMP|) and ends with |FRAME: URATE|, which in most organisms is degraded further, providing the organism with carbon, nitrogen and energy.

A key enzyme in this pathway is adenosine deaminase, which converts |FRAME: ADENOSINE| to |FRAME: INOSINE|. This has been shown to be the main form of adenosine degradation by the fungi |FRAME: TAX-36642| |CITS: [7551735]| and |FRAME:TAX-293373| |CITS: [15812856]|.

Xanthine degradation to allantoin has been observed in |FRAME:TAX-562|, but this degradation does not progress past allantoin or allantoate and this catabolism does not suffice as a source of nitrogen under aerobic growth conditions  |CITS: [10986234]|."	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6353"		"purine ribonucleotide/ribonucleoside metabolism"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Adenosine-Nucleotides-Degradation"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6617" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=SALVADEHYPOX-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6596"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Purine-Degradation"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=NUCLEO-DEG"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7208"	"superpathway of pyrimidine nucleobases salvage"	"PWY-7208"	"<b>General Background</b>

The essential ribonucleoside triphosphates (|FRAME:UTP| and |FRAME:CTP|) can be synthesized either <i>de novo</i> (see |FRAME: PWY0-162|) or by utilizing free pyrimidine bases (|FRAME: URACIL| and |FRAME: CYTOSINE|) or their nucleosides (|FRAME: URIDINE| and |FRAME: CYTIDINE|) by importing them from the environment. Both free bases and nucleosides can be imported into the cell by specialized transporters |CITS:[8982282][22616996][22857534]|. On the other hand, nucleotides (which are phosphorylated) can not be imported due to their negative charge, and thus can not be salvaged from the environment.

Salvage is very important for many types of organisms and cells. Studies with the plant |FRAME: TAX-3702| showed that uracil salvage is necessary for early development |CITS: [19563437]| and that uridine salvage plays a crucial role in photoassimilate allocation and partioning |CITS: [21828290]|. The inability to salvage uracil caused a light-dependent dramatic pale-green to albino phenotype, dwarfism and the inability to produce viable progeny in loss-of-function mutants |CITS: [19563437]|. In mammals it is generally accepted that only the liver and kidney maintain <i>de novo</i> pyrimidine and purine synthesis, and supply other tissues and organs, including the brain, with pyrimidine nucleosides (mainly uridine) and purine nucleosides and bases for nucleotide synthesis |CITS: [11782482][15772079][16769123]|. 

Any of the pyrimidine bases and pyrimidine nucleosides can in theory serve as a total source of pyrimidine for ribonucleoside triphosphates biosynthesis (and subsequently for deoxyribonucleoside triphosphates synthesis). It is well documented that yeast prefer to salvage nucleobases, while animals prefer the salvage of nucleosides.

<b>About This Pathway</b>

The key enzyme in the salvage of the pyrimidine nucleobase |FRAME: URACIL| is (|FRAME: EC-2.4.2.9 \"uracil phosphoribosyltransferase (EC 2.4.2.9)\"| (UPRT), which transfers a phosphoribosyl group from |FRAME: PRPP| (PRPP) to uracil, generating |FRAME: UMP| in a single step. The enzyme is found in archaea, bacteria, lower eukaryotes and plants |CITS: [16660311][216696][2189783][8856065][11773618][14658380]|. This pathway was shown to be the major route for uracil salvage in potato tubers |CITS: [12244448]|.

Mammals lack the enzyme, and thereby are unable to perform the one-step salvage of uracil |CITS: [15685165]| and are limited to recycling pyrimidine nucleosides via uridine kinases (see |FRAME: PWY-7193|).

Some archaea, bacteria and lower eukaryotes that possess the enzyme |FRAME: CPLX0-7932| (|FRAME: EC-3.5.4.1 \"EC 3.5.4.1\"|) are also able to salvage exogenously supplied |FRAME: CYTOSINE| by converting it to |FRAME: URACIL| (see |FRAME: PWY-7194|).

Once the nucleobases are converted to |FRAME: UMP|, it can be phosphorylated to form the RNA building blocks |FRAME: UTP| and |FRAME: CTP| by the enzymes that participate in the <i>de novo</i> biosynthetic pathway, as described in the pathway |FRAME: PWY-7176|." "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Pathways"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Nucleotide-Biosynthesis" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=NIL&object=Generalized-Reactions"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7196"	"superpathway of pyrimidine ribonucleosides salvage"	"PWY-7196"	"<b>General Background</b>

The essential ribonucleoside triphosphates (|FRAME:UTP| and |FRAME:CTP|) can be synthesized either <i>de novo</i> (see |FRAME: PWY0-162|) or by utilizing free pyrimidine bases (|FRAME: URACIL| and |FRAME: CYTOSINE|) or their nucleosides (|FRAME: URIDINE| and |FRAME: CYTIDINE|) by importing them from the environment. Both free bases and nucleosides can be imported into the cell by specialized transporters |CITS:[8982282][22616996][22857534]|. On the other hand, nucleotides (which are phosphorylated) can not be imported due to their negative charge, and thus can not be salvaged from the environment.

Salvage is very important for many types of organisms and cells. Studies with the plant |FRAME: TAX-3702| showed that uracil salvage is necessary for early development |CITS: [19563437]| and that uridine salvage plays a crucial role in photoassimilate allocation and partioning |CITS: [21828290]|. The inability to salvage uracil caused a light-dependent dramatic pale-green to albino phenotype, dwarfism and the inability to produce viable progeny in loss-of-function mutants |CITS: [19563437]|. In mammals it is generally accepted that only the liver and kidney maintain <i>de novo</i> pyrimidine and purine synthesis, and supply other tissues and organs, including the brain, with pyrimidine nucleosides (mainly uridine) and purine nucleosides and bases for nucleotide synthesis |CITS: [11782482][15772079][16769123]|. 

Any of the pyrimidine bases and pyrimidine nucleosides can in theory serve as a total source of pyrimidine for ribonucleoside triphosphates biosynthesis (and subsequently for deoxyribonucleoside triphosphates synthesis). It is well documented that yeast prefer to salvage nucleobases, while animals prefer the salvage of nucleosides.

<b>About This Pathway</b>

This superpathway combines multiple routes in which some organisms (including bacteria, yeast and plants) can salvage the pyrimidine ribonucleosides |FRAME: CYTIDINE| and |FRAME: URIDINE| and convert them to the ribonucleotide |FRAME: UMP|, which can serve as a precursor for the synthesis of all other pyrimidine nucleotides.

Since most of the salvage enzymes have higher activity with |FRAME: URIDINE|, most of the available |FRAME: CYTIDINE| is coverted to |FRAME: URIDINE| by cytidine deaminase, |FRAME: EC-3.5.4.5|.

|FRAME: URIDINE Uridine| is then converted to UMP in one of two routes. In the first route, this transformation is achieved in a single step by the enzyme |FRAME: EC-2.7.1.48 \"uridine kinase (EC 2.7.1.48)\"|. In most organisms this enzyme is also active with |FRAME: CYTIDINE|, and thus can form |FRAME: CMP| as well (although this has not been shown yet for the plant enzymes).

In the second route, |FRAME: URIDINE| is first hydrolyzed to the nucleobase |FRAME: URACIL| by |FRAME: EC-3.2.2.3 \"uridine nucleosidase (EC 3.2.2.3)\"|, and the nucleobase is phosphoribosylated to UMP by the enzyme |FRAME: EC-2.4.2.9 \"uracil phosphoribosyltransferase (EC 2.4.2.9)\"|.

Mammals have not been included in this superpathway, since they do not have the enzyme uridine nucleosidase and thus can not convert uridine to uracil. They do utilize a nucleoside kinase-based pathway (see |FRAME: PWY-7183|)." "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7200"	"superpathway of pyrimidine deoxyribonucleoside salvage"	"PWY-7200"	"<b>General Background</b>

Deoxyribonucleotides are synthesised <i>de novo</i> at the diphosphate level through reduction of the 2-hydroxyl group of the corresponding ribonucleotides (see |FRAME: PWY-7184|). This reduction is mediated by the key enzyme |FRAME: EC-1.17.4.1 \"ribonucleoside-diphosphate reductase\"|.

The <i>de novo</i> synthesis of ribonucleotides is very expensive, and organisms have adapted to salvage potential precursors from their environment. Since nucleotides can not be imported into the cell due to the negative charge of the phosphate groups, salvage is limited to free bases and nucleosides. 

Salvage is very important for many types of organisms and cells. It has been shown that in quiescent or terminally differentiated mammalian cells, resting in the G0 phase, ribonucleotide reductase is not produced due to a block during transcription and the cells rely on salvage for deoxyribonucleotides for DNA repair |CITS: [3044582][1696835]|. Similarly, the salvage pathway is the sole provider of deoxyribonucleotides to be used in DNA repair or mitochondrial DNA replication in G1 cells. Studies with the plant |FRAME: TAX-3702| showed that uracil salvage is necessary for early development |CITS: [19563437]| and that uridine salvage plays a crucial role in photoassimilate allocation and partioning |CITS: [21828290]|.

The deoxyribonucleosides enter through the cell membrane by facilitated diffusion via a low affinity, high capacity, non-concentrative nucleoside carrier protein with a wide specificity, possessed by almost all animal cells |CITS: [3048401]|. The next step in the salvage pathway is the phosphorylation of the nucleosides to monophosphates. Once phosphorylation occurs, the nucleotides are trapped intracellularly due to their negative charge.

<b>About This Pathway</b>

Deoxyribonucleoside kinases salvage deoxyribonucleosides by phosphorylating them at the 5' position. The key enzymes in the salvage of pyrimidine deoxyribonucleosides are |FRAME: EC-2.7.1.21 \"thymidine kinase (EC 2.7.1.21)\"|, (which also phosphorylates deoxyuridine) and |FRAME: EC-2.7.1.74 \"deoxycytidine kinase (EC 2.7.1.74)\"|.
This salvage pathway is well characterized in bacteria |CITS: [402352]|, mammals |CITS: [7494863]|, and plants |CITS: [22897443]|.

Mammalian cells contain both of these kinases. In humans |FRAME: CPLX-8618| is encoded by the |FRAME: HS08100| gene, while two isozymes, encoded by |FRAME: HS09657| and |FRAME: HS09420|, catalyze thymidine kinase activity |CITS: [6281270][8380161]|.
|FRAME: TAX-3702| posseses two thymidine kinase genes (|FRAME: AT3G07800| and |FRAME: AT5G23070|), and a broad substrate range |FRAME: AT1G72040-MONOMER| encoded by a single |FRAME: AT1G72040| gene that can phosphorylate both |FRAME: DEOXYURIDINE| and |FRAME: DEOXYCYTIDINE| |CITS: [22897443]|.
Most eubacteria also employ this salvage pathway. However, some organisms, including |FRAME: TAX-562| and |FRAME: TAX-90370|, lack the enzyme that phosphorylates deoxycytidine |CITS: [EcoSal]|. The yeast |FRAME: TAX-4932| does not have any deoxyribonucleoside kinases, and thus does not possess this pathway.

In addition to these two kinases, the pathway also shows how |FRAME: DEOXYCYTIDINE| can be salvaged for the synthesis of deoxythymidine nucleotides. This is enabled by deamination to |FRAME: DEOXYURIDINE|, followed by phosphorylation by thymidine kinase to form dUMP. The latter can be converted directly to |FRAME: TMP| by the action of |FRAME: EC-2.1.1.45 \"thymidylate synthase (EC 2.1.1.45)\"|.

Once formed, the monophosphates are phosphorylated further to form the triphosphates that are required for DNA synthesis. |FRAME: TMP| is phosphorylated to the diphosphate form by a specific |FRAME: EC-2.7.4.9 \" dTMP kinase (EC 2.7.4.9)\"|, while |FRAME: DCMP| is phosphorylated in eukaryotes by the |FRAME: EC-2.7.4.14 \"bifunctional UMP/CMP kinase (EC 2.7.4.14)\"| and in prokaryotes by a dedicated |FRAME: EC-2.7.4.25 \"(d)CMP kinase (EC 2.7.4.25)\"|. Both diphosphates, |FRAME: DUDP| and |FRAME: DCDP|, are phosphorylated to the triphosphate forms by the broad-substrate range |FRAME: EC-2.7.4.6 \"nucleoside-diphosphate kinase (EC 2.7.4.6)\"|." "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7199"	"pyrimidine deoxyribonucleosides salvage"	"PWY-7199"	"<b>General Background</b>

Deoxyribonucleotides are synthesised <i>de novo</i> at the diphosphate level through reduction of the 2-hydroxyl group of the corresponding ribonucleotides (see |FRAME: PWY-7184|). This reduction is mediated by the key enzyme |FRAME: EC-1.17.4.1 \"ribonucleoside-diphosphate reductase\"|.

The <i>de novo</i> synthesis of ribonucleotides is very expensive, and organisms have adapted to salvage potential precursors from their environment. Since nucleotides can not be imported into the cell due to the negative charge of the phosphate groups, salvage is limited to free bases and nucleosides. 

Salvage is very important for many types of organisms and cells. It has been shown that in quiescent or terminally differentiated mammalian cells, resting in the G0 phase, ribonucleotide reductase is not produced due to a block during transcription and the cells rely on salvage for deoxyribonucleotides for DNA repair |CITS: [3044582][1696835]|. Similarly, the salvage pathway is the sole provider of deoxyribonucleotides to be used in DNA repair or mitochondrial DNA replication in G1 cells. Studies with the plant |FRAME: TAX-3702| showed that uracil salvage is necessary for early development |CITS: [19563437]| and that uridine salvage plays a crucial role in photoassimilate allocation and partioning |CITS: [21828290]|.

The deoxyribonucleosides enter through the cell membrane by facilitated diffusion via a low affinity, high capacity, non-concentrative nucleoside carrier protein with a wide specificity, possessed by almost all animal cells |CITS: [3048401]|. The next step in the salvage pathway is the phosphorylation of the nucleosides to monophosphates. Once phosphorylation occurs, the nucleotides are trapped intracellularly due to their negative charge.

<b>About This Pathway</b>

Deoxyribonucleoside kinases salvage deoxyribonucleosides by phosphorylating them at the 5' position. The key enzymes in the salvage of pyrimidine deoxyribonucleosides are |FRAME: EC-2.7.1.21 \"thymidine kinase (EC 2.7.1.21)\"| (which also phosphorylates deoxyuridine) and |FRAME: EC-2.7.1.74 \"deoxycytidine kinase (EC 2.7.1.74)\"|.
This salvage pathway is well characterized in bacteria |CITS: [402352]|, mammals |CITS: [7494863]|, and plants |CITS: [22897443]|.

Mammalian cells contain both of these kinases. In humans |FRAME: CPLX-8618| is encoded by the |FRAME: HS08100| gene, while two isozymes, encoded by |FRAME: HS09657| and |FRAME: HS09420|, catalyze thymidine kinase activity |CITS: [6281270][8380161]|.

|FRAME: TAX-3702| posseses two thymidine kinase genes (|FRAME: AT3G07800| and |FRAME: AT5G23070|), and a broad substrate range |FRAME: AT1G72040-MONOMER| encoded by a single |FRAME: AT1G72040| gene that can phosphorylate both |FRAME: DEOXYURIDINE| and |FRAME: DEOXYCYTIDINE| |CITS: [22897443]|.

Most eubacteria also employ this salvage pathway. However, some organisms, including |FRAME: TAX-562| and |FRAME: TAX-90370|, lack the enzyme that phosphorylates deoxycytidine |CITS: [EcoSal]|. The yeast |FRAME: TAX-4932| does not have any deoxyribonucleoside kinases, and thus does not possess this pathway.

In addition to these two kinases, the pathway also shows how |FRAME: DEOXYCYTIDINE| can be salvaged for the synthesis of deoxythymidine nucleotides. This is enabled by deamination to |FRAME: DEOXYURIDINE|, followed by phosphorylation by thymidine kinase to form dUMP. The latter can be converted directly to dTMP by the action of |FRAME: EC-2.1.1.45 \"thymidylate synthase (EC 2.1.1.45)\"|."	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7200"			"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Pyrimidine-Nucleotide-Salvage"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7210" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7197" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7196" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7193" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7205" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7194" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6556" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7208" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7199" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7195" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7183" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7200"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PYR-NUC-SYN"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Nucleotide-Biosynthesis"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY0-166"	"superpathway of pyrimidine deoxyribonucleotides <i>de novo</i> biosynthesis (E. coli)"	"PWY0-166"	"<b>General Background</b>

Pyrimidine and purine nucleoside triphosphates are the activated precursors of DNA and RNA.  Their diphosphates
form activated derivatives of other molecules, such as |FRAME: CPD-12575|, for use in biosynthesis.  The
pathway for <i>de novo</i> biosynthesis of pyrimidine deoxyribonucleotides is derived from the pathway for
|FRAME: PWY0-162| as shown above in the pathway links.  In addition to <i>de novo</i> biosynthesis, salvage
pathways re-utilize exogenous free bases and nucleosides and some of the resulting pyrimidine nucleotides can
enter the <i>de novo</i> biosynthesis pathways (see |FRAME: PWY-7193|, |FRAME: PWY-7183| and |FRAME: PWY-7199|). These essential, evolutionarily conserved biosynthetic and salvage pathways are found in both prokaryotes and eukaryotes.

The pyrimidine nucleoside triphosphate products of these pathways are incorporated into DNA (|FRAME: DCTP| and
|FRAME: TTP|) and RNA (|FRAME: CTP| and |FRAME: UTP|).  The <i>de novo</i> biosynthetic pathways are
necessary in order to supply the cell with nucleoside triphosphates for stable RNA and DNA synthesis when
precursors are limiting.  These biosynthetic pathways consume relatively large amounts of high energy phosphate
and reducing power.  In |FRAME:TAX-562| they are regulated both by allosteric enzymes and at the gene
expression level in order to conserve resources under different growth conditions.

The pyrimidine nucleotide <i>de novo</i> biosynthetic pathways derive in part from the central metabolic
precursors |FRAME: OXALACETIC_ACID| and |FRAME: RIBOSE-5P|.  Oxaloacetate from the |FRAME: TCA|
gives rise to the aspartate family of amino acids and |FRAME: L-ASPARTATE| is a precursor of both pyrimidine
ribonucleotides and nicotinamide coenzymes (see |FRAME: ASPARTATESYN-PWY|).  The overall pathway begins
with the biosynthesis of |FRAME: CARBAMOYL-P| from bicarbonate, phosphate from ATP and nitrogen from
glutamine.  This compound then condenses with |FRAME: L-ASPARTATE| to
form |FRAME: CARBAMYUL-L-ASPARTATE| as shown in pathways |FRAME: PWY0-162| and |FRAME: PWY-5686|. 
The overall pathway branches at |FRAME: CARBAMOYL-P|, which is an intermediate in |FRAME: ARG|
biosynthesis (see |FRAME: ARGSYN-PWY|).  The activated intermediate |FRAME: PRPP| is derived from
|FRAME: RIBOSE-5P| and is a precursor in the <i>de novo</i> and salvage pathways for pyrimidine and purine
nucleotides, as well as in biosynthetic pathways for nucleotide coenzymes, |FRAME: HIS| and |FRAME: TRP|
(see |FRAME: PRPP-PWY|, and |FRAME: PWY0-662|).

<b>About This Pathway</b>

The pathway shown here illustrates the point at which the pyrimidine ribonucleotides |FRAME: CDP|, |FRAME: CTP|,
|FRAME: UDP| and |FRAME: UTP| are converted to their corresponding deoxyribonucleotides and the
DNA-specific thymine deoxyribonucleoside triphosphate |FRAME: TTP| is formed.  Deoxyribonucleotides are
synthesized by reduction of ribonucleotides, which is regulated by the rate-limiting enzyme ribonucleotide reductase
that carries out reduction at the C2' position.  This enzyme has a central role in DNA replication and repair. 
In |FRAME:TAX-562| this ribo- to deoxyribo- conversion is catalyzed by aerobic ribonucleoside diphosphate reductase, or
anaerobic ribonucleoside triphosphate reductase.  Electrons for these reductions are derived
from |FRAME: NADPH| and are transferred via |FRAME: Red-Thioredoxin|, |FRAME: Red-Glutaredoxins|,
or |FRAME: Reduced-flavodoxins|.

The ribonucleotide reductase product of genes |FRAME: EG10660| and |FRAME: EG10661| functions aerobically
and under microaerophilic conditions.  A normally cryptic enzyme encoded by genes |FRAME: EG20257|
and |FRAME: EG12381| cannot support aerobic, or microaerophilic growth in a <i>nrdAB</i> deletion mutant. 
However, it supports aerobic growth in such a mutant when genes <i>nrdHIEF</i> are overexpressed on a
plasmid |CITS: [16771665]|.  It has been speculated that this additional aerobic enzyme may enhance
ribonucleotide reductase activity under conditions of oxidative stress.  The anaerobic enzyme is encoded by
gene |FRAME: EG11417| which functions in a multienzyme complex with the products of genes |FRAME: G812|
and |FRAME: EG10628|.  Pathways for the reduction of these reductase enzymes have also been studied
|CITS: [16771665]|.

The major pathway for the aerobic, <i>de novo</i> formation of the intermediate |FRAME: DUMP|, the immediate
precursor of thymine-containing nucleotides, is via phosphorylation of |FRAME: DCDP|
to |FRAME: DCTP| and deamination of |FRAME: DCTP| to |FRAME: DUTP| which is hydrolyzed to |FRAME: DUMP|. 
This pathway supplies 70-80% of total |FRAME: DUMP| |CITS: [17651436]|.  Most of the remainder is presumed to
be formed from |FRAME: DUDP|, as shown.  In |FRAME:TAX-562| |FRAME: EG11418|, |FRAME: EG10219| mutants, an
alternate <i>de novo</i> deoxycytidine pathway to |FRAME: DUMP| is used that relies on salvage enzymes
|CITS: [17827303]|.  Formation of the DNA-specific end product |FRAME: TTP| requires reductive methylation of
|FRAME: DUMP| to |FRAME: TMP| by |FRAME: METHYLENE-THF| catalyzed by
|FRAME: THYMIDYLATESYN-CPLX|.  Two phosphorylations follow to form |FRAME: TTP|.  The first step is
catalyzed by the highly specific |FRAME: DTMPKI-MONOMER|, while the second step is catalyzed by the product
of gene |FRAME: EG10650| which also catalyzes two preceding reactions.

Review:  Neuhard J. and R.A. Kelln, Biosynthesis and Conversions of Pyrimidines, Chapter 35 in |CITS: [COLISALII]|"		"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7184" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY66-5"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Deoxyribonucleotide-Biosynthesis" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PYR-NUC-SYN" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=NIL&object=Generalized-Reactions"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7187"	"pyrimidine deoxyribonucleotides <i>de novo</i> biosynthesis II"	"PWY-7187"	"<b>General Background</b>

Pyrimidine and purine nucleoside triphosphates are the activated precursors of DNA and RNA. The pyrimidine deoxyribonucleoside triphosphates |FRAME: DCTP| and |FRAME: TTP| are incorporated into DNA while the ribonucleoside triphosphates |FRAME: CTP| and |FRAME: UTP| are incorporated into RNA. In addition, their diphosphates form activated derivatives of other molecules, such as |FRAME: CPD-12575|, |FRAME: CMP-KDO| and |FRAME: DTDP-D-FUCOSE|, for use in biosynthesis of polysaccharides, glycoproteins and phospholipids |CITS: [9576794][12369616][16024685][16669783]|.

In addition to <i>de novo</i> biosynthesis, salvage pathways reutilize exogenous free bases and nucleosides and some of the resulting pyrimidine nucleotides can enter the <i>de novo</i> biosynthesis pathways (see |FRAME: PWY-7193|, |FRAME: PWY-7183| and |FRAME: PWY-7199|). The <i>de novo</i> biosynthetic pathways consume relatively large amounts of high energy phosphate and reducing power, and thus organisms prefer to use salvage pathways when possible. However, the <i>de novo</i> biosynthetic pathways are necessary when exogenous precursors are limiting. In order to conserve resources, the <i>de novo</i> pathways are regulated both by allosteric enzymes and at the gene expression level.
These essential, evolutionarily conserved biosynthetic and salvage pathways are found in both prokaryotes and eukaryotes.

The pyrimidine nucleotide <i>de novo</i> biosynthetic pathway derives in part from the central metabolic precursors |FRAME: OXALACETIC_ACID| and |FRAME: RIBOSE-5P|. |FRAME: L-ASPARTATE|, a precursor of pyrimidine ribonucleotides, is derived from oxaloacetate, which is generated in the |FRAME: TCA \"TCA cycle\"|.

<b>About This Pathway</b>

The pathway shown here illustrates a route in which the pyrimidine ribonucleotides |FRAME: CTP| and |FRAME: UTP| are converted to the deoxyribonucleotides |FRAME: DCTP| and |FRAME: DUTP|, which are subsequently modified to other deoxyribonucleotides, including the thymine deoxyribonucleoside triphosphate |FRAME: TTP|. 
While most organisms utilize a different route (see |FRAME: PWY-7184|), this pathway is found in bacteria that possess two specialized enzymes - |FRAME: EC-1.17.4.2 \"ribonucleoside-triphosphate reductase (EC 1.17.4.2)\"|, an enzyme that can reduce nucleoside triphosphates to their respective deoxynucleoside triphosphates (most organism posses |FRAME: EC-1.17.4.1 \"EC 1.17.4.1\"|, which can only accept nucleoside diphosphates), and |FRAME: EC-3.5.4.13 \"dCTP deaminase (EC 3.5.4.13)\"|, an enzyme that can deaminate |FRAME: DCTP| to |FRAME: DUMP|.

In this pathway the deoxyribonucleotide |FRAME: DUTP| is formed in two ways - by the direct reduction of |FRAME: UTP|, and by the deamination of |FRAME: DCTP|, which is formed from |FRAME: CTP| either directly by |FRAME: RIBONUCLEOSIDE-TRIP-REDUCT-CPLX|, or in two steps, as described in |FRAME: PWY-7184|.
Once formed, |FRAME: DUTP| is dephosphorylated to |FRAME: DUMP|. Deamination of |FRAME: DCTP| is the major route for <i>de novo</i> formation of |FRAME: DUMP| in aerobically-growing |FRAME:TAX-562|. It supplies 70-80% of total |FRAME: DUMP| |CITS: [17651436]|.

Formation of the DNA-specific end product |FRAME: TTP| requires reductive methylation of |FRAME: DUMP| to |FRAME: TMP| by |FRAME: METHYLENE-THF| catalyzed by |FRAME: THYMIDYLATESYN-CPLX| (EC 2.1.1.45).
The enzyme only accepts the mono-phosphorylated form |FRAME: DUMP|. Thus, the first deoxyuridine nucleotide that is formed in this route, , |FRAME: DUTP|, needs to be converted to the monophosphate form by the removal of a diphosphate group, resulting in |FRAME: DUMP|.

Once |FRAME: TMP| is formed, two phosphorylations follow to form |FRAME: TTP|.  The first step is catalyzed by the highly specific |FRAME: DTMPKI-MONOMER|, while the second step is catalyzed by the broad substrate range enzyme |FRAME: NUCLEOSIDE-DIP-KIN-CPLX|."	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY0-166"			"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Pyrimid-Deoxyribonucleot-De-Novo-Biosyn"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6545" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7211" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7184" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY0-166" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7187" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7198"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Deoxyribonucleotide-Biosynthesis" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Pyrimidine-De-Novo-Biosyn"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Nucleotide-Biosynthesis" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PYR-NUC-SYN"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7211"	"superpathway of pyrimidine deoxyribonucleotides <i>de novo</i> biosynthesis"	"PWY-7211"	"<b>General Background</b>

Pyrimidine and purine nucleoside triphosphates are the activated precursors of DNA and RNA. The pyrimidine deoxyribonucleoside triphosphate |FRAME: DCTP| and |FRAME: TTP| are incorporated into DNA while the ribonucleoside triphosphates |FRAME: CTP| and |FRAME: UTP| are incorporated into RNA. In addition, their diphosphates form activated derivatives of other molecules, such as |FRAME: CPD-12575|, |FRAME: CMP-KDO| and |FRAME: DTDP-D-FUCOSE|, for use in biosynthesis of polysaccharides, glycoproteins and phospholipids |CITS: [9576794][12369616][16024685][16669783]|.

In addition to <i>de novo</i> biosynthesis, salvage pathways reutilize exogenous free bases and nucleosides and some of the resulting pyrimidine nucleotides can enter the <i>de novo</i> biosynthesis pathways (see |FRAME: PWY-7193|, |FRAME: PWY-7183| and |FRAME: PWY-7199|). The <i>de novo</i> biosynthetic pathways consume relatively large amounts of high energy phosphate and reducing power, and thus organisms prefer to use salvage pathways when possible. However, the <i>de novo</i> biosynthetic pathways are necessary when exogenous precursors are limiting. In order to conserve resources, the <i>de novo</i> pathways are regulated both by allosteric enzymes and at the gene expression level.
These essential, evolutionarily conserved biosynthetic and salvage pathways are found in both prokaryotes and eukaryotes.

The pyrimidine nucleotide <i>de novo</i> biosynthetic pathway derives in part from the central metabolic precursors |FRAME: OXALACETIC_ACID| and |FRAME: RIBOSE-5P|. |FRAME: L-ASPARTATE|, a precursor of pyrimidine ribonucleotides, is derived from oxaloacetate, which is generated in the |FRAME: TCA \"TCA cycle\"|.

<b>About This Pathway</b>

This superpathway illustrates the universal <i>do novo</i> biosynthetic route for producing pyrimidine ribonucleotides (|FRAME: CDP| and |FRAME: UDP|), and the most common route in which these ribonucleotides are converted to the deoxyribonucleotides, including the DNA-specific thymine deoxyribonucleoside triphosphate |FRAME: TTP|. This pathway is universal, and is found in archaea, bacteria, fungi, plants and animals.

Deoxyribonucleotides are synthesized by reduction of ribonucleotides at the C2' position, which in this pathway is catalyzed by the rate-limiting enzyme |FRAME: EC-1.17.4.1 \"EC 1.17.4.1, ribonucleoside-diphosphate reductase\"|. Since this enzyme, which plays a central role in DNA replication and repair, can only perform the reduction of nucleoside-diphosphates, the conversion of the product of <i>de novo</i> biosynthesis, |FRAME: UMP|, to a deoxyuridine form requires phosphorylation to |FRAME: UDP| followed by reduction to |FRAME: DUDP|. Likewise, reduction of the first cytidine-nucleotide that is formed <i>de novo</i>, |FRAME: CTP|, to a deoxycytidine form requires dephosphorylation to |FRAME: CDP| followed by reduction to |FRAME: DCDP|.

Formation of the DNA-specific end product |FRAME: TTP| requires reductive methylation of |FRAME: DUMP| to |FRAME: TMP| by |FRAME: METHYLENE-THF| catalyzed by |FRAME: EC-2.1.1.45 \"thymidylate synthase\"| (EC 2.1.1.45).
The enzyme only accepts the mono-phosphorylated form |FRAME: DUMP|. Thus, the first deoxyuridine nucleotide that is formed, |FRAME: DUDP|, needs to be converted to the monophosphate form. This is done in two steps - phosphorylation to |FRAME: DUTP|, followed by the removal of a diphosphate group, resulting in |FRAME: DUMP|.

Once |FRAME: TMP| is formed, two phosphorylations follow to form |FRAME: TTP|. The first step is catalyzed by the highly specific |FRAME: HS11626-MONOMER|, while the second step is catalyzed by the broad substrate range enzyme |FRAME: CPLX66-1052|.

In organisms that contain the enzyme |FRAME: DCTP-DEAM-CPLX| (|FRAME: EC-3.5.4.13 EC 3.5.4.13\"|), a second route forms |FRAME: DUMP| from |FRAME: DCDP|. |FRAME: DCDP| is phosphorylated to |FRAME: DCTP|, followed by deamination to |FRAME: DUTP| and hydrolysis to |FRAME: DUMP| (see |FRAME: PWY-7187|)." "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PYR-NUC-SYN" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=NIL&object=Generalized-Reactions"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7229"	"superpathway of adenosine nucleotides <i>de novo</i> biosynthesis I"	"PWY-7229"	"The first purine nucleotide that is synthesized <i>de novo</i> is |FRAME: IMP| (IMP). IMP is converted to |FRAME: ADENYLOSUCC| by the enzyme |FRAME: ADENYLOSUCCINATE-SYN-DIMER|, and the latter is converted to the first adenosine nucleotide, |FRAME: AMP| (AMP), by the action of |FRAME:AMPSYN-ENZRXN|.

AMP is phosphorylated to ADP and subsequently to ATP. While the first phosphorylation is catalyzed by the dedicated enzyme |FRAME: ADENYL-KIN-MONOMER|, reactions that convert ADP to ATP are numerous and found in multiple pathways,  including fueling pathways such as anaerobic respiration, TCA-aerobic respiration, fermentation, and glycolysis. However, a major source for this conversion is the |FRAME: CPLX490-3510 ATP synthase| complex, which is membrane bound and utilizes the proton gradient across membranes to phosphorylate ADP. This is the reaction depicted in this pathway.

ADP can also be converted to the deoxy form |FRAME: DADP| (dADP) by the enzyme nucleoside diphosphate reductase. Once formed, dADP can be phosphorylated into the DNA building block |FRAME: DATP dATP| by the broad substrate range enzyme |FRAME: NUCLEOSIDE-DIP-KIN-CPLX|.

In bacterial systems genetic studies indicate that the majority of <i>de novo</i> purine biosynthetic genes are unlinked but may act as a single unit of regulation controlled by the `purR' repressor protein |CITS:[2404765]|." "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6126"	"superpathway of adenosine nucleotides <i>de novo</i> biosynthesis II"	"PWY-6126"	"The first purine nucleotide that is synthesized <i>de novo</i> is |FRAME: IMP IMP|. IMP is converted to |FRAME: ADENYLOSUCC| by the enzyme |FRAME: ADENYLOSUCCINATE-SYN-DIMER|, and the latter is converted to the first adenosine nucleotide, |FRAME: AMP| (AMP), by the action of |FRAME:AMPSYN-ENZRXN|.

AMP is phosphorylated to ADP and subsequently to ATP. While the first reaction is catalyzed by the dedicated enzyme
|FRAME: ADENYL-KIN-MONOMER|, reactions that convert ADP to ATP are numerous and found in multiple pathways,  including fueling pathways such as anaerobic respiration, TCA-aerobic respiration, fermentation, and glycolysis. However, a major source for this conversion is the |FRAME: CPLX490-3510 ATP synthase| complex, which is membrane bound and utilizes the proton gradient across membranes to phosphorylate ADP. This is the reaction depicted in this pathway.

ADP can also be converted to the deoxy form |FRAME: DADP dADP|. In |FRAME: TAX-562| this conversion is catalyzed by either |FRAME: RIBONUCLEOSIDE-DIP-REDUCTI-CPLX| or |FRAME: RIBONUCLEOSIDE-DIP-REDUCTII-CPLX|, which differ by the type of thioredoxin-like enzyme they utilize as the electron donor. dADP is further phosphorylated to the DNA building block |FRAME: DATP dATP| by the broad-substrate range enzyme |FRAME: NUCLEOSIDE-DIP-KIN-CPLX|.

A few organisms, including the bacterium |FRAME: TAX-562|, also possess the enzyme |FRAME: RIBONUCLEOSIDE-TRIP-REDUCT-CPLX|, which can reduce nucleotide triphosphates to their 2'-deoxy forms.

In bacterial systems genetic studies indicate that the majority of <i>de novo</i> purine biosynthetic genes are unlinked but may act as a single unit of regulation controlled by the `purR' repressor protein |CITS:[2404765]|." "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=NIL&object=Generalized-Reactions"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-841"	"superpathway of purine nucleotides <i>de novo</i> biosynthesis I"	"PWY-841"	"Purine nucleotides participate in many aspects of cellular metabolism including the structure of DNA and RNA, serving as enzyme cofactors, functioning in cellular signaling, acting as phosphate group donors, and generating cellular energy.  Maintenance of the proper balance of intracellular pools of these nucleotides is critical to normal function.  This occurs through a combination of <i>de novo</i> biosynthesis and salvage pathways for pre-existing purine bases, nucleosides and nucleotides.

The <i>de novo</i> biosynthetic pathway for purine nucleotides is highly conserved among organisms, but its regulation and the organization of the genes encoding the enzymes vary. This fourteen step pathway contains ten steps that branch at |FRAME: IMP| to form |FRAME: AMP| and |FRAME: GMP|, each in two steps. Regulation of the pathway has been well studied in microbes such as <i>|FRAME:TAX-562|, |FRAME:TAX-1423|</i> and |FRAME:TAX-4932|, but little is known about its regulation in higher eukaryotes (metazoa and plants |CITS: [8938402]|). The pathway appears to vary in archaea |CITS: [9150241]|. Some organisms, such as the mycoplasmas, do not biosynthesize purine and pyrimidine bases <i>de novo</i> and must rely on salvage pathways |CITS: [11737647]|.   

In |FRAME: TAX-4932| regulation of the pathway occurs at both the enzyme level as shown in this pathway, and at the genetic level. For example, at the genetic level positive-acting regulatory proteins Bas1 and Pho2 and biosynthetic intermediates |FRAME: P-RIBOSYL-4-SUCCCARB-AMINOIMIDAZOLE| and/or |FRAME: AICAR| are required to derepress <i>ADE</i> gene expression. Reviewed in |CITS: [17052198]| and |CITS: [1574589]|." "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY66-5"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PUR-NUC-SYN" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=NIL&object=Generalized-Reactions"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6125"	"superpathway of guanosine nucleotides <i>de novo</i> biosynthesis II"	"PWY-6125"	"The first purine nucleotide that is synthesized <i>de novo</i> is |FRAME: IMP| (IMP).
IMP is converted to |FRAME: XANTHOSINE-5-PHOSPHATE| (XMP) by the enzyme |FRAME: IMP-DEHYDROG-CPLX|,
and the later is converted to the first guanosine nucleotide, |FRAME: GMP| (GMP), by the action of
|FRAME: GMP-SYN-CPLX|, an enzyme that can use either glutamine or ammonia as substrate.
GMP is then converted to |FRAME: GDP| (GDP) and subsequently to |FRAME: GTP| (GTP) by the enzymes
|FRAME: GUANYL-KIN-CPLX| and |FRAME: NUCLEOSIDE-DIP-KIN-CPLX|, respectively.

In |FRAME:TAX-562| both GDP and GTP can be converted to the deoxy forms of the nucleotide. GTP is converted to |FRAME: DGTP|
(dGTP) by the uncommon enzyme |FRAME: RIBONUCLEOSIDE-TRIP-REDUCT-CPLX|, while GDP can be converted to |FRAME: DGDP| (dGDP) by either |FRAME: RIBONUCLEOSIDE-DIP-REDUCTI-CPLX| or |FRAME: RIBONUCLEOSIDE-DIP-REDUCTII-CPLX|.

Finally, |FRAME: NUCLEOSIDE-DIP-KIN-CPLX| can also convert dGDP to dGTP.

In bacterial systems genetic studies indicate that the majority of <i>de novo</i> purine biosynthetic genes are unlinked but may act as a single unit of regulation controlled by the `purR' repressor protein |CITS: [2404765]|."	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=DENOVOPURINE2-PWY"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7222" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY66-5"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PUR-NUC-SYN" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=NIL&object=Generalized-Reactions"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7228"	"superpathway of guanosine nucleotides <i>de novo</i> biosynthesis I"	"PWY-7228"	"The first purine nucleotide that is synthesized <i>de novo</i> is |FRAME: IMP IMP| (see |FRAME:PWY-6123|).
IMP is converted to |FRAME: XANTHOSINE-5-PHOSPHATE XMP| by the enzyme |FRAME: IMP-DEHYDROG-CPLX|,
and the latter is converted to the first guanosine nucleotide, |FRAME: GMP GMP|, by the action of
|FRAME: GMP-SYN-CPLX|, an enzyme that can use either glutamine or ammonia as the nitrogen donor.

GMP is phosphorylated to |FRAME: GDP GDP| and subsequently to |FRAME: GTP GTP| by the enzymes
|FRAME: GUANYL-KIN-CPLX| and |FRAME: NUCLEOSIDE-DIP-KIN-CPLX|, respectively.

GDP can be converted to the deoxy form |FRAME: DGDP dGDP| by the enzyme ribonucleoside diphosphate reductase.
Once formed, dGDP can be phosphorylated to the DNA building block |FRAME: DGTP dGTP| by the enzyme |FRAME: NUCLEOSIDE-DIP-KIN-CPLX|.

In bacterial systems genetic studies indicate that the majority of <i>de novo</i> purine biosynthetic genes are unlinked but may act as a single unit of regulation controlled by the `purR' repressor protein |CITS: [2404765]|."		"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7226" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY66-5"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PUR-NUC-SYN" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Pathways"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Nucleotide-Biosynthesis" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=NIL&object=Generalized-Reactions"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=DENOVOPURINE2-PWY"	"superpathway of purine nucleotides <i>de novo</i> biosynthesis II"	"DENOVOPURINE2-PWY"	"Purine nucleotides participate in many aspects of cellular metabolism including the structure of DNA and RNA, serving as enzyme cofactors, functioning in cellular signaling, acting as phosphate group donors, and generating cellular energy.  Maintenance of the proper balance of intracellular pools of these nucleotides is critical to normal function.  This occurs through a combination of <i>de novo</i> biosynthesis and salvage pathways for pre-existing purine bases, nucleosides and nucleotides.

The <i>de novo</i> biosynthetic pathway for purine nucleotides is highly conserved among organisms, but its regulation and the organization of the genes encoding the enzymes vary.  This fourteen step pathway contains ten steps that branch at |FRAME: IMP| to form |FRAME: AMP| and |FRAME: GMP|, each in two steps. Regulation of the pathway has been well studied in microbes such as <i>|FRAME:TAX-562|, |FRAME:TAX-1423|</i> and |FRAME:TAX-4932|, but little is known about its regulation in higher eukaryotes (metazoa, and plants |CITS: [8938402]|). The pathway appears to vary in archaea |CITS: [9150241]|. Some organisms, such as the mycoplasmas, do not biosynthesize purine and pyrimidine bases <i>de novo</i> and must rely on salvage pathways |CITS: [11737647]|.

In bacterial systems genetic studies indicate that the majority of <i>de novo</i> purine biosynthetic genes are unlinked but may act as a single unit of regulation controlled by the |FRAME: PC00033| protein. In |FRAME:TAX-562| the 14 reactions involved in the <i>de novo</i> synthesis of AMP and GMP are catalyzed by 12 known genes. These genes occur mostly as unlinked single units or as small functional operons carrying two or, at the most, three structural genes each. The |FRAME: EG10800| gene encodes the repressor controlling the synthesis of all of these enzymes. Sequences similar to the protected region (PUR box) in purF are present in the regulatory regions of purMN. The expression of |FRAME: EG10800| was shown to be autoregulated, probably through blocking of transcription elongation by binding of PurR to the two PUR boxes. So far, six genes/operons have been reported to contain PUR box-like sequences.
The purine biosynthetic pathway is controlled by feedback regulation of activity as well as at the level of transcription
|CITS:[2404765]|.

Reactions that convert ADP to ATP are found in multiple pathways, including fueling pathways such as anaerobic respiration, TCA-aerobic respiration, fermentation, and glycolysis, and are thus not included in this pathway." "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6121"	"5-aminoimidazole ribonucleotide biosynthesis I"	"PWY-6121"	"|FRAME: 5-PHOSPHORIBOSYL-5-AMINOIMIDAZOLE| (AIR) is a key intermediate in the biosynthesis of purine nocleotides and |FRAME: THIAMINE|.
It is synthesized from |FRAME: PRPP| (PRPP) in 5 steps, catalyzed by the enzymes
|FRAME: PRPPAMIDOTRANS-CPLX|, |FRAME: GLYCRIBONUCSYN-MONOMER|, |FRAME: YDR408C-MONOMER|,
|FRAME: FGAMSYN-MONOMER| and |FRAME: AIRS-CPLX|.

The pathway is highly conserved among organisms, but its regulation and the organization of the genes encoding
the enzymes vary. Regulation of the pathway has been well studied in microbes such as |FRAME: TAX-562|,
|FRAME:TAX-1423| and |FRAME:TAX-4932|, but little is known about its regulation in higher eukaryotes |CITS: [8938402]|.

Some organisms, such as the mycoplasmas, do not biosynthesize purine and pyrimidine bases <i>de novo</i> and must rely on salvage pathways |CITS: [11737647]|."	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-841" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6277"			"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=AIR-Biosynthesis"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6121" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6122" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6277"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PUR-NUC-SYN"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Nucleotide-Biosynthesis"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6277"	"superpathway of 5-aminoimidazole ribonucleotide biosynthesis"	"PWY-6277"	"|FRAME: 5-PHOSPHORIBOSYL-5-AMINOIMIDAZOLE| (AIR) is a key intermediate in the biosynthesis of
purine nocleotides and thiamine.
It is synthesized from |FRAME: PRPP| (PRPP) in 5 steps, catalyzed by the enzymes
|FRAME: PRPPAMIDOTRANS-CPLX|, |FRAME: GLYCRIBONUCSYN-MONOMER|, |FRAME:GART-ENZRXN|, |FRAME: FGAMSYN-MONOMER| and |FRAME: AIRS-CPLX|.

In most organisms the third step is catalyzed by a folate-dependent |FRAME:GART-ENZRXN|.
However, |FRAME:TAX-562| the has two enzymes that catalyze this step - a folate-dependent |FRAME: GART-MONOMER| that utilizes |FRAME: 10-FORMYL-THF|, as well as a  |FRAME: FORMATE|-utilizing |FRAME: GARTRANSFORMYL2-MONOMER|.  These two enzymes share little homology." "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY66-5"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PUR-NUC-SYN" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Pathways"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Nucleotide-Biosynthesis" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=NIL&object=Generalized-Reactions"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6122"	"5-aminoimidazole ribonucleotide biosynthesis II"	"PWY-6122"	"|FRAME: 5-PHOSPHORIBOSYL-5-AMINOIMIDAZOLE \"5-Amino-1-(5-phospho-&beta;-D-ribosyl)imidazole\"| (AIR) is a key intermediate in the biosynthesis of purine nocleotides and |FRAME: THIAMINE|. It is synthesized from |FRAME: PRPP| (PRPP) in 5 steps, which are catalyzed in most organisms by the enzymes
|FRAME: PRPPAMIDOTRANS-CPLX|, |FRAME: GLYCRIBONUCSYN-MONOMER|, |FRAME: GART-MONOMER|,
|FRAME: FGAMSYN-MONOMER| and |FRAME: AIRS-CPLX|, as described in |FRAME: PWY-6121|.

In this variant of the pathway, found in |FRAME: TAX-562|, the third step is catalyzed by a different enzyme - |FRAME: GARTRANSFORMYL2-MONOMER|. Unlike |FRAME: GART-MONOMER|, which utilizes |FRAME: 10-FORMYL-THF| as the formyl donor, |FRAME: GARTRANSFORMYL2-MONOMER| utilizes |FRAME: FORMATE|. The two enzymes share little homology.

|FRAME: TAX-562| does have |FRAME: GART-MONOMER| as well, and both enzymes are used, as can be seen in |FRAME: PWY-6277|.

"HTTPS://biocyc.org/gene?orgid=META&id=G7553"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=GENE&object=BC-1"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=GENE&object=MultiFun"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6151"	"<i>S</i>-adenosyl-L-methionine cycle I"	"PWY-6151"	"About 20% of the |FRAME: MET| pool is used as a building block of proteins. The rest is converted to
|FRAME:S-ADENOSYLMETHIONINE| (SAM), the major methyl donor in the cell.
When SAM donates its methyl group, it is converted to |FRAME: ADENOSYL-HOMO-CYS|. This molecule can be
recycled back to SAM via the <i>S</i>-adenosyl-L-methionine cycle, also known as the activated methyl cycle (AMC).

There are two main variations of this pathway, one found mostly in prokaryotes, while the other is found predominantly, but not exclusively, in eukaryotes. The main difference between the variants is the processing of |FRAME: ADENOSYL-HOMO-CYS| (SAH), the immediate product of the methylation reactions.

In the first pathway (described in |FRAME: PWY-6151|) SAH is first hydrolyzed to |FRAME: CPD-564| by the |FRAME: MONOMER-1290|, followed by conversion to |FRAME: HOMO-CYS| by |FRAME: CPLX-7753|. 
In the second pathway, which is described in |FRAME: PWY-5041|, SAH is hydrolyzed to |FRAME: HOMO-CYS| in a single step, catalyzed by |FRAME: CPLX-5161|.

The cycle continues with the methylation of |FRAME: HOMO-CYS| to |FRAME: MET| using a methyl group from a methylated folate. In some organisms, including |FRAME: TAX-9606|, this reaction is catalyzed by a
|FRAME: HOMOCYSMETB12-MONOMER| (EC 2.1.1.13). In other organisms, such as |FRAME: TAX-1423|,
the reaction is catalyzed by a |FRAME: G18NG-10711-MONOMER| (EC 2.1.1.14). Yet some organisms,
such as |FRAME: TAX-562| and |FRAME: TAX-1718|, have both enzymes, as described in the pathway
|FRAME: HSERMETANA-PWY|. In |FRAME: TAX-562| the reaction catalyzed by the B12-dependent enzyme is more
than 100-fold faster than the reaction catalyzed by the B12-independent isoenzyme |CITS: [15215334]|.

Finally, the cycle is completed with the regeneration of SAM by |FRAME: CPLX-7754|." "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Pathways"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=METHIONINE-SYN" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=NIL&object=Generalized-Reactions"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=SO4ASSIM-PWY"	"assimilatory sulfate reduction I"	"SO4ASSIM-PWY"	"<b>General Background</b>

Sulfur is an essential nutrient for all life forms. Plants, fungi, and many bacteria reduce inorganic sulfate to sulfide to cover their need for the element. Before the sulfur can be assimilated into biosynthetic pathways it needs to be reduced to |FRAME:HS|. Pathways catalyzing the reduction of sulfate to sulfide for the purpose of incorporation into newly synthesized molecules are called pathways of assimilatory sulfate reduction.
In addition, certain organisms can use sulfate as an alternative electron acceptor in the absence of oxygen. Pathways of sulfate reduction for the purpose of energy production are called pathways of dissimilatory sulfate reduction.

The reduction of sulfate to sulfite requires two electrons at a standard redox potential (<i>E<sub>0</sub>'</i>) of -516 mV, which is too high for physiological electron carriers |CITS: [860983]|. The problem is solved by the activation of the sulfate, by forming a mixed anhydride between phosphate and sulfate as in |FRAME:APS| (APS) or |FRAME:PAPS| (PAPS). This linkage lowers the potential to <i>E<sub>0</sub>'</i> = -60 mV, which is easilly covered by thiols or pyrimidine nucleotides |CITS: [14627706]|.

<b>About This Pathway</b>

In many bacteria and lower eukaryotes, assimilatory sulfate reduction proceeds via activation of |FRAME: SULFATE| to APS by the enzyme |FRAME: EC-2.7.7.4| (also known as ATP sulfurylase). This enzyme has an unfavorable equilibrium (Keq ~ 10<sup>-7</sup> M) in the direction of APS formation, and it has been postulated that the reaction is driven by the hydrolysis of PPi by a ubiquitous inorganic pyrophosphatase |CITS: [2821345]|. In |FRAME: TAX-83333| it was found that the enzymes couples the formation of APS to hydrolysis of GTP |CITS: [8117661]|.

Following sulfate activation, the pathway consists of phosphorylation of APS to PAPS, which is catalyzed by |FRAME: EC-2.7.1.25| (APS kinase), reduction to |FRAME: SO3|, which is catalyzed by the thioredoxin (or glutaredoxin)-dependent |FRAME: EC-1.8.4.8| (PAPS reductase), and a final reduction of sulfite to sulfide, catalyzed by |FRAME: EC-1.8.1.2|." "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY66-5"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Sulfur-Metabolism" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=NONMEVIPP-PWY"	"methylerythritol phosphate pathway I"	"NONMEVIPP-PWY"	"<b>General Background</b>

The biosynthesis of |FRAME: DELTA3-ISOPENTENYL-PP| (IPP) can occur via two distinct routes: the |FRAME: PWY-922 \"mevalonate pathway\"| (MVA pathway) and the |FRAME:NONMEVIPP-PWY \"methylerythritol phosphate pathway\"| (MEP pathway, this pathway) |CITS: [11078528]|. In the former, IPP is synthesized from the condensation of  three acetyl-CoA molecules; in the MEP pathway IPP is synthesized via the condensation of |FRAME: PYRUVATE| and |FRAME: GAP|.

For many years, the MVA pathway was considered to be the sole source of IPP in all living organisms. However, several inconsistencies led to the discovery of the MEP pathway in bacteria and plants.
In plants the MVA pathway is located in the cytosol whilst the MEP pathway is found in plastids |CITS:[LICHTENTHALER97]|. The MEP pathway is present in most eubacteria, unicellular green algae, the chloroplasts of phototrophic organisms and some unicellular eukaryotes related to photosynthetic phyla, such as the Plasmodium parasites |CITS: [15473867]|.

<b>About This Pathway</b>

|FRAME: DELTA3-ISOPENTENYL-PP \"Isopentenyl diphosphate\"| (IPP) and its isomer |FRAME: CPD-4211| (DMAPP) are the fundamental units in isoprenoid biosynthesis. Both are produced from |FRAME: GAP| and |FRAME: PYRUVATE| via this pathway.

D-glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate and pyruvate are initially combined to yield |FRAME: DEOXYXYLULOSE-5P| (DOXP). DOXP is then rearranged and reduced to generate the pathway's namesake compound, |FRAME: 2-C-METHYL-D-ERYTHRITOL-4-PHOSPHATE| (MEP). 
Interestingly, two rather different enzymes, that share no sequence homology, are able to catalyze this reaction - the |FRAME: DXPREDISOM-CPLX \"DXR\"| enzymes, and the |FRAME:MONOMER-15827 \"DRL\"| (DXR-like) enzymes |CITS: [20660776]|.

In the third reaction MEP is converted into |FRAME: 4-CYTIDINE-5-DIPHOSPHO-2-C|, which is subsequently phosphorylated at the 2 position hydroxy group, yielding
|FRAME: 2-PHOSPHO-4-CYTIDINE-5-DIPHOSPHO-2-C-MET|. This product is then converted into
|FRAME: 2C-METH-D-ERYTHRITOL-CYCLODIPHOSPHATE|. Subsequently, it is reduced to generate |FRAME: HYDROXY-METHYL-BUTENYL-DIP| |CITS: [12198182]|.

This diphosphate compound is converted by a single enzyme into a 5-6:1 ratio of IPP and DMAPP in the final step. In |FRAME: TAX-562| this ratio is subsequently adjusted to 3:7 by |FRAME: IPPISOM-MONOMER|. IPP and DMAPP serve as the basic building blocks of polyisoprenoid biosynthesis.  

The difference between this pathway variant and the variant described in |FRAME: PWY-7560| is the conversion of |FRAME: HYDROXY-METHYL-BUTENYL-DIP| to |FRAME: 2C-METH-D-ERYTHRITOL-CYCLODIPHOSPHATE|. In this variant, that enzyme utilizes flavodoxin as the electron donor (|FRAME: EC-1.17.7.3|), while in the other variant the enzyme utilizes ferredoxin (|FRAME: EC-1.17.7.1|).

This pathway, which is not present in humans, is involved in production of phosphate-containing antigens recognized by &gamma;-&delta; T lymphocytes |CITS: [11675382]|."	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7156" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7392" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6270" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5121"		"nonmevalonate isopentenyl diphosphate biosynthesis" // "methylerythritol phosphate degradation" // "MEP degradation" // "deoxyxylulose phosphate pathway" // "DOXP pathway" // "Rohmer pathway" // "isopentenyl diphosphate biosynthesis -- mevalonate-independent" // "nonmevalonate isoprenoid pathway" // "MEP pathway"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=MEP-Pathways"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=NONMEVIPP-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7560"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Isopentenyl-Diphosphate-Biosynthesis"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=ISOPRENOIDS"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7560"	"methylerythritol phosphate pathway II"	"PWY-7560"	"<b>General Background</b>

The biosynthesis of |FRAME: DELTA3-ISOPENTENYL-PP| (IPP) can occur via two distinct routes: the |FRAME: PWY-922 \"mevalonate pathway\"| (MVA pathway) and the |FRAME:PWY-7560 \"methylerythritol phosphate pathway\"| (MEP pathway, this pathway) |CITS: [11078528]|. In the former, IPP is synthesized from the condensation of  three acetyl-CoA molecules; in the MEP pathway IPP is synthesized via the condensation of |FRAME: PYRUVATE| and |FRAME: GAP|.

For many years, the MVA pathway was considered to be the sole source of IPP in all living organisms. However, several inconsistencies led to the discovery of the MEP pathway in bacteria and plants.
In plants the MVA pathway is located in the cytosol whilst the MEP pathway is found in plastids |CITS:[LICHTENTHALER97]|. The MEP pathway is present in most eubacteria, unicellular green algae, the chloroplasts of phototrophic organisms and some unicellular eukaryotes related to photosynthetic phyla, such as the Plasmodium parasites |CITS: [15473867]|.

<b>About This Pathway</b>

|FRAME: DELTA3-ISOPENTENYL-PP \"Isopentenyl diphosphate\"| (IPP) and its isomer |FRAME: CPD-4211| (DMAPP) are the fundamental units in isoprenoid biosynthesis. Both are produced from |FRAME: GAP| and |FRAME: PYRUVATE| via this pathway.

D-glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate and pyruvate are initially combined to yield |FRAME: DEOXYXYLULOSE-5P| (DOXP). DOXP is then rearranged and reduced to generate the pathway's namesake compound, |FRAME: 2-C-METHYL-D-ERYTHRITOL-4-PHOSPHATE| (MEP). 
Interestingly, two rather different enzymes, that share no sequence homology, are able to catalyze this reaction - the |FRAME: DXPREDISOM-CPLX \"DXR\"| enzymes, and the |FRAME:MONOMER-15827 \"DRL\"| (DXR-like) enzymes |CITS: [20660776]|.

In the third reaction MEP is converted into |FRAME: 4-CYTIDINE-5-DIPHOSPHO-2-C|, which is subsequently phosphorylated at the 2 position hydroxy group, yielding
|FRAME: 2-PHOSPHO-4-CYTIDINE-5-DIPHOSPHO-2-C-MET|. This product is then converted into
|FRAME: 2C-METH-D-ERYTHRITOL-CYCLODIPHOSPHATE|. Subsequently, it is reduced to generate |FRAME: HYDROXY-METHYL-BUTENYL-DIP| |CITS: [12198182]|.

This diphosphate compound is converted by a single enzyme into a 5-6:1 ratio of IPP and DMAPP in the final step. In |FRAME: TAX-562| this ratio is subsequently adjusted to 3:7 by |FRAME: IPPISOM-MONOMER|. IPP and DMAPP serve as the basic building blocks of polyisoprenoid biosynthesis.  

The difference between this pathway variant and the bacterial variant described in |FRAME: NONMEVIPP-PWY| is the conversion of |FRAME: HYDROXY-METHYL-BUTENYL-DIP| to |FRAME: 2C-METH-D-ERYTHRITOL-CYCLODIPHOSPHATE|. In this variant, that enzyme utilizes ferredoxin as the electron donor (|FRAME: EC-1.17.7.1|), while in the other variant the enzyme utilizes flavodoxin (|FRAME: EC-1.17.7.3|).

This pathway, which is not present in humans, is involved in production of phosphate-containing antigens recognized by &gamma;-&delta; T lymphocytes |CITS: [11675382]|." "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7111"	"pyruvate fermentation to isobutanol (engineered)"	"PWY-7111"	"Higher alcohols, such as |FRAME: ISOBUTANOL|, possess several beneficial characteristics, such as a low hygroscopicity, vapor pressure and corrosivity, full compatibility with existing engines and pipelines, and a high energy density.

|FRAME: ISOBUTANOL Isobutanol| is produced biologically as a by-product of yeast fermentation. While most other eukaryotes (as well as many prokaryotes) catabolize |FRAME: VAL| through a succession of acyl-coA derivatives to metabolites that can enter the TCA cycle (see |FRAME: VALDEG-PWY|), providing the organism with carbon as well as nitrogen, yeast are not able to use |FRAME:VAL| as a carbon source, and process it through the |FRAME: PWY-5057 \"Ehrlich pathway\"| to |FRAME:ISOBUTANOL| |CITS: [8277258]|. In this pathway, the nitrogen is removed, creating the 2-oxo acid |FRAME: 2-KETO-ISOVALERATE|, which is metabolized to isobutanol via |FRAME: CPD-7000|.

Since the use of L-valine as a feed-stock would be cost prohibitive for industrial scale isobutanol production, the common strategy to engineer common microbial hosts such as |FRAME: TAX-562|, |FRAME: TAX-1423|, |FRAME: TAX-1718| and |FRAME: TAX-4932| for the production of isobutanol is to combine the last two reactions of the Ehrlich pathway with the pathway for |FRAME: VALSYN-PWY \"valine biosynthesis\"| from pyruvate via the mutual intermediate |FRAME: 2-KETO-ISOVALERATE| |CITS: [Donaldson10][21161324][22008938]|.

The two reactions from the Ehrlich pathway are usually catalyzed by a broad range 2-ketoacid decarboxylase (encoded by |FRAME: G-10082|) from |FRAME: TAX-1358| and an alcohol dehydrogenase from either |FRAME: TAX-4932|, |FRAME: TAX-1718|, |FRAME: TAX-562| or |FRAME: TAX-1358| (encoded by |FRAME: YMR303C|, <i>adhA</i>, |FRAME: G7564| and <i>adhA</i>, respectively) |CITS: [18172501][19609521][20376637][21441331][21533914]|.

In order to increase the isobutanol yield in the engineered organisms, it is essential to increase the pyruvate pool by knocking out enzymes that compete for the pyruvate, such as |FRAME: EG10031|, |FRAME: G592|, |FRAME: EG10330| and |FRAME: EG10331|, |FRAME: EG10325|, |FRAME: EG20173| and |FRAME:EG10701| (encoding alcohol dehydrogenase, D-lactate dehydrogenase, fumarate reductase, transcriptional regulator FNR, phosphate acetyltransferase, and pyruvate formate lyase, respectively) |CITS: [18172501]|." "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6389"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Fermentation"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Energy-Metabolism"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-3781"	"aerobic respiration I (cytochrome c)"	"PWY-3781"	"<b>General Background</b>

Like |FRAME: Fermentation fermentation|, respiration is a process by which electrons are passed from an electron donor to a terminal electron acceptor. However, in respiration the electrons do not pass directly from the donor to the acceptor. Instead, they pass a number of membrane-bound electron carriers that function as a transport chain, passing the electrons from one to another in steps that follow the electrochemical gradients between the electron donor and the acceptor.

Each oxidized member of the electron transfer chain (which can be |FRAME: Flavoproteins|, |FRAME: ETR-Quinones|, |FRAME: Cytochromes|, or other type of electron carrier) can be reduced by the reduced form of the preceding member, and the electrons flow through the chain all the way to the terminal acceptor, which could be oxygen in the case of aerobic respiration, or another type of molecule in anaerobic respiration. 

Known terminal acceptors include organic compounds (|FRAME: FUM|, |FRAME: DMSO|, or |FRAME: TRIMETHYLAMINE-N-O|), or inorganic compounds (|FRAME: NITRATE|, |FRAME: NITRITE|, |FRAME: NITROUS-OXIDE|, |FRAME: CHLORATE|, |FRAME: CPD0-1385|, |FRAME: MN+3 \"oxidized manganese ions\"|, |FRAME: FE+3 \"ferric iron\"|, gold, |FRAME: SELENATE|, |FRAME: ARSENATE|, |FRAME: SULFATE| and |FRAME: Elemental-Sulfur \"elemental sulfur\"|).

During the process of electron transfer, a proton gradient is formed across the membrane due to three potential processes:

1. The use of some of the energy associated with the electron transfer for active pumping of protons out of the cell.

2. Exporting protons out of the cell during electron-to-hydrogen transfers.

3. Scalar reactions that consume protons inside the cell, or produce them outside the cell, without actually moving a proton from one compartment to another.

Upon passage of protons back into the cytoplasm, they drive multisubunit |FRAME: EC-3.6.3.14 \"ATP synthase\"| enzymes that generate ATP.

<b>About This Pathway</b>

NADH and FADH<sub>2</sub> are formed in the glycolytic and TCA cycles. Each of these energy-rich molecules has a pair of electrons with high transfer potential. The free energy liberated during transfer of those electrons can be used for synthesizing ATP. This electron transfer is performed by a series of four large electron carriers complexes also known as complex I-IV (electron transport chain or respiratory chain), present in the inner mitochondrial membrane. These complexes facilitate the passage of electrons from lower to higher redox potentials. Of those complexes, complex I and II are involved in the oxidation of NADH and FADH<sub>2</sub>. The flow of electrons resulting from this oxidation causes protons to be pumped from the matrix side to the intermembrane space. This flow generates a proton-motive force composed of a pH gradient and a membrane potential. Those protons flow back into the matrix through various routes. Particularly, protons flow back through the ATP-synthesizing complex embedded in the mitochondrial membrane leading to the synthesis of ATP. Aerobic respiration parallels the transport of electrons resulting from the oxidation of NADH and FADH<sub>2</sub> with the creation of a proton gradient and accompanying membrane potential, leading to the synthesis of ATP |CITS: [DEY97]|.

In contrast to the mitochondrial respiration in mammals and plants (this pathway), the oxidative phosphorylation in |FRAME: TAX-4932| via the respiration chain occurs without complex I. Instead Baker's yeast employs three NADH:ubiquinone oxidoreductases (type II - one internal, two external) which catalyze the reoxidation of cytosolic |FRAME:NADH| to provide |FRAME:NAD| (see |FRAME:PWY-7279|) |CITS:[23086143] [1900238] [9733747] [9696750]|."
