"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY0-1584" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY0-1578" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=P108-PWY"	"pyruvate fermentation to propanoate I"	"P108-PWY"	"Propionic acid bacteria (also known as propionibacteria) are Gram-positive, anaerobic bacteria,
found as saprophytes on animals (including humans) and in dairy products (such as Swiss cheese).
Propionibacteria produce large amounts of |FRAME:PROPIONATE| as the end product of glucose
fermentaion.
The first work of importance on the chemistry of propionate fermentation was published as early
as 1878 |CITS:[Fitz78]|.

For a long time propionibacteria were assumed to form propionate by the direct decarboxylation
of |FRAME:SUC-COA| to |FRAME:PROPIONYL-COA| and |FRAME: CARBON-DIOXIDE|
|CITS: [13271286][Wood56]|. A similar mechanism (in the opposite direction) was believed to catalyze
propionate degradation |CITS: [13100070]|.
However, in 1957 it was shown that during propionate catabolism in animal cells the primary
product of |FRAME: PROPIONYL-COA| carboxylation was not |FRAME:SUC-COA|, but
<b>methylmalonyl-coA</b> |CITS: [13502357]|. That discovery prompted a re-evaluation of the
pathway of propionate fermentation.

A careful analysis revealed that |FRAME:SUC-COA| is not decarboxylated, but is converted to
|FRAME:METHYL-MALONYL-COA|, and that it is the latter compound (after racemization) that is cleaved,
transfering a C1 unit to |FRAME:PYRUVATE| |CITS: [16590594]|.
This reaction, catalyzed by the enzyme |FRAME:CPLX-7155|, generates |FRAME:PROPIONYL-COA|
and |FRAME:OXALACETIC_ACID|.
The |FRAME:PROPIONYL-COA| that is formed acts as a |FRAME:CO-A|  donor for a different step
of this cycle, where it is transferred to |FRAME:SUC|. This reaction, catalyzed by
|FRAME: MONOMER-13083|, forms |FRAME:SUC-COA| and |FRAME:PROPIONATE|, the final product
of this cycle.

Even though the pathway was investigated mostly in propionibacteria, many other species, including
|FRAME: TAX-894| |CITS: [Stams84]|, |FRAME: TAX-29543| |CITS: [Schink87]| and |FRAME: TAX-865|
|CITS: [Tholozan94]| use it as well.

Another propionate fermentation pathway is the acrylate pathway (see |FRAME:PWY-5494 |).
"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5088"		"succinate-propionate fermentation pathway" // "pyruvate fermentation to propionate I" // "succinate-propanoate fermentation pathway" // "pyruvic acid fermentation to propanoic acid I"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Pyruvate-Propanoate-Fermentation"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5494" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=P108-PWY"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Fermentation-to-propanoate" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Pyruvate-Degradation"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Fermentation-to-Acids" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Fermentation"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=ANAEROFRUCAT-PWY"	"homolactic fermentation"	"ANAEROFRUCAT-PWY"	"<b>General Background</b>

Lactic acid fermentation is a process by which sugars such as glucose, fructose, and sucrose are converted into cellular energy and the metabolic byproduct lactate. It occurs in many bacteria and anaerobic lower eukaryotes, as well as in animal cells, such as muscle cells, in the absence of oxygen.
In homolactic fermentation the only product is |FRAME: L-LACTATE|, and thus one molecule of glucose is ultimately converted to two such molecules.

The lactic acid bacteria (LAB) are a group of Gram positive bacteria that produce lactate as the major end product of the fermentation of carbohydrates. The LAB were divided early on into two main groups, depending on their fermentation products. One group included those bacteria that convert carbohydrates essentially into lactate, while the other group included those producing, in addition, substantial quantities of volatile acids and carbon dioxide |CITS: [Orla-Jensen19]|.
A few years after this initial classification was established the terms homo- and hetero-fermentative, respectively, were proposed for the two groups |CITS: [Kluyver24]|.
It should be noted that at least some organisms are capable of shifting from one mode of fermentation to the other depending on oxygen or nutrient availability |CITS: [108249]|.

<b>About This Pathway</b>

In homolactic fermentation sugars are metabolized via the Embden-Myerhof glycolytic pathway to pyruvate, which is then converted to lactate.

Sugars can enter bacterial cells in two different mechanisms. In most homofermentative strains sugars are transported by a sugar phosphotransferase system (PTS) that phosphorylates the sugar during transport. |FRAME: GLC| is  phosphorylated to |FRAME:GLC-6-P|, while |FRAME:FRU| is usually phosphorylated to |FRAME:FRU1P| (although some
PTSs were reported to generate |FRAME:FRUCTOSE-6P| |CITS: [8246840][8550437][10627040]|).
The second mechanism involves the transport of sugars via a permease, in which case they are not phophorylated.

All sugars are then activated to |FRAME:FRUCTOSE-16-DIPHOSPHATE| through different routes, depending on the nature of the sugar and on the way it enters the cell. Intracellular fructose (that entered by a permease) is phosphorylated first to fructose-6-phosphate, then to fructose-1,6-biphosphate.
Intracellular glucose (that entered by a permease) is first phosphorylated to glucose-6-phosphate, isomerized to fructose-6-phosphate, and finally phosphorylated to fructose-1,6-biphosphate |CITS: [16741753]|.

Fructose-6-phosphate and fructose-1-phosphate (that entered via a PTS) are both phosphorylated to fructose-1,6-biphosphate by |FRAME: CPLX-7324| and |FRAME:MONOMER-13047|, respectively, and  glucose-6-phosphate (that entered via a PTS) is isomerized to fructose-6-phosphate, and finally phosphorylated to fructose-1,6-biphosphate.

The common product, fructose-1,6-biphosphate, is processed via the Embden-Meyerhof (EM) pathway to pyruvate, which is then converted to lactate, the the sole end-product of homolactic fermentation |CITS: [8550437]|. Fructose-1,6-biphosphate is an important regulator of the pathway, being a positive effector of |FRAME:CPLX-7323| |CITS: [Thompson87]|." "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=P125-PWY"	"superpathway of (<i>R,R</i>)-butanediol biosynthesis"	"P125-PWY"	"2,3-butanediol is a compound of commercial interest, mostly as an antifreeze agent due to to its low freezing point |CITS: [Magee87]|. One of its well known applications is the formation of methyl ethyl ketone, by dehydration, which can be used as a liquid fuel additive |CITS: [11234948]|.

Many bacterial species can ferment pyruvate to |FRAME: 2-3-Butanediols \"2-3-butanediol\"| via several intermediate compounds,
including |FRAME: 2-ACETO-LACTATE|, |FRAME: ACETOIN|, and |FRAME: DIACETYL|. Not all species carry the process all the way through - some may stop earlier, accumulating some of the intermediates. 
Of particular importance is the production of |FRAME: DIACETYL|, an important flavor metabolite in dairy products, wine and beer |CITS: [2198252][15454314]|.

The metabolic function of 2,3-butanediol is not well understood, although it may play a role in preventing intracellular
acidification by changing the metabolism from acid production to the formation of a neutral compound
|CITS: [6298028]|.  In addition, the pathway might participate in regulation of the NADH/NAD<sup>+</sup> ratio
in the bacteria |CITS: [8444801]|.

In this pathway |FRAME: PYRUVATE|, which is produced by substrate level phosphorylation, is converted to |FRAME: 2-ACETO-LACTATE| by the enzyme |FRAME:CPLX-5243| (also known as &alpha;-ALS). 2-acetolactate is an unstable intermediate, and  in the presence of oxygen it can undergo a spontaneous decarboxylation, producing |FRAME: DIACETYL| that is converted to acetoin by the activity of the dual-function enzyme acetoin (diacetyl) reductase (see below).
Under anaerobic conditions  |FRAME: 2-ACETO-LACTATE| is converted directly to acetoin by a decarboxylation step catalyzed by the enzyme |FRAME: CPLX-5262| (&alpha;-ALD), and production of diacetyl is bypassed.
The relative activities of &alpha;-ALS and &alpha;-ALD in specific strains determine the fluxes and concentrations of the different intermediates in these organisms.

The two enzyme activities diacetyl reductase and acetoin reductase were initially reported to be catalyzed by two different enzymes |CITS: [13211662]|, and two different EC numbers were issued based on that observation (|FRAME: ACETOINDEHYDROG-RXN \"EC 1.1.1.5\"| and |FRAME: RR-BUTANEDIOL-DEHYDROGENASE-RXN \"EC 1.1.1.4|). However, later research indicated that in most bacteria both activities are catalyzed by the same enzyme, for which the name diacetyl(acetoin) reductase was suggested |CITS: [5540507][4350968][2040298][10647818]|. Moreover, the enzyme appears to have a much wider substrate range than orignally believed, and it has been suggested to rename it L-glycol dehydrogenase |CITS: [2040298]|.

This pathway includes multiple decarboxylation reactions, generating |FRAME: CARBON-DIOXIDE|.
This CO<sub>2</sub> is the source of the  \"eyes\", or holes that certain cheeses, such as Swiss cheese, develop during maturation." "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6396"	"superpathway of 2,3-butanediol biosynthesis"	"PWY-6396"	"<b>Please note:</b> This pathway does not necessarily represent a single organism. Rather, it is a super-pathway
assembled from several pathways found in a variety of organisms, each producing a different stereoisomer of |FRAME: 2-3-Butanediols \"2-3-butanediol\"|. The purpose of this pathway is to provide an overview of the metabolic capabilities of the ecosystem, pertaining to the biosynthesis of this compound. That said, there are indications that some organisms are indeed capable of producing all three stereoisomers.

2,3-butanediol is a compound of commercial interest, mostly as an antifreeze agent due to to its low freezing point |CITS: [Magee87]|. One of its well known applications is the formation of methyl ethyl ketone, by dehydration, which can be used as a liquid fuel additive |CITS: [11234948]|.

Many bacterial species can ferment pyruvate to |FRAME: 2-3-Butanediols \"2-3-butanediol\"| via several intermediate compounds,
including |FRAME: 2-ACETO-LACTATE|, |FRAME: ACETOIN|, and |FRAME: DIACETYL|. Not all species carry the process all the way through - some may stop earlier, accumulating some of the intermediates. 
Of particular importance is the production of |FRAME: DIACETYL|, an important flavor metabolite in dairy products, wine and beer |CITS: [2198252][15454314]|.

The metabolic function of 2,3-butanediol is not well understood, although it may play a role in preventing intracellular
acidification by changing the metabolism from acid production to the formation of a neutral compound
|CITS: [6298028]|.  In addition, the pathway might participate in regulation of the NADH/NAD<sup>+</sup> ratio
in the bacteria |CITS: [8444801]|.

In this pathway |FRAME: PYRUVATE|, which is produced by substrate level phosphorylation, is converted to |FRAME: 2-ACETO-LACTATE| by the enzyme |FRAME:CPLX-5243| (also known as &alpha;-ALS). 2-acetolactate is an unstable intermediate, and  in the presence of oxygen it can undergo a spontaneous decarboxylation, producing |FRAME: DIACETYL| that is converted to acetoin by the activity of the dual-function enzyme acetoin (diacetyl) reductase (see below).
Under anaerobic conditions  |FRAME: 2-ACETO-LACTATE| is converted directly to acetoin by a decarboxylation step catalyzed by the enzyme |FRAME: CPLX-5262| (&alpha;-ALD), and production of diacetyl is bypassed.

Diacetyl can be converted into any of the two stereoisomers of acetoin - |FRAME: CPD-10353| or |FRAME: CPD-255|, by stereo-specific enzymes.

The enzymes that catalyze the irreversible reduction of diacetyl to acetoin also catalyze the last step in the pathway - the reversible conversion of acetoin to 2,3-butanediol. These enzymes are known in the literature by several names, including acetoin reductase (AR), acetoin (diacetyl) reductase, and 2,3-butanediol dehydrogenase (BDH). Four types of AR activites have been described, differing in their stereo-specificity for both the substrate and the product:

1. An |FRAME: CPD-12004|-forming R-acetoin reductase

2. An |FRAME: CPD-12004|-forming S-acetoin reductase

3. An |FRAME: CPD-346|-forming S-acetoin reductase

4. An |FRAME: BUTANEDIOL|-forming R-acetoin reductase.

Among the enzymes that have been characteized, some appear to have only one of these activities, while others have multiple activities |CITS: [Ui84]|.

The two enzyme activities diacetyl reductase and acetoin reductase were initially reported to be catalyzed by two different enzymes |CITS: [13211662]|, and two different EC numbers were issued based on that observation (|FRAME: ACETOINDEHYDROG-RXN \"EC 1.1.1.5\"| and |FRAME: RR-BUTANEDIOL-DEHYDROGENASE-RXN \"EC 1.1.1.4|). However, later research indicated that in most bacteria both activities are catalyzed by the same enzyme, for which the name diacetyl(acetoin) reductase was suggested |CITS: [5540507][4350968][2040298][10647818]|. Moreover, the enzyme appears to have a much wider substrate range than orignally believed, and it has been suggested to rename it L-glycol dehydrogenase |CITS: [2040298]|.

Yeast appears to also have dedicated NADP-linked enzymes that reduce diacetyl but not acetoin |CITS: [2180695]|.

This pathway includes multiple decarboxylation reactions, generating |FRAME: CARBON-DIOXIDE|.
This CO<sub>2</sub> is the source of the  \"eyes\", or holes that certain cheeses, such as Swiss cheese, develop during maturation." "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY66-5"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Alcohol-Biosynthesis" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=NIL&object=Generalized-Reactions"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6282"	"palmitoleate biosynthesis I (from (5Z)-dodec-5-enoate)"	"PWY-6282"	"|FRAME: CPD-9245 Palmitoleate| is a common unsaturated fatty acid, found in bacteria, fungi |CITS: [8294460]|, plants |CITS: [7548115]| and animals |CITS:[14321753] [6030882]|. It is formed in different organisms by different mechanisms. Only bacteria can produce unsaturated fatty acids anaerobically, and thus the key enzymes of this pathway (particularly |FRAME: EG10273| which catalyzes an early step - see |FRAME: PWY0-862|) have been targeted for development of new antibacterial agents |CITS: [22188524][23174186]|.

In |FRAME:TAX-562| |FRAME: CPD-9245| is one of only two unsaturated fatty acids (along with |FRAME: CPD-9247|), which together comprise about one-half of the total fatty acid content of the organism. |FRAME: PALMITATE Palmitate|, |FRAME: CPD-9245|, and |FRAME: CPD-9247| make up the bulk of the fatty acids found in |FRAME:TAX-562| membranes |CITS: [8246839]|.

|FRAME:TAX-562| has three &beta;-ketoacyl-ACP synthases (KAS): |FRAME: FABB-CPLX|, |FRAME: 3-OXOACYL-ACP-SYNTHII-CPLX| and |FRAME: CPLX0-252|, encoded by |FRAME: EG10274|, |FRAME: EG12606| and |FRAME: EG10277|, respectively.

The extension of |FRAME: Cis-delta-3-decenoyl-ACPs| to |FRAME: Palmitoleoyl-ACPs| is believed to be catalyzed primarily by |FRAME: FABB-CPLX| (|FRAME: EG10274|). Inactivation of this enzyme leads to a lack of unsaturated fatty acids |CITS: [4901354]|. On the other hand, overexpression of KASI leads to the overproduction of |FRAME: CPD-9247| |CITS: [6337151]|.

It has been shown that the basal ratio of saturated to unsaturated fatty acids in |FRAME:TAX-562| is controlled by the level of two enzymes - |FRAME: FABA-CPLX| (|FRAME: EG10273|) and |FRAME: FABB-CPLX| (|FRAME: EG10274|) |CITS: [8246839]|. The former introduces unsaturation (see |FRAME: PWY0-862|), while the other elongates the unsaturated fatty acid to the level of |FRAME: Palmitoleoyl-ACPs| (this pathway).

Additional control over this ratio is provided by temperature. The proportion of unsaturated fatty acids is known to increase in |FRAME:TAX-562| with lower growth temperature, a phenomenon found in most organisms that provides a mechanism for adjusting the lipid phase transition of the membrane phospholipids to differing temperatures.
It has been shown that |FRAME: 3-OXOACYL-ACP-SYNTHII-CPLX| (|FRAME: EG12606|), which is responsible for the further elongation of the unsaturated fatty acids to the final level of |FRAME: CPD-9247| (see |FRAME: PWY-5973|), is more active at low temperatures (relative to the overall rate of fatty acid synthesis) than at high temperatures |CITS: [7002930]|. This relative increase results in the production of |FRAME: CPD-9247| rather than |FRAME: CPD-9245|.
Because the former (but not the later) can be incorporated into both positions of |FRAME: GLYCEROL-3P|, the synthesis of di-unsaturated phospholipids occurs and the thermotrophic phase transition of the membrane phospholipids is lowered |CITS: [6988423]|.

|FRAME: CPD-9245| is also found in some plants. For the biosynthesis of this compound in plants, see |FRAME: PWY-5366|."	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6285" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6284"		"palmitoleic acid biosynthesis I" // "palmitoleate biosynthesis (anaerobic)"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Palmitoleate-Biosynthesis"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6282" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7589" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5366"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Unsaturated-Fatty-Acids-Biosynthesis"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Fatty-acid-biosynthesis"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7664"	"oleate biosynthesis IV (anaerobic)"	"PWY-7664"	"The obligate anaerobic bacterium |FRAME: TAX-1520|, the saprophytic bacterium |FRAME: TAX-1377|, and the purple non-sulfur bacterium |FRAME: TAX-272943| produce the unusual monounsaturated fatty acids |FRAME: CPD-17289| and |FRAME: OLEATE-CPD| |CITS: [14498314][5554109][6886674][12583708][23972938][Granafei15]|. While |FRAME: OLEATE-CPD| is a common fatty acid in other organisms, where it is produced by oxygen-dependent desaturase enzymes, it is unusual in bacteria.

The pathway used by the bacteria to produce these fatty acids has been studied in |FRAME: TAX-1377| |CITS: [23972938]|. It is similar to the pathway used by many bacteria to produce |FRAME: CPD-17910| (see |FRAME: PWY0-862|). The key enzyme of that pathway is |FRAME: EC-5.3.3.14| (|FRAME: EG10273 FabA|), which has the unique ability of converting some of the |FRAME: Trans-D2-decenoyl-ACPs \"(2E)-dec-2-enoyl-[acp]\"| (an intermediate the |FRAME: PWY-5971 \"palmitate biosynthesis\"| pathway) to |FRAME: Cis-delta-3-decenoyl-ACPs \"(3Z)-dec-3-enoyl-[acp]\"|, which is then elongated in the usual fatty acid elongation process to form |FRAME: Cis-Delta5-dodecenoyl-ACPs \"(5Z)-dodec-5-enoyl-[acp]\"|. 

In the case of bacterial oleate prduction, the key step in the pathway is a similar isomerization, but of a later intermediate of the palmitate biosynthesis pathway, |FRAME: Dodec-2-enoyl-ACPs|, which contains a longer acyl chain. The enzyme catalyzing the isomerization reaction in |FRAME: TAX-1377| is a unique hydratase/isomerase, encoded by |FRAME: G-44009|, which fulfils the roles of both |FRAME: EG11284| (the hydratase involved in the fatty acid elongation process) and |FRAME: EG10273|, which is essential for production of unsaturated fatty acids |CITS: [23972938]|.
The enzyme responsible for the isomerization in |FRAME: TAX-1520| is still unknown, as it has been shown that the fabZ homolog in that organism is unable to perform the isomerization reaction |CITS: [19493359]|.

Another key enzyme in bacterial anaerobic unsaturated fatty acids biosynthesis is the enzyme that catalyzes the condensation of the FabA (or FabQ) product with malonyl-[acp], thus allowing the fatty acid elongation enzymes to continue the extension of the unsaturated fatty acid by two carbons. In |FRAME: TAX-562| this activity is provided by |FRAME: EG10274 FabB|. In |FRAME: TAX-1377|, which lacks FabB, this activity is carried out by a trifunctional |FRAME: G-44012 FabF| enzyme, which catalyzes the activities of the |FRAME: TAX-562| |FRAME: EG10274|, |FRAME: EG10277| and |FRAME: EG12606| |CITS: [23972938]|.

Three rounds of the sequential action of FabF - FabG - FabQ - FabK generate |FRAME: OLEATE-CPD|, as shown in this pathway. In |FRAME: TAX-1377| alone a fourth round generates |FRAME: CPD-12189| (see |FRAME: PWY-7663|)."			"<i>cis</i>-7-hexadecenoate biosynthesis" // "<i>cis</i>-9-octadecenoate biosynthesis" // "(7<i>Z</i>)-hexadec-7-enoate biosynthesis" // "(9<i>Z</i>)-octadec-9-enoate biosynthesis" // "(7<i>Z</i>)-hexadecenoate biosynthesis" // "(9<i>Z</i>)-octadecenoate biosynthesis"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Oleate-Biosynthesis"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7664" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5147" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5996" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7587"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Unsaturated-Fatty-Acids-Biosynthesis"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Fatty-acid-biosynthesis"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY0-862"	"(5Z)-dodecenoate biosynthesis I"	"PWY0-862"	"This pathway for the anaerobic biosynthesis of the unsaturated fatty acid |FRAME: CPD-17910| branches from the pathway leading to saturated fatty acids at |FRAME: Beta-hydroxydecanoyl-ACPs|. 

Only bacteria can produce unsaturated fatty acids anaerobically, and thus the key enzymes of this pathway (particularly |FRAME: EG10273 FabA|) have been targeted for development of new antibacterial agents |CITS: [22188524][23174186]|.

The pathway was originally characterized in the &gamma;-proteobacterium |FRAME: TAX-562|. In that organism, two dehydratases, |FRAME: EG10273 FabA| and |FRAME: EG11284 FabZ|, function for the most part interchangeably in converting |FRAME: OH-ACYL-ACP \"(3<i>R</i>)-3-hydroxyacyl-[acyl-carrier protein]\"| of various chain lengths, saturated or unsaturated, to the corresponding |FRAME: TRANS-D2-ENOYL-ACP \"<i>trans</i>-2-enoyl-[acyl-carrier protein]\"| forms. However, |FRAME: EG10273 FabA| alone has the unique ability of converting some of the <i>trans</i> form |FRAME: Trans-D2-decenoyl-ACPs \"(2<i>E</i>)-dec-2-enoyl-[acp]\"| produced to the <i>cis</i> form |FRAME: Cis-delta-3-decenoyl-ACPs \"(3Z)-dec-3-enoyl-[acyl-carrier protein]\"|.

While the <i>trans</i> form can be reduced and elongated leading to saturated fatty acids, the <i>cis</i>-form cannot be reduced. Instead it serves directly as a substrate for the condensing enzyme, |FRAME: EG10274 FabB|, producing a product that can be acted on by the regular fatty acid elongation enzymes, resulting in an unsaturated acid with a chain  lengthened by two carbon atoms. As might be predicted, mutant strains unable to produce active FabA are unable to make unsaturated fatty acids, but make a normal complement of saturated fatty acids.

It should be noted that only &alpha;- and &gamma;-proteobacteria have the <i>fabA</i> and <i>fabB</i> genes. Other bacterial species that produce unsaturated fatty acids anaerobically possess alternative enzymes, such as |FRAME: G-44021| and |FRAME: G-44022| in |FRAME: TAX-1351| |CITS: [15194690]| and |FRAME: G-44020| in |FRAME: TAX-1313| |CITS: [12237320]|.

Repeated cycling of these four elongation reactions eventually lead to the unsaturated fatty acids |FRAME: CPD-9245| and |FRAME: CPD-9247| that are incorporated into various lipids (see pathways |FRAME: PWY-6282| and |FRAME: PWY-5973|)."	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY0-881" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6285" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6284"		"(5Z)-dodec-5-enoate biosynthesis I" // "<i>cis</i>-dodecenoate biosynthesis I"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=5Z-Dodec-5-enoate-Biosynthesis"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY0-862" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7858"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Unsaturated-Fatty-Acids-Biosynthesis"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Fatty-acid-biosynthesis"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7663"	"gondoate biosynthesis (anaerobic)"	"PWY-7663"	"The saprophytic bacterium |FRAME: TAX-1377| produces the unusual monounsaturated fatty acid |FRAME: CPD-12189| |CITS: [23972938]|. While |FRAME: CPD-12189| is also found in plants, it is produced in bacteria in an anaerobic pathway that does not involve oxygen-dependent desaturase enzymes.

The pathway in |FRAME: TAX-1377| is similar to the pathway used by many bacteria to produce |FRAME: CPD-17910| (see |FRAME: PWY0-862|). The key enzyme of that pathway is |FRAME: EC-5.3.3.14| (|FRAME: EG10273 FabA|), which has the unique ability of converting some of the |FRAME: Trans-D2-decenoyl-ACPs \"(2E)-dec-2-enoyl-[acp]\"| (an intermediate the |FRAME: PWY-5971 \"palmitate biosynthesis\"| pathway) to |FRAME: Cis-delta-3-decenoyl-ACPs \"(3Z)-dec-3-enoyl-[acp]\"|, which is then elongated in the usual fatty acid elongation process to form |FRAME: Cis-Delta5-dodecenoyl-ACPs \"(5Z)-dodec-5-enoyl-[acp]\"|. 

In the case of bacterial gondoate prduction (which involves oleate as an intermediate), the key step in the pathway is a similar isomerization, but of a later intermediate of the palmitate biosynthesis pathway, |FRAME: Dodec-2-enoyl-ACPs|, which contains a longer acyl chain. The enzyme catalyzing the isomerization reaction in |FRAME: TAX-1377| is a unique hydratase/isomerase, encoded by |FRAME: G-44009|, which fulfills the roles of both |FRAME: EG11284| (the hydratase involved in the fatty acid elongation process) and |FRAME: EG10273|, which is essential for production of unsaturated fatty acids |CITS: [23972938]|.

Another key enzyme in bacterial anaerobic unsaturated fatty acids biosynthesis is the enzyme that catalyzes the condensation of the FabA (or FabQ) product with malonyl-[acp], thus allowing the fatty acid elongation enzymes to continue the extension of the unsaturated fatty acid by two carbons. In |FRAME: TAX-562| this activity is provided by |FRAME: EG10274 FabB|. In |FRAME: TAX-1377|, which lacks FabB, this activity is carried out by a trifunctional |FRAME: G-44012 FabF| enzyme, which catalyzes the activities of the |FRAME: TAX-562| |FRAME: EG10274|, |FRAME: EG10277| and |FRAME: EG12606| |CITS: [23972938]|.

Three rounds of the sequential action of FabF - FabG - FabQ - FabK generate |FRAME: OLEATE-CPD| (see |FRAME: PWY-7664|). A fourth round extends the fatty acid to |FRAME: CPD-12189|." "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5973"	"<i>cis</i>-vaccenate biosynthesis"	"PWY-5973"	"The only unsaturated fatty acids found in |FRAME:TAX-562|, |FRAME: CPD-9245| and |FRAME: CPD-9247|, comprise about one-half the fatty acid content of the organism. The proportion of unsaturated fatty acids is known to increase in |FRAME:TAX-562| with lower growth temperature, a phenomenon found in most organisms that provides a mechanism for adjusting the lipid phase transition of the membrane phospholipids to differing temperatures.

|FRAME: 3-OXOACYL-ACP-SYNTHII-CPLX| is the only enzyme that can catalyze the conversion of |FRAME: CPD-9245| to |FRAME: CPD-9247|, and is believed to play a major role in the thermal regulation of fatty acid composition of the membrane phospholipids of |FRAME:TAX-562| |CITS: [6988423]|. |FRAME: 3-OXOACYL-ACP-SYNTHII-CPLX| is one of three &beta;-ketoacyl-ACP synthases (KAS) in |FRAME:TAX-562|: |FRAME: FABB-CPLX|, |FRAME: 3-OXOACYL-ACP-SYNTHII-CPLX| and |FRAME: CPLX0-252|, encoded by |FRAME: EG10274|, |FRAME: EG12606| and |FRAME: EG10277|, respectively.

It has been shown that |FRAME: 3-OXOACYL-ACP-SYNTHII-CPLX| is more active at low temperatures (relative to the overall rate of fatty acid synthesis) than at high temperatures |CITS: [7002930]|. This relative increase results in the production of |FRAME: CPD-9247| rather than |FRAME: CPD-9245|. Furthermore, because the former (but not the later) can be incorporated into both positions of |FRAME: GLYCEROL-3P|, the synthesis of diunsaturated phospholipids occurs and the thermotrophic phase transition of the membrane phospholipids is lowered |CITS: [6988423]|.

Some plant species such as |FRAME: TAX-48545| and |FRAME: TAX-73871| (<i>Doxantha unguis-cati</i> L.) produce relatively high levels of |FRAME: CPD-9245| and |FRAME: CPD-9247| in their seed oils |CITS: [CHISHOLMMJ60][CHISHOLMMJ65]|. The plastidal synthesis of |FRAME: CPD-9247| from |FRAME: CPD-9245| via KASII is thought to be similar to that of the <i>|FRAME:TAX-562|</i> pathway (in |CITS: [20943853]|). KAS II enzymes (EC 2.3.1.179) have been characterized in |FRAME: TAX-3708| |CITS: [11442062]| and |FRAME: TAX-3562| |CITS: [6756317]|, and a |FRAME: NADH|-dependent enoyl-ACP reductase (EC 1.3.1.9) has been characterized in these and several other plant species |CITS: [6756317][1912503][7075600 ][7125663]|." "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5998"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Fatty-acid-biosynthesis"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Lipid-Biosynthesis"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5989"	"stearate biosynthesis II (bacteria and plants)"	"PWY-5989"	"|FRAME: STEARIC_ACID Stearate| is a saturated fatty acid that occurs in many animal and vegetable fats and oils. It is an important constituent of milk fats, lard, and cocoa and shea butters. Stearate was first described by Michel Eugene Chevreul in 1823, and its name comes from Greek for \"hard fat\", reflecting the fact that stearate forms a waxy solid |CITS: [16477801]|.

<i>De novo</i> plant fatty acid synthesis occurs primarily in plastids and chloroplasts (it was shown that at least in Arabidopsis fatty acid synthesis also occurs in the mitochondria). The process involves a series of reactions catalyzed by fatty acid synthase (FAS) complexes that provoke the condensation of |FRAME: MALONYL-ACP| and |FRAME: ACYL-ACP| (see |FRAME: FASYN-ELONG-PWY|).

In animals the last [acp]-bound intermediate appears to be |FRAME: Palmitoyl-ACPs \"palmitoyl-[acp]\"|, and elongation to |FRAME: STEARIC_ACID| proceeds via CoA-bound intermediates in the ER (see |FRAME: PWY-5972|). In bacteria and plants elongation to stearate appears to continue via [acp]-bound intermediates, and |FRAME: Stearoyl-ACPs \"stearoyl-[acp]\"| has been detected in many species |CITS: [4831331]|. 
At least in plants, the elongation from |FRAME: Palmitoyl-ACPs \"palmitoyl-[acp]\"| to |FRAME: Stearoyl-ACPs \"stearoyl-[acp]\"| is catalyzed by a dedicated &beta;-ketoacyl-[acp] synthase, encoded by |FRAME: G-10790| (The enzyme involved in <i>de novo</i> fatty acid synthesis system up to |FRAME: Palmitoyl-ACPs \"palmitoyl-[acp]\"| is encoded by |FRAME: AT5G46290|) |CITS: [4153356][11337402]|.

|FRAME: Stearoyl-ACPs \"Strearoyl-[acp]\"| can be hydrolyzed by acyl-ACP thioesterase enzymes |CITS: [7734968]|. However, before the fatty acids can be exported out of the chloroplast they must be activated to fatty acyl-CoAs by an outer envelope |FRAME: AT1G77590| activity. Once activated, they are exported to the endoplasmic reticulum |CITS: [14973169]|.

A more common route involves desaturation of |FRAME: STEARIC_ACID| to |FRAME: OLEATE-CPD|. Plants contain acyl-ACP desaturase enzymes, which introduce a double bond in the 9 position of |FRAME: Stearoyl-ACPs \"stearoyl-[acp]\"| to generate |FRAME: Oleoyl-ACPs \"oleoyl-[acp]\"| (see |FRAME: PWY-5147|). Stearate is the only fatty acid that is desaturated in its ACP-bound form. All other desaturation reactions occur only after the fatty acid has been attached to a glycerolipid backbone.

In cyanobacteria stearate is also often desaturated to oleate. However, unlike plants, in cyanobacteria this desaturation reaction occurs only after the incorporation of stearate into a lipid. Prior to incorporation into a lipid, the fatty acid is transferred to a coenzyme A molecule, resulting in formation of |FRAME: STEAROYL-COA|.

Since the activity of the desaturase enzymes is often very high, |FRAME: OLEATE-CPD| is often the main product of intraplastidial fatty acid synthesis |CITS: [8652653]|."	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6113" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5156"		"stearic acid biosynthesis"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Stearate-Biosynthesis"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY3O-355" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5972" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5989"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Fatty-acid-biosynthesis"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Lipid-Biosynthesis"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY4FS-7"	"phosphatidylglycerol biosynthesis I (plastidic)"	"PWY4FS-7"	"The plastid envelope, like the thylakoid membrane, is predominated by glycolipids. The only phospholipid found in chloroplast thylakoids is |FRAME: L-1-PHOSPHATIDYL-GLYCEROL \"phosphatidylglycerol\"|, which is critical for the structural and functional integrity of the thylakoid membranes.

The acyl donors for the two acyltransferase reactions leading to the formation of |FRAME: L-PHOSPHATIDATE|, the precursor of phosphatidylglycerol, can be either an acyl-ACP or an acyl-CoA, depending on the location of the pathway. In plants the biosynthesis of phosphatidylglycerol can occur at three subcellular locations - chloroplast, mitochondrion and ER. In the plastid phosphatidylglycerol is assembled <i>de novo</i> from the newly synthesized fatty acids, and acyl-ACPs are the acyl donors |CITS: [16774646]|.
In the non-plastidic pathway (see |FRAME: PWY4FS-8|) acyl-CoA are used as the acyl-donor |CITS: [Moore82]|.

In Arabidopsis, this pathway accounts for about 85% of phosphatidylglycerol in the plastid.

"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY66-5"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Phospholipid-Biosynthesis" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Pathways"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Lipid-Biosynthesis" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=NIL&object=Generalized-Reactions"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY4FS-8"	"phosphatidylglycerol biosynthesis II (non-plastidic)"	"PWY4FS-8"	"|FRAME: L-1-PHOSPHATIDYL-GLYCEROL \"Phosphatidylglycerol\"| is the only phospholipid found in chloroplast thylakoids, and is critical for the structural and functional integrity of the thylakoid membranes.

The acyl donors for the two acyltransferase reactions leading to the formation of |FRAME: L-PHOSPHATIDATE|, the precursor of phosphatidylglycerol, can be either an acyl-ACP or an acyl-CoA, depending on the location of the pathway. In plants the biosynthesis of phosphatidylglycerol can occur at three subcellular locations - chloroplast, mitochondrion and ER. In the plastid (see |FRAME: PWY4FS-7|), phosphatidylglycerol is assembled <i>de novo</i> from the newly synthesized fatty acids, and acyl-ACPs are the acyl donors |CITS: [16774646]|.
In the non-plastidic pathway depicted here acyl-CoA are used as the acyl-donor |CITS: [Moore82]|.
"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PHOSLIPSYN2-PWY"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5667"		"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PhosphatidylglycerolBiosynthesis" "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY66-5"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Phospholipid-Biosynthesis" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Pathways"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Lipid-Biosynthesis" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=NIL&object=Generalized-Reactions"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY0-1319"	"CDP-diacylglycerol biosynthesis II"	"PWY0-1319"	"<b>General Background</b>

Phospholipids are important membrane components. Most of the phospholipids belong to the category of phosphoglycerides. The simplest phosphoglycerides, which are known as phosphatidates, are composed of a glycerol molecule attached to two fatty acids and one phosphate group.
The carboxyl group of each fatty acid is esterified to the hydroxyl groups on carbon-1 and carbon-2 of the glycerol molecule, while the phosphate group is attached to carbon-3 by an ester link.
Phosphatidates are precursors for many phosphoglycerides found in animals, plants and yeast, including |FRAME: Phosphatidylinositols|, |FRAME: L-1-PHOSPHATIDYL-SERINE|, |FRAME: L-1-PHOSPHATIDYL-ETHANOLAMINE|, and |FRAME: CARDIOLIPIN|.

As part of the synthesis of phosphoglycerides, either the phosphatidate or the modifying compound need to be activated by |FRAME:CTP|. In some cases, the modifying compound is activated, as in the case of |FRAME: CHOLINE| and |FRAME: ETHANOL-AMINE|, which form |FRAME: CDP-CHOLINE| and |FRAME: CDP-ETHANOLAMINE|, respectively. However, in the case of other compounds, such as |FRAME: SER| and |FRAME: MYO-INOSITOL|, the phosphatidate is activated first, forming |FRAME: CDPDIACYLGLYCEROL|, which then reacts with the modifying compound to form the phosphoglyceride.

<b>About This Pathway</b>

This pathway describes the biosynthesis of |FRAME: CDPDIACYLGLYCEROL| in some Gram-negative bacteria (primarily the |FRAME: TAX-1236|) as well as the chloroplasts of green plants. In this pathway the production of the intermediate |FRAME: ACYL-SN-GLYCEROL-3P| is catalyzed by a type of the membrane-bound enzyme |FRAME: GLYCEROL-3-P-ACYLTRANSFER-MONOMER| that uses |FRAME: ACYL-ACP| as the acyl donor.

Bacteria enzymes that can utilze |FRAME: ACYL-ACP| are found only in some Gram-negative bacteria.
They are encoded by the |FRAME: EG10740| gene, and can also utilize |FRAME: Long-Chain-Acyl-CoAs| thioesters. The plasitidic enzyme can use only |FRAME: ACYL-ACP| |CITS: [9370311]|.

The addition of the second acyl moiety is catalyzed by |FRAME: 1-ACYLGLYCEROL-3-P-ACYLTRANSFER-MONOMER|. The bacterial enzyme, which is universally expressed in all bacteria, is encoded by |FRAME: EG11377|.
As in the case of PlsB, it can utilize either a fatty acyl-[acp] or an acyl-CoA thioester as the acyl donor.

A pathway that describes the usage of acyl-CoA donors can be found at |FRAME: PWY-5667|.
It should be noted that most bacteria utilize a different route for the synthesis of |FRAME: ACYL-SN-GLYCEROL-3P|, as described in |FRAME: PWY-5981|.

More information can be found in |FRAME: PHOSLIPSYN2-PWY|."	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PHOSLIPSYN2-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY4FS-7" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PHOSLIPSYN-PWY"			"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=CDP-diacylglycerol-Biosynthesis"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5981" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY0-1319" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5667"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Phospholipid-Biosynthesis"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Lipid-Biosynthesis"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5667"	"CDP-diacylglycerol biosynthesis I"	"PWY-5667"	"<b>General Background</b>

Phospholipids are important membrane components. Most of the phospholipids belong to the category of phosphoglycerides. The simplest phosphoglycerides, which are known as phosphatidates, are composed of a glycerol molecule attached to two fatty acids and one phosphate group. The carboxyl group of each fatty acid is esterified to the hydroxyl groups on carbon-1 and carbon-2 of the glycerol molecule, while the phosphate group is attached to carbon-3 by an ester link. Phosphatidates are precursors for many phosphoglycerides found in animals, plants and yeast, including |FRAME: Phosphatidylinositols|, |FRAME: L-1-PHOSPHATIDYL-SERINE|, |FRAME: L-1-PHOSPHATIDYL-ETHANOLAMINE|, and |FRAME: CARDIOLIPIN|.

As part of the synthesis of phosphoglycerides, either the phosphatidate or the modifying compound need to be activated by |FRAME:CTP|. In some cases, the modifying compound is activated, as in the case of |FRAME: CHOLINE| and
|FRAME: ETHANOL-AMINE|, which form |FRAME: CDP-CHOLINE| and |FRAME: CDP-ETHANOLAMINE|, respectively. However, in the case of other compounds, such as |FRAME: SER| and |FRAME: MYO-INOSITOL|, the phosphatidate is activated first, forming |FRAME: CDPDIACYLGLYCEROL|, which then reacts with the modifying compound to form the
phosphoglyceride.

<b>About This Pathway</b>

This pathway describes the biosynthesis of |FRAME: CDPDIACYLGLYCEROL| in eukaryotes and some Gram-negative bacteria (primarily the |FRAME: TAX-1236|). In this pathway the production of the intermediate |FRAME: ACYL-SN-GLYCEROL-3P| is catalyzed by the membrane-bound enzyme |FRAME: GLYCEROL-3-P-ACYLTRANSFER-MONOMER|. The bacterial enzyme, encoded by |FRAME: EG10740|, can utilize either |FRAME: ACYL-ACP| or |FRAME: Long-Chain-Acyl-CoAs| thioesters as the acyl donors, while the eukaryotic enzymes can only accept the acyl-CoA thiesters.

The addition of the second acyl moiety is catalyzed by |FRAME: 1-ACYLGLYCEROL-3-P-ACYLTRANSFER-MONOMER|. The bacterial enzyme, which is universally expressed in all bacteria, is encoded by |FRAME: EG11377|. As in the case of PlsB, the bacterial enzyme can utilize either a fatty acyl-[acp] or an acyl-CoA thioester as the acyl donor, while the eukaryotic enzyme can only accept acyl-CoA thioesters.

A pathway that describes the usage of fatty acyl-[acp] donors can be found at |FRAME: PWY0-1319|. It should be noted that most bacteria utilize a different route for the synthesis of |FRAME: ACYL-SN-GLYCEROL-3P|, as described in |FRAME: PWY-5981|.

More information can be found in |FRAME: PHOSLIPSYN2-PWY|."	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PHOSLIPSYN2-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY4FS-8" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PHOSLIPSYN-PWY"		"CDP-diacylglycerol biosynthesis"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=CDP-diacylglycerol-Biosynthesis"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5981" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY0-1319" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5667"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Phospholipid-Biosynthesis"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Lipid-Biosynthesis"

"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Super-Pathways"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Methylthiopropionate-Degradation" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Dimethylsulfoniopropionate-Degradation" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Tetrathionate-Reduction" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Sulfur-reduction" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Sulfolactate-Degradation" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Sulfide-Oxidation" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Dissimilatory-Sulfate-Reduction" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=ARGORNPROST-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5863" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY66-5"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Noncarbon-Nutrients" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Pathways"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Degradation" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=NIL&object=Generalized-Reactions"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6507"	"4-deoxy-L-<i>threo</i>-hex-4-enopyranuronate degradation"	"PWY-6507"	"<b>General Background</b>

Many organisms produce large complex polymers that contain |FRAME: Uronates \"uronic acids\"|. A few examples include |FRAME: Pectin pectin|, an important component of  plant cell walls that contains |FRAME: D-GALACTURONATE|, and glycosaminoglycans produced by animals, which include |FRAME: HEPARIN|, |FRAME: Heparan-Sulfate|, |FRAME: Hyaluronan|, |FRAME: Chondroitin-sulfates| etc.

The bacterial degradation pathways for these polymers usually invovle an intial attack on the polymer that breaks it into short oligosaccharides. Two main types of enzymes that perform this task are the hydrolases and the endolyases. While hydrolases produce oligosaccharides that contain sugar residues similar to those in the polymer, lyases produce oligosaccharides that have a 4-5 unsaturated uronic acid at their non-reducing end. This is typically followed by the action of exolyases or hydrolases that cleave the oligosaccharides, resulting in the production of unstable unsaturated mono uronic acid monomers. Two forms of unsaturated uronic acids are formed, depending on the stereochemistry of the original acid - |FRAME: CPD-17705| and |FRAME: CPD-13122|. The degradation of many polymers, including gellan, rhamnogalacturan, pectin, heparin, heparan sulfate, dermatan sulfate, hyaluronan and chondroitin results in formation the latter. |FRAME: CPD-13122| is unstable and the ring opens spontaneously, forming the keto acid |FRAME: CPD-37|. This pathway describes the degradation of that intermediate to metabolites of central metabolism.

<b>About This Pathway</b>

The pathway, which was first studied in detail in the pectin degrader |FRAME: TAX-556|, begins with the isomerization of |FRAME: CPD-37| (DKI) to |FRAME: CPD-343| (DKII). The <i>kduI</i> gene encoding the isomerase has been identified in this organism |CITS: [1766386]|, but the enzyme has not been characterized. Earlier work characterized this enzyme in a pseudomonad |CITS: [13986017]|. |FRAME: CPD-343| is reduced to the common metabolite |FRAME: 2-DEHYDRO-3-DEOXY-D-GLUCONATE|, a compound that is also an intermediate in |FRAME: GALACTUROCAT-PWY|. |FRAME: 2-DEHYDRO-3-DEOXY-D-GLUCONATE| is phosphorylated and then cleaved by an aldolase encoded by the <i>kdgA</i> gene, producing the central metabolites |FRAME: GAP| and |FRAME: PYRUVATE|.

The same pathway has also been characterized from the heparin/hyaluronan-degradating bacterium |FRAME: TAX-211110| |CITS: [25605731]|. Two of the enzymes (|FRAME: EC-5.3.1.17| and |FRAME: EC-1.1.1.127|) have been characterized in detail from this organism. While their actions are identical to those of the |FRAME: TAX-556| enzymes, they share very little sequence similarity and possess different structures, suggesting parallel evolution. The |FRAME: G-14833| and |FRAME: G-12012| genes are found in enterococci and clostridia, while the |FRAME: G-43933| and |FRAME: G-43934| genes are much less common and found primarily in streptococci |CITS: [25605731]|.

In |FRAME:TAX-562| the aldolase encoded by gene <i>eda</i> is involved in the |FRAME: ENTNER-DOUDOROFF-PWY|.
However, in |FRAME: TAX-556| this enzyme does not appear to be involved in |FRAME: GLUCONATE| catabolism and no product of the <i>edd</i> gene that encodes the |FRAME: PGLUCONDEHYDRAT-MONOMER| could be detected in various species of |FRAME:TAX-551|. These observations question the existence of the Entner-Doudoroff pathway in these organisms (|CITS: [8145647][8905080]|. 

Most of the enzymes in this pathway are controlled by <i>kdgR</i> a transcriptional regulator that is induced by |FRAME: 2-DEHYDRO-3-DEOXY-D-GLUCONATE| |CITS: [1840643] [1874406]|.  A comparative genomics analysis of the <i>kdgR</i> regulon in eight enterobacteria including |FRAME: TAX-198628| and |FRAME: TAX-554| and two members of the genus |FRAME:TAX-662|, yielded a metabolic map of pectin and pectin-derivative degradation in these organisms |CITS: [15528647]|." "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7242"	"D-fructuronate degradation"	"PWY-7242"	"Multiple degradation pathways lead to the metabolite |FRAME: FRUCTURONATE|.

One group of such pathways is the degradation of glucuronate-containing polymers such as |FRAME: Glucuronoxylans|. These pathways contain a step for the removal of |FRAME: GLUCURONATE| residues, which are then converted to |FRAME: FRUCTURONATE| by the action of |FRAME: EC-5.3.1.12| |CITS: [13794771]|.

In the hyper thermophilic bacterium |FRAME: TAX-2336|, the degradation of |FRAME: Pectin pectin|, which results in formation of |FRAME: D-GALACTURONATE|, also feeds into |FRAME: FRUCTURONATE|, since |FRAME: D-GALACTURONATE| is isomerized to |FRAME: D-TAGATURONATE| by |FRAME: CPLX-8661|, which is then epimerized to |FRAME: FRUCTURONATE| by |FRAME: CPLX-8660| |CITS: [22925190]|.

Another |FRAME: TAX-2336| pathway that leads to |FRAME: FRUCTURONATE| is the degradation of |FRAME: MYO-INOSITOL| |CITS: [23441918]|.

|FRAME: FRUCTURONATE| is converted in three steps (dehydrogenation, dehydration, and phosphorylation) to |FRAME: 2-KETO-3-DEOXY-6-P-GLUCONATE|, which is then cleaved by |FRAME: EC-4.1.2.14| to form the central metabolites |FRAME: PYRUVATE| and |FRAME: GAP|, leading to the TCA cycle and glycolysis (the last two steps are known as the |FRAME: PWY-2221 \"semi-phosphorylative Entner-Doudoroff pathway\"|)." "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY0-1298"	"superpathway of pyrimidine deoxyribonucleosides degradation"	"PWY0-1298"	"|FRAME:TAX-562| can use all three naturally occurring pyrimidine deoxyribonucleosides (deoxycytidine, deoxyuridine, and
thymidine) as total sources of carbon and energy.  Deoxyuridine and thymidine are cleaved by a specific
phosphorylase, yielding a pyrimidine base and D-deoxyribose-1-phosphate, which is converted to
D-deoxyribose-5-phosphate by a mutase that also can utilize D-ribose-1-phosphate as a substrate.  A specific
aldolase splits D-deoxyribose-5-phosphate, yielding D-glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate, which enters central
metabolism through the glycolytic pathway, and acetaldehyde, which must be converted to acetyl-CoA before it can
enter central metabolism.  It does so via the TCA cycle.  In contrast, |FRAME:TAX-562| lacks a specific phosphorylase
capable of cleaving deoxycytidine.  This nucleoside must be deaminated (thereby yielding deoxyuridine) before it can
be cleaved.

Although |FRAME:TAX-562| is able to utilize the deoxyribose moiety of deoxyribonucleosides, it is unable to utilize
exogenously supplied deoxyribose; however, the closely related organism |FRAME:TAX-90371| can.

The amino nitrogen of cytidine but not the ring-nitrogen of uracil or thymine, generated as by-products of this
pathway, can serve as a total nitrogen source for |FRAME:TAX-562| over its entire temperature range of growth.  However,
these ring nitrogens do become available to serve as total nitrogen sources at room temperature via a pathway
encoded by genes in the <i>rut</i> operon |CITS: [16540542]|.  

Review: Linn, E.C.C. Dissimilatory Pathways for Sugars, Polyols, and Carboxylates. |FRAME:TAX-562| and |FRAME:TAX-590|,
F.C. Neidhardt, Ed. |CITS:[ColiSalII]|

"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5695"	"inosine 5'-phosphate degradation"	"PWY-5695"	"Nitrogen is frequently the limiting nutrient for growth of many crop plants. Legumes solved this problem by establishing a symbiotic relationship with bacteria from the genus |FRAME: TAX-374|, which contain the enzyme nitrogenase.
Nitrogenase catalyzes the conversion of atmospheric |FRAME: NITROGEN-MOLECULE| to |FRAME: AMMONIA|, which can be used to meet the plant's metabolic nitrogen requirements (see |FRAME: N2FIX-PWY|).

The ammonia generated by the bacteria is first converted into the amino acid |FRAME:GLN| and then incorporated into |FRAME: IMP| (IMP), a purine synthesized <i>de novo</i> during nitrogen fixation by roots (see |FRAME: PWY-841|).

Before the fixed nitrogen can be used by the plant, it must be converted into organic forms that can be transported throughout the plant and further metabolized.
There are two major forms of organic nitrogen compounds that can be transported - amides (such as |FRAME:ASN| and |FRAME:GLN|) and ureides (such as |FRAME: ALLANTOIN| and |FRAME: ALLANTOATE|).
Temperate-region legumes, such as pea, are amide exporters, while legumes of tropical origin, such as soybean, kidney bean and peanut, export nitrogen in the form of ureides (see |FRAME: URSIN-PWY|). 

The pathway that is described here, the conversion of |FRAME:IMP| to |FRAME:URATE|, is part of the pathway leading to the production of ureides in plants. However, it is also a part of the degradation of purines, which is found in many organisms.
Many mammals, for example, can mineralize purines completely to TCA cycle building blocks in a pathway that includes this subpathway. Humans and apes possess this pathway, but do not have the enzyne urate oxidase (|FRAME: URATE-OXIDASE-RXN \"EC 1.7.3.3\"|, and thus accumulate urate, which has to be disposed of via urine."	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=URSIN-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6353"		"IMP degradation" // "urate biosynthesis"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Purine-Degradation"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Adenosine-Nucleotides-Degradation" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Guanosine-Nucleotides-Degradation" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6617" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=SALVADEHYPOX-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6596" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5044" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY0-1296" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6606" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6353" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6607" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7179" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6608" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5695" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6595" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7179-1" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6019" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5497" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=P164-PWY"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=NUCLEO-DEG"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Degradation"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY0-1296"	"purine ribonucleosides degradation"	"PWY0-1296"	"|FRAME:TAX-562| can use all four naturally occurring purine ribonucleosides (adenosine, guanosine, inosine and
xanthosine) as total sources of carbon and energy.  The first three (adenosine, guanosine, and inosine) are cleaved
by the same <i>deoD</i>-encoded phosphorylase, yielding the corresponding purine bases (adenine, guanine, and
hypoxanthine) and D-ribose-1-phosphate, which, after being converted to D-ribose-5-phosphate by a mutase that
also can utilize D-deoxyribose-1-phosphate as a substrate, enters central metabolism through the nonoxidative
branch of the pentose phosphate pathway.  In contrast, xanthosine is cleaved by a specific phosphorylase encoded
by <i>xapA</i> before it enters the same pathway.  Adenosine may be deaminated before it enters the pathway.

The amino nitrogens of adenosine and guanine, but not the ring-nitrogen of any of the four purines, generated as a
by-product of this pathway, can serve as a total nitrogen source for |FRAME:TAX-562|.  

Review: Linn, E.C.C. Dissimilatory Pathways for Sugars, Polyols, and Carboxylates. |FRAME:TAX-562| and |FRAME:TAX-590|, F.C. Neidhardt, Ed. |CITS:[COLISALII]|

Note that unlike the prokaryotic |FRAME: DEOD-CPLX|, |FRAME: ADENOSINE| is not a natural substrate for mammalian |FRAME: CPLX-6181| (in |CITS: [12180982]|).
"				"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Purine-Degradation"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Adenosine-Nucleotides-Degradation" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Guanosine-Nucleotides-Degradation" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6617" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=SALVADEHYPOX-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6596" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5044" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY0-1296" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6606" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6353" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6607" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7179" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6608" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5695" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6595" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7179-1" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6019" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5497" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=P164-PWY"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=NUCLEO-DEG"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Degradation"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PROTOCATECHUATE-ORTHO-CLEAVAGE-PWY"	"protocatechuate degradation II (ortho-cleavage pathway)"	"PROTOCATECHUATE-ORTHO-CLEAVAGE-PWY"	"<b>General Background</b>

|FRAME: 3-4-DIHYDROXYBENZOATE \"Protocatechuate\"| is one of the key intermediate metabolites in the microbial degradation of various aromatic compounds, including phthalates, hydroxybenzoates, and lignin-derived aromatic compounds such as |FRAME: VANILLATE| and |FRAME: FERULIC-ACID|.

The key step in these degradation pathways, the fission of the protocatechuate aromatic ring, can be catalyzed by one of the three distinct dioxygenases |FRAME: CPLX-2701|, |FRAME: CPLX-2721| and |FRAME: CPLX-7915|.
The fission products, and thus the degradation pathways, depend on the type of dioxygenase employed. The three pathways are described in |FRAME: P184-PWY|, |FRAME: PROTOCATECHUATE-ORTHO-CLEAVAGE-PWY| and |FRAME: PWY-6336|, respectively.

<b>About This Pathway</b>

The pathway that starts with |FRAME: CPLX-2721| is part of a pathway known as the |FRAME: PWY-5431 \"3-oxoadipate pathway\"| (or &beta;-ketoadipate pathway). It is widely distributed among soil bacteria and fungi |CITS: [8905091]|, although the pathway organization and regulation varies among species |CITS: [8905091]|.  

The &beta;-ketoadipate pathway is comprised of two parallel branches, one branch converts |FRAME: 3-4-DIHYDROXYBENZOATE| to |FRAME: 3-KETO-ADIPATE| and the other converts |FRAME: CATECHOL| to |FRAME: 3-KETO-ADIPATE|.  |FRAME: 3-KETO-ADIPATE| is then converted to |FRAME: SUC-COA| and |FRAME: ACETYL-COA|, which are processed by the TCA cycle.

A variety of aromatic compounds, such as 4-hydroxybenzoate and benzoate, are shuttled into the respective protocatechuate and catechol branches of the &beta;-ketoadipate pathway.

In |FRAME: TAX-303|, all of the enzymes involved in protocatechuate degradation via the &beta;-ketoadipate pathway are inducible |CITS: [5916393]|.  
Protocatechuate dioxygenase is induced by protocatechuate (as reported in |CITS: [8905091]|, 
and the remaining five enzymes, 3-carboxymuconate cycloisomerase, 4-carboxymuconolactone
decarboxylase, &beta;-ketoadipate enol-lactone hydrolase, &beta;-ketoadipate:succinyl-CoA transferase, and
&beta;-ketoadipyl CoA thiolase are induced by &beta;-ketoadipate |CITS: [5916393][8905091]|. 

The genes that encode for the synthesis of the regulatory proteins and the enzymes of the protocatechuate 
branch of the &beta;-ketoadipate pathway in <i>P. putida</i> are clustered into four distinct groups 
(as reported in |CITS: [7961399]|):  pcaHG |CITS: [8407791]|, 
pcaBDC |CITS: [1390752]|, pcaIJ |CITS: [8376330]|, and pcaRKF |CITS: [761399]|.  In 
|FRAME:TAX-471| the genes are arranged in gene cluster pcaIJFBDKCHG that is induced by
protocatechuate (as reported in |CITS: [7961399]|)."	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5181" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-2504" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5431"		"protocatechuate branch of the 3-oxoadipate pathway" // "protocatechuate branch of the 3-ketoadipate pathway" // "protocatechuate branch of the &beta;-ketoadipate pathway" // "protocatechuate degradation via ortho-cleavage" // "protocatechuate degradation via the &beta;-ketoadipate pathway" // "protocatechuate 3,4-cleavage"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Protocatechuate-Degradation"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PROTOCATECHUATE-ORTHO-CLEAVAGE-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6336" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=P184-PWY"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=AROMATIC-COMPOUNDS-DEGRADATION"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Degradation"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-4984"	"urea cycle"	"PWY-4984"	"Most organisms have to deal with the excretion of nitrogen waste originating from protein and amino acid catabolism. In aquatic organisms the most common form of nitrogen waste is ammonia (ammonotelism), while land-dwelling organisms developed ways to convert the toxic ammonia to either urea (ureotelism) or uric acid (uricotelism). Generally, birds and saurian reptiles excrete uric acid, while the remaining species, including mammals, excrete urea |CITS:[13672961][13672962]|. Remarkably, tadpoles excrete ammonia, and shift to urea production during metamorphosis
|CITS:[13672962]|.

The urea is formed in the livers of mammals in a cyclic pathway which was initially named the Krebs-Henseleit cycle after its discoverers, and later became known simply as the urea cycle. This cycle was partially deduced by Krebs and Henseleit in 1932 |CITS: [Krebs32]| and was clarified in the 1940s as the roles of citrulline and argininosuccinate as intermediates were understood |CITS:[3545062]|.

In this cycle, amino groups donated by |FRAME:AMMONIA| and |FRAME:L-ASPARTATE| are converted to |FRAME:UREA|, while |FRAME:L-ORNITHINE|, |FRAME:L-CITRULLINE|, |FRAME:L-ARGININO-SUCCINATE|, and |FRAME:ARG| act as intermediates.

Despite the generalization above, the pathway has been documented not only in mammals and amphibians, but in many other organisms as well, including birds |CITS:[4217066]|, invertebrates |CITS:[14465664][5869779]|, insects |CITS: [697760][5791517]|, plants |CITS: [13741005] [13958361]|, yeast |CITS:[11946245]|, fungi |CITS:[4996649]|, and even microorganisms |CITS:[5593971][5709377]|." "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=P161-PWY"	"acetylene degradation"	"P161-PWY"	"Aerobic bacteria that can utilize |FRAME: ACETYLENE| for growth have been reported several
times in the literature, although not often |CITS: [Birch32][37235][DeBont80][Tam83][Germon88][9084145]|.
Certain anaerobic bacteria are also able to utilize |FRAME: ACETYLENE| for growth |CITS: [16345714]|.
Several strains of strictly anaerobic bacteria that can use  |FRAME: ACETYLENE| as a sole carbon
and energy source were purified from marine and freshwater sediments, and were described as a new
species in the genus |FRAME:TAX-18| |CITS: [Schink1985]|.

In all cases where the pathway has been investigated, |FRAME: ACETALD| was shown to be
an intermediate, and |FRAME:ACET| a product |CITS: [DeBont80]|.
|FRAME: TAX-29542| converts |FRAME: ACETYLENE| to |FRAME: ACETALD| by a unique
tungsten-containing enzyme, |FRAME: MONOMER-941|. Other acetylene hydratase enzymes
from aerobic organisms have been shown to be molybdenum enzymes that do not cross-react with
antibodies raised against the |FRAME: TAX-29542| enzyme, suggesting that acetylene hydratases
are a biochemically heterogenous group of enzymes |CITS: [9084145]|.

|FRAME: ACETALD| is only an intermediate in the pathway, and is subsequently converted to other compounds.
In all cases that have been studied |FRAME:ACET| is formed. In the case of |FRAME: TAX-29542|,
|FRAME: ACETALD| is also converted to |FRAME:ETOH| |CITS: [Schink1985]|.
Though the hydration of acetylene to acetaldehyde is highly exergonic, studies on cell yield in this
organism showed that only the free energy of the |FRAME: MONOMER-13297| reaction (0.5 mol ATP per
mol acetylene) is used for growth |CITS: [Schink1985]|.

Other substrates that are utilized by |FRAME: TAX-29542| include |FRAME: ACETOIN|,
|FRAME: ETHANOL-AMINE|, |FRAME: CHOLINE|, |FRAME: DL-12-Propanediol| and
|FRAME:GLYCEROL| |CITS: [Schink1985]|." "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=FERMENTATION-PWY"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=CARBOXYLATES-DEG" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=FAO-PWY"	"fatty acid &beta;-oxidation I"	"FAO-PWY"	"The catabolism of fatty acids proceeds via several routes, which depend on the length of the acids, whether the number of carbons is odd or even, and whether they are saturated or unsaturated. This pathway represents the \"core\" cycle of &beta;-oxidation, a mechanism that removes two carbon atoms with each turn of the cycle. 

Saturated fatty acids that are routed into this core pathway are processed until only two or three carbons remain. When even-numbered fatty acids are broken down, the final product is the two-carbon compound |FRAME: ACETYL-COA|, which is a basic intermediate of central metabolism, and can be routed into the |FRAME: TCA \"TCA cycle\"| for complete catabolism or routed into the |FRAME: GLYOXYLATE-BYPASS| to be used for biosynthesis.
When odd number fatty acids are broken down, the final product of the pathway is the three-carbon compound |FRAME: PROPIONYL-COA|, which in |FRAME:TAX-562| is carboxylated to |FRAME: Methylmalonyl-CoA| and converted to |FRAME: SUC-COA| (see |FRAME: PROPIONMET-PWY|). 

Unsaturated fatty acids with <i>cis</i> double bonds located at odd-numbered carbon atoms enter the main pathway after a modification (see |FRAME: PWY-5137|). When <i>cis</i> double bonds are located at even-numbered carbon atoms (such as in |FRAME: LINOLEIC_ACID|), the acids are modified by a different route (see |FRAME: PWY-5138|).

Although enzymes of the pathway handle both short and long chain fatty acids, it is the long chain compounds that induce the enzymes of the pathway |CITS: [6271734]|. 

<b>The pathway under anaerobic conditions</b>

In the facultative anaerobic bacterium |FRAME:TAX-562| the pathway can proceed under anaerobic conditions |CITS: [12535077]|. The enzymatic steps are identical, and the main difference is that the product of the pathway, acetyl-CoA, is oxidized using fumarate as the terminal electron acceptor |CITS: [15213221]|. However, a different set of enzymes is active under anaerobic conditions. In the anaerobic pathway FadI, FadJ, and FadK serve functions parallel to those of FadA, FadB, and FadD in the aerobic pathway |CITS: [12535077]|. In contrast to the aerobic pathway, octanoate and decanoate can serve as substrates for the anaerobic fatty acid oxidation pathway |CITS: [12535077]|. 

The |FRAME: GLYOXYLATE-BYPASS| is necessary under both anaerobic and aerobic conditions of fatty acid oxidation to provide the carbon and energy for cell growth |CITS: [12535077]|."				"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Fatty-Acid-Degradation"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-2724" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY0-1337" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7338" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7292" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6837" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5136" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY66-387" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=FAO-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7339" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7307" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7288" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5137" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY66-388" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-2501" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7340" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7337" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7291" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5138" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY66-391"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Fatty-Acid-and-Lipid-Degradation"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Degradation"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5415"	"catechol degradation I (<I>meta</I>-cleavage pathway)"	"PWY-5415"	"The <i>meta</i>-cleavage pathway of catechol is one of the major pathways for the degradation of
aromatic compounds. Its importance has been well demonstrated in bacteria of many
genera, including species of <i>Azotobacter</i>, <i>Ralstonia</i> and numerous species of
<i>Pseudomonas</i>. 

The most comprehensively studied <i>meta</i>-cleavage pathway is that of the TOL plasmid pWWO,
which encodes a toluene degradation pathway in |FRAME: TAX-303|.
The genes are located in an operon that encodes the enzymes for conversion of benzoate to catechol,
and catechol to the cenrtal metabolites pyruvate and acetaldehyde |CITS: [2183008]|.

|FRAME: CATECHOL \"Catechol\"| itself is an intermediate in the degradation of many different aromatic compounds.
In addition to |FRAME:BENZOATE|, including toluate, |FRAME:NAPHTHALENE|, |FRAME:CPD-110|, and |FRAME: PHENOL|, and substituted catechols are intermediates in the catabolism of methylated and chlorinated derivatives
of these compounds.

In this pathway, the aromatic ring of |FRAME:CATECHOL| is cleaved by the enzyme |FRAME:CPLX-2841|
adjacent to the two catechol hydroxyls.
The product of this cleavage, |FRAME:HYDROXYMUCONATE-SALD|, can be metabolized in two routes. In the variant described in this pathway, it is hydrolyzed by |FRAME:MONOMER-12763|, generating the important intermediate |FRAME:OXOPENTENOATE| in a single step.

In the second variant (see |FRAME:PWY-5420|), |FRAME:HYDROXYMUCONATE-SALD| is dehydrogenated by |FRAME:CPLX-7245| to the enol-form of 4-oxalocrotonate, which is then isomerized by |FRAME:CPLX-7237| to the keto-form, and decarboxylated by |FRAME:CPLX-7239|. The later is in a tight complex with the enzyme |FRAME: CPLX-7240|. It's product, |FRAME:CPD-6761|, is an unstable tautomer of |FRAME:OXOPENTENOATE|. This product is transferred to |FRAME: CPLX-7240| within the complex.

Thus, the two variants, which separated at |FRAME:HYDROXYMUCONATE-SALD|, join again at
|FRAME:OXOPENTENOATE| (or its tautomer |FRAME:CPD-6761|).
The hydrolase-based variant is the preferred route for 3-substituted catechols, while the dehydrogenase-based route is the preferred route for non-substituted and 4-substituted catechols |CITS: [7890778]|.

|FRAME:OXOPENTENOATE| is metabolized to pyruvate and acetaldehyde (and eventually, acetyl-coA) by successive action of the enzymes |FRAME:CPLX-7240|, |FRAME:MONOMER-12778| and |FRAME:MONOMER-12780|. The last two enzymes form a |FRAME: CPLX-7250| complex, which facilitates the transfer of the toxic acetaldehyde intermediate between them |CITS: [8419288]|." "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=CATECHOL-ORTHO-CLEAVAGE-PWY"	"catechol degradation to &beta;-ketoadipate"	"CATECHOL-ORTHO-CLEAVAGE-PWY"	"|FRAME: CATECHOL| can be degraded in several possible routes, including this route via
|FRAME:3-KETO-ADIPATE|.
For more information about this pathway, please see |FRAME: PWY-5417|."	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-2504" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5431" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6182" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5417"		"catechol degradation, ortho-cleavage"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Catechol-Degradation"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5419" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=P183-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5420" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5415" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5431" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5417" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=CATECHOL-ORTHO-CLEAVAGE-PWY"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=AROMATIC-COMPOUNDS-DEGRADATION"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Degradation"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5417"	"catechol degradation III (ortho-cleavage pathway)"	"PWY-5417"	"Catechol can be degraded via either of two routes: the <i>meta</i> cleavage pathway
(see |FRAME:PWY-5430|), or the <i>ortho</i>-cleavage pathway (this pathway).
When degraded by this pathway, catechol is cleaved between the two ring hydroxyls by the enzyme
|FRAME:CPLX-2842| forming |FRAME:CIS-CIS-MUCONATE|, which is then further metabolyzed in three
steps to the important intermediate |FRAME:3-KETO-ADIPATE|.

|FRAME:3-KETO-ADIPATE| is a convergence point of the two branches of the &beta;-ketoadipate
pathway (see |FRAME:PWY-5431|); one of the branches is this pathway, while the other one starts
with protocatechuate (see |FRAME:PROTOCATECHUATE-ORTHO-CLEAVAGE-PWY|.
Once &beta;-Ketoadipate is formed, it is converted to succinyl-CoA and acetyl-CoA.  

The pathway is widely distributed among soil bacteria and fungi, even though its
organization and regulation vary among species |CITS:[15421941][8905091][3941043][16885292]|.
For example, in |FRAME: TAX-303| the genes that encode the regulatory proteins and the enzymes
of this pathway are clustered into two distinct groups |CITS: [761399]|, while in |FRAME: TAX-471| they
are arranged in a single cluster induced by protocatechuate |CITS: [7961399]|.

In |FRAME: TAX-303| the enzymes involved in &beta;-ketoadipate degradation
(|FRAME:CPLX-2722|, and |FRAME:CPLX-7260|) are inducible by |FRAME:3-KETO-ADIPATE|
|CITS: [5916393]|." "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5431"	"aromatic compounds degradation via &beta;-ketoadipate"	"PWY-5431"	"The intermediate role of |FRAME:3-KETO-ADIPATE| in the oxidative metabolism of aromatic compounds
by bacteria was first suggested by Kilby, who reported its accumulation in cultures of
|FRAME:TAX-475| growing on phenol |CITS: [Kilby48]|.
This observation was confirmed by the demonstration that cell-free extracts of |FRAME: TAX-303|,
induced by growth on aromatic precursors, can convert both catechol or protocatechuate
to |FRAME:3-KETO-ADIPATE| |CITS: [15421941]|.

The pathway is widely distributed among bacteria |CITS: [4599397]|. It consists of two parallel branches
for the dissimilation of |FRAME: 3-4-DIHYDROXYBENZOATE| and |FRAME:CATECHOL|.
While the enzymes of the pathway from different microorganisms share common ancestry
|CITS:[4199895][4199896][4215816]|, many different gene organizations
and forms of regulation have evolved |CITS: [1624453]|." "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY66-5"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=AROMATIC-COMPOUNDS-DEGRADATION" //
