"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=NIL&object=Generalized-Reactions"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5022"	"4-aminobutanoate degradation V"	"PWY-5022"	"<b>General Background</b>

|FRAME: 4-AMINO-BUTYRATE|  (GABA) is the major inhibitory neurotransmitter in the mammalian brain.  Recent
findings suggest that GABA has a role as a signal molecule in plants as well |CITS: [15003233]|. In animals and plants GABA is produced by the cytosolic enzyme |FRAME: GLUTDECARBOX-RXN \"glutamate decarboxylase\"|.

The most common path for GABA degradation involves transamination to |FRAME:SUCC-S-ALD|, followed by oxidation to |FRAME: SUC|. Diiferent variants of both enzymes are known. The amino-group acceptor for the transamination can be either |FRAME: 2-KETOGLUTARATE| (e.g. in mammalian brain |CITS: [13044808]|) or |FRAME:PYRUVATE| (e.g. in the plant |FRAME: ORG-5862| |CITS: [Vancauwenberghe02]|). Different variants of the second enzyme, succinate semialdehyde dehydrogenase, were shown to possess different cofactor requirement, for either NAD+, NADP+, or NAD(P)+.

The action of glutamate decarboxylase, &gamma;-aminobutyrate aminotransferase and succinate semialdehyde
dehydrogenase, combined, defines a short pathway known as the \"GABA shunt\", since it can channel glutamate into the |FRAME: TCA|, bypassing two steps of that cycle.  

While there is no evidence for a special role for GABA in bacteria, the capabillity to degrade it exists in many strains.  GABA is present in the environment as a product of plant and animal tissue decay, and many bacteria can synthesize GABA as an intermediate in the degradation of putrescine (see |FRAME: Putrescine-Degradation \"putrescine degradation\"|). 
The first indication for a bacterial pathway for GABA degradation was found in |FRAME: TAX-294|
|CITS:[13654294][13654295]|.  While some organisms, like |FRAME: TAX-294|, can grow on GABA as the sole carbon and nitrogen source, others, such as |FRAME: TAX-1423|, can grow on it only as a nitrogen source |CITS: [8951816][12123465]|.

<b>About This Pathway</b>

When the fate of |FRAME: 4-AMINO-BUTYRATE| was studied in |FRAME: TAX-1511|, a strict anaerobe isolated from North Carolina swamp mud |CITS:[14399736]|, a different pathway was observed.
Among the products produced by this strain were |FRAME:4-HYDROXY-BUTYRATE|, |FRAME:AMMONIA|, and |FRAME:ACET|. While the first step of the pathway was found to be identical to that in |FRAME: TAX-294|, the second
step was different: In |FRAME: TAX-1511| |FRAME:SUCC-S-ALD| is converted to |FRAME:4-HYDROXY-BUTYRATE|. The |FRAME:GLT| formed during the transamination of |FRAME: 4-AMINO-BUTYRATE| is converted back to |FRAME: 2-KETOGLUTARATE|, liberating |FRAME:AMMONIA| in the process |CITS:[13952769]|.

Recently the |FRAME: G-10272|, |FRAME: G-10271|  and |FRAME: G-10270| genes, encoding |FRAME: MONOMER-13486|, |FRAME: CPLX-7514| and |FRAME: CPLX-7515|, respectively, were cloned and expressed in |FRAME:TAX-562| |CITS: [11041350]|. These are the first |FRAME: TAX-33953| proteins with a known gene sequence.
"			"GABA degradation" // "4-aminobutyrate degradation V" // "4-aminobutanoic acid degradation V"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=4-Aminobutyraye-Degradation" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Acetyl-CoA-Butyrate"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6536" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6537" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6473" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=4AMINOBUTMETAB-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6535" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=GLUDEG-I-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5022" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=GLUDEG-II-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5676" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=P163-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=CENTFERM-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=P162-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5677"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=AMINE-DEG" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Fermentation-to-Acids"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Degradation" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Fermentation"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PYRIDOXSYN-PWY"	"pyridoxal 5'-phosphate biosynthesis I"	"PYRIDOXSYN-PWY"	"<b>General Background</b>

|FRAME: Vitamins-B6 Vitamin B6| is a group term for |FRAME:PYRIDOXAL| (PL), |FRAME:PYRIDOXINE| (PN), |FRAME:PYRIDOXAMINE| (PM) and their 5'-phosphorylated derivatives |FRAME:PYRIDOXAL_PHOSPHATE| (PLP), |FRAME:PYRIDOXINE-5P| (PNP) and |FRAME:PYRIDOXAMINE-5P| (PMP), which are also referred to as vitamers. Pyridoxal 5'-phosphate (PLP) is the biochemically active form, and is an essential cofactor in all living systems |CITS: [7748903]|. It plays an important role in amino acid and carbohydrate metabolism and has recently been implicated in singlet oxygen resistance |CITS: [11701851]|.  Most bacteria, archaebacteria, fungi, and plants synthesize PLP in a single reaction, as described in |FRAME: PWY-6466|, although some bacteria, such as |FRAME:TAX-562|, use a longer, more complex pathway (|FRAME: PYRIDOXSYN-PWY|) |CITS: [9696782][12896974]|. Animals do not synthesize this compound, making it an essential nutrient in their diet.

PLP is an essential cofactor of numerous metabolic enzymes, predominantly in amino acid metabolism. It is one of the most versatile cofactors and participates in transamination, decarboxylation, racemization, C&alpha;-C&beta; cleavage and &alpha;-&beta; elimination reactions. In humans this vitamin has a role in numerous functions ranging from modulation of hormone function to potent antioxidant activity.

<b>About This Pathway</b>

The biosynthesis of this vitamin was thoroughly studied in |FRAME:TAX-562| and involves two branches with seven enzymatic steps. In one branch, the sequential action of the enzymes Epd, PdxB and SerC results in the convesrion of erythrose 4-phosphate into 4-phosphohydroxy-L-threonine. The latter then undergoes oxidation and decarboxylation by PdxA to form 3-hydroxy-1-aminoacetone phosphate. In the other branch, deoxyxylulose 5-phosphate (DXP) is derived from glyceraldehyde 3-phosphate (GAP) and pyruvate by the action of Dxs. The products of the two branches, i.e. 3-hydroxy-1-aminoacetone phosphate and DXP, are then condensed by PdxJ to form PNP, which enters the salvage pathway to undergo oxidation by PdxH to form the PLP cofactor.

From the six pdx genes, two of them, <i>epd</i> and <i>serC</i>, are involved in other metabolic processes, but <i>pdxA</i>, <i>pdxB</i>, <i>pdxJ</i> and <i>pdxH</i> are unique for PLP biosynthesis |CITS: [1537800]|. PdxJ, the PNP synthase is the key ezyme that catalyzes a multistep ring closure yielding PNP and inorganic phosphate (Pi). This is the last step in the <i>de novo</i> synthetic pathway.

This topic has been reviewed in |CITS: [17822383][15242009][12686115]|.

An alternative DXP-independent pathway for PNP biosynthesis is described at |FRAME: PWY-6466|."	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY0-845"		"vitamin B<sub>6</sub> biosynthesis"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Vitamin-B6-Biosynthesis"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY0-845" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PLPSAL-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PYRIDOXSYN-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6466" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7204"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Vitamin-Biosynthesis"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Cofactor-Biosynthesis"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6708"	"ubiquinol-8 biosynthesis (prokaryotic)"	"PWY-6708"	"<b>General Background</b>

|FRAME: Ubiquinones Ubiquinone| (also known as coenzyme Q) is an isoprenoid quinone that functions as an electron carrier in membranes. In eukaryotes ubiquinone is found mostly within the inner mitochondrial membrane, where it functions in respiratory electron transport, transferring two electrons from either complex I (NADH dehydrogenase) or complex II (succinate-ubiquinone reductase) to complex III (<i>bc</i><sub>1</sub> complex). The quinone nucleus of ubiquinone is derived directly from |FRAME: 4-hydroxybenzoate|, while the isoprenoid subunits of the polyisoprenoid tail are synthesized via either a |FRAME: MEP-Pathways \"\"methylerythritol phosphate pathway\"| or a |FRAME: Mevalonate-Pathways \"mevalonate pathway\"|, which feed isoprene units into the |FRAME: Polyprenyl-Biosynthesis| pathways.

The number of isoprenoid subunits in the ubiquinone side chain vary in different species. For example, |FRAME: TAX-4932| has 6 such subunits, |FRAME: TAX-83333| has 8, rat and mouse have 9, and |FRAME: TAX-9606| has 10. The ubiquinones are often named according to the number of carbons in the side chain (e.g. ubi-30) or the number of isoprenoid subunits (e.g. Q-10).

Following addition of the polyprenyl tail, the product (4-hydroxy-3-polyprenylbenzoate), is processed in three steps, namely decarboxylation, oxidation, and methylation. The prokaryotic and eukaryotic pathways differ in the order of these steps: in eukaryotes the compound is oxidized and methylated prior to decarboxylation; in prokaryotes the compound is first decarboxylated, followed by oxidation and methylation |CITS: [Shepherd96]|.

The ubiquinone biosynthesis pathway has been elucidated primarily by the use of mutant strains that accumulate pathway intermediates; some of the enzymes in this pathway have not been biochemically characterized.

<b>About This Pathway</b>

|FRAME: UBIQUINONE-8 Ubiquinone 8| (Q-8) is a common form of ubiquinone among bacteria. Most of the Gram-negative facultative anaerobes, such as the enterobacteria, produce Q-8 (in addition to |FRAME: CPD-9728| and |FRAME: DEMETHYLMENAQUINONE|). Q-8 has been documented in several strains of |FRAME: TAX-562| |CITS: [13673033]|,
|FRAME: TAX-546|, |FRAME: TAX-548|, |FRAME: TAX-554|, |FRAME: TAX-584|, |FRAME: TAX-585| |CITS: [4886765]| and |FRAME: TAX-615| |CITS: [Bezborodov69]|, as well as in the non-eneterobacteria |FRAME: TAX-644|, |FRAME: TAX-648| |CITS: [4886765]| and |FRAME: TAX-51367| |CITS: [Collins81]|. It is also common in aerobic Gram-negative bacteria, including |FRAME: TAX-354| |CITS:[13673033] [4288128]|, |FRAME: TAX-353| |CITS: [13869492]|, |FRAME: TAX-107673| |CITS: [Denis75]|, |FRAME: TAX-520| |CITS: [4351160]|, |FRAME: TAX-106590| |CITS: [Yamada68]|, and various
|FRAME: TAX-338| strains |CITS: [Ikemoto80]|. Q-8 was also found to be the major quinone in an unidentified strain of the gliding bacterium |FRAME: TAX-1021| |CITS: [Carr67]| and in some phototrophic bacteria, including |FRAME:TAX-1049|
|CITS:[14240125]|, |FRAME:TAX-1053|, |FRAME: TAX-28068| |CITS: [Carr65][5727384]|, and a strain of |FRAME: TAX-1081| |CITS: [5727384]|. Q-8 is often found as a secondary quinone in |FRAME: TAX-286| strains |CITS: [4886765]|.

The best studied ubiquinone biosynthesis pathway is that of |FRAME: TAX-83333|, which produces a |FRAME: UBIQUINONE-8|. The first committed step of the pathway is the conversion of chorismate to |FRAME: 4-hydroxybenzoate|
by |FRAME: CHORPYRLY-MONOMER|. The enzyme retains and is efficiently inhibited by the product of the reaction, 4-hydroxybenzoate, which may present a control mechanism for the ubiquinone biosynthesis pathway or a mechanism for delivery of 4-hydroxybenzoate to the membrane |CITS: [11455603][11825618]|.

The second step in the pathway is the transfer of the polyisoprenoid tail onto |FRAME: 4-hydroxybenzoate| by the membrane-bound |FRAME: 4OHBENZOATE-OCTAPRENYLTRANSFER-MONOMER|. This is followed by the
decarboxylation of the ring structure by |FRAME: CPLX0-301| (or possibly by UbiX) to form |FRAME: 2-OCTAPRENYLPHENOL|.  Under anaerobic conditions, this compound accumulates in the membrane and is not converted into ubiquinone. Further steps in the pathway require the presence of dioxygen |CITS: [361395]|.

Following is the alternating introduction of three hydroxyl- and three methyl groups. With the exception of the methyltransferase that catalyzes both of the <i>O</i>-methyltransferase reactions, UbiG, none of the enzymes have been studied biochemically and their substrate and cofactor requirements are still unknown. The hydroxylation reactions are catalyzed by different types of enzymes in different bacterial clades. some bacteria, such as |FRAME: TAX-562|, have three enzymes, each dedicated to one of the three hydroxylation events. In some organisms two hydroxylases catalyze the three reactions, yet in some organism a single enzyme, encoded by the ubiM gene, catalyzes all three reactions |CITS: [27822549]|. 

The enzymes of this pathway may form a membrane-associated complex |CITS: [393264]|. UbiX shows a genetic interaction with UbiG, suggesting a possible physical interaction within a complex |CITS: [16923914]|.

For the biosynthesis of |FRAME: UBIQUINONE-8| in yeast, see |FRAME: PWY-5870|."	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=UBISYN-PWY"		"ubiquinone-8 biosynthesis (prokaryotic)"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Ubiquinone-Biosynthesis"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7233" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5873" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5870" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5855" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6708" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5871" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5856" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7235" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY3O-19" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7230" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5872" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5857" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=UBISYN-PWY"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Quinone-Biosynthesis"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Cofactor-Biosynthesis"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5857"	"ubiquinol-10 biosynthesis (prokaryotic)"	"PWY-5857"	"<b>General Background</b>

|FRAME: Ubiquinones Ubiquinone| (also known as coenzyme Q) is an isoprenoid quinone that functions as an electron carrier in membranes. In eukaryotes ubiquinone is found mostly within the inner mitochondrial membrane, where it functions in respiratory electron transport, transferring two electrons from either complex I (NADH dehydrogenase) or complex II (succinate-ubiquinone reductase) to complex III (<i>bc</i><sub>1</sub> complex). The quinone nucleus of ubiquinone is derived directly from |FRAME: 4-hydroxybenzoate|, while the isoprenoid subunits of the polyisoprenoid tail are synthesized via either a |FRAME: MEP-Pathways \"\"methylerythritol phosphate pathway\"| or a |FRAME: Mevalonate-Pathways \"mevalonate pathway\"|, which feed isoprene units into the |FRAME: Polyprenyl-Biosynthesis| pathways.

The number of isoprenoid subunits in the ubiquinone side chain vary in different species. For example, |FRAME: TAX-4932| has 6 such subunits, |FRAME: TAX-83333| has 8, rat and mouse have 9, and |FRAME: TAX-9606| has 10. The ubiquinones are often named according to the number of carbons in the side chain (e.g. ubi-30) or the number of isoprenoid subunits (e.g. Q-10).

Following addition of the polyprenyl tail, the product (4-hydroxy-3-polyprenylbenzoate), is processed in three steps, namely decarboxylation, oxidation, and methylation. The prokaryotic and eukaryotic pathways differ in the order of these steps: in eukaryotes the compound is oxidized and methylated prior to decarboxylation; in prokaryotes the compound is first decarboxylated, followed by oxidation and methylation |CITS: [Shepherd96]|.

The ubiquinone biosynthesis pathway has been elucidated primarily by the use of mutant strains that accumulate pathway intermediates; some of the enzymes in this pathway have not been biochemically characterized.

<b>About This Pathway</b>

|FRAME: UBIQUINONE-10 Ubiquinone-10| (Q-10) has been described in many bacterial species that belong to the ||FRAME: TAX-28211|. Species that were found to contain Q-10 as their major quinone include |FRAME: TAX-358| |CITS: [12501289]|, |FRAME: TAX-235| |CITS: [Thiele69]| and |FRAME: TAX-29459| |CITS: [4351160]|, |FRAME: TAX-318683|, |FRAME:TAX-38307| and |FRAME:TAX-28448| |CITS:[Yamada69]|, |FRAME: TAX-266| |CITS: [14429752][4296023][12501289]|, |FRAME: TAX-375| |CITS: [Daniel79]|, and the purple bacteria |FRAME: TAX-1061|, |FRAME: TAX-1063| and |FRAME: TAX-1076| |CITS: [5862408][4147456][5727384]| and |FRAME: TAX-1085| |CITS: [172493][12501289]|.

Since Q-10 is the only quinone found in humans, and since it has been suggested that administration of Q-10 has a positive effect for various diseases (for example, |CITS: [7612003]|), there has been an interest in the utilization of bacterial Q-10 producers for the manufacture of this compound |CITS: [12501289][16528515][16797569][16815062][17124579]|.

Various microorganisms, including bacteria (e.g. Agrobacterium, Rhodobacter, Paracoccus) and yeasts (e.g. Candida, Rhodotorula, Saitoella) have been reported as Q-10 producers in patented laid-open applications |CITS: [Yajima03][25817210]|. A review of the biotechnological production of Q-10 is found in |CITS: [15744486]|.

For the biosynthesis of Q-10 in eukaryotes see |FRAME: PWY-5872|." "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5856"	"ubiquinol-9 biosynthesis (prokaryotic)"	"PWY-5856"	"<b>General Background</b>

|FRAME: Ubiquinones Ubiquinone| (also known as coenzyme Q) is an isoprenoid quinone that functions as an electron carrier in membranes. In eukaryotes ubiquinone is found mostly within the inner mitochondrial membrane, where it functions in respiratory electron transport, transferring two electrons from either complex I (NADH dehydrogenase) or complex II (succinate-ubiquinone reductase) to complex III (<i>bc</i><sub>1</sub> complex). The quinone nucleus of ubiquinone is derived directly from |FRAME: 4-hydroxybenzoate|, while the isoprenoid subunits of the polyisoprenoid tail are synthesized via either a |FRAME: MEP-Pathways \"\"methylerythritol phosphate pathway\"| or a |FRAME: Mevalonate-Pathways \"mevalonate pathway\"|, which feed isoprene units into the |FRAME: Polyprenyl-Biosynthesis| pathways.

The number of isoprenoid subunits in the ubiquinone side chain vary in different species. For example, |FRAME: TAX-4932| has 6 such subunits, |FRAME: TAX-83333| has 8, rat and mouse have 9, and |FRAME: TAX-9606| has 10. The ubiquinones are often named according to the number of carbons in the side chain (e.g. ubi-30) or the number of isoprenoid subunits (e.g. Q-10).

Following addition of the polyprenyl tail, the product (4-hydroxy-3-polyprenylbenzoate), is processed in three steps, namely decarboxylation, oxidation, and methylation. The prokaryotic and eukaryotic pathways differ in the order of these steps: in eukaryotes the compound is oxidized and methylated prior to decarboxylation; in prokaryotes the compound is first decarboxylated, followed by oxidation and methylation |CITS: [Shepherd96]|.

The ubiquinone biosynthesis pathway has been elucidated primarily by the use of mutant strains that accumulate pathway intermediates; some of the enzymes in this pathway have not been biochemically characterized.

<b>About This Pathway</b>

|FRAME: UBIQUINONE-9| (Q-9) is the major quinone of several large families of aerobic Gram-negative bacteria, including the the &gamma;-proteobacteria |FRAME: TAX-135621| |CITS:[13869492][13673033] [14429752][4886765 ]| and the phototrophic &alpha;-proteobacteria |FRAME: TAX-41295| |CITS:[13673033][5727384][Sasaki79]|. Pseudomonads are known to have ubiquinones exclusively |CITS: [6774977]| (while Q-9 is their major form, they often produce smaller amounts of Q-6, Q-7 and Q-8). Members of the |FRAME: TAX-41295| family, on the other hand, were reported to also produce menaquinones, such as MK-9 |CITS: [5727384]|.

Q-9 is also common in fungi and animals. For discussion of its biosynthesis in eukaryotic organisms, see |FRAME: PWY-5871|."			"Q9 biosynthesis" // "ubiquinone-9 biosynthesis (prokaryotic)"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Ubiquinone-Biosynthesis"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7233" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5873" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5870" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5855" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6708" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5871" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5856" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7235" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY3O-19" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7230" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5872" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5857" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=UBISYN-PWY"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Quinone-Biosynthesis"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Cofactor-Biosynthesis"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5855"	"ubiquinol-7 biosynthesis (prokaryotic)"	"PWY-5855"	"<b>General Background</b>

Ubiquinone (also known as coenzyme Q) is an isoprenoid quinone that functions as an electron carrier
in membranes.
In eukaryotes ubiquinone is found mostly within the inner mitochondrial membrane, where it functions
in respiratory electron transport, transferring two electrons from either complex I (NADH dehydrogenase)
or complex II (succinate-ubiquinone reductase) to complex III (<i>bc</i><sub>1</sub> complex).
The quinone nucleus of ubiquinone is derived directly from |FRAME: 4-hydroxybenzoate|, while the
isoprenoid subunits of the polyisoprenoid tail are synthesized via the |FRAME: NONMEVIPP-PWY|,
which feeds isoprene units into the |FRAME: Polyprenyl-Biosynthesis| pathways.

The number of isoprenoid subunits in the ubiquinone side chain vary in different species. For example,
|FRAME: TAX-4932| has 6 such subunits, |FRAME: TAX-83333| has 8, rat and mouse have 9, and
|FRAME: TAX-9606| has 10. The ubiquinones are often named according to the number of carbons in
the side chain (e.g. ubi-30) or the number of isoprenoid subunits (e.g. Q-10).

Following addition of the polyprenyl tail, the product (4-hydroxy-3-polyprenylbenzoate), is processed
in three steps, namely decarboxylation, oxidation, and methylation. The prokaryotic and eukaryotic
pathways differ in the order of these steps: in eukaryotes the compound is oxidized and methylated
prior to decarboxylation; in prokaryotes the compound is first decarboxylated, followed by oxidation
and methylation |CITS: [Shepherd96]|.

The ubiquinone biosynthesis pathway has been elucidated primarily by the use of mutant strains that
accumulate pathway intermediates; some of the enzymes in this pathway have not been biochemically
characterized.

<b>About This Pathway</b>

|FRAME: CPD-9717| (Q-7) is not common in bacteria. The only bacterium that was found to use Q-7
as its main quinone is the phototrophic bacterium |FRAME: ORG-6034| |CITS:[13673033][Takamiya75]|.
Other species were reported to contain small amounts of Q-7 in addition to their major form of ubiquinone.
For example, 10% of the ubiquinone in |FRAME:TAX-562| was found to be Q-7 |CITS: [4861596]|.
Small amounts of Q-7 were also reported in |FRAME: TAX-303|, |FRAME: TAX-294|, |FRAME: TAX-86179|,
|FRAME: TAX-296| and |FRAME: TAX-339| |CITS: [4886765][5797102][5420949]|.

Q-7 is much more common in yeast. Many strains of |FRAME: TAX-5475|, |FRAME: TAX-4919| and
|FRAME: TAX-4962| form Q-7 (see |FRAME: PWY-5873|)."			"ubiquinone-7 biosynthesis (prokaryotic)"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Ubiquinone-Biosynthesis"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7233" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5873" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5870" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5855" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6708" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5871" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5856" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7235" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY3O-19" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7230" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5872" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5857" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=UBISYN-PWY"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Quinone-Biosynthesis"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Cofactor-Biosynthesis"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5863"	"superpathway of phylloquinol biosynthesis"	"PWY-5863"	"<b>General Background</b>

Phylloquinone (vitamin K1, 2-methyl-3-phytyl-1,4-naphthoquinone) acts as the electron 
transfer cofactor A1 of photosystem I (PS I) in higher plants and cyanobacteria. In non-photosynthetic
microbes the very similar compound |FRAME: Menaquinones| plays an
essential role in several anaerobic electron transport systems |CITS: [8626063]|.
The chemical structure of menaquinone (vitamin K2)  exhibits a partly unsaturated side chain consisting
most often 7 prenyl units, whereas phylloquinone consists of a mostly saturated phytyl side chain of
4 units |CITS: [15686525]|.

The biosynthesis of phylloquinone was studied in detail in the cyanobacterium |FRAME: TAX-1148| and
the genes encoding enzymes of this pathway were identified by comparison with genes encoding
enzymes of the menaquinone biosynthetic pathway in |FRAME:TAX-562|
(see |FRAME:MENAQUINONESYN-PWY|) |CITS: [8626063]|. With the isolation and functional
confirmation of the homolog genes in |FRAME:TAX-1142| encoding for |FRAME: MONOMER-13822|,
|FRAME: MONOMER-13896| |CITS: [10722690]|, |FRAME: MONOMER-13821|
|CITS:[11772039]|, |FRAME: MONOMER-13897| and |FRAME: MONOMER-11678| |CITS: [JOHNSON03]|,
most of the enzymatic steps of the phylloquinone bisoynthesis have been determined and proven to be highly
identical with those in the menaquinone biosynthesis.

The biosynthesis of certain components of the multienzyme complex PS I (such as phylloquinone)
in cyanobacteria and plants have been found to follow analogous routes, including corresponding
enzymatic activities |CITS: [HEIDE82]| |CITS: [KOLKMANN87][SIMANTIRAS89][SIMANTIRAS91]|,
reflecting the phylogenetic origin of PS I in photosynthetic microbes.  

<b>About This Pathway</b>

The enzymatic steps involved in the biosynthesis of phylloquinone in cyanobacteria and plants are almost
identical to the biosynthetic route leading to the microbial complement menaquinone.
The discernible step between phylloquinone and menaquinone biosynthesis is the prenylation of
|FRAME: DIHYDROXYNAPHTHOATE| (DHNA).
The DHNA phytyltransferase catalyzes the attachment of a C-20 phytyl side chain leading to
|FRAME:CPD-6947| |CITS: [15686525]|, whereas microbial DHNA prenyltransferases attache a
multiprenyl side chain, forming  demethylmenaquinones. The length of the side chain varies among
different species.

It has been found that phylloquinone is not absolutely required for efficient electron transfer in PS I
|CITS: [10722690]|. At least in |FRAME: TAX-1148|, benzoquinones such as
|FRAME:PLASTOQUINONE-9|, which usually act as secondary electron acceptors in PS II
|CITS: [11470786][15681848]|, can efficiently replace phylloquinone in the A1-site of PS I as a
one-electron cofactor. However, as shown in both |FRAME:TAX-3701| and |FRAME: TAX-1148| mutants,
the deficiency of phylloquinone causes distortions in the thylakoid structure of chloroplasts,
decreases the content of PS I, and affects the functionality of PS II |CITS: [15686525]|.

It has been demonstrated that the final step of the pathway, a transmethylation reaction to form |FRAME:CPD-12831|, depends on the oxidation state of the penultimate substrate. This led to the discovery that one more reaction was inserted in between |FRAME:CPD-6947| and the final product |FRAME:CPD-12831|. This reaction was catalyzed by type II NAD(P)H dehydrogenases in both <i>Arabidopsis thaliana</i> and the cyanobacterium <i>Synechocystis</i>  sp. PCC 6803 encoded by NDC1 and ndbB, respectively, which resulted in the formation of the reduced |FRAME:CPD-12830| |CITS:[26023160]|. Only this reduced (quinol) substrate was able to accept the electrons from the electrophilic |FRAME:S-ADENOSYLMETHIONINE| for the subsequent transmethylation step of the |FRAME:PWY-5027| to yield |FRAME:CPD-12831| |CITS:[26023160]|. In general, the intermediates of the |FRAME:PWY-5027| including in-feeding pathways such as |FRAME:PWY-5837| are depicted in their dihydroxy conformation, for example see |FRAME:DIHYDROXYNAPHTHOATE| and |FRAME:CPD-9925|, although the latter has been shown to be used <i>in vitro</i> in its diketo form |CITS:[19321747]|. However, the study on the dehydrogenases of <i>Arabidopsis</i> and <i>Synechocystis</i> provide evidence that |FRAME:CPD-6947| and probably any other preceding intermediates occur in their diketo instead of the dihydroxy form |CITS:[Basset15]|." "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY66-5"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Quinone-Biosynthesis" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Pathways"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Cofactor-Biosynthesis" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=NIL&object=Generalized-Reactions"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PANTO-PWY"	"phosphopantothenate biosynthesis I"	"PANTO-PWY"	"<b>General Background</b>

|FRAME: 4-P-PANTOTHENATE| is the universal precursor for the synthesis of the 4'-phosphopantetheine moiety of |FRAME:CO-A| and |FRAME: ACP \"acyl carrier protein\"|. Only plants and microorganisms (including some eukaryotic microbes, such as |FRAME: TAX-4932|) can synthesize pantothenate <i>de novo</i> - animals require a dietary supplement. The enzymes of this pathway are therefore considered to be antimicrobial drug targets.

<b>About This Pathway</b>

The starting compound for pantothenate biosynthesis, |FRAME: 2-KETO-ISOVALERATE|, is derived from the |FRAME: VALSYN-PWY| pathway. The first committed step in the pathway is the transfer of a methyl group to 2-keto-isovalerate by |FRAME: 3-METHYL-2-OXOBUT-OHCH3XFER-CPLX|. The product of this reaction, |FRAME: 2-DEHYDROPANTOATE|, is subsequently reduced by |FRAME: 2-DEHYDROPANTOATE-REDUCT-MONOMER| to |FRAME: L-PANTOATE|. The final step is the ATP hydrolysis-dependent condensation of L-pantoate with |FRAME: B-ALANINE| to form |FRAME: PANTOTHENATE|, which is catalyzed by |FRAME: PANTOATE-BETA-ALANINE-LIG-CPLX|.

The enzymes of this pathway are not essential for viability of |FRAME: TAX-83333| grown on media supplemented with pantothenate, due to the presence of a transporter for pantothenate, PanF |CITS: [2193919]|.

<b>This pathway in Yeast</b>

Three out of the four reactions involved in the conversion of |FRAME:2-KETO-ISOVALERATE| to the common intermediate towards |FRAME:CO-A| biosynthesis, i.e. |FRAME:4-P-PANTOTHENATE| have been associated with enzymes in |FRAME:TAX-4932|. The second reaction in the pathway catalyzed by the 2-dehydropantoate 2-reductase in bacteria is still elusive for yeast and remains to be resolved. Utilizing genetic and biochemical approaches the functions of |FRAME:MONOMER3O-90| |CITS:[11154694] [16232925] [19266201]|, |FRAME:YIL145C-MONOMER| |CITS:[11154694] [19266201]| and |FRAME:MONOMER3O-268| |CITS:[19266201]| have been elucidated and emphasizes the general notion that the pathway sequences of |FRAME:4-P-PANTOTHENATE| and |FRAME:CO-A| biosynthesis are almost identical among the various kingdoms.  

<b>This Pathway in Plants</b>

Feeding studies in |FRAME:TAX-3888| leaf discs support the existence of a similar biosynthesis pathway of pantothenate via pantoate: when fed with [<sup>14</sup>C]valine, the radiolabel was incorporated into &alpha;-oxoisovalerate, oxopantoate and pantoate |CITS:[jones94]|.
A number of enzymes involved in pantothenate biosynthesis have been characterized from different plants, including the enzyme catalyzing the last step of the pathway: pantothenate synthetase. This enzyme catalyzes the formation of pantothenate from pantoate and &beta;-alanine. The origin of plant &beta;-alanine is uncertain but appears to be different from that of bacteria which synthesize it from L-aspartate. Instead plants seem to produce &beta;-alanine from a variety of other sources, like polyamines, uracil and propionate (see |FRAME:PWY-3941|) |CITS: [RAMAN04]|."	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-4221" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PANTOSYN-PWY"		"vitamin B<sub>5</sub> biosynthesis"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Pantothenate-Biosynthesis"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PANTO-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-3961" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6654"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Vitamin-Biosynthesis"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Cofactor-Biosynthesis"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PYRIDNUCSYN-PWY"	"NAD <i>de novo</i> biosynthesis I (from aspartate)"	"PYRIDNUCSYN-PWY"	"<b>General Background</b>

Nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD) and its phosphorylated derivative, nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide phosphate (NADP) are two of the most important coenzymes in redox reactions in the cell. Generally, NAD is involved in catabolic reactions, while NADP is involved in anabolic reactions. Because of the positive charge on the nitrogen atom in the nicotinamide ring, the oxidized forms of these compounds are often depicted as NAD<sup>+</sup> and NADP<sup>+</sup>, respectively.

Most oxidation reactions in cells are accomplished by the removal of hydrogen atoms. In reactions where NAD or NADP participate, two hydrogen atoms are typically removed from the substrate. During the reduction of NAD<sup>+</sup> (or NADP<sup>+</sup>)  the molecule acquires two electrons and one proton, while the second proton is released into the medium. Thus a typical reaction involving NAD is in the form:

NAD<sup>+</sup> + 2H -> NADH + H<sup>+</sup>

Additional roles for NAD in the cell have been suggested, including involvement in transcriptional regulation, longevity, and age-associated diseases. In yeast, it has been shown that NAD affects longevity and transcriptional silencing through the regulation of the Sir2p family of NAD-dependent deacetylases |CITS: [12648681][14724176]|.

NAD is synthesised via two major pathways in both prokaryotic and eukaryotic systems; the <i>de novo</i> pathway, and the salvage pathway. In the prokaryotic <i>de novo</i> pathway, the nicotinate moiety of NAD is synthesized from |FRAME: L-ASPARTATE| (this pathway), while in eukaryotes the <i>de novo</i> pathway starts with |FRAME: TRP| (|FRAME:NADSYN-PWY|).

<b>About This Pathway</b>

As a general rule, most prokaryotes utilize the aspartate <i>de novo</i> pathway, in which the nicotinate moiety of NAD is synthesized from aspartate |CITS: [11153263]|, while in eukaryotes, the <i>de novo</i> pathway starts with  tryptophan |CITS: [12062417]| (|FRAME: NADSYN-PWY|).

The first attempt to elucidate a procaryotic pathway to NAD was reported by Ortega and Brown in 1960 |CITS: [13731310]|. They implicated (incorrectly) glycerol and a dicarboxylic acid as precursors in the synthesis of the pyridine ring of NAD in |FRAME:TAX-562|. Subsequent work by Chandler et al. |CITS: [4321550]| established that L-aspartate is the dicarboxylic acid precursor. Suzuki et al., in 1973, established that the three carbon precursor is dihydroxyacetone phosphate (DHAP) and not glycerol |CITS: [4351074]|.
In addition, Andreoli et al demonstrated that quinolinate was a key intermediate in this pathway |CITS: [14013029]|. Eventually it became clear that quinolinate is indeed a precursor, not only in this pathway, but in all known NAD biosynthetic pathways.

<b>NAD biosynthesis In Plants</b>

In plants current evidence strongly supports the NAD biosynthetic route from L-aspartate. However, the finding of gene homologs encoding enzymes of the early steps in the kynurenine pathway (|FRAME:NADSYN-PWY| in the genome sequence of rice (|FRAME:TAX-4530|) does not rule out this pathway in monocotyledones and remains to be further investigated |CITS: [16698895]| |CITS: [14977569]|. 

The genome of the dicotyledonous plant <i>Arabidopsis thaliana</i> contains homologs to all genes that encode enzymatic steps in the corresponding bacterial pathway (this pathway). Many of those homologous sequences are found in cDNA databases |CITS: [14593172]| which indicates their transcription and functional role as protein encoding genes. 

The first reaction is the conversion of L-aspartate to iminoaspartate catalyzed by the L-aspartate oxidase (AO). This enzyme has been partially purified from cotton |CITS: [6338879]|. The cDNA has also been isolated from <i>Arabidopsis thaliana</i> and its molecular function confirmed through functional complementation of L-aspartate oxidase deficient |FRAME:TAX-562| mutants (<i>nadB</i><sup>-</sup>) |CITS: [16698895]|. It should be pointed out that the catalyzed reaction differs from the enzyme of the same name, assigned to EC 1.4.3.16, which deaminates L-aspartate forming oxaloacetate and NH<sub>3</sub>.

Comparable to the L-aspartate oxidase of <i>Arabidopsis thaliana</i> the quinolinate synthase (QS) of this plant has been identified using a genomic approach. It could be demonstrated that the recombinant protein complemented quinolinate synthase deficient |FRAME:TAX-562| mutants (<i>nadA</i><sup>-</sup>) as well as the embryo-lethal phenotype of the homozygous allele in Arabidopsis |CITS: [16698895]|.

The third reaction in the early steps of NAD biosynthesis from L-aspartate is catalyzed by quinolinate phosphoribosyltransferase (QPRtase) which has been isolated and characterized from different plants |CITS: [4422841]| |CITS: [11198422]| |CITS: [16698895]|. The enzyme catalyzes the formation of nicotinate mononucleotide (NaMN) the first intermediate that is also a component of the NAD recycling cycle |CITS: [Zheng04]| |CITS: [16714307]|.

The activity of the last two enzymes of the pathway, nicotinic-acid mononucleotide adenylyltransferase (NaMN-AT) and NAD synthase (NAD-S) has been determined in tobacco |CITS: [WAGNER86]| |CITS: [WAGNER86A]|. For <i>Arabidopsis thaliana</i> those enzymes have been shown to exist as homologs in the genome, each of them encoded by a single gene |CITS: [HUNT04]| |CITS: [16698895]| |CITS: [14977569]| but their biochemical function remains to be confirmed."	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY0-781"		"nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide biosynthesis"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=NAD-SYN"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY3O-4107" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5653" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=NAD-BIOSYNTHESIS-III" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PYRIDNUCSAL-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7761" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=NADSYN-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PYRIDNUCSYN-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY3O-4106" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-3502" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=NAD-BIOSYNTHESIS-II"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=NAD-Metabolism"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Cofactor-Biosynthesis"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PYRIDNUCSAL-PWY"	"NAD salvage pathway I (PNC VI cycle)"	"PYRIDNUCSAL-PWY"	"<b>General Background</b>

Nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD) and its phosphorylated derivative, nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide phosphate (NADP) are two of the most important coenzymes in redox reactions in the cell. Generally, NAD is involved in catabolic reactions, while NADP is involved in anabolic reactions. Because of the positive charge on the nitrogen atom in the nicotinamide ring, the oxidized forms of these compounds are often depicted as NAD<sup>+</sup> and NADP<sup>+</sup>, respectively.

Most oxidation reactions in cells are accomplished by the removal of hydrogen atoms. In reactions where NAD or NADP participate, two hydrogen atoms are typically removed from the substrate. During the reduction of NAD<sup>+</sup> (or NADP<sup>+</sup>)  the molecule acquires two electrons and one proton, while the second proton is released into the medium. Thus a typical reaction involving NAD is in the form:

NAD<sup>+</sup> + 2H -> NADH + H<sup>+</sup>

Additional roles for NAD in the cell have been suggested, including involvement in transcriptional regulation, longevity, and age-associated diseases. In yeast, it has been shown that NAD affects longevity and transcriptional silencing through the regulation of the Sir2p family of NAD-dependent deacetylases |CITS: [12648681][14724176]|.

NAD is synthesised via two major pathways in both prokaryotic and eukaryotic systems; the <i>de novo</i> pathway, and the salvage pathway. In the prokaryotic <i>de novo</i> pathway, the nicotinate moiety of NAD is synthesized from |FRAME: L-ASPARTATE| (see |FRAME: PYRIDNUCSYN-PWY|, while in eukaryotes the <i>de novo</i> pathway starts with |FRAME: TRP| (|FRAME:NADSYN-PWY|).

<b>About This Pathway</b>

Even though NAD molecules are not consumed during oxidation reactions, they have a relatively short half-life. For example, in |FRAME:TAX-562| the NAD<sup>+</sup> half-life is 90 minutes. Once enzymatically degraded, the pyrimidine moiety of the molecule can be recouped via the NAD salvage cycles. This pathway is used for two purposes: it recycles the internally degraded NAD products |FRAME: NICOTINAMIDE_NUCLEOTIDE| (also known as nicotinamide mononucleotide, or NMN) and |FRAME: NIACINAMIDE|, and it is used for the assimilation of exogenous NAD<sup>+</sup>.

Since the NAD<sup>+</sup> molecule is highly polar, it has to be hydrolyzed before it can be transported across the cytoplasmic membrane for final uptake. It does seem to be able to penetrate the external membrane, though, as the enzymes that break it down are found in the periplasm |CITS: [2841298]|. NAD<sup>+</sup> is first hydrolyzed by |FRAME: EC-3.6.1.22|, into |FRAME: NICOTINAMIDE_NUCLEOTIDE| (NMN), which can be hydrolyzed further to |FRAME: NIACINAMIDE| by |FRAME: EC-3.2.2.14|. Both enzymes are periplasmic. It should be noted that even though the activity of |FRAME: EC-3.2.2.14|. has been reported from a few organisms several decades ago |CITS: [4342726][457634]|, the identity of the enzyme has not been reported.

Both NMN and nicotinamide can be transported across the inner membrane into the cytoplasm. Once there, |FRAME: NIACINAMIDE| is converted via |FRAME: NIACINE| to |FRAME: NICOTINATE_NUCLEOTIDE|, at which point the pathway merges with the <i>de novo</i> biosynthesis pathway, and continues to NAD via |FRAME: DEAMIDO-NAD| (deamido-NAD).

There are several flavors of the salvage pathway found in different organisms, and even within the same organism. The one described above contains 6 reaction steps, and is often referred to as the PNC VI pathway, for Pyridine Nucleotide Cycling. However, there are also a four-step cycle (|FRAME: PWY-7761|) and a five-step cycle (|FRAME: PWY3O-4107|), termed PNC IV and V, respectively |CITS: [220211][6445894]|.

PNC IV is the major intracellular recycling pathway in |FRAME:TAX-562| |CITS: [7021549]|, while PNC VI is the major cycle of |FRAME:TAX-90371| |CITS: [6445894]| and yeast |CITS:[12062417][11884393]|."			"pyridine nucleotide cycling" // "nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide salvage"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=NAD-SYN"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY3O-4107" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5653" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=NAD-BIOSYNTHESIS-III" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PYRIDNUCSAL-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7761" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=NADSYN-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PYRIDNUCSYN-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY3O-4106" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-3502" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=NAD-BIOSYNTHESIS-II"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=NAD-Metabolism"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Cofactor-Biosynthesis"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=NAD-BIOSYNTHESIS-II"	"NAD salvage pathway III (to nicotinamide riboside)"	"NAD-BIOSYNTHESIS-II"	"<b>General Background</b>

Nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD) and its phosphorylated derivative, nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide
phosphate (NADP) are two of the most important coenzymes in redox reactions in the cell.
Generally, NAD is involved in catabolic reactions, while NADP is involved in anabolic reactions.
Because of the positive charge on the nitrogen atom in the nicotinamide ring, the oxidized forms of these
compounds are often depicted as NAD<sup>+</sup> and NADP<sup>+</sup>, respectively.

Most oxidation reactions in cells are accomplished by the removal of hydrogen atoms. In reactions where NAD or
NADP participate, two hydrogen atoms are typically removed from the substrate. During the reduction of 
NAD<sup>+</sup> (or NADP<sup>+</sup>)  the molecule acquires two electrons and one proton, while
the second proton is released into the medium. Thus a typical reaction involving NAD is in the form:

NAD<sup>+</sup> + 2H -> NADH + H<sup>+</sup>

Additional roles for NAD in the cell have been suggested, including involvement in transcriptional regulation,
longevity, and age-associated diseases. In yeast, it has been shown that NAD affects longevity and
transcriptional silencing through the regulation of the Sir2p family of NAD-dependent deacetylases
|CITS: [12648681][14724176]|.

NAD is synthesised via two major pathways in both prokaryotic and eukaryotic systems; the <i>de novo</i> 
pathway, and the salvage pathway.
In the prokaryotic <i>de novo</i> pathway, the nicotinate moiety of NAD is synthesized from aspartate
(see |FRAME: PYRIDNUCSYN-PWY|, while in eukaryotes the <i>de novo</i> pathway starts with  tryptophan
(|FRAME:NADSYN-PWY|).

<b>About This Pathway</b>

This pathway is an NAD salvage pathway which proceeds via the intermediate |FRAME: NICOTINAMIDE_RIBOSE| (nicotinamide riboside, (<i>N</i>-ribosylnicotinamide, or NR). While the presence of this pathway has been suggested for several organisms, including |FRAME:TAX-562|, |FRAME: TAX-272131|, |FRAME:TAX-1358|, |FRAME:TAX-727|, |FRAME: TAX-730|, |FRAME: TAX-714|, and |FRAME:TAX-747| |CITS: [12446641]|, it is of particular importance to |FRAME:TAX-727| and other V-factor-dependent members of the |FRAME:TAX-745| family. These organisms lack the enzymes necessary for the <i>de novo</i> synthesis of NAD, as well as most of the enzymes for the more common NAD salvage pathway, and therefore require exogenous NAD supply in the form of one of the V-factor compounds, which include
NADP, NAD, NMN, and NR. However, only the non-phosphorylated V factor, NR, can be transported across the inner
membrane into the cytoplasm, where it can be converted to NAD and NADP |CITS: [12446641]|. Thus this pathway
is critical for these organisms |CITS: [1694467]|. For additional information about V-factor-dependent bacteria, look at the pathway |FRAME: NAD-BIOSYNTHESIS-III|.

Since NAD<sup>+</sup>, which is obtained from extracellular sources, is highly polar, it has to be hydrolyzed before it can be transported across the cytoplasmic membrane for final uptake. A key enzyme in this pathway is the periplasmic NadN protein, encoded by the <i>nadN</i> gene (<i>ushA</i> in |FRAME:TAX-562|). It has been shown that NadN has two activities: firstly, it hydrolyzes NAD<sup>+</sup> to nicotinamide mononucleotide (NMN), and secondly, it hydrolyzes NMN to nicotinamide riboside (NR) |CITS: [11395461]|. After NAD<sup>+</sup> is transported into the periplasmic space it is hydrolyzed into NMN and AMP by the NAD-nucleotidase activity of NadN. NMN is then hydrolyzed to NR and pyrophosphate, and the nicotinamide riboside thus formed is transported across the inner membrane into the cytoplasm, where it is it is converted back to NMN, and eventually, to NAD<sup>+</sup>.

The identity of the NR transporter has not been confirmed experimentally, but it is suggested that it is encoded by the <i>pnuC</i> gene, although earlier work with the PnuC protein of |FRAME:TAX-28901| serovar Typhimurium suggested that it encodes the transport of NMN |CITS: [6216244][11395461]|.

NADP<sup>+</sup> is recycled in the same manner, following dephosphorylation to NAD<sup>+</sup>. In |FRAME: TAX-727|, this dephosphorylation is performed by the outer membrane glycoprotein <i>e</i> (P4), encoded by the <i>hel</i> gene.

While the pathway is predicted to be present in |FRAME:TAX-543|, it probably serves a minor role compared to <i>de novo</i> biosynthesis and the main NAD salvage cycle (|FRAME: PYRIDNUCSAL-PWY|). Some of the enzymatic activities associated with this pathway have been described in |FRAME:TAX-543| as early as 1951 |CITS: [14907738]|, but it was only recently that the genes responsible for them were identified. Surprisingly, several activities were found to be functions of the multifunctional protein NadR, which was initially believed to have a role in regulation only |CITS: [10464228][12446641]|."			"nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide salvage"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=NAD-SYN"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY3O-4107" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5653" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=NAD-BIOSYNTHESIS-III" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PYRIDNUCSAL-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7761" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=NADSYN-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PYRIDNUCSYN-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY3O-4106" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-3502" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=NAD-BIOSYNTHESIS-II"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=NAD-Metabolism"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Cofactor-Biosynthesis"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5897"	"superpathway of menaquinol-11 biosynthesis"	"PWY-5897"	"<b>General Background</b>

Menaquinones (MK) and demethylmenaquinones (DMK) are low-molecular weight lipophilic components of the cytoplasmic membrane, found in many bacterial species.  These quinones function as a reversible redox component of the electron transfer chain, mediating electron transfer between hydrogenases and cytochromes.
Menaquinones have also been implicated in regulation, as they are necessary for sporulation and proper regulation of cytochrome formation in some Gram-positive bacteria |CITS: [4353869][4202999]|.

Most aerobic Gram-negative bacteria contain ubiquinone as the sole quinone, while most aerobic Gram-positive bacteria contain menaquinone and/or demethylmenaquinones as the main quinone. However, most of the anaerobic bacteria, regardless whether they are Gram-negative or Gram-positive, contain menaquinone or demethylmenaquinone as their main quinones. Some facultatively anaerobic bacteria, such as |FRAME:TAX-562|, contain ubiquinone, menaquinone, and demethylmenaquinone, which they use under different growth conditions |CITS: [11153266]|. The main difference between
these quinone molecules is their redox potential. For example, the redox potential for ubiquinone, demethylmenaquinone, and menaquinone has been measured as +112 mv, +36 mv, and -74 mv, respectively, in the bacterium |FRAME: TAX-729| |CITS: [187454]|.

Menaquinones are considered a vitamin (vitamin K<sub>2</sub>), since they are essential for animals, mostly for the posttranslational modification of certain proteins required for blood coagulation. Animals can not synthesize menaquinones, but usually receive a sufficient amount from bacteria growing in their intestines. In the absence of menaquinone or the related compound |FRAME: 2-METHYL-3-PHYTYL-14-NAPHTHOQUINONE| (vitamin K<sub>1</sub>) which is synthesized in plants, animals suffer from hemorrhage |CITS: [Dam35]|. Menaquinone was first isolated from putrefied fish meal by McKee in 1939 |CITS: [17783315]|, and its structure resolved in 1958 |CITS: [Isler58]|.

The biosynthesis of menaquinones is essentially identical to that of demethylmenaquinones, with one additional step, comprising the addition of a methyl group to the naphthoquinone ring. Many bacterial species do not have this methylase and produce demethylmenaquinone as their sole quinone |CITS: [7022156]|.

All three quinones are synthesized from |FRAME: CHORISMATE|, an intermediate of aromatic amino acid biosynthesis. However, the pathways of (demethyl)menaquinone synthesis diverts from that for ubiquinones early on.
Most organisms synthesize their menaquinones via |FRAME: ISOCHORISMATE|, although some organisms, including |FRAME: TAX-210|, |FRAME: TAX-197|, |FRAME: TAX-1902| and |FRAME: TAX-274|, synthesize menaquinones in alternative pathways, via |FRAME: CPD-10477| or |FRAME: CPD-13324| |CITS: [18801996][21489995][23972005]|.

Menaquinones are known to have side chains of different sizes in different organisms, and sometimes even within the same organism. The most common menaquinones contain 7, 8 and 9 isoprene units. However, menaquinones containing 4 |CITS:[413478][6048777]|, 5 |CITS: [6048777][5005959]|, 6 |CITS: [5005959][6102980][5418698][5412037]|, 10 |CITS: [6102980][7462123]|, 11 |CITS: [6102980] [7462123]|, 12 |CITS: [6102980]|, and 13 |CITS: [6102980]| isoprene units have been reported in bacteria.

<b>About This Pathway</b>

A few bacterial phyla appear to possess menaquinones with very long prenyl side chains. Several members of the |FRAME: TAX-976| phylum, which consists of obligate anaerobes, were reported to produce |FRAME: CPD-9723| as either their main quinone (as in the case of |FRAME: TAX-28131| |CITS: [6102980][6363375]|), in combination with |FRAME: CPD-9719|, as reported for |FRAME: TAX-28111| |CITS: [6363375]|, |FRAME: TAX-817| |CITS: [6363375][7118751][7462123]|, |FRAME: TAX-28132| |CITS: [6102980][6363375]|, |FRAME: TAX-28116| |CITS: [6363375]|, |FRAME: TAX-28134| strains 5540, G9a-C2 and 7880, |FRAME: TAX-818|, and |FRAME: TAX-821| |CITS: [6102980][6363375]|, or in combination with |FRAME: CPD-9722|, as in |FRAME: TAX-28134| strains 1210 and 1221and |FRAME: TAX-839| |CITS: [6102980][6363375]|.

In addition, several species that belong to the |FRAME: TAX-201174| phylum, and especially to the |FRAME: TAX-33882| genus, were reported to contain |FRAME: CPD-9723|. Some of these, such as |FRAME: TAX-144185|, contain |FRAME: CPD-9723| along with |FRAME: CPD-9719| |CITS: [Yamada76b]| . Others, including |FRAME: TAX-33884|, |FRAME: TAX-33917|, |FRAME: TAX-41986|, |FRAME: TAX-33885|, |FRAME: TAX-33918| |CITS:[7462123][7022156]|, |FRAME: TAX-69368| and |FRAME: TAX-2033| |CITS: [6775048]| contain |FRAME: CPD-9723| along with |FRAME: CPD-9722|." "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Pathways"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Cofactor-Biosynthesis" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=NIL&object=Generalized-Reactions"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5898"	"superpathway of menaquinol-12 biosynthesis"	"PWY-5898"	"<b>General Background</b>

Menaquinones (MK) and demethylmenaquinones (DMK) are low-molecular weight lipophilic components of the cytoplasmic membrane, found in many bacterial species.  These quinones function as a reversible redox component of the electron transfer chain, mediating electron transfer between hydrogenases and cytochromes.
Menaquinones have also been implicated in regulation, as they are necessary for sporulation and proper regulation of cytochrome formation in some Gram-positive bacteria |CITS: [4353869][4202999]|.

Most aerobic Gram-negative bacteria contain ubiquinone as the sole quinone, while most aerobic Gram-positive bacteria contain menaquinone and/or demethylmenaquinones as the main quinone. However, most of the anaerobic bacteria, regardless whether they are Gram-negative or Gram-positive, contain menaquinone or demethylmenaquinone as their main quinones. Some facultatively anaerobic bacteria, such as |FRAME:TAX-562|, contain ubiquinone, menaquinone, and demethylmenaquinone, which they use under different growth conditions |CITS: [11153266]|. The main difference between
these quinone molecules is their redox potential. For example, the redox potential for ubiquinone, demethylmenaquinone, and menaquinone has been measured as +112 mv, +36 mv, and -74 mv, respectively, in the bacterium |FRAME: TAX-729| |CITS: [187454]|.

Menaquinones are considered a vitamin (vitamin K<sub>2</sub>), since they are essential for animals, mostly for the posttranslational modification of certain proteins required for blood coagulation. Animals can not synthesize menaquinones, but usually receive a sufficient amount from bacteria growing in their intestines. In the absence of menaquinone or the related compound |FRAME: 2-METHYL-3-PHYTYL-14-NAPHTHOQUINONE| (vitamin K<sub>1</sub>) which is synthesized in plants, animals suffer from hemorrhage |CITS: [Dam35]|. Menaquinone was first isolated from putrefied fish meal by McKee in 1939 |CITS: [17783315]|, and its structure resolved in 1958 |CITS: [Isler58]|.

The biosynthesis of menaquinones is essentially identical to that of demethylmenaquinones, with one additional step, comprising the addition of a methyl group to the naphthoquinone ring. Many bacterial species do not have this methylase and produce demethylmenaquinone as their sole quinone |CITS: [7022156]|.

All three quinones are synthesized from |FRAME: CHORISMATE|, an intermediate of aromatic amino acid biosynthesis. However, the pathways of (demethyl)menaquinone synthesis diverts from that for ubiquinones early on.
Most organisms synthesize their menaquinones via |FRAME: ISOCHORISMATE|, although some organisms, including |FRAME: TAX-210|, |FRAME: TAX-197|, |FRAME: TAX-1902| and |FRAME: TAX-274|, synthesize menaquinones in alternative pathways, via |FRAME: CPD-10477| or |FRAME: CPD-13324| |CITS: [18801996][21489995][23972005]|.

Menaquinones are known to have side chains of different sizes in different organisms, and sometimes even within the same organism. The most common menaquinones contain 7, 8 and 9 isoprene units. However, menaquinones containing 4 |CITS:[413478][6048777]|, 5 |CITS: [6048777][5005959]|, 6 |CITS: [5005959][6102980][5418698][5412037]|, 10 |CITS: [6102980][7462123]|, 11 |CITS: [6102980] [7462123]|, 12 |CITS: [6102980]|, and 13 |CITS: [6102980]| isoprene units have been reported in bacteria.

<b>About This Pathway</b>

A few bacterial phyla appear to possess menaquinones with very long prenyl side chains. Several members of the |FRAME: TAX-838| genus, which consists of obligate anaerobes, were reported to produce |FRAME: CPD-9722|. This quinone was found in combination with either |FRAME: CPD-9723|, as reported for |FRAME: TAX-28134| strains 1210 and 1221, |FRAME: TAX-83231| strains B5 and 118B, and |FRAME:TAX-839| strain R2, or |FRAME:CPD-9721|, as in |FRAME:TAX-28134| strains VP1 8906D and HS4 and |FRAME: TAX-83231| strains NP333, 75J1, J1 and WP H61
|CITS: [6102980][6363375]|.

In addition, several species that belong to the |FRAME: TAX-201174| phylum, and especially to the |FRAME: TAX-33882| genus, were reported to contain |FRAME: CPD-9722|. These organisms, which contain |FRAME: CPD-9722| along with |FRAME: CPD-9723|, include: |FRAME: TAX-33884|, |FRAME: TAX-33917|, |FRAME: TAX-41986|, |FRAME: TAX-33885|,
|FRAME: TAX-33918| |CITS:[7462123][7022156]|, |FRAME: TAX-69368| and |FRAME: TAX-2033| |CITS: [6775048]|." "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5840"	"superpathway of menaquinol-7 biosynthesis"	"PWY-5840"	"<b>General Background</b>

Menaquinones (MK) and demethylmenaquinones (DMK) are low-molecular weight lipophilic components of the cytoplasmic membrane, found in many bacterial species.  These quinones function as a reversible redox component of the electron transfer chain, mediating electron transfer between hydrogenases and cytochromes.
Menaquinones have also been implicated in regulation, as they are necessary for sporulation and proper regulation of cytochrome formation in some Gram-positive bacteria |CITS: [4353869][4202999]|.

Most aerobic Gram-negative bacteria contain ubiquinone as the sole quinone, while most aerobic Gram-positive bacteria contain menaquinone and/or demethylmenaquinones as the main quinone. However, most of the anaerobic bacteria, regardless whether they are Gram-negative or Gram-positive, contain menaquinone or demethylmenaquinone as their main quinones. Some facultatively anaerobic bacteria, such as |FRAME:TAX-562|, contain ubiquinone, menaquinone, and demethylmenaquinone, which they use under different growth conditions |CITS: [11153266]|. The main difference between
these quinone molecules is their redox potential. For example, the redox potential for ubiquinone, demethylmenaquinone, and menaquinone has been measured as +112 mv, +36 mv, and -74 mv, respectively, in the bacterium |FRAME: TAX-729| |CITS: [187454]|.

Menaquinones are considered a vitamin (vitamin K<sub>2</sub>), since they are essential for animals, mostly for the posttranslational modification of certain proteins required for blood coagulation. Animals can not synthesize menaquinones, but usually receive a sufficient amount from bacteria growing in their intestines. In the absence of menaquinone or the related compound |FRAME: 2-METHYL-3-PHYTYL-14-NAPHTHOQUINONE| (vitamin K<sub>1</sub>) which is synthesized in plants, animals suffer from hemorrhage |CITS: [Dam35]|. Menaquinone was first isolated from putrefied fish meal by McKee in 1939 |CITS: [17783315]|, and its structure resolved in 1958 |CITS: [Isler58]|.

The biosynthesis of menaquinones is essentially identical to that of demethylmenaquinones, with one additional step, comprising the addition of a methyl group to the naphthoquinone ring. Many bacterial species do not have this methylase and produce demethylmenaquinone as their sole quinone |CITS: [7022156]|.

All three quinones are synthesized from |FRAME: CHORISMATE|, an intermediate of aromatic amino acid biosynthesis. However, the pathways of (demethyl)menaquinone synthesis diverts from that for ubiquinones early on.
Most organisms synthesize their menaquinones via |FRAME: ISOCHORISMATE|, although some organisms, including |FRAME: TAX-210|, |FRAME: TAX-197|, |FRAME: TAX-1902| and |FRAME: TAX-274|, synthesize menaquinones in alternative pathways, via |FRAME: CPD-10477| or |FRAME: CPD-13324| |CITS: [18801996][21489995][23972005]|.

Menaquinones are known to have side chains of different sizes in different organisms, and sometimes even within the same organism. The most common menaquinones contain 7, 8 and 9 isoprene units. However, menaquinones containing 4 |CITS:[413478][6048777]|, 5 |CITS: [6048777][5005959]|, 6 |CITS: [5005959][6102980][5418698][5412037]|, 10 |CITS: [6102980][7462123]|, 11 |CITS: [6102980] [7462123]|, 12 |CITS: [6102980]|, and 13 |CITS: [6102980]| isoprene units have been reported in bacteria.

<b>About This Pathway</b>

|FRAME: CPD-9718| (MK-7) is by far the most common quinone in Gram-positive bacteria. It has been shown to be the major form of quinone in dozens of species, including many |FRAME: TAX-1386| species, as well as |FRAME: TAX-1562|, |FRAME: TAX-2755|, |FRAME: TAX-1637|, and |FRAME: TAX-1279| (see |CITS: [7022156]| for an exhaustive list).
The best studied menaquinone biosynthetic pathway outside of |FRAME: TAX-83333| (which makes |FRAME: CPD-9728|) is that of |FRAME: TAX-1423|, which makes MK-7 |CITS: [6780515][3131309] [1629163][8169214][8566759][10194342]|.

Even though MK-7 is most prevalent in Gram-positive bacteria, it has been documented in other organisms as well. It has been shown to be the major quinone in several members of the |FRAME: TAX-68336|, including |FRAME: TAX-115852| (along with |FRAME: CPD-9611|) |CITS: [5782248]|, |FRAME: TAX-997| |CITS: [4216336]|, and |FRAME: TAX-28132| |CITS: [5411759]|.

MK-7 also occurs as a minor quinone in several Gram-negative species, including |FRAME: TAX-51367| (which belongs to the |FRAME: TAX-1236|) |CITS: [Collins81]|, |FRAME: TAX-33| (which belongs to the |FRAME: TAX-28221|) |CITS: [5782248]|, and |FRAME: TAX-274| and |FRAME: TAX-271|, which belong to the |FRAME: TAX-1297| phylum |CITS: [7462123][7022156]|.

In Green sulfur bacteria MK-7 is present in their photosystem I-type reaction centers |CITS: [11687219]|.

In addition, MK-7 was found to be the major quinone of the archaebacterium |FRAME: TAX-2303|
|CITS: [4344918]|." "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Pathways"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Cofactor-Biosynthesis" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5838"	"superpathway of menaquinol-8 biosynthesis I"	"PWY-5838"	"<b>General Background</b>

Menaquinones (MK) and demethylmenaquinones (DMK) are low-molecular weight lipophilic components of the cytoplasmic membrane, found in many bacterial species.  These quinones function as a reversible redox component of the electron transfer chain, mediating electron transfer between hydrogenases and cytochromes.
Menaquinones have also been implicated in regulation, as they are necessary for sporulation and proper regulation of cytochrome formation in some Gram-positive bacteria |CITS: [4353869][4202999]|.

Most aerobic Gram-negative bacteria contain ubiquinone as the sole quinone, while most aerobic Gram-positive bacteria contain menaquinone and/or demethylmenaquinones as the main quinone. However, most of the anaerobic bacteria, regardless whether they are Gram-negative or Gram-positive, contain menaquinone or demethylmenaquinone as their main quinones. Some facultatively anaerobic bacteria, such as |FRAME:TAX-562|, contain ubiquinone, menaquinone, and demethylmenaquinone, which they use under different growth conditions |CITS: [11153266]|. The main difference between
these quinone molecules is their redox potential. For example, the redox potential for ubiquinone, demethylmenaquinone, and menaquinone has been measured as +112 mv, +36 mv, and -74 mv, respectively, in the bacterium |FRAME: TAX-729| |CITS: [187454]|.

Menaquinones are considered a vitamin (vitamin K<sub>2</sub>), since they are essential for animals, mostly for the posttranslational modification of certain proteins required for blood coagulation. Animals can not synthesize menaquinones, but usually receive a sufficient amount from bacteria growing in their intestines. In the absence of menaquinone or the related compound |FRAME: 2-METHYL-3-PHYTYL-14-NAPHTHOQUINONE| (vitamin K<sub>1</sub>) which is synthesized in plants, animals suffer from hemorrhage |CITS: [Dam35]|. Menaquinone was first isolated from putrefied fish meal by McKee in 1939 |CITS: [17783315]|, and its structure resolved in 1958 |CITS: [Isler58]|.

The biosynthesis of menaquinones is essentially identical to that of demethylmenaquinones, with one additional step, comprising the addition of a methyl group to the naphthoquinone ring. Many bacterial species do not have this methylase and produce demethylmenaquinone as their sole quinone |CITS: [7022156]|.

All three quinones are synthesized from |FRAME: CHORISMATE|, an intermediate of aromatic amino acid biosynthesis. However, the pathways of (demethyl)menaquinone synthesis diverts from that for ubiquinones early on.
Most organisms synthesize their menaquinones via |FRAME: ISOCHORISMATE|, although some organisms, including |FRAME: TAX-210|, |FRAME: TAX-197|, |FRAME: TAX-1902| and |FRAME: TAX-274|, synthesize menaquinones in alternative pathways, via |FRAME: CPD-10477| or |FRAME: CPD-13324| |CITS: [18801996][21489995][23972005]|.

Menaquinones are known to have side chains of different sizes in different organisms, and sometimes even within the same organism. The most common menaquinones contain 7, 8 and 9 isoprene units. However, menaquinones containing 4 |CITS:[413478][6048777]|, 5 |CITS: [6048777][5005959]|, 6 |CITS: [5005959][6102980][5418698][5412037]|, 10 |CITS: [6102980][7462123]|, 11 |CITS: [6102980] [7462123]|, 12 |CITS: [6102980]|, and 13 |CITS: [6102980]| isoprene units have been reported in bacteria.

<b>About This Pathway</b>

The best characterized menaquinone biosynthetic pathway is that of |FRAME: TAX-83333| that synthesizes |FRAME: CPD-9728| (MK-8). MK-8 is not unique to E. coli, and is found in many different bacterial species.

A study of the quinones of halophilic archaebacteria found that MK-8 was the major quinone in most species included in the study, including |FRAME: TAX-2246|, |FRAME: TAX-2250|, |FRAME: TAX-2242|, |FRAME: TAX-2248| and |FRAME: TAX-29284| |CITS: [5049648][4822788][Collins81]|.

MK-8 is very common in facultatively anaerobic Gram negative bacteria, such as the enterobacteria. In addition to |FRAME: TAX-83333| it has been documented in |FRAME: TAX-546|, |FRAME: TAX-548|, |FRAME: TAX-554|, |FRAME: TAX-584|, |FRAME: TAX-585| |CITS: [4886765]| and |FRAME: TAX-615| |CITS: [Bezborodov69]|, as well as the non-eneterobacteria |FRAME: TAX-644|, |FRAME: TAX-648| |CITS: [4886765]| and |FRAME: TAX-51367| |CITS: [Collins81]|.
MK-8 has not been discovered in obligate anaerobes so far.

Some aerobic Gram-negative bacteria that contain MK-8 as their major quinone include the gliding bacterium |FRAME: TAX-33| |CITS: [4216336]|, and several members of the |FRAME: TAX-1297| phylum, including |FRAME: TAX-271| and |FRAME: TAX-274| |CITS: [7462123][7022156]|, |FRAME: TAX-32062|  and |FRAME: TAX-1299| |CITS: [Yamada77]|.

Even though most Gram-positive bacteria contain |FRAME: CPD-9718| as their major quinone, a few are known to make MK-8 instead, including |FRAME: TAX-1473| |CITS: [119033]|, |FRAME: TAX-1428| |CITS: [119033]|, |FRAME: TAX-1618| |CITS: [7462123]|, |FRAME: TAX-37922| |CITS: [Collins81]|, certain |FRAME:TAX-1270| strains |CITS:[Watanuki72][Yamada76]|, and |FRAME:TAX-1373| |CITS:[Yamada76]|.

MK-8 was also found as a minor component in the phototrophic bacteria |FRAME: TAX-1049| |CITS: [14240125]|, |FRAME: TAX-28068| and Rhodospirillum sp. 2761 |CITS: [5727384]|." "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Pathways"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Cofactor-Biosynthesis" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=NIL&object=Generalized-Reactions"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5899"	"superpathway of menaquinol-13 biosynthesis"	"PWY-5899"	"<b>General Background</b>

Menaquinones (MK) and demethylmenaquinones (DMK) are low-molecular weight lipophilic components of the cytoplasmic membrane, found in many bacterial species.  These quinones function as a reversible redox component of the electron transfer chain, mediating electron transfer between hydrogenases and cytochromes.
Menaquinones have also been implicated in regulation, as they are necessary for sporulation and proper regulation of cytochrome formation in some Gram-positive bacteria |CITS: [4353869][4202999]|.

Most aerobic Gram-negative bacteria contain ubiquinone as the sole quinone, while most aerobic Gram-positive bacteria contain menaquinone and/or demethylmenaquinones as the main quinone. However, most of the anaerobic bacteria, regardless whether they are Gram-negative or Gram-positive, contain menaquinone or demethylmenaquinone as their main quinones. Some facultatively anaerobic bacteria, such as |FRAME:TAX-562|, contain ubiquinone, menaquinone, and demethylmenaquinone, which they use under different growth conditions |CITS: [11153266]|. The main difference between
these quinone molecules is their redox potential. For example, the redox potential for ubiquinone, demethylmenaquinone, and menaquinone has been measured as +112 mv, +36 mv, and -74 mv, respectively, in the bacterium |FRAME: TAX-729| |CITS: [187454]|.

Menaquinones are considered a vitamin (vitamin K<sub>2</sub>), since they are essential for animals, mostly for the posttranslational modification of certain proteins required for blood coagulation. Animals can not synthesize menaquinones, but usually receive a sufficient amount from bacteria growing in their intestines. In the absence of menaquinone or the related compound |FRAME: 2-METHYL-3-PHYTYL-14-NAPHTHOQUINONE| (vitamin K<sub>1</sub>) which is synthesized in plants, animals suffer from hemorrhage |CITS: [Dam35]|. Menaquinone was first isolated from putrefied fish meal by McKee in 1939 |CITS: [17783315]|, and its structure resolved in 1958 |CITS: [Isler58]|.

The biosynthesis of menaquinones is essentially identical to that of demethylmenaquinones, with one additional step, comprising the addition of a methyl group to the naphthoquinone ring. Many bacterial species do not have this methylase and produce demethylmenaquinone as their sole quinone |CITS: [7022156]|.

All three quinones are synthesized from |FRAME: CHORISMATE|, an intermediate of aromatic amino acid biosynthesis. However, the pathways of (demethyl)menaquinone synthesis diverts from that for ubiquinones early on.
Most organisms synthesize their menaquinones via |FRAME: ISOCHORISMATE|, although some organisms, including |FRAME: TAX-210|, |FRAME: TAX-197|, |FRAME: TAX-1902| and |FRAME: TAX-274|, synthesize menaquinones in alternative pathways, via |FRAME: CPD-10477| or |FRAME: CPD-13324| |CITS: [18801996][21489995][23972005]|.

Menaquinones are known to have side chains of different sizes in different organisms, and sometimes even within the same organism. The most common menaquinones contain 7, 8 and 9 isoprene units. However, menaquinones containing 4 |CITS:[413478][6048777]|, 5 |CITS: [6048777][5005959]|, 6 |CITS: [5005959][6102980][5418698][5412037]|, 10 |CITS: [6102980][7462123]|, 11 |CITS: [6102980] [7462123]|, 12 |CITS: [6102980]|, and 13 |CITS: [6102980]| isoprene units have been reported in bacteria.

<b>About This Pathway</b>

A few bacterial phyla appear to possess menaquinones with very long prenyl side chains. Several oral strains of the |FRAME: TAX-838| genus, which consists of obligate anaerobes, were reported to produce |FRAME: CPD-9721|. This quinone was found in combination with |FRAME: CPD-9722| in |FRAME:TAX-28134| strains VP1 8906D and HS4 and in |FRAME: TAX-83231| strains NP333, 75J1, J1 and WP H61 |CITS: [6102980][6363375]|.

In addition, several species that belong to the |FRAME: TAX-33882| genus were reported to contain |FRAME: CPD-9721| as a minor component. These organisms, which contain |FRAME: CPD-9723| and |FRAME: CPD-9722| as their major quinones, include |FRAME: TAX-33885|, |FRAME: TAX-33918| |CITS:[7462123][7022156]|, |FRAME: TAX-69368| and |FRAME: TAX-2033| |CITS: [6775048]|."
