"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY66-5"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Quinone-Biosynthesis" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Pathways"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Cofactor-Biosynthesis" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=NIL&object=Generalized-Reactions"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=1CMET2-PWY"	"<i>N</i><sup>10</sup>-formyl-tetrahydrofolate biosynthesis"	"1CMET2-PWY"	"<b>General Background</b>

Folates are tripartite molecules comprising pterin, p-aminobenzoate (pABA), and glutamate moieties. In natural folates the pterin ring exists in the dihydro or tetrahydro state. Folate usually has a gamma-linked polyglutamyl tail of up to eight residues attached to the first glutamate. The one-carbon units (methyl or formyl) are either attached to the N-5 of the pterin moiety, to the N-10 of the pABA moiety or bridged in between these two (e.g., 5,10-methenyl or methylene-THF). 10-formyl-tetrahydrofolates are involved in tetrahydrofolate, purine and formate synthesis |CITS: [7868604] [17645794]|. 

<b>About This Pathway</b>

The formation of the formyl and methyl derivatives of tetrahydrofolate (vitamin B9) directly involved in or representing sidesteps of the biosynthesis of this vital cofactor is displayed in this pathway. Conversion of 10-formyl-tetrahydrofolate to tetrahydrofolate occurs either directly through hydrolysis or via 5-methyl-tetrahydrofolate in several steps |CITS: [7868604] [17645794]|."			"<i>N</i><sup>10</sup>-formyl-THF biosynthesis"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Folate-Biosynthesis"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Folate-Transformations" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=6-HM-Dihydropterin-PP-Biosynthesis" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7852" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6147" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6614" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6613" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6612" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-2201" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6543" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-3841" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-2161B" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-2161" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=FOLSYN-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=1CMET2-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7853" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6797" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7539"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Vitamin-Biosynthesis"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Cofactor-Biosynthesis"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=FOLSYN-PWY"	"superpathway of tetrahydrofolate biosynthesis and salvage"	"FOLSYN-PWY"	"<b>General Background</b>

Tetrahydrofolate (vitamin B9) and its derivatives, commonly termed folates, are essential cofactors that facilitate the transfer of one-carbon units from donor molecules into important biosynthetic pathways leading to methionine, purine, and pyrimidine biosynthesis. Folates also mediate the interconversion of serine and glycine, play a role in histidine catabolism 
|CITS: [11001804]|, and in plants are also involved in photorespiration, amino acid metabolism and chloroplastic protein biosynthesis |CITS: [11960743]| |CITS: [12644692]|.

Folates are abundant in green leaves, and folic acid was initially isolated from a large amount (four tons) of spinach leaves. The name folate is derived from the Latin <i>folium</i> (leaf) |CITS: [3067148]|.

Folates are modified by the addition of glutamate moieties conjugated one to another via a series of &gamma;-glutamyl links to form an oligo-&gamma;-glutamyl tail. The polyglutamylated forms are usually preferred by the enzymes that use folates since the turnover rate of those compounds is markedly increased |CITS: [9190084][SCOTT00][KIRK94]|. In addition, in eukaryotic cells the glutamylated forms of folate facilitate the retention of the vitamin within the cell and its subcellular compartments |CITS: [1916088]|.

The product of this pathway, |FRAME: THF| (tetrahydropteroylmonoglutamate, H<sub>4</sub>PteGlu<sub>1</sub>,
THF), is merely the parent structure of this large family of coenzymes. Members of the family differ in the oxidation state
of the pteridine ring, the character of the one-carbon substituent at the N5 and N10 positions (see |FRAME: PWY-2201|), and the number of conjugated glutamate residues  (see |FRAME: PWY-2161|).

<b>About This Pathway</b>

This pathway for the <i>de novo</i> biosynthesis of folates is found in bacteria, fungi, and plants.

Folates are tripartite molecules and are made up of a pterin, |FRAME: P-AMINO-BENZOATE| and |FRAME:GLT| moieties.
The first two are synthesized from |FRAME:GTP| and |FRAME:CHORISMATE|, respectively.
The first committed step catalyzed by |FRAME: FOLE-CPLX| converts GTP into |FRAME: DIHYDRONEOPTERIN-P3|.
The triphosphate motif is removed by a still unknown process, and the resulting
|FRAME: DIHYDRO-NEO-PTERIN| is converted to |FRAME: AMINO-OH-HYDROXYMETHYL-DIHYDROPTERIDINE|
by |FRAME: CPLX0-3936| (FolB).
The consecutive action of the FolK, FolP, FolC, and FolA enzymes finally produces the final product, |FRAME: THF| |CITS: [12039964]|.

In plants the pterin moiety is formed from GTP in the cytosol, which couples to pABA (synthesized in plastids) in mitochondria followed by subsequent glutamylation and reduction steps which may take place in cytosol, mitochondria and plastids |CITS: [11960743][11752472]|. The recent discovery that folylpolyglutamate synthases are present in cytosol, mitochondria and plastids with each of them encoded by a different gene in <i>Arabidopsis thaliana</i> |CITS: [11752472]| points to the fact that at least parts of the pathway can be carried out independently in those compartments.

In addition to the <i>de novo</i> pathway, many organisms also possess a salvage pathway that is used to re-synthesize tetrahydrofolate from breakdown products of folates in the cell, such as 5 or 10-formyl-tetrahydrofolate.

<b>About Folates In Animals</b>

While plants and many microorganisms can synthesize folate coenzymes by the <i>de novo</i> synthesis pathway, vertebrates are absolutely dependent on nutritional sources, making folate a vitamin. Food folates exist mainly as  |FRAME: 5-METHYL-THF-GLU-N \"<i>N</i><sup>5</sup>-methyl-tetrahydrofolate\"| and |FRAME:FORMYL-THF-GLU-N \"<i>N</i><sup>10</sup>-formyl-tetrahydrofolate\"| (formyl-H<sub>4</sub>PteGlu<sub>n</sub>) |CITS: [405403]|.

Polyglutamyl folates are hydrolyzed to folylmonoglutamates by |FRAME: HS06361-MONOMER|, and metabolized within the enterocyte into 5-methyl-H<sub>4</sub>PteGlu<sub>1</sub>. This monoglutamyl folate coenzyme is the plasma form of the vitamin |CITS: [13906633][2736319]|, and is transported to peripheral tissues where it is demethylated by the vitamin B12-dependent |FRAME:ENZRXN-5465| to monoglutamyl tetrahydrofolate (H<sub>4</sub>PteGlu<sub>1</sub>).

Insufficient supply of the vitamin in vertebrates leads to anemia in adults, and has been shown to cause neural tube malformation in human embryos |CITS: [11744531]|. In addition, folate defficiency has been linked to a number of other birth defects, several types of cancer, dementia, affective disorders, Down's syndrom, and serious conditions affecting pregnancy outcome (for a review, see |CITS: [11001804]|)." "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Pathways"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Cofactor-Biosynthesis" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=NIL&object=Generalized-Reactions"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6612"	"superpathway of tetrahydrofolate biosynthesis"	"PWY-6612"	"<b>General Background</b>

Tetrahydrofolate (vitamin B9) and its derivatives, commonly termed folates, are essential cofactors that facilitate the transfer of one-carbon units from donor molecules into important biosynthetic pathways leading to methionine, purine, and pyrimidine biosynthesis.
Folates also mediate the interconversion of serine and glycine, play a role in histidine catabolism |CITS: [11001804]|, and in plants are also involved in photorespiration, amino acid metabolism and chloroplastic protein biosynthesis |CITS: [11960743]| |CITS: [12644692]|.

Folates are abundant in green leaves, and folic acid was initially isolated from a large amount (four tons) of spinach leaves. The name folate is derived from the Latin <i>folium</i> (leaf) |CITS: [3067148]|.

Folates are modified by the addition of glutamate moieties conjugated one to another via a series of &gamma;-glutamyl links to form an oligo-&gamma;-glutamyl tail. The polyglutamylated forms are usually preferred by the enzymes that use folates since the turnover rate of those compounds is markedly increased |CITS: [9190084][SCOTT00][KIRK94]|. In addition, in eukaryotic cells the glutamylated forms of folate facilitate the retention of the vitamin within the cell and its subcellular compartments |CITS: [1916088]|.

The product of this pathway, |FRAME: THF| (tetrahydropteroylmonoglutamate, H<sub>4</sub>PteGlu<sub>1</sub>,
THF), is merely the parent structure of this large family of coenzymes. Members of the family differ in the oxidation state
of the pteridine ring, the character of the one-carbon substituent at the N5 and N10 positions (see
|FRAME: PWY-2201|), and the number of conjugated glutamate residues  (see |FRAME: PWY-2161|).

<b>About This Pathway</b>

This pathway for the <i>de novo</i> biosynthesis of folates is found in bacteria, fungi, and plants.

Folates are tripartite molecules and are made up of a pterin, |FRAME: P-AMINO-BENZOATE| and |FRAME:GLT| moieties.
The first two are synthesized from |FRAME:GTP| and |FRAME:CHORISMATE|, respectively.
The first committed step catalyzed by |FRAME: FOLE-CPLX| converts GTP into |FRAME: DIHYDRONEOPTERIN-P3|.
The triphosphate motif is removed by a still unknown process, and the resulting
|FRAME: DIHYDRO-NEO-PTERIN| is converted to |FRAME: AMINO-OH-HYDROXYMETHYL-DIHYDROPTERIDINE|
by |FRAME: CPLX0-3936| (FolB). The consecutive action of the FolK, FolP, FolC, and FolA enzymes finally produces the final product, |FRAME: THF| |CITS: [12039964]|.

In plants the pterin moiety is formed from GTP in the cytosol, which couples to pABA (synthesized in plastids) in mitochondria followed by subsequent glutamylation and reduction steps which may take place in cytosol, mitochondria and plastids |CITS: [11960743][11752472]|.
The recent discovery that folylpolyglutamate synthases are present in cytosol, mitochondria and plastids with each
of them encoded by a different gene in <i>Arabidopsis thaliana</i> |CITS: [11752472]| points to the fact that at least
parts of the pathway can be carried out independently in those compartments.

In addition to the <i>de novo</i> pathway, many organisms also possess a salvage pathway that is used
to re-synthesize tetrahydrofolate from breakdown products of folates in the cell, such as 5 or 10-formyl-tetrahydrofolate.

<b>About Folates In Animals</b>

While plants and many microorganisms can synthesize folate coenzymes by the <i>de novo</i> synthesis pathway, vertebrates are absolutely dependent on nutritional sources, making folate a vitamin.
Food folates exist mainly as |FRAME: 5-METHYL-THF-GLU-N \"<i>N</i><sup>5</sup>-methyl-tetrahydrofolate\"| (<i>N</i><sup>5</sup>-methyl-H<sub>4</sub>PteGlu<sub>n</sub>) and |FRAME: FORMYL-THF-GLU-N \"<i>N</i><sup>10</sup>-formyl-tetrahydrofolate\"| (<i>N</i><sup>10</sup>-formyl-H<sub>4</sub>PteGlu<sub>n</sub>) |CITS: [405403]|.

Polyglutamyl folates are hydrolyzed to folylmonoglutamates by |FRAME: HS06361-MONOMER|, and metabolized within the enterocyte into 5-methyl-H<sub>4</sub>PteGlu<sub>1</sub>. This monoglutamyl folate coenzyme is the plasma form of the vitamin |CITS: [13906633][2736319]|, and is transported to peripheral tissues where it is demethylated by the vitamin B12-dependent |FRAME:ENZRXN-5465| to monoglutamyl tetrahydrofolate (H<sub>4</sub>PteGlu<sub>1</sub>).

Insufficient supply of the vitamin in vertebrates leads to anemia in adults, and has been shown to cause neural tube malformation in human embryos |CITS: [11744531]|. In addition, folate defficiency has been linked to a number of other birth defects, several types of cancer, dementia, affective disorders, Down's syndrom, and serious conditions affecting pregnancy outcome (for a review, see |CITS: [11001804]|)." "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY66-5"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Vitamin-Biosynthesis" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Pathways"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Cofactor-Biosynthesis" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=NIL&object=Generalized-Reactions"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=RIBOSYN2-PWY"	"flavin biosynthesis I (bacteria and plants)"	"RIBOSYN2-PWY"	"|FRAME:RIBOFLAVIN \"Riboflavin\"| is the precursor for the essential flavin cofactors |FRAME:FMN| and |FRAME:FAD|, which are used in a wide variety of redox reactions. Riboflavin is also known as vitamin B2, because it is an essential nutrient and can not be synthesized by mammals.

The biosynthesis of one riboflavin molecule requires one molecule of |FRAME: GTP| and two molecules of
|FRAME: RIBULOSE-5P| as substrates.
The imidazole ring of GTP is hydrolytically opened, yielding a 4, 5-diaminopyrimidine which is converted to
|FRAME: AMINO-RIBOSYLAMINO-1H-3H-PYR-DIONE| by a sequence of deamination, side chain reduction
and dephosphorylation. Condensation of |FRAME: AMINO-RIBOSYLAMINO-1H-3H-PYR-DIONE| with
|FRAME: DIHYDROXY-BUTANONE-P| obtained from |FRAME: RIBULOSE-5P| results in the formation of
|FRAME: DIMETHYL-D-RIBITYL-LUMAZINE|.
Dismutation of the lumazine derivative yields |FRAME: RIBOFLAVIN| and
|FRAME: AMINO-RIBOSYLAMINO-1H-3H-PYR-DIONE|, which is recycled in the pathway |CITS: [10940330]|.

The riboflavin biosynthesis pathway and its enzymes are well understood, although the enzymes catalyzing the dephosphorylation of |FRAME: CPD-1086| has been identified only recently |CITS: [24123841]|. 

Several bifunctional enzymes are involved in this pathway in |FRAME: TAX-562| and |FRAME: TAX-1423|.
One bifunctional enzyme catalyzes the two steps required for converting |FRAME: DIAMINO-OH-PHOSPHORIBOSYLAMINO-PYR| to |FRAME: CPD-1086|. Another such enzyme catalyzes the last two steps of the pathway, |FRAME:ENZRXN-16078| and |FRAME:ENZRXN-16079|.

In addition, in both |FRAME: TAX-562| and |FRAME: TAX-1423| |FRAME: CPLX-7778| is a bifunctional enzyme complex
that catalyzes the two steps leading from |FRAME:AMINO-RIBOSYLAMINO-1H-3H-PYR-DIONE| and
|FRAME:DIHYDROXY-BUTANONE-P| to |FRAME:RIBOFLAVIN| via |FRAME:DIMETHYL-D-RIBITYL-LUMAZINE|.
This complex consists of a core of three &alpha; subunits and 60 &beta; subunits arranged in an icosahedral
capsid around the &alpha; trimer in the central core |CITS: [7473709]|.

Different variations of the pathway are found in the different kingdoms of life.
The enzymes catalyzing the fungal pathway are similar to the bacterial/plant ones, but there is a difference in the order in which they act. Two enzymatic steps are required to convert |FRAME: DIAMINO-OH-PHOSPHORIBOSYLAMINO-PYR| to |FRAME: CPD-1086| - a demaination and a reduction.
In bacteria and plants, the deaminase acts first, followed by the reductase (although both steps are catalyzed by a single
bifunctional enzyme in some organisms) |CITS: [15208317]|, while in fungi the reductase acts first, followed by the deaminase (see |FRAME: PWY-6168|). The archaeal pathway also differs in several steps (see |FRAME: PWY-6167|)."			"riboflavin, FMN and FAD biosynthesis" // "vitamin B<sub>2</sub> biosynthesis"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Flavin-Biosynthesis"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6168" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY0-1597" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY66-366" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6167" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=RIBOSYN2-PWY"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Vitamin-Biosynthesis"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Cofactor-Biosynthesis"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=BIOTIN-BIOSYNTHESIS-PWY"	"biotin biosynthesis I"	"BIOTIN-BIOSYNTHESIS-PWY"	"|FRAME: BIOTIN \"Biotin\"| is an essential cofactor for carboxyl group transfer enzymes such as
|FRAME: ACETYL-COA-CARBOXYLMULTI-CPLX|, and is required by all forms of life |CITS: [ColiSalII]|. 

Despite the importance and prevalance of biotin, its detailed biosynthetic pathway remained enigmatic for over 70 years. The first complete pathway for biotin synthesis was suggested for its synthesis in |FRAME:TAX-562| |CITS: [20693992]|.

Biotin consists of two fused heterocyclic rings and a |FRAME: VALERATE| side chain, derived from a |FRAME: CPD-205|-like structure. The early steps of the pathway, which are described here, are responsible for the synthesis of the precursor of the pimelate moiety in the bacterium |FRAME: TAX-562|. The late steps of the pathway, which are responsible for forming the two rings in the structure of biotin, are described in |FRAME: PWY0-1507|.

The origins of the biotin carbon atoms in |FRAME: TAX-562| are known from <sup>13</sup>C NMR analysis of products labeled <i>in vivo</i> |CITS: [8125118][Indrajit94]|. The C3, C5 and C7 carbons are derived from carbon C1 of acetate, while the C2, C4 and C6 carbons are derived from carbon C2 of acetate. The C1 carbon originates from |FRAME: CARBON-DIOXIDE|. This labeling pattern indicated that the pimeloyl moiety of biotin is formed by head-to-tail incorporation of three intact acetate units, similar to the synthesis of fatty acids |CITS: [Indrajit94]|. As the biotin C1 and C7 atoms show different labeling patterns, free pimelic acid (a symmetrical molecule) could not be an intermediate, and thus it has been assumed that |FRAME: CPD-558| is the precursor |CITS: [Webb07]|.

The elucidation of the pathway proved difficult, mostly since only two genes, |FRAME: EG10119| and |FRAME: EG10122|, were implicate in the synthesis of the pimeloyl moiety |CITS: [4563978][8830257][4877129]|.
Based on these finding, there have been several suggestions that enzymes of the fatty acid biosynthesis pathway are involved, although none of these suggestions could explain the full process |CITS: [Indrajit94][13930373]|. An inclusive model was finally suggested in 2010 |CITS: [20693992]|. Based on this model, |FRAME: EG10119 \"BioC\"| converts the free carboxyl group of a |FRAME: MALONYL-COA| thioester to its methyl ester by transfer of a methyl group from |FRAME: S-ADENOSYLMETHIONINE|.The newly acquired methyl group mimics the methyl ends of normal fatty acyl chains, and enables the esterified |FRAME: CPD-12454| to enter the fatty acid synthetic pathway.

Two reiterations of the fatty acid elongation cycle (see |FRAME: FASYN-ELONG-PWY|) produce |FRAME: Pimeloyl-ACP-methyl-esters \"pimeloyl-[acp] methyl ester\"|, which is cleaved by |FRAME: EG10122 \"BioH\"| to give |FRAME: Pimeloyl-ACPs \"pimeloyl-[acp]\"|. The [acp] protein is then removed in a complex reaction catalyzed by |FRAME: EG10121 \"BioF\"|, forming |FRAME: 8-AMINO-7-OXONONANOATE|, the first intermediate in biotin ring assembly.

It should be noted that many organisms that have a |FRAME: EG10119| gene do not have a homolog of the |FRAME: EG10122| gene. A remarkable diversity was found in the enzymes catalyzing this step, with different, non-related genes found in different organisms, including |FRAME: G-17965| from |FRAME: TAX-401614| |CITS: [23152908]|, |FRAME: G-15494| from |FRAME: TAX-93059| |CITS: [23152908]|, |FRAME: G-15495| from |FRAME: TAX-71421| |CITS: [24313380]|, and |FRAME: HP0287| from |FRAME: TAX-210| |CITS: [26868423]|.

The next step in the pathway involves the unusual use of the common methyl-group donor |FRAME: S-ADENOSYLMETHIONINE| as an amino-group donor, a reaction catalyzed by the |FRAME: EG10117|-encoded |FRAME: DAPASYN-CPLX| |CITS: [1092681][1092682][12379100]|. This product of this reaction, |FRAME: DIAMINONONANOATE|, is the target of a unique carboxylase, the |FRAME: EG10120|-encoded |FRAME: DETHIOBIOTIN-SYN-CPLX|. This enzye catalyzes the first ring closure by a carboxylation reaction that does not require biotin as a prosthetic group, forming |FRAME: DETHIOBIOTIN| |CITS: [4921568]|.

The ultimate step in the pathway is catalyzed by |FRAME: BIOTIN-SYN-CPLX|, encoded by |FRAME: EG10118|.
This enzyme inserts a sulfur atom between C6 and C9 of dethiobiotin in a |FRAME: S-ADENOSYLMETHIONINE|-dependent reaction.  It has not been possible to reconstitute a catalytic reaction of this enzyme <i>in vitro</i>, and there is some uncertainty regarding the reaction mechanism, cofactor requirements, and the
source of the sulfur atom |CITS: [15850974]|. However, recent experiments have suggested that a |FRAME: CPD-6| of the enzyme is the source of the sulfur atom.  Consistent with its proposed role as the sulfur donor, degradation of the [2Fe-2S] cluster |CITS: [14967042]| as well as exchange of sulfur atoms between the [2Fe-2S] and [4Fe-4S] clusters |CITS: [16533066]| is observed during turnover of the enzyme.

According to this model, the introduction of the methyl ester early in the pathway disguises the biotin synthetic intermediates so that they become substrates for the fatty acid synthetic pathway. When the synthesis of the pimeloyl moiety is complete and disguise is no longer needed, the methyl group is removed to free the carboxyl group that will eventually be used to attach biotin to its target metabolic enzymes.

An <i>in vitro</i> system that uses dialyzed cell extracts was used in combination with several mutant strains and purified proteins to verify the proposed pathway |CITS: [20693992]|." "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5837"	"2-carboxy-1,4-naphthoquinol biosynthesis"	"PWY-5837"	"|FRAME: DIHYDROXYNAPHTHOATE| is a branch point metabolite leading to the biosynthesis of |FRAME: Menaquinones 
menaquinone| (vitamin K2, in bacteria), |FRAME: 2-METHYL-3-PHYTYL-14-NAPHTHOQUINONE| (vitamin K1 in plants), and many plant pigments, including some two-ring naphthoquinones (such as |FRAME: CPD-9608| and |FRAME: HYDROXYNAPHTHOQUINONE|) and the three-ring anthraquinones (such as |FRAME: ALIZARIN| and |FRAME: CPD-9759|). These pigments are mostly found in |FRAME: TAX-24966|, where at least some of them are phytoalexins involved in plant defense. Many of these pigments were used as dyes since the early human history.

The benzenoid ring (or A ring) of 1,4-dihydroxy-2-naphthoate is derived from |FRAME: CHORISMATE|, derived via the shikimate pathway. The quinone ring (or B ring) is formed by addition of |FRAME: 2-KETOGLUTARATE|."	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5863" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=ALL-CHORISMATE-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5861" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5899" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5898" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5897" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5896" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5838" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5862" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5860" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5845" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5840" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5850"			"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=DHNA-Biosynthesis"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5837"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Quinone-Biosynthesis"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Cofactor-Biosynthesis"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5509"	"adenosylcobalamin biosynthesis from adenosylcobinamide-GDP I"	"PWY-5509"	"This pathway describes the late steps in the biosynthesis of adenosylcobalamin starting with |FRAME: ADENOSYLCOBINAMIDE-GDP| - the last common intermediate used for the synthesis of cobamides with different lower ligand bases. By definition, the lower ligand base of cobalamin-type B12 vitamins is |FRAME: DIMETHYLBENZIMIDAZOLE|.

In this pathway |FRAME: DIMETHYLBENZIMIDAZOLE| is tethered to the corrin ring via a structure known as the nucleotide loop, which is composed from |FRAME:R-1-AMINOPROPAN-2-YL-PHOSPHATE| and |FRAME:DIMETHYLBENZIMIDAZOLE|.

Until 2007 it was believed that the last reaction in the biosynthesis of |FRAME:ADENOSYLCOBALAMIN| was the linking of |FRAME:ALPHA-RIBAZOLE| (a product of |FRAME: DIMETHYLBENZIMIDAZOLE|) to |FRAME:ADENOSYLCOBINAMIDE-GDP|, in a reaction catalyzed by cobalamine synthase. However, it has been shown that at least in |FRAME: TAX-90371| the true substrate for the enzyme is |FRAME:ALPHA-RIBAZOLE-5-P|, and not |FRAME:ALPHA-RIBAZOLE| |CITS: [17209023]|, and that the product of the reaction is actually |FRAME:ADENOSYLCOBALAMIN-5-P|. Thus, there is one more reaction in the pathway, the dephosphorylation of |FRAME:ADENOSYLCOBALAMIN-5-P| to |FRAME:ADENOSYLCOBALAMIN|, which is catalyzed by |FRAME:MONOMER-13213|, the enzyme initially proposed to catalyze the dephosphorylation of |FRAME: ALPHA-RIBAZOLE-5-P| |CITS: [17209023]|.

This model addresses several questions that were associated with the previous model, such as the presence of |FRAME:ADENOSYLCOBALAMIN-5-P| (which has been documented much earlier in the organism |FRAME: TAX-1752| |CITS: [4296474]|), the higher affinity of the CobS protein (and its homologs in other organisms) towards |FRAME:ALPHA-RIBAZOLE-5-P|, and the inability of |FRAME:G-10054| mutants to salvage cobyrate under aerobic conditions |CITS: [17209023]|.

For more information, please see the summaries for the pathways |FRAME:PWY-5507| and |FRAME:P381-PWY|."	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5507" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=P381-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6269" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=COBALSYN-PWY"			"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Adenosylcobamide-Biosynthesis"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=De-Novo-Adenosylcobalamin-Biosynthesis" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7961" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7969" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7966" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7963" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=P381-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5507" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7970" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7967" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7964" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5509" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7975" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7968" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7965"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Cobamide-De-Novo-Biosynthesis"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Cobalamin-Biosynthesis"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=COBALSYN-PWY"	"superpathway of adenosylcobalamin salvage from cobinamide I"	"COBALSYN-PWY"	"<i>De novo</i> synthesis of cobamides requires a great deal of genetic information, which is only found in some prokaryotes.
Many bacterial species do not have the full genetic information required for <i>de novo</i> biosynthesis of |FRAME: ADENOSYLCOBALAMIN|, but can synthesize cobalamin when supplied with |FRAME: COBINAMIDE|, a stable cobamide that is not a true intermediate of the <i>de novo</i> pathway |CITS: [14351147][8770581]|.

In order to process |FRAME: COBINAMIDE| to |FRAME: ADENOSYLCOBALAMIN|, it has to be converted into a real intermediate of the pathway. In most bacteria this is done by the attachment of the upper ligand 5'-deoxyadenosine to yield |FRAME: ADENOSYLCOBINAMIDE|, followed by phosphorylation to yield |FRAME: ADENOSYLCOBINAMIDE-P|, an intermediate of the <i>de novo</i> biosynthetic pathway (this pathway).

Archaebacteria as well as many bacterial species utilze a different salvage pathway, where |FRAME: ADENOSYLCOBINAMIDE| is first converted to |FRAME: CPD-691| (see |FRAME: PWY-6269|).

"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY66-5"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Cobamide-Salvage" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Pathways"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Cobalamin-Biosynthesis" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=NIL&object=Generalized-Reactions"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6269"	"superpathway of adenosylcobalamin salvage from cobinamide II"	"PWY-6269"	"<i>De novo</i> synthesis of cobamides requires a great deal of genetic information, which is only found in some prokaryotes.
Many bacterial species do not have the full genetic information required for <i>de novo</i> biosynthesis of |FRAME: ADENOSYLCOBALAMIN|, but can synthesize cobalamin when supplied with |FRAME: COBINAMIDE|, a stable cobamide that is not a true intermediate of the <i>de novo</i> pathway |CITS: [14351147][8770581]|.

In order to process |FRAME: COBINAMIDE| to |FRAME: ADENOSYLCOBALAMIN|, it has to be converted into a real intermediate of the pathway. In most bacteria this is done by the attachment of the upper ligand 5'-deoxyadenosine to yield |FRAME: ADENOSYLCOBINAMIDE|, followed by phosphorylation to yield |FRAME: ADENOSYLCOBINAMIDE-P|, an intermediate of the <i>de novo</i> biosynthetic pathway (see |FRAME: COBALSYN-PWY|).

Archaebacteria utilze a different salvage pathway, where |FRAME: ADENOSYLCOBINAMIDE| is first converted to |FRAME: CPD-691| by |FRAME: EC-3.5.1.90| (CbiZ). |FRAME: CPD-691 \" Adenosylcobyrate\"| is then converted to |FRAME: ADENOSYLCOBINAMIDE-P| by the action of |FRAME: EC-6.3.1.10| (CbiB) |CITS: [14990804]|.

Archaea possess several enzymes that are non-orthologous replacements for the bacterial genes. For example, the archaeal |FRAME: G-11341| catalyzes the same reaction as the bacterial |FRAME: G-10054| |CITS: [16547066]|, and the archaeal |FRAME: G-11343| replaces the bacterial |FRAME: G-502| and |FRAME: G-10056| |CITS: [12486068]|.
Some archaea carry the |FRAME: G-11342| gene, which encodes a fusion of the genes |FRAME: G-11339| and |FRAME: G-11341| |CITS: [16740929]|.

There are many bacterial species that carry the genes of the archaeal salvage pathway. It is believed that the origin of the genes is archaeal, and that the bacterial genes were acquired by horizontal gene transfer |CITS: [18808385]|

"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Pathways"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Cobalamin-Biosynthesis" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=NIL&object=Generalized-Reactions"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=P42-PWY"	"incomplete reductive TCA cycle"	"P42-PWY"	"<b>General Background</b>

The complete, oxidative tricarboxylic acid (TCA) cycle plays a central role in the energy metabolism of
aerobic organisms.  In most autotrophic bacteria and anaerobic archaea, the TCA cycle operates in a
reductive, biosynthetic direction  (see MetaCyc pathways |FRAME: TCA| and |FRAME: P23-PWY|).
Some anaerobic archaea such as |FRAME: TAX-2271|, contain an oxidative TCA cycle that uses
elemental sulfur or thiosulfate as terminal electron acceptor |CITS: [Selig94]| and reviewed in
|CITS: [9084754]|.  Incomplete oxidative or reductive TCA cycles have also been identified in some
organisms, including obligate autotrophs and methanotrophs.  Although the gene encolding
&alpha;-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase is absent, or not expressed, these incomplete cycles can still
convert pyruvate to necessary biosynthetic intermediates in response to anaerobic, or microaerophilic
growth conditions (reviewed in |CITS: [15449607]|).

Methanogens (anaerobic archaea) lack the ability to perform a complete oxidative or reductive TCA cycle,
and biosynthetic intermediates are proposed to be synthesized by incomplete cycles (in
|CITS: [15595725]|).  Most methanogens use the incomplete reductive TCA cycle for biosynthesis of
intermediates (in |CITS: [3922956]|).  An incomplete reductive TCA cycle has been shown in the
methanogen |FRAME: TAX-2203| using <sup>13</sup>C labeling and NMR, although no
enzyme assays were provided |CITS: [6619097]|.  It has also been shown in |FRAME: TAX-145262| by
radiolabeled succinate incorporation studies |CITS: [29586]|.

<b>About This Pathway</b>

Enzymes of an incomplete reductive TCA cycle have been experimentally demonstrated in the
autotrophic methanogen |FRAME: TAX-39152| |CITS: [3667534]| and the pathway is shown here.
Acetyl-CoA entering this pathway may be biosynthesized by the acetyl-CoA pathway of autotrophic
carbon dioxide fixation (see |FRAME: CODH-PWY|) |CITS: [11607093] [3133359]|, or it may be
biosynthesized from acetate when this facultative autotroph is grown on acetate (see
|FRAME: PWY0-1313|) |CITS: [3667534]|. Acetyl-CoA is converted to pyruvate by |FRAME: CPLX-7031|,
and pyruvate is converted to the necessary biosynthetic intermediates |FRAME:OXALACETIC_ACID|,
|FRAME: SUC-COA|, and |FRAME:2-KETOGLUTARATE|. The later is a precursor of |FRAME:GLT|,
as indicated by the pathway link.

The acetogenic methanogens |FRAME: TAX-2208| and |FRAME: TAX-2223| have
been shown to contain incomplete oxidative TCA cycles involved in acetate assimilation
(in |CITS: [762016] [3840474] [3922956]|).  Evidence for an incomplete oxidative TCA cycle for amino
acid biosynthesis in the cold-adapted (psychrophilic) archaeon |FRAME: TAX-29291| has
been obtained by proteomic analysis, but no enzyme activity assays were provided |CITS: [15595725]|.  

It should be noted, however, that if current genome-based predictions are verified experimentally,
some organisms, such as |FRAME: TAX-145262|, with incomplete TCA
cycles might eventually be shown to contain complete cycles.  In these cases, other gene products
would provide the missing enzyme activity (|CITS: [14568143]|, and reviewed in |CITS: [10390638]|)."	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6146"		"citric acid cycle variant" // "tricarboxylic acid cycle variant" // "TCA cycle variation I" // "incomplete reductive tricarboxylic acid cycle"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Reductive-TCA-Cycles"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=P42-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5392" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=P23-PWY"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Autotrophic-CO2-Fixation"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=CO2-Fixation"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6387"	"UDP-<i>N</i>-acetylmuramoyl-pentapeptide biosynthesis I (<i>meso</i>-diaminopimelate containing)"	"PWY-6387"	"Peptidoglycan is best described as a fisherman's net, with each cell of the mesh defined by two segments of parallel, glycan threads, held together by two small elastic peptide crosslinks, which allow the net to expand or shrink |CITS: [10532377]|. These peptide crosslinks are usually composed of two petapeptides, each attached in one end to one of the glycan segment and extending towards (but no reaching) the other one. The two pentapeptides can form a crosslink with each other in more than one way.

The composition and structure of peptidoglycan varies among different bacterial species, but in generals consists of alternating &beta;-1,4-linked <i>N</i>-acetylglucosamine and <i>N</i>-acetyl muramate residues. The pentapeptide is bound through its N terminus to the carboxyl group of muramate.

The petapeptide is formed through the action of soluble enzymes that couple ATP-hydrolysis to the ligation of the amino acid monomers. This ATP-dependent coupling of amino acid monomers and elongating peptides by soluble enzymes is very unusual, as oligopeptides are usually formed either by ribosomes or by |FRAME: Non-ribosomal-peptide-synthetases \"nonribosomal peptide synthases\"|. A similar mechanism is also found in the |FRAME: GLUTATHIONESYN-PWY \"biosynthesis of glutathione\"|.

The pentapeptide, which contains alternating L and D amino acids, reveals considerable variation among species, with the greatest variation found in the third position. This pathway describes the biosynthesis of the |FRAME: UDP-NAcMur-Peptides \"UDP-<i>N</i>-acetylmuramoyl-pentapeptide\"| found in most of the Gram-negative organisms and some Gram-positive organisms, which contains |FRAME: MESO-DIAMINOPIMELATE| is the third position.

Review: |CITS: [18266853]|
"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PEPTIDOGLYCANSYN-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6385"			"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Acetylmuramoyl-Pentapeptide-Biosynthesis"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6386" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6387" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7953"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Cell-Wall-Biosynthesis"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Cell-Structure-Biosynthesis"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6386"	"UDP-<i>N</i>-acetylmuramoyl-pentapeptide biosynthesis II (lysine-containing)"	"PWY-6386"	"Peptidoglycan is best described as a fisherman's net, with each cell of the mesh defined by two segments of parallel, glycan threads, held together by two small elastic peptide crosslinks, which allow the net to expand or shrink |CITS: [10532377]|. These peptide crosslinks are usually composed of two petapeptides, each attached in one end to one of the glycan segment and extending towards (but no reaching) the other one. The two pentapeptides can form a crosslink with each other in more than one way.

The composition and structure of peptidoglycan varies among different bacterial species, but in generals consists of alternating &beta;-1,4-linked <i>N</i>-acetylglucosamine and <i>N</i>-acetyl muramate residues. The pentapeptide is bound through its N terminus to the carboxyl group of muramate.

The petapeptide is formed through the action of soluble enzymes that couple ATP-hydrolysis to the ligation of the amino acid monomers. This ATP-dependent coupling of amino acid monomers and elongating peptides by soluble enzymes is very unusual, as oligopeptides are usually formed either by ribosomes or by |FRAME: Non-ribosomal-peptide-synthetases \"nonribosomal peptide synthases\"|. A similar mechanism is also found in the |FRAME: GLUTATHIONESYN-PWY \"biosynthesis of glutatione\"|.

The pentapeptide, which contains alternating L and D amino acids, reveals considerable variation among species, with the greatest variation found in the third position. This pathway describes the biosynthesis of the |FRAME: UDP-NAcMur-Peptides \"UDP-<i>N</i>-acetylmuramoyl-pentapeptide\"| found in most of the Gram-positive organisms, which contains |FRAME:LYS| in the third position.

For a complete peptidoglycan biosynthesis pathway that incorporates this variation of pentapeptide, see |FRAME: PWY-5265|."	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6471" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5265" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6470"			"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Acetylmuramoyl-Pentapeptide-Biosynthesis"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6386" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6387" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7953"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Cell-Wall-Biosynthesis"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Cell-Structure-Biosynthesis"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PEPTIDOGLYCANSYN-PWY"	"peptidoglycan biosynthesis I (<I>meso</I>-diaminopimelate containing)"	"PEPTIDOGLYCANSYN-PWY"	"<b>General Background</b>

The bacterial bag-shaped envelope (sacculus) can resist turgor pressures of 2-5 atmospheres in Gram-negative bacteria, and up to 20 atm in Gram-positive bacteria.
This remarkable tensile strength, combined with elasticity, is achieved by the structure of the cell wall's main component, peptidoglycan (also known as \"basal structure\", \"mucopeptide\", \"glycopeptide\", \"glycosaminopeptide\" and \"murein\"). Peptidoglycan is found on the outside of the cytoplasmic membrane of almost all eubacteria, and is unique to these organisms.

Peptidoglycan is best described as a fisherman net. The mesh of the net is made of two segments of parallel, rather inextensible glycan threads, held together by two small elastic peptide crosslinks allowing the net to expand or shrink |CITS: [10532377]|.
The glycan moiety of the peptidoglycan is remarkably uniform among all bacteria, and is made up of alternating &beta;-1,4-linked <i>N</i>-acetylglucosamine and <i>N</i>-acetyl muramate residues, with an average chain length (in different organisms) of 10 to 65 disaccharide units (although it is about 5000 in |FRAME: TAX-1423|). The peptide moiety is less uniform, as described in |FRAME: PWY-5265|.

<b>About This Pathway</b>

This pathway describes the biosynthesis of the peptidoglycan found in most Gram-negative bacteria, as well as some Gram-positive bacteria. The pathway starts at the cytoplasm, where in six steps the peptidoglycan precursor |FRAME:UDP-NAcMur-Peptides| is synthesized. This precursor is then attached to the memberane acceptor |FRAME:UNDECAPRENYL-P|, generating |FRAME:NAcMur-Peptide-Undecaprenols|, also known as lipid I.
Another transferase then adds |FRAME:UDP-N-ACETYL-D-GLUCOSAMINE|, yielding the complete monomeric unit |FRAME:NAcMur-Peptide-NAcGlc-Undecaprenols|, also known as lipid II.

This final lipid intermediate is transferred by an as yet unknown mechanism through the membrane. The peptidoglycan monomers are then polymerized on the outside surface by glycosyltransferases, which form the linear glycan chains, and transpeptidases, which catalyze the formation of peptide crosslinks |CITS: [11320055]|. While some of these enzymes are mono-functional, a group of bifunctional proteins possessing both glycosyltransferase and transpeptidase activity plays a major role in this process in both Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria. These bifunctional proteins are known as |FRAME: Class-A-PBPs \"Class A Penicillin-binding Proteins\"| (PBPs) |CITS: [9791115]|.

Peptide crosslinks form between different parts of the peptides depending on the organism. For example, in Mycobacteria and in |FRAME:TAX-562| most links form between the carboxyl group of the penultimate |FRAME: D-ALANINE| (residue 4) of one peptide to the amino group at the D-center of |FRAME: MESO-DIAMINOPIMELATE| (residue 3) of an adjacent peptide of a second glycan chain (as in |FRAME:TAX-562|). The crosslinking reaction is catalyzed by transpeptidases and involves the cleavage of the D-alanyl-D-alanine bond of the donor peptide, providing the energy to drive the reaction. As a result, the peptides in the peptidoglycan polymers are one or two amino acids shorter than the peptides in the monomers.
The transpeptidases include either the bifunctional protein described above (|FRAME: Class-A-PBPs \"Class A PBPs\"|) or monofunctional proteins,  known as |FRAME: Class-B-PBPs \"Class B PBPs\"|.

<b>About the variability of peptidoglycan composition</b>

Peptidoglycan is the only cell wall polymer common to both Gram-negative and Gram-positive bacteria, as well as cyanobacteria.
The composition and structure of peptidoglycan is rather constant among Gram-negative bacteria.
Significant variability is found among Gram-positive bacteria, and is discussed in |FRAME: PWY-5265|.

"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6385"	"peptidoglycan biosynthesis III (mycobacteria)"	"PWY-6385"	"<b>General Background</b>

The bacterial bag-shaped envelope (sacculus) can resist turgor pressures of 2-5 atmpspheres in Gram-negative bacteria, and up to 20 atm in Gram-positive bacteria.
This remarkable tensile strength, combined with elasticity, is achieved by the structure of the cell wall's main component, peptidoglycan (also known as \"basal structure\", \"mucopeptide\", \"glycopeptide\", \"glycosaminopeptide\" and \"murein\"). Peptidoglycan is found on the outside of the cytoplasmic membrane of almost all eubacteria, and is unique to these organisms.

Peptidoglycan is best described as a fisherman net. The mesh of the net is made of two segments of parallel, rather inextensible glycan threads, held together by two small elastic peptide crosslinks allowing the net to expand or shrink |CITS: [10532377]|.
The glycan moiety of the peptidoglycan is remarkably uniform among all bacteria, and is made up of alternating &beta;-1,4-linked <i>N</i>-acetylglucosamine and <i>N</i>-acetyl muramate residues, with an average chain length (in different organisms) of 10 to 65 disaccharide units (although it is about 5000 in |FRAME: TAX-1423|). The peptide moiety is less uniform, as described in |FRAME: PWY-5265|.

<b>About This Pathway</b>

This pathway describes the biosynthesis of peptidoglycan in Mycobacteria. The Mycobacterial peptidoglycan is similar to that found in |FRAME:TAX-562|, with one main difference: the membrane acceptor portion of the molecule is the unusual |FRAME: CPD-11994|, instead of the much more common |FRAME:UNDECAPRENYL-P|.

As in other bacteria, the peptidoglycan monomer precursor |FRAME:UDP-NAcMur-Peptides| is produced in the cytoplasm by six enzymes (see |FRAME: PWY-6387|). This molecule is then attached to |FRAME: CPD-11994| by a transferase encoded by |FRAME: G185E-6364|, generating |FRAME:CPD-11997|, also known as lipid I.

A second transferase, encoded by |FRAME: G185E-6361|, then adds |FRAME:UDP-N-ACETYL-D-GLUCOSAMINE|, yielding lipid II, which carries the full monomer unit, |FRAME: CPD-11998|.

This final lipid intermediate is transferred by an as yet unknown mechanism through the membrane, and the peptidoglycan monomers are then polymerized on the outside surface by glycosyltransferases, which form the linear glycan chains, and transpeptidases, which catalyze the formation of peptide cross-links |CITS: [11320055]|. 

Most of the cross-links in Mycobacteria are between the the carboxyl group of the penultimate |FRAME: D-ALANINE| (residue 4) of one peptide to the amino group at the D-center of |FRAME: MESO-DIAMINOPIMELATE| (residue 3) of an adjacent peptide of a second glycan chain (as in |FRAME:TAX-562|). The reaction is catalyzed by D-D transpeptidases also known as |FRAME: Penicillin-Binding-Proteins \"penicillin-binding proteins\"| (PBPs), and involves the cleavage of the D-alanyl-D-alanine bond of the donor peptide, providing the energy to drive the reaction.

However, about third of the linkages are between the carboxyl group at the L-center of a |FRAME: MESO-DIAMINOPIMELATE| of one chain and the amino group at the D-center of the |FRAME: MESO-DIAMINOPIMELATE| of another peptide side chain, resulting in an L,D-cross-link |CITS: [4210702 ]|. In stationary phase bacteria up to 80% of the cross-links were in the L,D form |CITS:[18408028]|. The |FRAME: G185E-4233-MONOMER| has been identified as the product of the |FRAME: G185E-4233| gene |CITS: [18408028]|. The prevalance of L,D cross-links enables the bacteria to resist &beta;-lactam antiobiotics." "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=ARGORNPROST-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5863" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY66-5"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Cell-Wall-Biosynthesis" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Pathways"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Cell-Structure-Biosynthesis" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=NIL&object=Generalized-Reactions"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY0-1586"	"peptidoglycan maturation (<i>meso</i>-diaminopimelate containing)"	"PWY0-1586"	"The peptidoglycan (PG) or murein sacculus of <i>E. coli</i> K-12 is assembled from monomer subunits of the disaccharide pentapeptide, <i>N</i>-acetyl-(<i>N</i>-acetylglucosaminyl)muramoyl-L-alanyl-&gamma;-D-glutamyl-<I>meso</I>-2,6-diaminopimeloyl-D-alanyl-D-alanine (also known as GlcNAc-MurNAc-pentapeptide) which are synthesized in the cytoplasm as lipid linked molecules (lipid II) and then flipped across the inner membrane by a flippase protein (see |FRAME: PEPTIDOGLYCANSYN-PWY|). Mature peptidoglycan is assembled on the outer face of the inner membrane through the action of transglycosylases, transpeptidases and peptidoglycan hydrolases. 

Peptidoglycan is a heterogeneous polymer; the length of mature glycan strands varies |CITS: [2285138][3292521]| - the average degree of oligomerization is about 25 to 40 disaccharide units |CITS: [17658458]| - and may be affected by growth conditions. The length of the peptide stem also varies - di-, tri-, tetra- and pentapeptide muropeptides have all been identified - as have different levels of cross-linkage from monomeric peptides to tetrameric peptides |CITS: [3292521]|. Growing glycan chains remain linked to the lipid carrier (<i>di-trans,octa-cis</i>-undecaprenyl phosphate); the terminal residues of released strands are GlcNAc and 1,6-anyhdroMurNAc |CITS: [357]| however the mechanism resulting in release remains unknown - lytic transglycosylases which cleave PG producing 1,6-anyhdroMurNAc muropeptides during PG recycling and turnover do not seem to be involved (see |CITS: [22126997]|.

Transglycosylases catalyse the formation of a &beta;1 &rarr; 4 N-acetylmuramoyl-N-acetylglucosamine bond between a growing glycan chain and a newly flipped disaccharide pentapeptide monomer releasing a molecule of <i>di-trans,octa-cis</i>-undecaprenyl diphosphate (UPP) for recycling in the process. It is not clear whether the growing glycan chain serves as glycosyl donor and the disaccharide monomer as acceptor or vice versa; evidence for the former has been presented (|CITS: [16351056]|). Transpeptidases cross link glycan strands within newly synthesized peptidoglycan and between newly made material and preexisting peptidoglycan; they also link peptidoglycan to Braun's lipoprotein (Lpp) in the outer membrane and catalyse the exchange of carboxy terminal D-alanine residues with glycine in the peptide stem. 

DD-transpeptidases catalyse the cross-linking of the glycan strands between the the D-alanine at position 4 of a pentapeptide stem and the meso-diaminopimelyl residue (m-A<sub>2</sub>pm) at position 3 of a separate tetrapeptide stem (a D-Ala &rarr; m-A<sub>2</sub>pm cross-link); LD transpeptidases catalyse the cross link between two m-A<sub>2</sub>pm residues of separate stems. <i>E. coli K-12</i> contains bifunctional transglycosylases/DD transpeptidases (|FRAME: CPLX0-7717 \"MrcA\"| also known as penicillin binding protein 1A or PBP1A, |FRAME: CPLX0-3951 \"MrcB\"|/PBP1B and |FRAME: G7322-MONOMER \"PbpC\"|/PBP1C) |CITS: [7006606][16840781][7001458][10542235]|, monofunctional DD transpeptidases (|FRAME: EG10606-MONOMER \"MrdA\"|/PBP2, |FRAME: EG10341-MONOMER \"FtsI\"|/PBP3) |CITS: [6297485][3531167]|, a monofunctional transglycosylase (|FRAME: G7668-MONOMER \"MtgA\"|) |CITS: [8772200]| and 2 LD transpeptidases (|FRAME: EG11253-MONOMER \"LdtD\"| and |FRAME: G6904-MONOMER \"LdtE\"|) which form m-A<sub>2</sub>pm &rarr; m-A<sub>2</sub>pm cross links within peptidoglycan |CITS: [18456808]|.  A further three LD-transpeptidases (|FRAME: G7073-MONOMER \"LdtA\"|, |FRAME: G6571-MONOMER \"LdtC\"| and |FRAME: G6422-MONOMER \"LdtB\"|) cleave the m-A<sub>2</sub>pm-d-Ala peptide bond of a peptidoglycan donor stem and link the m-A<sub>2</sub>pm residue to the the C-terminal lysine residue of Braun's lipoprotein and catalyse the exchange of D-alanine with glycine in tetrapeptide stems |CITS: [17369299][18456808]|.   

The murein of <i>E. coli</i> K-12 is characterised by the presence of 'free' penta-, tetra-, and tripeptide stems (ie. stems not involved in cross linkages) in varying proportions. Pentapeptide stems are converted to tetrapeptides by the action of DD carboxypeptidases (primarily |FRAME: EG10201-MONOMER \"DacA or PBP5\"|) which remove the C-terminal D-alanine residue |CITS: [7002918]| while tripeptide stems are formed by cleavage of the (L)-<i>meso</i>-A<sub>2</sub>pm &rarr;D-Ala bond of tetrapeptide stems. This latter reaction is catalysed by the LD-transpeptidase enzymes (LdtA, LdtB, LdtC, LdtD and LdtE) which also have LD-carboxypeptidase activity |CITS: [18456808]|. The amount of dipeptide subunits in isolated murein is low and the mechanism by which they might be formed is not clear.

Please note: This pathway has been designed to include many of the reactions that are involved during the assembly of nascent peptidoglycan but the heterogeneous nature of the mature polymer precludes depiction by a single pathway. This pathway does not depict the insertion of newly made peptidoglycan into the existing sacculus - several models for this process have been proposed (see |CITS: [17658458]|). The insertion of new material requires cleavage of mature peptidoglycan and <i>E. coli</i> contains a variety of peptidoglycan hydrolases which cleave the glycoside and amide bonds of mature peptidoglycan (reviewed in |CITS: [22126997]|). There is a significant turnover of peptidoglycan during cell growth and this is accompanied by recycling of the turnover products for reuse (see |FRAME: PWY0-1261| and |FRAME: PWY0-1546|).

Reviews: |CITS: [1779930][11320055][17658458][18081839][22126997]|"				"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Peptidoglycan-Biosynthesis"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6470" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6471" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY0-1586" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6385" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PEPTIDOGLYCANSYN-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5265"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Cell-Wall-Biosynthesis"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Cell-Structure-Biosynthesis"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6467"	"Kdo transfer to lipid IV<SUB>A</SUB> III (Chlamydia)"	"PWY-6467"	"|FRAME: Lipopolysaccharides Lipopolysaccharides| (LPS) are a major component of the outer membrane of Gram-negative bacteria. While they protect the membrane from certain kinds of chemical attacks, they also induce a strong response from animal immune systems. 

Lipopolysaccharides can be conceptually divided into three parts: |FRAME: Lipid-A \"lipid A\"|, which anchors LPS into the membrane; the |FRAME: LPS-Core-Oligosaccharides \"core oligosaccharide\"|, which contributes to membrane stability; and the |FRAME: O-Antigens O-antigen|, which is a polysaccharide that extends away from the cell surface.

Lipid A, which is common to most Gram-negative bacteria, is the most toxic part and elicits the strongest immune response. Despite some variability in its structure, it is rather conserved among species. The core oligosaccharide, which contains unusual 7-carbon and 8-carbon sugars, is genus-specific, and and the <i>O</i>-antigen side chains vary greatly in their structure and toxicity. The polysaccharide usually contains of about 20-40 repeats of the <i>O</i>-antigen basic monomeric unit.

|FRAME: KDO \"3-Deoxy-D-<i>manno</i>-octulosonate\"| (known as Kdo, which is an acronym for its old name ketodeoxyoctonate) is a part of the inner core of lipopolysaccharides. It is added to the lipid A precursor |FRAME: LIPID-IV-A| in sequential steps, with different Kdo units added by different linkages. The first unit is always added by a (2->6) glycosidic linkage and the second one by a (2->4) linkage.

Bacteria of the |FRAME: TAX-810| genus contain a genus-specific epitope that consists of the trisccharide &alpha;-Kdo-(2->8)-&alpha;-Kdo-(2->4)-&alpha;-Kdo (in the form of |FRAME: CPD-12281|) |CITS: [7686488][7515346]|. 

The third Kdo unit in this epitope was shown to be attached by the same enzyme that attaches the other two units. The |FRAME: G-11884| gene of |FRAME: TAX-83558| strain TW-183 that encodes this enzyme has been cloned and expressed in the bacterium |FRAME: TAX-1718|, which lacks any LPS biosynthetic background. The host bacterium produced |FRAME: CPD-12281|, confirming that the enzyme acts as a trifunctional glycosyltransferase |CITS: [8748024]|.

When the |FRAME: G-11886| of |FRAME: TAX-331636| was cloned and expressed in a rough mutant of |FRAME:TAX-562|,
the LPS produced by the mutant was shown to contain two additional products - |FRAME: CPD-12284| and |FRAME: CPD-12285|. Thus this enzyme enables the formation of at least five different bonds |CITS: [7744029]|." "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=NIL&object=Generalized-Reactions"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5100"	"pyruvate fermentation to acetate and lactate II"	"PWY-5100"	"|FRAME: TAX-2336| is a hyperthermophilic anaerobic eubacterium that can utilize various sugars or complex organic substrates as carbon and energy sources. With glucose as a substrate, |FRAME: TAX-2336| produces lactate, acetate, carbon dioxide and hydrogen as the main fermentation products.
Glucose degradation to pyruvate occurs via the conventional Embden-Meyerhof pathway (see |FRAME:ANAGLYCOLYSIS-PWY|  |CITS: [ArchMicr161-460] [8791626] [9075622] [2318202]|.

In this pathway |FRAME:CPLX-1868| replaces the NAD-utilizing |FRAME: PYRUVDEHYD-PWY| that |FRAME:TAX-562| and other organisms use to convert pyruvate to |FRAME: ACETYL-COA| (see MetaCyc pathway |FRAME: P41-PWY|)." "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5747"	"2-methylcitrate cycle II"	"PWY-5747"	"Propionate can have broad negative effects on the bacterial cell functions, including cytosol acidification,
dissipation of the proton motive force, disruption of CoA homeostasis, and, in some cases,
inhibition of the key TCA enzymes aconitase and citrate synthase due to formation of |FRAME: CPD-622|.
For these reasons propionate is sometimes used as a preservative in foods.
However, some bacteria are able to degrade propionate, and even use it the sole carbon source. Out
of all the propionate degradation pathways, the 2-methylcitric acid cycle is the most widely destributed.
In this pathway, the C&alpha; methylene group of propionate is oxidized to a keto group yielding
|FRAME:PYRUVATE|, a common precursor for biosynthesis and energy production.

The pathway, which was discovered in fungi |CITS: [Tabuchi74]| was best characterized in
|FRAME: TAX-90371| |CITS:[10482501][11294638]| (see |FRAME: PWY0-42|).
In that organism the pathway begins with the activation of |FRAME: PROPIONATE| to
|FRAME: PROPIONYL-COA| by |FRAME: MONOMER-62|, followed by the synthesis of
|FRAME: CPD-622| from |FRAME: PROPIONYL-COA| and |FRAME:OXALACETIC_ACID|, catalyzed
by |FRAME: MONOMER-63|. |FRAME: CPD-622| is then dehydrated to |FRAME: CPD-1136| by
|FRAME: MONOMER-64|, followed by rehydration to |FRAME: CPD-618| (catalyzed by
|FRAME: MONOMER-65| and |FRAME: MONOMER-13618|) and cleavage of the later into
|FRAME:PYRUVATE| and |FRAME:SUC|, performed by |FRAME: CPLX-7556|. 

As mentioned above, pyruvate is a common precursor for biosynthesis and energy production.
Oxaloacetate may be regenerated from succinate via the |FRAME:TCA| |CITS: [10482501]|.

<b>About This Pathway</b>

A key reaction in the |FRAME: TAX-90371| pathway catalyzes the conversion of |FRAME: CPD-622| to
|FRAME: CPD-1136|. This reaction is catalyzed by the |FRAME: MONOMER-64| enzyme, encoded by
the |FRAME: G-10383| gene. Some organisms do not have this enzyme, and thus utilize a different
variant of the pathway. These organism use a combination of two enzymes, encoded by the
|FRAME: G-10386| and |FRAME: G-10387| enzymes |CITS:[11495997][14702315]|. Characterization of
the proteins revealed that the |FRAME: G-10386| gene product is a |FRAME: MONOMER-13619|, 
while the |FRAME: G-10387| gene product is an isomerase that catalyzes the transfer between
|FRAME: CPD-9421| and |FRAME: CPD-1136|. Since both proteins are required for the pathway to
proceed, the dehydratase must produce a stereoisomer of 2-methylaconitate that is not a substrate for
the aconitate hydratase enzyme, which catalyzes the next step, and thus this stereoisomer must be
converted by |FRAME: CPLX-7555| to the different form |CITS: [17567742]|.

The Gram-negative bacterium |FRAME: TAX-106590| possesses both a <i>prpD</i> gene and  the <i>acnD</i>
(called <i>acnM</i> in that organism) and <i>prpF</i> genes. However, it was shown by gene
inactivation that while the <i>prpD</i> gene was dispensible, the latter two genes were required for growth
on propionate, suggesting that the organism is utilizing this variant of the pathway |CITS: [11495997]|.
In addition, |FRAME: TAX-106590|, like several other organisms, lack the <i>prpE</i> gene. It is assumed that
in these organisms |FRAME:MONOMER-13637| is responsible for propionate activation |CITS:[11495997]|."				"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Methyl-Citrate-Cycle"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5747" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY0-42"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Propionate-Degradation"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=CARBOXYLATES-DEG"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6737"	"starch degradation V"	"PWY-6737"	"<b>General Background</b>

Many organisms including bacteria, fungi, metazoa, and plants can degrade glucose polymers derived from |FRAME: Starch| or |FRAME: Glycogens glycogen| (see pathways |FRAME: PWY-6724|, |FRAME: PWY-842|, |FRAME: GLYCOCAT-PWY| and |FRAME: PWY-5941|).  Some hyperthermophilic archaea have also been shown to produce |FRAME: Starch|-degrading enzymes, and pathways for the utilization of |FRAME: Starch| and its derivatives, such as |FRAME: Cyclodextrins|, |FRAME: Maltodextrins|, and |FRAME: MALTOSE| have been proposed.  These hyperthermophilic archaea can utilize |FRAME: Starch| and its degradation products as primary carbon sources during anaerobic growth.  Thermostable starch-degrading enzymes produced by hyperthermophilic organisms are of industrial interest |CITS: [16513741] [11489857] [17921308] [11702074]|.

|FRAME: TAX-186497| was shown to degrade |FRAME: Starch| mainly via maltodextrins in a pathway involving an extracellular amylopullulanase, a transporter, an intracellular 4-&alpha;-glucanotransferase, and a maltodextrin phosphorylase, as described below in <b>About This Pathway</b> (|CITS: [16513741]| and in |CITS: [17921308]|).

The sulfate-reducing archaeon |FRAME: ORG-6178| has been shown to degrade |FRAME: Starch| via a unique pathway involving cyclodextrin intermediates |CITS: [17921308] [11702074]| (see pathway |FRAME: PWY-6731|).

In the hyperthermophilic archaeon |FRAME: TAX-91619| evidence suggested a |FRAME: Starch| degradation pathway via formation of cyclodextrins from |FRAME: Starch| extracellularly by a |FRAME: MONOMER-16282|, transport of cyclodextrins into the cell, and their degradation by a |FRAME: MONOMER-16283| to the end products |FRAME: MALTOSE| and |FRAME: ALPHA-GLUCOSE| (|CITS: [11489857]| and in |CITS: [17921308]|) (see pathway |FRAME: PWY-6735|).

Among bacteria |FRAME:TAX-562| cannot utilize |FRAME: Starch|, but it can metabolize short, linear maltodextrins (see pathway |FRAME: GLYCOCAT-PWY|).  However the enterobacterium |FRAME: TAX-290336| can utilize |FRAME: Starch| as a sole source of carbon and energy.  Mutant analysis suggested that it metabolizes |FRAME: Starch| by two pathways.  The first was a proposed maltose/maltodextrin pathway involving extracellular degradation of |FRAME: Starch| by pullulanase and the disproportionation activity of cyclodextrin glucanotransferase to form linear maltodextins.  After transport into the cell they are degraded to |FRAME: GLC| and |FRAME: GLC-1-P| by the products of <i>malP</i>, <i>malQ</i> and <i>malZ</i>.  The second was a proposed cyclodextrin pathway involving extracellular conversion of |FRAME: Starch| to cyclodextrins (see |FRAME: Cyclodextrins|) by cyclodextrin glucanotransferase, transport into the cell, linearization by |FRAME: MONOMER-16314| (CymH) |CITS: [8599539]|, and further catabolism as in the maltose/maltodextrin pathway |CITS: [8594196] [9573146]|.

<b>About This Pathway</b>

The hyperthermophilic archaeon |FRAME: TAX-186497| is an obligately anaerobic heterotroph that is able to utilize a variety of sugars as a primary carbon source.  Its genome encodes many glycosyl hydrolases and transferases, the physiological function of which are unclear.  Using global transcriptional profiling data and biochemical studies |CITS: [16513741]| have defined the pathway for starch metabolism in |FRAME: TAX-186497|.  This pathway involves an |FRAME: MONOMER-16303| (PF1935*) acting extracellularly, and |FRAME: MONOMER-16304| (PF0272), |FRAME: MONOMER-16305| (maltodextrin phosphorylase) (PF1535) and phosphoglucomutase (PF0588) acting intracellularly.  Although other candidates for |FRAME: Starch| degrading enzymes were annotated in the |FRAME: TAX-186497| genome, they did not appear to be functionally involved in |FRAME: Starch| degradation (|CITS: [16513741]| and in |CITS: [17921308]|).

In this pathway |FRAME: Starch| is degraded extracellularly by |FRAME: MONOMER-16303| which has both pullulanase and &alpha;-amylase activity.  Products of its &alpha;-amylase activity include maltodextrins (see |FRAME: Maltodextrins|), |FRAME: MALTOSE| and |FRAME: D-Glucose| |CITS: [15599521] [9293009]|.  Two active transporters Mal-II and Mal-I transport maltodextrins and |FRAME: MALTOSE| respectively, into the cell |CITS: [15803655]|.  A |FRAME: MONOMER-16304| generates |FRAME: ALPHA-GLUCOSE| from |FRAME: MALTOSE| and maltodextrins.  |FRAME: MONOMER-16305| (maltodextrin phosphorylase) converts maltodextrins to |FRAME: GLC-1-P| |CITS: [16513741]|.

The |FRAME: ALPHA-GLUCOSE| and |FRAME: GLC-1-P| produced in the pathway are proposed to enter the novel glycolytic pathway of this organism after conversion of the latter compound to |FRAME: ALPHA-GLC-6-P| by phosphoglucomutase (EC 5.4.2.2) |CITS: [16513741]|.  In aqueous solution the epimers |FRAME: ALPHA-GLUCOSE| and |FRAME: GLC| spontaneously interconvert, forming an equilibrium mixture |CITS: [FRANKS87]|.  Likewise, |FRAME: ALPHA-GLC-6-P| exists in equilibrium with its epimer |FRAME: GLC-6-P|.  These reactions can also be enzyme-catalyzed.  Whether the &alpha;, &beta;, or both &alpha; and &beta; epimers are used depends upon the anomeric specificity of the enzymes that utilize these compounds.




"				"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Starch-Degradation"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-842" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6737" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6724" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6731" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6735"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=POLYSACCHARIDES-DEG"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Carbohydrates-Degradation" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Polymer-Degradation"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=GLYCOGENSYNTH-PWY"	"glycogen biosynthesis I (from ADP-D-Glucose)"	"GLYCOGENSYNTH-PWY"	"<b>General Background</b>

Glycogen is a highly branched glucose polymer that serves as a form of energy storage in animals and fungi. It resembles plant-produced |FRAME: Starch starch| and is sometimes called \"animal starch\".

Glycogen is formed of small chains of 8 to 12 glucose molecules linked together by &alpha; (1->4) bonds. These small chains, also known as |FRAME: Maltodextrins maltodextrins|, are in turn linked together by &alpha; (1->6) bonds. The &alpha;-1,4 linkages make up approximately 95% of the total molecule.  The &alpha;-1,6 branches accounts for 710% of the linkages and are evenly distributed within the glycogen particle.

Since each chain (with the exception of the outer unbranched chains) supports two branches, glycogen particles grow spherically by adding tiers (a tier corresponds to the spherical space separating two consecutive branches from all chains located at similar distance from the center of the particle).
Mathematical modelling predicts a maximal value for the particle size above which further growth is impossible as there would not be sufficient space for interaction of the chains with the catalytic sites of glycogen metabolism enzymes. This generates a particle consisting of 12 tiers corresponding to a 42 nm maximal diameter including 55 000 glucose residues. 36% of this total number rests in the outer (unbranched) shell and is thus readily accessible to glycogen catabolism without debranching |CITS: [12179957]|.

Although glycogen and starch are two distinct physical states of the same type of storage polysaccharide, starch is solid semi-crystalline while glycogen particles are entirely hydrosoluble |CITS: [21220783]|.

Glucose is polymerized within the polysaccharides thanks to its activation in the form of a nucleotide-sugar through the action of NDP-glucose pyrophosphorylase. All eukaryotes known synthesize glycogen from |FRAME: CPD-12575| while all Gram-negative glycogen accumulating bacteria use |FRAME:ADP-D-GLUCOSE| (see |FRAME: PWY-5067| and |FRAME:GLYCOGENSYNTH-PWY|).

<b>About This Pathway</b>

Unlike |FRAME: CPD-12575|, which is used by all living cells to synthesize a large number of different molecules, |FRAME:ADP-D-GLUCOSE| is devoted to the synthesis of glycogen in bacteria (and also to the synthesis of the osmoprotectant glucosylglycerol in cyanobacteria). Thus, the synthesis of ADP-glucose defines the first committed step of glycogen synthesis in bacteria while glucan elongation defines the first committed step of eukaryotic glycogen synthesis. The enzyme catalyzing this reaction, |FRAME: EC-2.7.7.27|, is rate-limiting for the pathway. 

The glucose from the glycosyl-nucleotide is transferred to the non-reducing end of either a maltodextrin or a glycogen primer forming a new &alpha;-1,4-glucosidic linkage in an elongation reaction catalysed by |FRAME: EC-2.4.1.21 \"EC 2.4.1.21, glycogen synthase\"|.

After chain elongation the formation of the branched &alpha;-1,6-glucosidic linkages is catalyzed by the glycogen branching enzyme. Branching proceeds differently through an hydrolytic cleavage of a pre-existing &alpha;-1,4-linked glucan synthesized through glycogen synthase and an intra or intermolecular transfer of a segment of chain in the &alpha;-1,6 position."				"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=GLYCOGEN-BIOSYN"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7900" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=GLYCOGENSYNTH-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5067" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-622"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Polysaccharides-Biosynthesis"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Carbohydrates-Biosynthesis" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Glycan-Biosynthesis"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=GLUCONEO-PWY"	"gluconeogenesis I"	"GLUCONEO-PWY"	"Gluconeogenesis is the generation of glucose from non-sugar carbon substrates such as |FRAME: PYRUVATE|, |FRAME: L-LACTATE|, |FRAME: GLYCEROL|, and glucogenic amino acids (primarily |FRAME: L-ALPHA-ALANINE| and |FRAME: GLN|). The process is essentially the reversal of the |FRAME:GLYCOLYSIS glycolysis| pathway. However, two glycolytic enzymes catalyze irreversible reactions. In order to enable the pathway to flow in the direction of glucose production, these reactions are catalyzed by other enzymes (|FRAME:EC-3.1.3.11| and |FRAME:EC-2.7.9.2|) in the opposite direction.

Enzymes of the gluconeogenic pathway are widely distributed in archaea, bacteria, fungi, plants and animals, and are often considered to be central to the origins of metabolism |CITS: [15803666]|. Note that this pathway describes gluconeogenesis in plants and microorganisms, the mammalian pathway is described at |FRAME: PWY66-399|.

Bacteria use gluconeogenesis to synthesize glucose from non-sugar C2 or C3 compounds or the intermediates of the tricarboxylic acid (TCA) cycle when there sufficient amounts of hexose are not available to them |CITS: [9168612][11815613][16109965][20439709]|.

In photosynthetic organisms, the product of photosynthetic carbon fixation (|FRAME: GAP|) is transported from the chloroplast into the cytoplasm, where it is transformed to hexose phosphate via gluconeogenesis. In plants, these hexose phosphates are used to synthesize sucrose, as documented in |FRAME: PWY-7347| |CITS: [Sung88]|."				"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Gluconeogenesis"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6142" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY66-399" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=GLUCONEO-PWY"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=CARBO-BIOSYNTHESIS"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Carbohydrates-Biosynthesis"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=CALVIN-PWY"	"Calvin-Benson-Bassham cycle"	"CALVIN-PWY"	"The Calvin cycle is the major |FRAME: CARBON-DIOXIDE| fixation pathway, found in all in green plants and many autotrophic bacteria.

In this cycle, one |FRAME: CARBON-DIOXIDE| molecule at a time is added to the acceptor molecule |FRAME: D-RIBULOSE-15-P2| (RuBP) generating two molecules of |FRAME: G3P|. The |FRAME: G3P| is then passed through a cyclic series of reactions in which the acceptor molecule (RuBP) is regenerated. Out of the six carbons present in two molecules of |FRAME: G3P|, five are recycled and only one remains available for biosynthesis. Since in each turn of the cycle only one carbon atom is assimilated, the cycle must go through three turns to produce one molecule of |FRAME: G3P|, or six turns to produce one molecule of a hexose sugar.

The Calvin cycle can be divided into three stages: fixation, reduction and regeneration.

In the first stage the reductive carboxylation of |FRAME: D-RIBULOSE-15-P2| (RuBP) is catalyzed by the the enzyme |FRAME:CPLX-105| (RubisCO), forming 2 molecules of |FRAME: G3P|. 

In the second stage these two molecules are phosphorylated to |FRAME: DPG| and then reductively dephosphorylated to |FRAME: GAP|. In three turns of the cycle 3 molecules of |FRAME: CARBON-DIOXIDE| are fixed, and 6 molecules of |FRAME: GAP| are formed. Out of these, one is diverted to biosynthetic pathways, while the other 5 are used up in the next stage.

The third stage is the most complicated one. It consists of a series of rearrangements that eventually regenerate RuBP.
Some of the |FRAME:GAP| molecules are converted to |FRAME:DIHYDROXY-ACETONE-PHOSPHATE|. |FRAME:GAP| and |FRAME:DIHYDROXY-ACETONE-PHOSPHATE| are then condensed into |FRAME:FRUCTOSE-16-DIPHOSPHATE| which is dephosphorylated to |FRAME:FRUCTOSE-6P|. |FRAME:FRUCTOSE-6P| is then combined with another |FRAME: GAP| molecule and cleaved into |FRAME:XYLULOSE-5-PHOSPHATE| (X5P) and |FRAME:ERYTHROSE-4P|. The later is combined with |FRAME:DIHYDROXY-ACETONE-PHOSPHATE| forming |FRAME: D-SEDOHEPTULOSE-1-7-P2|, which is dephosphorylated to |FRAME:D-SEDOHEPTULOSE-7-P|. 
|FRAME:D-SEDOHEPTULOSE-7-P| is combined with |FRAME: GAP| and is cleaved into a second |FRAME:XYLULOSE-5-PHOSPHATE| and a |FRAME:RIBOSE-5P| (R5P). Both of these are converted into |FRAME:RIBULOSE-5P|, which is finally phosphorylated to |FRAME: D-RIBULOSE-15-P2|, regenerating the key |FRAME: CARBON-DIOXIDE|-acceptor molecule.

During this cycle, especially during the day, |FRAME: G3P|, |FRAME:DIHYDROXY-ACETONE-PHOSPHATE|, or |FRAME:GAP| can be siphoned off and sent out to the cytosol via the triose phosphates transporter for |FRAME: SUCSYN-PWY|. Plants need to carefully control the carbon flux between this and competeing pathways to make sure that the Calvin cycle can proceed |CITS: [19325167]|."	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7218" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6886" //
