"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-181"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=CO2-Fixation" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Carbohydrates-Biosynthesis" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Energy-Metabolism"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=C1-COMPOUNDS" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Biosynthesis" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Pathways"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5189"	"tetrapyrrole biosynthesis II (from glycine)"	"PWY-5189"	"Tetrapyrrole compounds include four rings of the pyrrole type, generally linked
together by single-atom bridges between the &alpha; positions of the five-membered pyrrole rings.
Tetrapyrroles usually function as a metal-binding cofactor in many important enzymes, proteins and pigments,
such as heme, chlorophyll, cobalamine (vitamin B12), siroheme, and cofator F430.

The tetrapyrrole biosynthetic pathway shown here beginning
with glycine and succinyl-CoA (a TCA cycle intermediate) is found in animals, fungi, apicomplexan protozoa (such
as the malaria parasite |FRAME: TAX-5833| |CITS: [15144063]|), and members of the
&alpha;-proteobacteria.  In other bacteria (including |FRAME:TAX-562|) and archaea, tetrapyrrole biosynthesis
begins with glutamate instead of glycine (see |FRAME: PWY-5188|). Plants, who biosynthesize
tetrapyrrole for use as heme and chlorophyll, also synthesize it from glutamate.
Interestingly, the chloroplast-containing protozoan |FRAME: TAX-3039| possesses both pathways.

Regardless whether the starting point is glycine or glutamate, both pathways converge at the intermediate
|FRAME: 5-AMINO-LEVULINATE| and proceed through the important intermediate
|FRAME:UROPORPHYRINOGEN-III|, which is a major branch point that leads to biosynthesis of different
tetrapyrrole compounds, such as the corrinoid cobalamine
(vitamin B<sub>12</sub>) (see MetaCyc pathways |FRAME: P381-PWY| and |FRAME: PWY-5507|),
the methanogenic coenzyme F<sub>430</sub> (see |FRAME: PWY-5196|), |FRAME: SIROHEME|
(see |FRAME: PWY-5194|), and heme D.

This pathway has been studied in the photosynthetic purple nonsulfur &alpha;-proteobacterium |FRAME: TAX-1063|, which posesses two chromosomes and five additional replicons. In this organism there are two genes encoding  5-aminolevulinate synthase, |FRAME: G-9025| and |FRAME:G-10074|, that are present on chromosomes 1 and 2, respectively.
Biosynthesis of the tetrapyrrole cofactors |FRAME: Hemes|, |FRAME: CPD-9067|, |FRAME: SIROHEME| and |FRAME: COB-I-ALAMIN| in this organism is highly regulated and is dependent upon expression of these two isozymes (in |CITS: [7592416], [10491185]|)."	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5529" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5920"			"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Tetrapyrrole-Biosynthesis"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5188" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5189"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Cofactor-Biosynthesis"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Biosynthesis"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5188"	"tetrapyrrole biosynthesis I (from glutamate)"	"PWY-5188"	"Tetrapyrroles are compounds whose molecules have four rings of the pyrrole type, generally linked together by single-atom bridges between the alpha positions of the five-membered pyrrole rings. Tetrapyrroles function as a metal-binding cofactor in many important enzymes, proteins and pigments, such as heme, chlorophyll, cobalamine (vitamin B12), siroheme, and cofator F430.
The biosynthesis of all of these cofactors start in a similar manner, with the production of the intermediate |FRAME: UROPORPHYRINOGEN-III|. This intermediate is an important branch point: its methylation directs it toward siroheme, cobalamin or cofactor F430 synthesis, while decarboxylation directs it toward the synthesis of heme and chlorophyll |CITS: [14633982]|.

The tetrapyrrole biosynthetic pathway shown here, which starts with glutamate, is found in plants, many bacteria (including |FRAME:TAX-562|), and the archaea. A second tetrapyrrole biosynthetic pathway, which is found in animals, fungi, certain protozoans, and members of the &alpha;-proteobacteria, starts with glycine and succinyl-coA (see
|FRAME:PWY-5189|). Interestingly, both pathways are present in the chloroplast-containing protozoan |FRAME: TAX-3039|.

Regardless whether the starting point is glycine or glutamate, both pathways converge at the intermediate |FRAME: 5-AMINO-LEVULINATE| and proceed through the important intermediate |FRAME:UROPORPHYRINOGEN-III|, which is a major branch point that leads to biosynthesis of different tetrapyrrole compounds, such as the corrinoid cobalamine (vitamin B<sub>12</sub>) (see MetaCyc pathway |FRAME: P381-PWY|), the methanogenic coenzyme F<sub>430</sub> (see |FRAME: PWY-5196|),  |FRAME: SIROHEME| (see |FRAME: PWY-5194|, and heme D."	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5507" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=P381-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5918"			"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Tetrapyrrole-Biosynthesis"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5188" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5189"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Cofactor-Biosynthesis"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Biosynthesis"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=POLYISOPRENSYN-PWY"	"polyisoprenoid biosynthesis (<i>E. coli</i>)"	"POLYISOPRENSYN-PWY"	"In this pathway multiple units of |FRAME: DELTA3-ISOPENTENYL-PP| (IPP) undergo a series of
polymerizations to form various polyisoprenoids.

There are two different pathways for the biosynthesis of IPP. Bacteria that possess ubiquinone generally
use the |FRAME: NONMEVIPP-PWY| (MEP), while the eukaryotic microorganisms use the
|FRAME: PWY-922|. However, exceptions exist - for example, some eukaryotic microbes, like the green
algae and the malarial parasite |FRAME: TAX-5833|, appear to utilize the MEP pathway,
and some bacteria utilze the mevalonate pathway |CITS:[11173292][15197467]|.

In |FRAME: TAX-83333| the initial addition of two isoprenyl units to form |FRAME: FARNESYL-PP| is
catalyzed by |FRAME: FPPSYN-MONOMER|, and further polymerizations are carried out by additional
enzymes, depending on the configuration.
Additions in the <i>trans</i> configuration are carried out by |FRAME: CPLX0-7426|, while addition in
the <i>cis</i> configuration is catalyzed by |FRAME: UPPSYN-CPLX|.

In |FRAME:TAX-562|, the <i>trans</i>-polyisoprenoid pathway continues to form
|FRAME: OCTAPRENYL-DIPHOSPHATE|, which is utilized in the |FRAME: UBISYN-PWY| and
|FRAME: MENAQUINONESYN-PWY| pathways for formation the inner membrane electron carriers
ubiquinone, menaquinone, and demethylmenaquinone.

The <i>cis,trans</i>-polyisoprenoid pathway continues to form
|FRAME: UNDECAPRENYL-DIPHOSPHATE|, the precursor for |FRAME: UNDECAPRENYL-P|, which
functions as the carrier lipid in the biosynthesis of peptidoglycan, enterobacterial common antigen
and lipopolysaccharides (LPS).

"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PHOSLIPSYN-PWY"	"superpathway of phospholipid biosynthesis I (bacteria)"	"PHOSLIPSYN-PWY"	"Phospholipids are membrane components in |FRAME:TAX-562|. The major phospholipids of
|FRAME:TAX-562| are phosphatidylethanolamine, phosphatidylglycerol and cardiolipin.
All phospholipids contain <I>sn</I>-glycerol-3-phosphate esterified with fatty
acids at the <I>sn</I>-1 and <I>sn</I>-2 positions. 

In addition to providing the membrane matrix, phospholipids are also involved in
synthesizing several types of surface molecules. The phosphoethanolamine head
groups of phosphatidylethanolamine are transferred and attached to the 
lipopolysaccharide (LPS) core sugars and to periplasmic membrane-derived 
oligosaccharides (MDO). The head group of phosphatidylglycerol is used for 
modifying various lipoproteins and MDO. The entire molecule is used in the 
synthesis of cardiolipin.   |CITS: [2404013] [ColiSalII]|"		"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY0-1545" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY0-1319" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5669" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5668" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5667"		"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Phospholipid-Biosynthesis" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Super-Pathways"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PhosphatidylglycerolBiosynthesis" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Cardiolipin-Biosynthesis" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Phosphatidylinositol-Biosynthesis" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PhosphatidylcholineBiosynthesis" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Phosphatidylserine-Biosynthesis" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PhosphatidylethanolamineBiosynthesis" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=CDP-diacylglycerol-Biosynthesis" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY66-5"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Lipid-Biosynthesis" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=NIL&object=Generalized-Reactions"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=FASYN-ELONG-PWY"	"fatty acid elongation -- saturated"	"FASYN-ELONG-PWY"	"This pathway shows the reactions that constitute one turn of a cycle that lengthens the chain of an acyl-[acyl-carrier protein] molecule by two carbons. The pathway is fed acetoacetyl-[acp] (see Pathway |FRAME: FASYN-INITIAL-PWY|), which  is a substrate of the second reaction shown here.

The products of multiple turns of this cycle are drawn off to become components of fatty acid-containing compounds, such as phospholipids, lipid A, and lipoproteins. They comprise saturated fatty acids such as |FRAME: DODECANOATE| (dodecanoate), |FRAME: CPD-7836| (tetradecanoate), |FRAME: PALMITATE| (hexadecanoate), and |FRAME: STEARIC_ACID| (octadecanoate).

In |FRAME: TAX-562|, of the four reactions involved in a cycle of fatty-acid elongation, two are catalyzed by more that one enzyme. These function preferentially on substrates of different chain length. They also act differentially on saturated and unsaturated substrates |CITS: [8910376]|.

The first reaction in the sequence, the condensation reaction, is catalyzed in |FRAME:TAX-562| by three enzymes, FabB, FabF, and FabH. However, FabH initiates fatty-acid synthesis: it uses only acetyl-[acp] as a substrate, and is thus not included in this pathway (see Pathway |FRAME: FASYN-INITIAL-PWY|) |CITS: [14523010]|. Other organisms may use other initiation enzymes, such as |FRAME: G-15300 FabY|.

Bacteria such as <i>|FRAME:TAX-562| </i> also contain unsaturated fatty acids. These are formed by a pathway that branches at the level of the 10-carbon intermediate (see |FRAME:PWY0-862|) |CITS: [14527277][8246839]|.
FabB, but not FabF, participates in the synthesis of unsaturated fatty acids |CITS: [11566998]|. The activity of FabF, and hence the fraction of fatty acids that are saturated, is modultated by temperature. However, the distribution of the flow of synthesis that proceeds to saturated vs. unsaturated fatty acids is determined mostly by the activities of FabA and FabZ |CITS: [8910376]|.

The final step of the cycle, the reductase, is known to be catalzed by enzymes that utilize either NADH, or NADPH, or both |CITS: [9022698]|. The |FRAME:TAX-562| |FRAME: EG11528 FabI| can use both cofactors, although the activity with NADH was shown to be over 17-fold higher than with NADPH |CITS: [9022698]|. |FRAME: G-15301 FabV| and |FRAME: G-15302 FabK| are NADH-specific. FabV enzymes are common in Gram-negative bacteria, and have been described from multiple organisms, including |FRAME: TAX-208964| |CITS: [19933806]|, |FRAME: TAX-13373| |CITS: [20055482]|, |FRAME: TAX-347| |CITS: [22039545]|, |FRAME: TAX-668| |CITS: [22232178]|, and |FRAME: TAX-632| |CITS: [22244758]|. FabK enzymes are found only in some Gram-positive bacteria such as |FRAME: TAX-1313| |CITS: [10910344][12487627]| and |FRAME: TAX-837| |CITS: [22820244]|. Another isoform, |FRAME: BSU08650 FabL|, which is found in |FRAME: TAX-1423| and some other Gram-positive bacteria, uses only NADPH |CITS: [11007778]|." "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7587"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Lipid-Biosynthesis"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Biosynthesis"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=FASYN-INITIAL-PWY"	"superpathway of fatty acid biosynthesis initiation (E. coli)"	"FASYN-INITIAL-PWY"	"<b>General Background</b>

Fatty acids are key building blocks for the phospholipid components of cell membranes and are
determinants of intracellular communication, in the form of lipid second messengers |CITS: [11094259]|,
and fatty acyl moieties of proteins that modify their location and function |CITS: [10446384]|.

There are two basic types of fatty acid (FAS) biosynthesis mechanisms. The type I system is found in
mammals and lower eukaryotes. The mammalian system consists of a single gene product that contains all of the reaction centers required to produce a fatty acid (see
|FRAME: CPLX-7628| from |FRAME: TAX-9606|), while the system of lower eukaryotes (such as yeast)
consists of two genes, whose polypeptide products combine to form a multifunctional complex
(see |FRAME: CPLX-7627| from |FRAME: TAX-4932|).

Type II systems are found in bacteria, plants |CITS: [15952903]|, parasites of the |FRAME: TAX-5794|
phylum |CITS: [17112527]| and mitochondria |CITS: [12882974][12654921]|.
The reactions in these systems are catalyzed by a series of individual soluble proteins that are each
encoded by a discrete gene, and the pathway intermediates are transferred between the enzymes as
thioesters of |FRAME: ACP|.

The best studied pathway is that of |FRAME: TAX-83333|, from which all the enzymes have been purified
and crystalized. In plants fatty acid synthesis occurs mainly in plastids of leaf mesophyll cells, seeds,
and oil-accumulating fruits. Although most of the synthesis occurrs in plastids, it has been shown that
mitochondria are also capable of synthesizing fatty acids |CITS: [14660674]|.

Fatty acid biosynthesis starts with an initiation sequence that produces |FRAME: Acetoacetyl-ACPs|,
an activated molecule that is used for subsequent elongation reactions, which ultimately
produce the final fatty acid products. This superpathway describes only the initiation sequence,
subsequent elongation reactions are described in the pathways |FRAME: FASYN-ELONG-PWY| and
|FRAME: PWY0-862|.

<b>About This Pathway</b>

|FRAME: TAX-83333| has several different routes in which it can produce acetoacetyl-ACP, using
different combinations of its three &beta;-ketoacyl-ACP synthases (KAS),
|FRAME: FABB-CPLX|, |FRAME: 3-OXOACYL-ACP-SYNTHII-CPLX| and |FRAME: CPLX0-252|,
which are encoded by |FRAME: EG10274|, |FRAME: EG12606| and |FRAME: EG10277|, respectively.
In general, the |FRAME: EG10277|-encoded enzyme is responsible for the initiation of fatty acid
elongation, utilizing acyl-coA primers, while the |FRAME: EG10274|/|FRAME: EG12606| products
are responsible for the subsequent rounds of elongation, condensing malonyl-ACP with different length
acyl-ACPs to extend the acyl chain by two carbons |CITS: [15952903][18384517]|.

Three pathways for the initiation of fatty acid biosynthesis have been proposed |CITS: [1551888]|.

In the first pathway (see |FRAME: PWY-4381|) |FRAME: CPLX0-252| catalyzes the condensation of
|FRAME: ACETYL-COA| with |FRAME: MALONYL-ACP| to yield |FRAME: Acetoacetyl-ACPs|.

In the second pathway (see |FRAME: PWY-5966|) the acetate moiety is first transferred from
|FRAME: ACETYL-COA| to |FRAME: ACETYL-ACP| by |FRAME:ACP-S-ACETYLTRANSFER-ENZRXN|
(this is a second function of |FRAME: CPLX0-252|; it is not clear whether an additional dedicated
enzyme exists in the organism). The acetyl-ACP is then condensed with |FRAME: MALONYL-ACP|
by |FRAME: FABB-CPLX| (or alternatively |FRAME: 3-OXOACYL-ACP-SYNTHII-CPLX|).

The third pathway (see |FRAME: PWY-5965|) involves the decarboxylation of |FRAME: MALONYL-ACP|
by |FRAME: FABB-CPLX| to form |FRAME: ACETYL-ACP| followed by subsequent condensation with
a second |FRAME: MALONYL-ACP|.

It is now believed that |FRAME: CPLX0-252| is the key enzyme in the initiation of fatty acids biosynthesis
|CITS: [15952903]|. It selectively catalyzes the formation of acetoacetyl-ACP and specifically uses CoA
thioesters rather than acyl-ACP as the primer. The products tend to be shorter than the products of KASI
and II, which are involved primarily in elongation reactions, and unlike the other two enzymes, KASIII
cannot participate in the terminal elongation steps of fatty acid biosynthesis.

While |FRAME: FABB-CPLX| and |FRAME: 3-OXOACYL-ACP-SYNTHII-CPLX| have been shown <i>in
vitro</i> to utilize substrates with short acyl moieties, forming acetoacetyl-ACP,
the importance of these enzyme for initiation of fatty acid biosynthesis <i>in vivo</i> is not clear
|CITS: [15952903]|.

"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY66-5"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Lipid-Biosynthesis" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7094"	"fatty acid salvage"	"PWY-7094"	"Fatty acid biosynthesis in the bacterium |FRAME: TAX-208964| is initiated by the &beta;-ketoacyl-[acyl-carrier-protein] synthase |FRAME: G-15300 FabY| that catalyzes the condensation of |FRAME: ACETYL-COA| with |FRAME: MALONYL-ACP \"malonyl-[acp]\"|, producing |FRAME: Acetoacetyl-ACPs \"acetoacetyl-[acp]\"|, which can be elongated into longer fatty acids via the |FRAME: FASYN-ELONG-PWY \"fatty acid elongation cycle\"| |CITS: [22753059]|.

|FRAME: G-15300|-mutants are defficient in fatty acid biosynthesis. However, this phenotype can be suppressed by supplementation of the growth media with exogenous fatty acids with chain lengths of eight or more carbons |CITS: [22753057]|. Upon transport into the cell the fatty acids form acyl-CoA thioesters, which are catabolized by the &beta;-oxidation cycle.

Studies showed that when |FRAME: CPD-196| is formed, it can be shunted into the fatty acid elongation cycle by a dedicated enzyme, encoded by the |FRAME: G-15305| gene |CITS: [22753057]|. This enzyme, which has a storng preference for |FRAME: CPD-196| (although |FRAME: CPD-10267| is also used at a lower rate), condenses the acyl-CoA thioester with |FRAME: MALONYL-ACP malonyl-[acp]|, forming |FRAME: 3-oxo-decanoyl-ACPs \"3-oxo-decanoyl-[acp]\"|, an intermediate of the fatty acid elongation cycle, thus by-passing the limitation imposed by lack of initiation, and enabling fatty acid biosynthesis.

The presence of this shunt may curtail the efficacy of inhibitors targeting the |FRAME: G-15300 FabY| initiator." "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWYG-321"	"mycolate biosynthesis"	"PWYG-321"	"<b>General Background</b>

Mycolic acids are the hallmark of the cell envelope of |FRAME: TAX-1773| and related species and genera. They comprise a homologous series of C60-C90 (2<i>R</i>)-alkyl-(3<i>R</i>)-hydroxy very long-chain fatty acids, and are found as either esters of |FRAME: Arabinogalactan| or as free lipids in the form of trehalose dimycolate (TDM). Both forms contribute to forming the two leaflets of the mycobacterial outer membrane, also called the mycomembrane, which protects the organism from antibiotics and the host's immune system  |CITS: [15653820][17555433][15353567]|.

There is a significant variability in the structure of mycolic acids among different species. Acids from |FRAME: TAX-1716| species contain 22-38 carbon atoms, |FRAME: TAX-697025| and |FRAME: TAX-697025| spp. contain 30-36, |FRAME: TAX-37914| spp. contain 34-38, |FRAME: TAX-1827| spp. contain 34-52 in, |FRAME: TAX-1817| spp. contain 46-60, |FRAME: TAX-2053 <i>Gordonia</i>| spp. contain 46-66, |FRAME: TAX-2060| spp. contain 64-78 , |FRAME: TAX-1763| spp. contain 60-90, and |FRAME: TAX-286801| spp. contain up to 100 carbon atoms |CITS: [24374164]|.

The acids are formed by a Claisen-type condensation of two components - the meromycolic chain and a fatty acid.
Several structural classes of mycolic acids exist. In |FRAME: TAX-1773| the most apolar ones, known as &alpha;-mycolic acids, contain 74-80 carbon atoms (out of which 22-26 carbons are located in the fatty acid moiety and the rest on the mero-chain) and generally two double bonds (that can be in either <i>cis</i>- or <i>trans</i>-configuration) or two <i>cis</i>-cyclopropyl groups located in the meromycolic chain. The cyclopropane rings are believed to protect the organism from oxidative stress |CITS: [15653820]|. &alpha;-Mycolic acids usually comprise more than 70 percent of the total mycolic acids in the cell.

Other classes are defined by additional oxygen functions located in the distal part of the meromycolic chain, and include keto-, methoxy-, wax ester-, epoxy-, and hydroxy-types. In |FRAME: TAX-1773| the oxygenated mycolic acids (keto-, methoxy-, and hydroxy-types) contain ~84-88 carbon atoms, and are thus four to six carbons longer than the &alpha;-mycolic acids from the same strains.

<b>About This Pathway</b>

The biosynthesis of mycolic acids could be divided conceptually into three parts: the biosynthesis of the fatty acid moiety, the biosynthesis of the mero-acid moiety, and the condensation of both parts.

The fatty acid moiety is produced by a \"eukaryotic-like\" multifunctional FAS-I enzyme complex (encoded by the |FRAME: G185E-6762 \"Rv2524C\"| gene), which produces C24-C26 acids (lignocerotate and cerotate), which are used as the \"&alpha; branch\" of the mycolic acids following carboxylation at position 2.

At the level of C22 (|FRAME: trans-delta2-behenoyl-ACPs \"<i>trans</i>-docos-2-enoyl-[acp]\"|) an isomerase encoded by |FRAME: G185E-5309| or |FRAME: G185E-5308| acts on some of the acids, transferring the double bond at position 2, which is introduced by the fatty acid dehydratase domain, to position 3. While those acids that were not affected by the isomerase continue elongation by FAS-I to the level of C26, the desaturated acid that result from isomerization, |FRAME: cis-delta3-behenoyl-ACPs \"<i>trans</i>-docos-3-enoyl-[acp]\"|, is no longer recognized by the FAS I enzyme. Instead, it is processed by a second, bacterial-like FAS-II system, which is composed of multiple discrete soluble enzymes (encoded by  |FRAME: G185E-6461|/|FRAME: G185E-6462|, |FRAME: G185E-5667|, |FRAME: CPLX-7729|/|FRAME: CPLX-7730|, and |FRAME: G185E-5668|. The longer fatty acids generated by FAS II eventually form the mero-chain moieties of the mycolic acids.

Although the two FAS systems differ in their molecular organizations, substrates, and carrier specificities, they share the typical reaction sequence, with an iterative series of reactions built on successive additions of a two-carbon unit from malonyl-CoA (FAS I) or malonyl-[acp] (FAS II) to the nascent acyl group.

During elongation by the FAS-II system, continuous introduction of 2-carbon units upstream of the the double bond at position 3 results in its \"migration\" farther from the carboxylate (to positions 5, 7, 9 etc). At the level of C35 the isomerase (encoded by echA10 or echA11) acts again, shifting another double bond from position 2 to position 3. This action of the isomerase results in a second branch in the pathway, where some of the acids continue with an additional double bond, while others continue without it. Both continue to be elongated by the FAS-II system.
The acids that escaped the isomeization at the C35 level undergo an isomerization at the level of C40. This isomerization event does not result in a branch in the pathway.

Following completion of the elongation process, the acids are modified by several additional enzymes which introduce methoxy groups and convert double bonds to cyclopropyl groups (including |FRAME: G185E-4788|, |FRAME: G185E-4787|, |FRAME: G185E-4786|, |FRAME: G185E-4785|, |FRAME: G185E-4597|, |FRAME: G185E-4635|). The final modified acids, as well as the final product of the FAS-I system, are then transferred from their [acp] and CoA carriers (respectively) to a polyketide enzyme, encoded by the |FRAME: G185E-8096| gene, which catalyzes their condensation into a mycolic acid |CITS: [14695899][15042094]|.

Additional enzymes catalyze the conjugation of the mycolic acids first to |FRAME: CPD1G-69| and subsequently to |FRAME: TREHALOSE-6P|. Following the removal of the phosphate, the free mycolic acid is exported to the periplasm, where it is attached to arabinogalactan in the cell wall, or to a second mycolic acid, forming a dimycolate." "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7587"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Lipid-Biosynthesis"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Biosynthesis"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=COA-PWY"	"coenzyme A biosynthesis I (prokaryotic)"	"COA-PWY"	"<b>General Background</b>

|FRAME: CO-A \"Coenzyme A\"| (CoA) is a cofactor of ubiquitous occurrence in plants, bacteria, and animals needed in
a large number of enzymatic reactions central to intermediary metabolism, including the oxidation of fatty acids, carbohydrates, and amino acids. Coenzyme A is the common acyl carrier in prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells required for a multitude of reactions for both biosynthetic and degradative pathways amongst others forming derivatives that are key intermediates in energy metabolism |CITS: [16415216]|.

The biosynthesis of CoA is of equal importance with regard to its recognition as a target for antibacterial drug discovery and to the association of human neurodegenerative disorder with mutations in |FRAME: EC-2.7.1.33| |CITS: [15893380]|.

<b>About This Pathway</b>

The CoA biosynthesis precursor |FRAME: 2-KETO-ISOVALERATE| is an intermediate in the synthesis of |FRAME: VAL| (see |FRAME: VALSYN-PWY|). This compound is converted in two steps to |FRAME: L-PANTOATE|, as shown in |FRAME: PANTO-PWY|.
The latter is converted into |FRAME: 4-P-PANTOTHENATE| is two steps, involving a &beta;-alanine ligase and a kinase.
In most organsims the ligase acts before the kinase (|FRAME: EC-6.3.2.1| followed by |FRAME: EC-2.7.1.33|, as described in |FRAME: PANTO-PWY| and |FRAME: PWY-3961|. However, in archaea the order is reversed, and |FRAME: EC-2.7.1.169| acts before |FRAME: EC-6.3.2.36|, as described in |FRAME: PWY-6654|.

The kinases are feedback inhibited by CoA itself, accounting for the primary regulatory mechanism of CoA biosynthesis.
The addition of |FRAME: CYS| to |FRAME: 4-P-PANTOTHENATE|, resulting in the formation of |FRAME: R-4-PHOSPHOPANTOTHENOYL-L-CYSTEINE| (PPC), is followed by decarboxylation of PPC to |FRAME: PANTETHEINE-P|. The ultimate reaction is catalyzed by |FRAME: EC-2.7.1.24|, which converts 4'-phosphopantetheine to CoA. All enzymes of this pathway are essential for growth.

The reactions in the biosynthetic route towards CoA are identical in most organisms, although there are differences in the functionality of the involved enzymes. In plants every step is catalyzed by single monofunctional enzymes, whereas in bacteria and mammals bifunctional enzymes are often employed |CITS: [16415216]|.

<b>About this pathway in yeast</b>

The conversion of |FRAME:R-4-PHOSPHOPANTOTHENOYL-L-CYSTEINE| to |FRAME:PANTETHEINE-P| is catalyzed by |FRAME: EC-4.1.1.36|. In |FRAME:TAX-4932| this is a unique heterotrimeric enzyme encoded by three genes, |FRAME:YKL088W|, |FRAME:YKR072C| and |FRAME:YOR054C| which although similar in structure are irreplaceable and fulfill distinctive essential functions in the protein complex. Two of the three genes, |FRAME:YKR072C| and |FRAME:YOR054C|, are moonlighting proteins which are not only involved as PPCDC subunits in CoA biosynthesis but also known to be inhibitors/negative regulators of the serine/threonine protein phosphatase Ppz1 |CITS:[9636153][11856338][15192104]|. Hence, this enzyme complex stands as an example of cross-talks between metabolic and signaling pathways indicating the possibility of exerting regulatory influence from one pathway to another |CITS:[19915531]|."	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PANTOSYN-PWY"		"CoA biosynthesis"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=CoA-Biosynthesis"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-4221" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=COA-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7851" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=COA-PWY-1" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PANTOSYN-PWY"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Cofactor-Biosynthesis"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Biosynthesis"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PANTOSYN-PWY"	"superpathway of coenzyme A biosynthesis I (bacteria)"	"PANTOSYN-PWY"	"<b>General Background</b>

|FRAME: CO-A \"Coenzyme A\"| (CoA) is a cofactor of ubiquitous occurrence in plants, bacteria, and animals needed in
a large number of enzymatic reactions central to intermediary metabolism, including the oxidation of fatty acids, carbohydrates, and amino acids. Coenzyme A is the common acyl carrier in prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells required for a multitude of reactions for both biosynthetic and degradative pathways amongst others forming derivatives that are key intermediates in energy metabolism |CITS: [16415216]|.

The biosynthesis of CoA is of equal importance with regard to its recognition as a target for antibacterial drug discovery and to the association of human neurodegenerative disorder with mutations in |FRAME: EC-2.7.1.33| |CITS: [15893380]|.

<b>About This Pathway</b>

The CoA biosynthesis precursor |FRAME: 2-KETO-ISOVALERATE| is an intermediate in the synthesis of |FRAME: VAL| (see |FRAME: VALSYN-PWY|). This compound is converted in two steps to |FRAME: L-PANTOATE|, as shown in |FRAME: PANTO-PWY|.
The latter is converted into |FRAME: 4-P-PANTOTHENATE| is two steps, involving a &beta;-alanine ligase and a kinase.
In most organsims the ligase acts before the kinase (|FRAME: EC-6.3.2.1| followed by |FRAME: EC-2.7.1.33|, as described in |FRAME: PANTO-PWY| and |FRAME: PWY-3961|. However, in archaea the order is reversed, and |FRAME: EC-2.7.1.169| acts before |FRAME: EC-6.3.2.36|, as described in |FRAME: PWY-6654|.

The kinases are feedback inhibited by CoA itself, accounting for the primary regulatory mechanism of CoA biosynthesis.
The addition of |FRAME: CYS| to |FRAME: 4-P-PANTOTHENATE|, resulting in the formation of |FRAME: R-4-PHOSPHOPANTOTHENOYL-L-CYSTEINE| (PPC), is followed by decarboxylation of PPC to |FRAME: PANTETHEINE-P|. The ultimate reaction is catalyzed by |FRAME: EC-2.7.1.24|, which converts 4'-phosphopantetheine to CoA. All enzymes of this pathway are essential for growth.

The reactions in the biosynthetic route towards CoA are identical in most organisms, although there are differences in the functionality of the involved enzymes. In plants every step is catalyzed by single monofunctional enzymes, whereas in bacteria and mammals bifunctional enzymes are often employed |CITS: [16415216]|." "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=ARO-PWY"	"chorismate biosynthesis I"	"ARO-PWY"	"|FRAME: CHORISMATE Chorismate| is an important intermediate that leads to the biosyntrhesis of several essential metabolites,
including the aromatic amino acids |FRAME: PHE|, |FRAME: TYR| and |FRAME: TRP|, vitamins E and K, ubiquinone and certain siderophores |CITS: [4200844][2279393]|.

In this pathway, which is often referred to as <b>the shikimate pathway</b>, chorismate is synthesized from the central metabolite |FRAME:ERYTHROSE-4P|. 
The pathway is found in prokaryotes (mostly bacteria) and several eukaryotes, including ascomycete fungi, apicomplexans, plants and algae |CITS: [16963634]|. The presence of the pathway in many parasites and pathogens, but not in metazoa, makes it a prime drug target |CITS: [17348836]|. The broad-spectrum systemic herbicide |FRAME: CPD0-1308|, which is used to kill weeds (known best under the tradename Roundup) is an inhibitor of the enzyme |FRAME: 2.5.1.19-RXN \"5-enolpyruvylshikimate-3-phosphate synthase\"| (EC 2.5.1.19), which catalyzes a reaction in the pathway (the condensation of |FRAME: SHIKIMATE-5P| and |FRAME: PHOSPHO-ENOL-PYRUVATE| to form |FRAME: 3-ENOLPYRUVYL-SHIKIMATE-5P|).

The organization and structure of the shikimate pathway enzymes varies between taxonomic groups |CITS: [2824247]|, with a differential distribution of fused genes. In most prokaryotes the seven shikimate pathway enzymes are encoded as separate polypeptides. The plant enzymes (which are nucleus encoded, but assumed to function within the plastid) are also encoded as separate polypeptides, with the exception of AroD and AroE that have fused to a single bifunctional polypeptide.
In contrast, all fungi, as well as the apicomplexan |FRAME: TAX-5811|, possess a pentafunctional supergene which includes conserved domains homologous to the genes (in fusion order) AroB, AroA, AroL/K, AroD, and AroE |CITS:[2825635][14711585]|.

In |FRAME: TAX-562|, the first reaction in the pathway is catalyzed by three separate enzymes, each of which is subject to feedback inhibition by one of the three amino acids that are synthesized from chorismate - |FRAME: PHE|, |FRAME: TYR| and |FRAME: TRP|.
The enzyme subject to regulation by tryptophan (encoded by |FRAME: EG10080|) cannot be inhibited more than 60 percent, ensuring that sufficient enzymatic activity is present to permit synthesis of the other four metabolites synthesized from chorismate even in the presence of all three amino acids |CITS: [Pittard04]|." "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY66-5"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=AROMATIC-COMPOUNDS-BIOSYN" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=NIL&object=Generalized-Reactions"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6163"	"chorismate biosynthesis from 3-dehydroquinate"	"PWY-6163"	"<b>Background</b>

In this pathway chorismate is synthesized from |FRAME: DEHYDROQUINATE|. The pathway is found in prokaryotes (both bacteria and archaea) and several eukaryotes, including ascomycete fungi, apicomplexans, plants and algae |CITS: [16963634]|. However, it's starting point, |FRAME: DEHYDROQUINATE|, can be synthesized in different routes. In most microorganisms it is synthesized from |FRAME: ERYTHROSE-4P| (see |FRAME: PWY-6164|), but the methanogens of the |FRAME: TAX-28890| phylum utilize an alternative route |CITS: [15182204]| (see |FRAME: PWY-6160|). 

|FRAME: CHORISMATE \"Chorismate\"| is an intermediate in the synthesis of the three aromatic amino acids: |FRAME: PHE|, |FRAME: TYR| and |FRAME: TRP|. These amino acids serve as substrates in other pathways for secondary metabolites such as alkaloids, flavonoids, lignin, coumarin, indole derivatives and other phenolic compounds |CITS: [22296303]|. 

|FRAME: SHIKIMATE \"Shikimate\"| is an important intermediate in the chorismate biosynthetic pathway. It was first isolated from Japanese star anise. Shikimate is used for the production of some antiviral drugs used to halt the spread of the flu virus, but as a biosynthetic intermediate, it is usually not found in high concentrations in organisms. Shikimate can be easily harvested from the needles of several species of pine trees, and biosynthetic pathways in |FRAME:TAX-562| have been enhanced to obtain sufficient amounts of the metabolite for commercial use.  

<b>About this Pathway</b>

The first enzyme in this section of the pathway, |FRAME: EC-4.2.1.10|, dehydrates |FRAME: DEHYDROQUINATE| to |FRAME: 3-DEHYDRO-SHIKIMATE|, which is subsequently reduced to |FRAME: SHIKIMATE| by |FRAME: EC-1.1.1.25| (or in some organisms also by |FRAME: EC-1.1.1.282|). The next enzyme, |FRAME: EC-2.7.1.71|, was shown in |FRAME: TAX-1423| to form a complex with the bifunctional |FRAME: CPLX-1101| (|FRAME: G-279|). The complex may serve as a regulatory unit |CITS: [170268] [BSUB225]|.

|FRAME: EC-2.5.1.19|, catalyzes the penultimate step in chorismate biosynthesis. The synthase is activated by ammonium ions and exhibits allosteric behavior. |FRAME: CPD0-1308 Glyphosate| acts as a competitive inhibitor with respect to |FRAME: PHOSPHO-ENOL-PYRUVATE| and as a partial uncompetitive inhibitor with respect to |FRAME: SHIKIMATE-5P| |CITS: [3111378] [7744055][7589547]|.

The last enzyme of the pathway, |FRAME: EC-4.2.3.5|, catalyzes the conversion of |FRAME: 3-ENOLPYRUVYL-SHIKIMATE-5P| into |FRAME: CHORISMATE|, the key branch-point intermediate in aromatic biosynthesis."	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=ARO-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6165"			"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Chorismate-Biosynthesis"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6163" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6165" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=ARO-PWY"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=AROMATIC-COMPOUNDS-BIOSYN"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Biosynthesis"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6519"	"8-amino-7-oxononanoate biosynthesis I"	"PWY-6519"	"<b>General Background</b>

|FRAME: BIOTIN \"Biotin\"| is a water soluble, heterocyclic cofactor for a small number of enzymes that facilitate the transfer of CO<sub>2</sub> during carboxylation, decarboxylation and transcarboxylation reactions involved in fatty acid and carbohydrate metabolism |CITS: [SHELLHAMMER90][11706201][15012185]|.
The biotin-requiring enzymes identified so far (including |FRAME: ACETYL-COA-CARBOXYLMULTI-CPLX|,
|FRAME: CPLX66-17|, |FRAME: CPLX-5203|, and |FRAME: CPLX-6001|) play essential roles in cell metabolism
|CITS: [8676868]|.
Biotin may also have functions in metabolism other than its mere catalytic role as an enzyme cofactor. It has been shown that biotin also carries out non-catalytic functions in the expression of methylcrotonyl-CoA carboxylase in |FRAME:TAX-3701| biotin-auxotroph mutants, by modulating and regulating gene expression |CITS: [12644697]|.

Biotin biosynthesis is found in plants, bacteria and certain fungi. Although animals and most fungi cannot synthesize their own biotin, a daily intake is required for normal growth and development |CITS: [11322938]|. While the biotin biosynthetic pathway has been explored in detail only in bacteria, ongoing success in sequencing whole genomes from other organisms has provided evidence that the general steps in bacterial biotin synthesis are conserved in plants |CITS: [11322938]|.

<b>About This Pathway</b>

Despite the importance and prevalance of biotin, its detailed biosynthetic pathway remained enigmatic for over 70 years. The first complete pathway for biotin synthesis was suggested for its synthesis in |FRAME:TAX-562| |CITS: [20693992]|.

Biotin consists of two fused heterocyclic rings and a |FRAME: VALERATE| side chain, derived from a |FRAME: CPD-205|-like structure. The early steps of the pathway, which are described here, describe the synthesis of the precursor of the pimelate moiety in |FRAME: TAX-562|. The late steps of the pathway, which are responsible for forming the two rings in the structure of biotin, are described in |FRAME: PWY0-1507|.

The origins of the biotin carbon atoms in |FRAME: TAX-562| are known from <sup>13</sup>C NMR analysis of products labeled <i>in vivo</i> |CITS: [8125118][Indrajit94]|. The C3, C5 and C7 carbons are derived from carbon C1 of acetate, while the C2, C4 and C6 carbons are derived from carbon C2 of acetate. The C1 carbon originates from |FRAME: CARBON-DIOXIDE|. This labeling pattern indicated that the pimeloyl moiety of biotin is formed by head-to-tail incorporation of three intact acetate units, similar to the synthesis of fatty acids |CITS: [Indrajit94]|. As the biotin C1 and C7 atoms show different labeling patterns, free pimelic acid (a symmetrical molecule) could not be an intermediate, and thus it has been assumed that |FRAME: CPD-558| is the precursor |CITS: [Webb07]|.

The elucidation of the pathway proved difficult, mostly since only two genes, |FRAME: EG10119| and |FRAME: EG10122|, were implicated in the synthesis of the pimeloyl moiety |CITS: [4563978][8830257][4877129]|.
Based on these finding, there have been several suggestions that enzymes of the fatty acid biosynthesis pathway are involved, although none of these suggestions could explain the full process |CITS: [13930373][Indrajit94]|. An inclusive model was finally suggested in 2010 |CITS: [20693992]|. Based on this model, |FRAME: EG10119 \"BioC\"| converts the free carboxyl group of a |FRAME: MALONYL-COA| thioester to its methyl ester by transfer of a methyl group from |FRAME: S-ADENOSYLMETHIONINE|.The newly acquired methyl group mimics the methyl ends of normal fatty acyl chains, and enables the esterified |FRAME: CPD-12454| to enter the fatty acid synthetic pathway.

Two reiterations of the fatty acid elongation cycle (see |FRAME: FASYN-ELONG-PWY|) produce |FRAME: Pimeloyl-ACP-methyl-esters \"pimeloyl-[acp] methyl ester\"|, which is cleaved by |FRAME: EG10122 \"BioH\"| to give |FRAME: Pimeloyl-ACPs \"pimeloyl-[acp]\"|. According to this model, the introduction of the methyl ester early in the pathway disguises the biotin synthetic intermediates so that they become substrates for the fatty acid synthetic pathway. When the synthesis of the pimeloyl moiety is complete and disguise is no longer needed, the methyl group is removed to free the carboxyl group that will eventually be used to attach biotin to its target metabolic enzymes.

It should be noted that many organisms that have a |FRAME: EG10119| gene do not have a homolog of the |FRAME: EG10122| gene. A remarkable diversity was found in the enzymes catalyzing this step, with different, non-related genes found in different organisms, including |FRAME: G-17965| from |FRAME: TAX-401614| |CITS: [23152908]|, |FRAME: G-15494| from |FRAME: TAX-93059| |CITS: [23152908]|, |FRAME: G-15495| from |FRAME: TAX-71421| |CITS: [24313380]|, and |FRAME: HP0287| from |FRAME: TAX-210| |CITS: [26868423]|.

The [acp] protein is then removed in a complex reaction catalyzed by |FRAME: EG10121 \"BioF\"|, forming |FRAME: 8-AMINO-7-OXONONANOATE|, the first intermediate in biotin ring assembly. An <i>in vitro</i> system that uses dialyzed cell extracts was used in combination with several mutant strains and purified proteins to verify the proposed pathway |CITS: [20693992]|."	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=BIOTIN-BIOSYNTHESIS-PWY"		"7-keto-8-aminopelargonate biosynthesis I"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=7-Keto-8-aminopelargonate-Biosynthesis"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6578" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7147" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6519"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Other-biosynthesis"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Biosynthesis"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=TYRFUMCAT-PWY"	"L-tyrosine degradation I"	"TYRFUMCAT-PWY"	"This pathway of L-tyrosine degradation has been characterized in mammals, some bacteria, and the fungi
|FRAME: TAX-162425| and |FRAME: TAX-746128| |CITS: [9734339] [7568087] [15262943][19028908]| and reviewed 
in |CITS: [15581571]| and |CITS: [11567547]|.  L-Phenylalanine degradation shares this pathway after its initial hydroxylation to L-tyrosine (see MetaCyc pathway |FRAME: PHENYLALANINE-DEG1-PWY|).  |FRAME: TAX-162425|
also degrades phenylacetate via 2-hydroxyphenylacetate to homogentisate using this pathway |CITS: [7673153]|.
The pathway ends in intermediates of central metabolism, as indicated by the pathway links.  Deficiencies of 
enzymes in this pathway have been associated with several human genetic disorders (as indicated in the 
comments for the individual enzymes in this pathway).  Homogentisate is a central intermediate.  In addition to being 
further catabolized, it can also be a biosynthetic precursor for melanins (in |CITS: [8071207]|), and is used by higher 
plants in the biosynthesis of plastoquinone and tocopherols (in |CITS: [15157070]| and reviewed 
in |CITS: [15581571]|) (see MetaCyc pathways |FRAME: PWY-1581| and |FRAME: PWY-1422|).   

This pathway does not occur in |FRAME:TAX-562| and |FRAME:TAX-590|, which cannot utilize L-tyrosine 
as a carbon and energy source (McFall, E. and Newman E. G. in |CITS: [COLISAL]|).  The pathway is also lacking in 
the yeast |FRAME:TAX-4932| which uses a limited number of carbon sources for growth, but 
can use most amino acids as sole nitrogen source (in |CITS: [15933030]|) (see MetaCyc pathways 
|FRAME: ANAPHENOXI-PWY| and |FRAME: PWY-5079|).      

A variation of this pathway has been reported in some Gram positive bacteria that can degrade L-tyrosine 
via 2,5-dihydroxyphenylacetate (homoprotocatechuate), rather than homogentisate, to pyruvate and 
succinate |CITS: [931949] [20216]|.  Another variation has been shown in the gram positive bacterium |FRAME:TAX-1817| 
sp. 239 which can degrade L-tyrosine to homogentisate via p-hydroxyphenylpyruvate, 
p-hydroxyphenylacetaldehyde, and p-hydroxyphenylacetate.  D- and L-phenylalanine were similarly degraded 
by this organism via the corresponding non-hydroxylated compounds |CITS: [DEBOER88]|.  There is also 
evidence that the yeast |FRAME:TAX-4952| can degrade tyrosine to homogentisate through these 
intermediates |CITS: [11472920]|.  Among the archaea, however, there is little information regarding aromatic 
amino acid degradation, even in the well studied hyperthermophile |FRAME:TAX-2261| 
(in |CITS: [15803651]|), although a preliminary pathway has been proposed |CITS: [8206994]|."			"tyrosine fumarate catabolism"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=TYROSINE-DEG"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY3O-4108" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5151" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=TYRFUMCAT-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7514" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-8016"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Proteinogenic-Amino-Acids-Degradation"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Amino-Acid-Degradation"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=LEU-DEG2-PWY"	"L-leucine degradation I"	"LEU-DEG2-PWY"	"|FRAME: LEU| is one of the three main branched chain amino acids (BCAAs), along with |FRAME: ILE|
and |FRAME:VAL|.
The catabolic pathways of the BCAAs can be divided into two sequential series of reactions, referred to
as the common pathway and the distal pathway.

The common pathway includes the enzymes |FRAME: CPLX-6941|, |FRAME: CPLX-6940|, and
|FRAME: CPLX-6942|. These three enzymes catalyze the conversion of all three BCAAs to their
respective acyl-CoA derivatives
(|FRAME:METHACRYLYL-COA|, |FRAME:3-METHYL-CROTONYL-COA|, and |FRAME: CPD-1083|
for |FRAME:VAL|, |FRAME:LEU|, and |FRAME:ILE|, respectively), though the intermediates formed
by these enzymes are different for the different amino acids.
The distal parts of the pathways are completely different for the three BCAAs, and comprise enzymes
specific for each amino acid |CITS: [773366]|.

This Leucine degradation pathway is wide spread, and is found in microorganisms, higher plants, and
animals, including mammals.

The catabolism of |FRAME: LEU| begins with its transamination to |FRAME:2K-4CH3-PENTANOATE|,
followed by oxidative decarboxylation to |FRAME:ISOVALERYL-COA|.
|FRAME:ISOVALERYL-COA| then undergoes a four-step process, involving
dehydrogenation to |FRAME:3-METHYL-CROTONYL-COA|, carboxylation to
|FRAME:TRANS-3-METHYL-GLUTACONYL-COA|, hydration to
|FRAME: 3-HYDROXY-3-METHYL-GLUTARYL-COA|, and finally a thioester hydrolysis
forming |FRAME: ACETYL-COA| and |FRAME:3-KETOBUTYRATE| |CITS: [4150714]|.
Leucine degradation is different from the degradation of the other branched-chain amino acids, in that it
includes a carboxylation step. The |FRAME: CARBON-DIOXIDE| fixing enzyme, |FRAME: CPLX66-17|,
requires a biotin cofactor.

In adipocytes, unlike other tissues, leucine is a significant precursor for fatty acid and sterol
biosynthesis, especially in the presence of glucose |CITS: [13892210]|.  Furthermore, leucine apparently
serves as a source of nitrogen for synthesis of |FRAME: GLN| and, to lesser extents, |FRAME: GLT|
and |FRAME: L-ALPHA-ALANINE|, which are released by adipocytes |CITS: [6773935]| and can serve as
substrates for gluconeogenesis in liver and kidney |CITS: [6304077]|.

It should be mentioned that alternative leucine degradation pathways exist. In one such pathway, 
documented in |FRAME: TAX-1509|, leucine is degraded to |FRAME:ISOBUTYRATE| and
|FRAME: ACET| via |FRAME:CPD-2041| (see |FRAME:PWY-5075|).  Additional pathways which are currently not characterized very well include the conversion
of leucine to |FRAME: ACETONE| by members of the |FRAME:TAX-662| family |CITS: [10601206]|, and the
catabolism of leucine to branched-chain fatty acids in |FRAME: TAX-1288| |CITS: [15078537]|.

A portion of this leucine degradation pathway also participates in the final phase of the acyclic terpene utilization pathway, beginning at |FRAME: 3-METHYL-CROTONYL-COA| as shown in the pathway link from |FRAME: PWY-6672|.  The acyclic terpene utilization pathway includes pathways |FRAME: PWY-6670|, |FRAME: PWY-6672| and this pathway, with its associated pathway link to |FRAME: ACETOACETATE-DEG-PWY|.  In species of |FRAME:TAX-286| the enzymes of |FRAME: LEU|/|FRAME: ISOVALERATE| utilization are encoded in the <i>liuRABCDE</i> gene cluster (reviewed in |CITS: [20490788]|)."				"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=LEUCINE-DEG"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5076" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7767" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=LEU-DEG2-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5075"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Proteinogenic-Amino-Acids-Degradation"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Amino-Acid-Degradation"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=HISDEG-PWY"	"L-histidine degradation I"	"HISDEG-PWY"	"<b>General Background</b>

|FRAME: HIS| can be catabolized by both prokaryotic and eukaryotic organisms in two principal routes.
The main difference between these two routes is the first step, which is performed by either
a |FRAME: CPLX-6925| (as in this pathway) or a histidine transaminase (|FRAME: HISTDEG-PWY| and
|FRAME: PWY-5031|).

At least three different flavors of |FRAME: CPLX-6925|-based pathways have been found so far.
All proceed in a similar manner up to the intermediate |FRAME: N-FORMIMINO-L-GLUTAMATE|.
Three steps, catalyzed by distinct enzymes, lead to this intermediate.
In the first step |FRAME: HIS| is split into |FRAME: UROCANATE| and |FRAME: AMMONIA| by
a |FRAME: CPLX-6925| |CITS: [14367318][12980948]|; Next |FRAME: UROCANATE|
is converted to |FRAME: 4-IMIDAZOLONE-5-PROPIONATE| by |FRAME: CPLX-981|
|CITS: [13587518][13821933]|; and finally, |FRAME: 4-IMIDAZOLONE-5-PROPIONATE| is converted to
|FRAME: N-FORMIMINO-L-GLUTAMATE| by |FRAME: HUTIBACSU-MONOMER| |CITS: [13587518]
[13739526]|.

In all three flavors |FRAME: N-FORMIMINO-L-GLUTAMATE| is further degraded to |FRAME: GLT|.
However, the mechanism of |FRAME: GLT| production is different in the three pathways.  
In several Gram-negative and Gram-positive bacteria, including |FRAME: TAX-90371|,
|FRAME: TAX-573|, |FRAME: TAX-548| and |FRAME: TAX-1423|, |FRAME: N-FORMIMINO-L-GLUTAMATE|
is split into |FRAME: GLT| and |FRAME: FORMAMIDE| |CITS: [14367318]|; the latter compound
does not appear to be metabolized further (|FRAME: HISDEG-PWY|) |CITS: [13416179]|.  
In fluorescent Pseudomonads, including |FRAME: TAX-303|, |FRAME: TAX-294| and |FRAME: TAX-287|,
|FRAME: N-FORMIMINO-L-GLUTAMATE| is first hydrolyzed to |FRAME: AMMONIA| and 
|FRAME: CPD-600|, which in turn is hydrolyzed to |FRAME: GLT| and |FRAME: FORMATE|
(|FRAME: PWY-5028|) |CITS: [13211593][4290562]|; the |FRAME: FORMATE| can serve as
a source of single carbon compounds |CITS: [13563517]|.   
Finally, in the livers of mammals |FRAME: GLT| is generated by the transfer of the formimino group to
|FRAME: THF| (|FRAME: PWY-5030|). |FRAME: THF| is metabolized further, transferring
the formyl moiety to the pool of single carbon compounds |CITS: [13672973]|.

<b>About This Pathway</b>

Urocanic acid was first isolated in 1874 by the chemist M. Jaffe from the urine of a dog, hence the name
(latin: <i>urina</i> = urine, and |FRAME:TAX-9611| = dog) |CITS: [7944380]|.
Unfortunately the dog escaped before Jaffe was able identify the structure.
The identity and structure of the substance was eventually revealed in 1912 by Hunter, who was the first
to suggest that it is an intermediate in the catabolism of |FRAME: HIS| |CITS: [Hunter12]|.
Edlbacher identified  the locus of histidine degradation as the liver of various animals, and named the
enzyme that degrades |FRAME: HIS| to |FRAME: GLT| \"histidase\" |CITS: [Edlbacher26][Edlbacher30]|.
In 1930 Kauffmann and Mislowitzer defined histidase more correctly, as the enzyme that converts
|FRAME: HIS| to |FRAME: UROCANATE| |CITS: [Kauffmann30]|.
After a lengthy debate concerning the nature of the third intermediate, it was finally
shown conclusively that it is |FRAME:N-FORMIMINO-L-GLUTAMATE | by Borek and Waelsch
|CITS: [13117923]|. Finally, Revel and Magasanik discovered an additional intermediate, and
suggested that it is |FRAME:4-IMIDAZOLONE-5-PROPIONATE| |CITS: [13587518]|. This suggestion
was confirmed with the isolation of the substance |CITS: [13804907]|, thus establishing the pathway.

This pathway has been demonstrated in both Gram-negative and Gram-positive bacteria,
including |FRAME: TAX-548| |CITS: [14367318]|, |FRAME: TAX-90371| |CITS: [4899017][4930059]|,
|FRAME: TAX-573| |CITS: [6321433]| and |FRAME: TAX-1423| |CITS: [Magasanik71]|.

The pathway is subject to a strong catabolite repression, preventing bacteria from using |FRAME: HIS|
as a nitrogen source if |FRAME: GLC| or |FRAME: SUC| are present in the growth medium
|CITS: [4990471]|. It is induced by |FRAME:UROCANATE|."				"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=HISTIDINE-DEG"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=HISHP-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5031" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=HISTDEG-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5028" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=HISDEG-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5030"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Proteinogenic-Amino-Acids-Degradation"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Amino-Acid-Degradation"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=AST-PWY"	"L-arginine degradation II (AST pathway)"	"AST-PWY"	"The arginine succinyltransferase (AST) pathway is a catabolic pathway whose purpose is the dissimilation
of the carbon skeleton of |FRAME:ARG| |CITS:[2865249][3129535]|. 
The pathway was detected in many Gram-negative proteobacteria able to utilize arginine as a
sole carbon and nitrogen source, including |FRAME: TAX-287|, |FRAME: TAX-303|, |FRAME: TAX-294|,
|FRAME: TAX-300|, |FRAME: TAX-333|, |FRAME: TAX-548|, |FRAME: TAX-292|, |FRAME: TAX-648|,
|FRAME: TAX-84158|, and |FRAME: TAX-45465| |CITS:[3534538]|. 
The pathway is also present in the enteric bacteria |FRAME: TAX-83333| and |FRAME: TAX-90371|, and it has been
shown to account for 97% of the total arginine degradation in |FRAME: TAX-83333| |CITS:[9696779]|. 
In most organisms the pathway coexists with other arginine dissimilation pathways, such as
the |FRAME: ARGDEG-III-PWY| and the |FRAME:ARGDEGRAD-PWY|, which provide different purposes
(e.g. polyamine production and energy generation).  However, in some organisms, such as
|FRAME: TAX-292|, the arginine succinyltransferase pathway is the only arginine catabolic pathway. 
In |FRAME: TAX-287| this is the major arginine utilization pathway under aerobic conditions
|CITS:[9393691]|.

The enzyme arginine succinyltransferase, which catalyzes the succinylation of |FRAME:ARG|,
also catalyzes the succinylation of |FRAME:L-ORNITHINE| to |FRAME:N2-SUCCINYLORNITHINE|,
which is another intermediate of this pathway.  Thus, the routes for the degradation of both |FRAME:ARG|
and |FRAME:L-ORNITHINE| converge at |FRAME:N2-SUCCINYLORNITHINE| |CITS:[3144259][7523119]|.

The <i>aru</i> genes encoding all of the proteins of this pathway have been cloned from
|FRAME: TAX-287| and sequenced.  They all belong to a single operon, controlled by the ArgR regulatory protein
|CITS:[9393691]|.

This pathway is also the only arginine-degrading pathway found in |FRAME:TAX-562|.  This pathway, which
yields 2 molecules of |FRAME: AMMONIA| and 2 of |FRAME: GLT|, can satisfy |FRAME:TAX-562|'s total nitrogen
requirement, but not its total carbon requirement.  It does, however, permit other organisms, for
example |FRAME: TAX-548| to utilize |FRAME: ARG| as a total source of carbon.  With the exception of the
third enzyme in the pathway, succinylornithine transaminase (encoded by <i>astC</i>), enzymes of this pathway
from |FRAME:TAX-562| have not been characterized beyond assaying crude extracts.  Succinylornithine transaminase
gained special attention and was originally designated as <i>argM</i> because is can substitute for acetylornithine
transaminase (encoded by <i>argD</i>) in the biosynthesis of arginine.  The substrates of the two enzymes differ
only in |FRAME: L-ORNITHINE| being acetylated in the biosynthetic pathway and succinylated in the degradative
pathway.  Reviewed in Reitzer, L. (2005) \"Catabolism of Amino Acids and Related Compounds.\"  EcoSal
3.4.7 |CITS: [ecosal]|
"			"L-arginine succinyltransferase pathway" // "AST pathway" // "ammonia-producing L-arginine catabolic pathway" // "L-arginine catabolism"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=ARGININE-DEG"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7523" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-4983" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=ARGORNPROST-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=ARGDEG-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=ARGASEDEG-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY0-823" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5024" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=AST-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=ARGDEG-V-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=ARGDEG-III-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=ARG-GLU-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5742" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=ORNARGDEG-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=ARGDEGRAD-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=ARGDEG-IV-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=ARG-PRO-PWY"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Proteinogenic-Amino-Acids-Degradation"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Amino-Acid-Degradation"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=VALSYN-PWY"	"L-valine biosynthesis"	"VALSYN-PWY"	"The pathway of valine biosynthesis is a four-step pathway that shares all
of its steps with the parallel pathway of isoleucine biosynthesis. These
entwined pathways are part of the |FRAME:BRANCHED-CHAIN-AA-SYN-PWY|, that generates
not only isoleucine and valine, but also leucine.

As a consequence of having several of its component enzymes involved in the synthesis
of three different amino acids, the pathway of isoleucine biosynthesis is subject
to regulation by all three amino acids. The first step in the pathway is primarily
inhibited by valine, along with inhibition by isoleucine and leucine.
The potential disruption this might cause to the parallel
isoleucine biosynthesis pathway step using the same enzymes is resolved by
upregulation of an earlier step that is unique to isoleucine biosynthesis, as explained
in the |FRAME:ILEUSYN-PWY| summary. In this way, valine biosynthesis can be regulated
independently of isoleucine biosynthesis, despite all four valine biosynthesis enzymes
also participating in isoleucine biosynthesis."	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=BRANCHED-CHAIN-AA-SYN-PWY"			"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=VALINE-BIOSYNTHESIS"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=VALSYN-PWY"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=IND-AMINO-ACID-SYN"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Amino-Acid-Biosynthesis"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=TRPSYN-PWY"	"L-tryptophan biosynthesis"	"TRPSYN-PWY"	"Tryptophan biosynthesis in microbes involves five enzymes, encoded by 7 genes. The genes (trpA,B,C,D,E,F) 
are usually arranged in a single cluster |CITS: [2679363]|, and form an operon whose transcription 
is negatively regulated by tryptophan |CITS: [7007895]|. Additional regulation mechanisms exist at the translational and 
post-translational levels, presumably because tryptophan synthesis is very expensive (78 mol ATP for each mol
of tryptophan produced).
In addition, hyperthermophilic organisms usually have an additional gene, trpB2, which is located outside of the 
tryptophan operon. This gene encodes an additional enzyme which is similar to a subunit of tryptophan synthase.

The two last steps in this pathway are catalyzed by a single enzyme, tryptophan synthase, which
is composed of two &alpha; and two &beta; subunits (E.C. reaction 4.2.1.20). 
However, it has been shown that each of the subunits is responsible for catalyzing an individual step, and is able 
to catalyze that step on its own. Thus, the activity of tryptophan synthase was divided into 
two individual steps in the pathway, each catalyzed by the corresponding subunit."	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6629" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=COMPLETE-ARO-PWY"			"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=TRYPTOPHAN-BIOSYNTHESIS"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=TRPSYN-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6629"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=IND-AMINO-ACID-SYN"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Amino-Acid-Biosynthesis"
