"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY66-5"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=IND-AMINO-ACID-SYN" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Pathways"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Amino-Acid-Biosynthesis" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=NIL&object=Generalized-Reactions"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=GLUTORN-PWY"	"L-ornithine biosynthesis I"	"GLUTORN-PWY"	"<b>General Background</b>

While the amino acid |FRAME: L-ORNITHINE| is not involved
directly in protein synthesis, it is an important intermediate in many metabolic pathways, such as
the |FRAME:PWY-4984| and the biosynthesis of several compounds, including arginine
(see |FRAME:ARGSYN-PWY| and |FRAME:ARGSYNBSUB-PWY|), proline (see |FRAME:PWY-3341|
and |FRAME:PWY-4981|), and putrescine (|FRAME:PWY-46|), which leads to the biosynthesis of other
polyamines and pyrimidines.  It is also involved in |FRAME: PWY-6818|.

This pathway documents the synthesis of |FRAME:L-ORNITHINE| from |FRAME:GLT| via
<i>N</i>-acetylated intermediates. The presumed reason for the acetylation is that it prevents the
spontaneous cyclization of glutamate derivatives, which leads to proline biosynthesis (see
|FRAME:PROSYN-PWY|), thus keeping the pathways leading to arginine and proline separate
(|CITS: [12633501]| and references therein). 

Two alternative pathways have evolved, which differ in the way the key intermediate
|FRAME: ACETYL-GLU| (NAG) is formed, and in the way the acetyl group is removed from another
intermediate, |FRAME:N-ALPHA-ACETYLORNITHINE|.
In this pathway, which is less common, NAG is formed by NAG synthase, and
|FRAME:N-ALPHA-ACETYLORNITHINE| is hydrolyzed by the enzyme acetylornithine deacetylase,
forming |FRAME: L-ORNITHINE| and |FRAME: ACET|.
In the other pathway (see |FRAME:ARGSYNBSUB-PWY|), which is found in most of the prokaryotic and
eukaryotic microbes investigated up to now, the two reactions are linked: the acetyl group which is
removed from |FRAME: N-ALPHA-ACETYLORNITHINE| is recycled onto |FRAME: GLT|, regenerating
|FRAME: ACETYL-GLU| (NAG). 

<b>About This Pathway</b>

This ornithine biosynthesis pathway has been found in the |FRAME:TAX-543|
|FRAME: TAX-83333| and |FRAME: TAX-90371| |CITS: [3534538]|,
the |FRAME: TAX-641| |CITS: [10692366]|, the Gram-negative bacterium |FRAME: TAX-34|
|CITS: [ 9829957]|, and the archaeon |FRAME: TAX-2287| |CITS: [vandecasteele90]|.
In it |FRAME: GLT| is acetylated to NAG by the enzyme
|FRAME:N-ACETYLTRANSFER-CPLX|, encoded by the |FRAME:EG10063| gene.
The acetyl donor for this reaction is |FRAME: ACETYL-COA|. 
NAG is then converted in several enzymatic steps to |FRAME: N-ALPHA-ACETYLORNITHINE|.
The acetyl group is removed in the form of |FRAME: ACET| by the enzyme
|FRAME:ACETYLORNDEACET-CPLX|, encoded by the |FRAME:EG11286| gene, resulting in
|FRAME:L-ORNITHINE|."	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=ARGSYN-PWY"			"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=L-Ornithine-Biosynthesis"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6922" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=ARGININE-SYN4-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=GLUTORN-PWY"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Other-Amino-Acid-Biosynthesis"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Amino-Acid-Biosynthesis"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-2942"	"L-lysine biosynthesis III"	"PWY-2942"	"<b>General Background</b>

Six pathways are now recognized in bacteria, most algae, fungi and higher plants for the biosynthesis of lysine. They are divided into two groups - the diaminopimelate (DAP) pathways, and the |FRAME:CPD-468| pathways.

In the pathways that belong to the DAP group, lysine is produced from aspartate (along with methionine, threonine and isoleucine). All of the DAP group pathways share the upper segments, which include the four steps required for conversion of  L-aspartate to |FRAME: DELTA1-PIPERIDEINE-2-6-DICARBOXYLATE|. They also share the last step, which is the conversion of the intermediate |FRAME: MESO-DIAMINOPIMELATE| (D,L-DAP, or <i>meso</i>-DAP) to lysine.
However, these pathways differ in the routes leading from |FRAME: DELTA1-PIPERIDEINE-2-6-DICARBOXYLATE| to |FRAME:MESO-DIAMINOPIMELATE|. The four variations include:

(I) the succinylase variant (see |FRAME: DAPLYSINESYN-PWY|), which involves succinylated intermediates. In this route |FRAME: DELTA1-PIPERIDEINE-2-6-DICARBOXYLATE| is coverted to |FRAME:MESO-DIAMINOPIMELATE| in four enzymatic steps.

(II) the acetylase variant (see |FRAME: PWY-2941|), which involves acetylated intermediates. This route also involves four enzymatic steps for the conversion of |FRAME: DELTA1-PIPERIDEINE-2-6-DICARBOXYLATE| to |FRAME:MESO-DIAMINOPIMELATE|.

(III) the dehydrogenase variant (see |FRAME: PWY-2942|), in which |FRAME: DELTA1-PIPERIDEINE-2-6-DICARBOXYLATE| is converted to |FRAME:MESO-DIAMINOPIMELATE| in a single enzymatic step. 

(IV) the diaminopimelate-aminotransferase variant (see |FRAME: PWY-5097|), in which |FRAME: DELTA1-PIPERIDEINE-2-6-DICARBOXYLATE| is converted to |FRAME:MESO-DIAMINOPIMELATE| in two steps.

In addition to lysine, all of the pathways in this group also produce |FRAME: MESO-DIAMINOPIMELATE|, which is an important metabolite on its own (for example, as a constituent of bacterial cell wall peptidoglycan).

The two other pathways belong to the |FRAME: CPD-468| group. They are found in organisms that have no requirement for |FRAME:MESO-DIAMINOPIMELATE|, as it is not a component of their cell walls. These pathways also share the first segments, leading to the synthesis of the intermediate |FRAME: CPD-468| (&alpha;-aminoadipate).
However, in yeast and fungi, as well as  |FRAME: TAX-3038|, the pathway continues with the key enzyme |FRAME: YBR115C-MONOMER|, leading to the intermediate |FRAME: SACCHAROPINE| (see |FRAME: LYSINE-AMINOAD-PWY|), while in prokaryotes the pathway continues in a path similar to bacterial arginine biosynthesis (see |FRAME: PWY-3081|).

Most of the bacteria that have been investigated in detail appear to utilize only one of these pathways |CITS: [1906065]|. A few exceptions include |FRAME: TAX-44252|, in which variants (II) and (III) seem to coexist |CITS: [BARTLETT85]|, and |FRAME: TAX-1718|, in which variant (I) and (III) coexist |CITS: [1906065]|.

Lysine is one of the 10 essential amino acids that mammals are unable to synthesize, and must therefore acquire in their diets.  

<b>About This Pathway</b>

Some Gram-positive bacteria, including |FRAME:TAX-1718|, <i>Brevibacterium
lactofermentum</i> and |FRAME:TAX-1421|, can convert tetrahydrodipicolinate to
<i>meso</i>-diaminopimelate in a single enzymatic step, catalyzed by the enzyme diaminopimelate dehydrogenase.
In some organisms, such as <i>B. sphaericus</i>,  this is the only lysine biosynthesis pathway |CITS: [White83]|, 
while in others, such as <i>C. glutamicum</i>, it exists in parallel with alternative pathways.

Even though the conversion of tetrahydrodipicolinate to <i>meso</i>-diaminopimelate
involves a single enzymatic step, the full reaction is composed of two steps. In the first step, which is presumably
spontaneous, tetrahydrodipicolinate loses a water molecule, and opens to its acyclic form,
L-&alpha;-amino-&epsilon;-keto-pimelate. The second step is the enzymatic conversion to
<i>meso</i>-DAP |CITS: [762012]|."				"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=LYSINE-SYN"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-2942" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=DAPLYSINESYN-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-3081" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=LYSINE-AMINOAD-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5097" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-2941"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=IND-AMINO-ACID-SYN"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Amino-Acid-Biosynthesis"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5097"	"L-lysine biosynthesis VI"	"PWY-5097"	"<b>General Background</b>

Six pathways are now recognized in bacteria, most algae, fungi and higher plants for the biosynthesis of lysine. They are divided into two groups - the diaminopimelate (DAP) pathways, and the |FRAME:CPD-468| pathways.

In the pathways that belong to the DAP group, lysine is produced from aspartate (along with methionine, threonine and isoleucine). All of the DAP group pathways share the upper segments, which include the four steps required for conversion of  L-aspartate to |FRAME: DELTA1-PIPERIDEINE-2-6-DICARBOXYLATE|. They also share the last step, which is the conversion of the intermediate |FRAME: MESO-DIAMINOPIMELATE| (D,L-DAP, or <i>meso</i>-DAP) to lysine.
However, these pathways differ in the routes leading from |FRAME: DELTA1-PIPERIDEINE-2-6-DICARBOXYLATE| to |FRAME:MESO-DIAMINOPIMELATE|. The four variations include:

(I) the succinylase variant (see |FRAME: DAPLYSINESYN-PWY|), which involves succinylated intermediates. In this route |FRAME: DELTA1-PIPERIDEINE-2-6-DICARBOXYLATE| is coverted to |FRAME:MESO-DIAMINOPIMELATE| in four enzymatic steps.

(II) the acetylase variant (see |FRAME:

 PWY-2941|), which involves acetylated intermediates. This route also involves four enzymatic steps for the conversion of |FRAME: DELTA1-PIPERIDEINE-2-6-DICARBOXYLATE| to |FRAME:MESO-DIAMINOPIMELATE|.

(III) the dehydrogenase variant (see |FRAME: PWY-2942|), in which |FRAME: DELTA1-PIPERIDEINE-2-6-DICARBOXYLATE| is converted to |FRAME:MESO-DIAMINOPIMELATE| in a single enzymatic step. 

(IV) the diaminopimelate-aminotransferase variant (see |FRAME: PWY-5097|), in which |FRAME: DELTA1-PIPERIDEINE-2-6-DICARBOXYLATE| is converted to |FRAME:MESO-DIAMINOPIMELATE| in two steps.

In addition to lysine, all of the pathways in this group also produce |FRAME: MESO-DIAMINOPIMELATE|, which is an important metabolite on its own (for example, as a constituent of bacterial cell wall peptidoglycan).

The two other pathways belong to the |FRAME: CPD-468| group. They are found in organisms that have no requirement for |FRAME:MESO-DIAMINOPIMELATE|, as it is not a component of their cell walls. These pathways also share the first segments, leading to the synthesis of the intermediate |FRAME: CPD-468| (&alpha;-aminoadipate).
However, in yeast and fungi, as well as  |FRAME: TAX-3038|, the pathway continues with the key enzyme |FRAME: YBR115C-MONOMER|, leading to the intermediate |FRAME: SACCHAROPINE| (see |FRAME: LYSINE-AMINOAD-PWY|), while in prokaryotes the pathway continues in a path similar to bacterial arginine biosynthesis (see |FRAME: PWY-3081|).

Most of the bacteria that have been investigated in detail appear to utilize only one of these pathways |CITS: [1906065]|. A few exceptions include |FRAME: TAX-44252|, in which variants (II) and (III) seem to coexist |CITS: [BARTLETT85]|, and |FRAME: TAX-1718|, in which variant (I) and (III) coexist |CITS: [1906065]|.

Lysine is one of the 10 essential amino acids that mammals are unable to synthesize, and must therefore acquire in their diets.

<b>About This Pathway</b>

Lysine biosynthesis in plants was thought to be identical to the prokaryotic DAP (diaminopimelate) pathway that uses N-succinylated intermediates (|FRAME: DAPLYSINESYN-PWY|) |CITS: [15652176]|. However the Arabidopsis genome does not contain a homolog of |FRAME: EC-2.3.1.117|. Furthermore, the Arabidopsis homologs of |FRAME: EC-2.6.1.17|, and |FRAME: EC-3.5.1.18|, are not likely to function in lysine biosynthesis |CITS: [15652176]|. It was thus suggested that plants may synthesize lysine via an enzyme that bypasses the three reactions by directly converting tetrahydrodipicolinate to L,L-diaminopimelate. An Arabidopsis enzyme that catalyzes this reaction, |FRAME: AT4G33680-MONOMER|, was indeed discovered |CITS: [16361515]|. Despite the fact that the forward reaction (towards lysine biosynthesis) seems to be unfavorable, the enzyme was shown to be involved in lysine biosynthesis under physiological conditions by functional complementation of an |FRAME: TAX-562| lysine biosynthesis double mutant of dapD and dapE.

The key enzyme, |FRAME: EC-2.6.1.83|, was discovered not only in green plants, but also in bacteria belonging to the |FRAME: TAX-1117| and |FRAME: TAX-1783257| |CITS: [17093042]|, and in archeaebacteria of the |FRAME: TAX-183925| and the |FRAME: TAX-183939| classes |CITS: [18371309][20418392]|. Soon after it was reported that a diverged form of the enzyme is also common in many other bacterial phyla |CITS: [18310350]|. Phylogenetic analyses suggested that two lateral gene transfers occurred in the DapL genes, one from archaea to  bacteria, forming  the DapL2 group, and one from bacteria to archaea, forming the DapL1 group |CITS: [20418392]|.

The first committed enzyme in this pathway, |FRAME: EC-4.3.3.7|, is feedback regulated by lysine |CITS: [8000011]|. Its catalyzed reaction is the rate-limiting step for lysine biosynthesis. |FRAME: EC-2.6.1.83|, may impose another regulation point of lysine biosynthesis - using maize cultured embryo cells, it was shown that the overall rate of lysine synthesis is in the same range of the forward reaction catalyzed by this enzyme |CITS: [16361515]|.

Lysine biosynthesis in plants occurs within chloroplasts. No evidence exists for extra plastidic location of the pathway |CITS: [15652176]|."	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-724"			"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=LYSINE-SYN"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-2942" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=DAPLYSINESYN-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-3081" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=LYSINE-AMINOAD-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5097" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-2941"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=IND-AMINO-ACID-SYN"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Amino-Acid-Biosynthesis"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=DAPLYSINESYN-PWY"	"L-lysine biosynthesis I"	"DAPLYSINESYN-PWY"	"<b>General Background</b>

Six pathways are now recognized in bacteria, most algae, fungi and higher plants for the biosynthesis of lysine. They are divided into two groups - the diaminopimelate (DAP) pathways, and the |FRAME:CPD-468| pathways.

In the pathways that belong to the DAP group, lysine is produced from aspartate (along with methionine, threonine and isoleucine). All of the DAP group pathways share the upper segments, which include the four steps required for conversion of |FRAME: L-ASPARTATE| to |FRAME: DELTA1-PIPERIDEINE-2-6-DICARBOXYLATE|. They also share the last step, which is the conversion of the intermediate |FRAME: MESO-DIAMINOPIMELATE| (D,L-DAP, or <i>meso</i>-DAP) to lysine.
However, these pathways differ in the routes leading from |FRAME: DELTA1-PIPERIDEINE-2-6-DICARBOXYLATE| to |FRAME:MESO-DIAMINOPIMELATE|. The four variations include:

(I) the succinylase variant (see |FRAME: DAPLYSINESYN-PWY|), which involves succinylated intermediates. In this route |FRAME: DELTA1-PIPERIDEINE-2-6-DICARBOXYLATE| is coverted to |FRAME:MESO-DIAMINOPIMELATE| in four enzymatic steps.

(II) the acetylase variant (see |FRAME: PWY-2941|), which involves acetylated intermediates. This route also involves four enzymatic steps for the conversion of |FRAME: DELTA1-PIPERIDEINE-2-6-DICARBOXYLATE| to |FRAME:MESO-DIAMINOPIMELATE|.

(III) the dehydrogenase variant (see |FRAME: PWY-2942|), in which |FRAME: DELTA1-PIPERIDEINE-2-6-DICARBOXYLATE| is converted to |FRAME:MESO-DIAMINOPIMELATE| in a single enzymatic step. 

(IV) the diaminopimelate-aminotransferase variant (see |FRAME: PWY-5097|), in which |FRAME: DELTA1-PIPERIDEINE-2-6-DICARBOXYLATE| is converted to |FRAME:MESO-DIAMINOPIMELATE| in two steps.

In addition to lysine, all of the pathways in this group also produce |FRAME: MESO-DIAMINOPIMELATE|, which is an important metabolite on its own (for example, as a constituent of bacterial cell wall peptidoglycan).

The two other pathways belong to the |FRAME: CPD-468| group. They are found in organisms that have no requirement for |FRAME:MESO-DIAMINOPIMELATE|, as it is not a component of their cell walls. These pathways also share the first segments, leading to the synthesis of the intermediate |FRAME: CPD-468| (&alpha;-aminoadipate).
However, in yeast and fungi, as well as  |FRAME: TAX-3038|, the pathway continues with the key enzyme |FRAME: YBR115C-MONOMER|, leading to the intermediate |FRAME: SACCHAROPINE| (see |FRAME: LYSINE-AMINOAD-PWY|), while in prokaryotes the pathway continues in a path similar to bacterial arginine biosynthesis (see |FRAME: PWY-3081|).

Most of the bacteria that have been investigated in detail appear to utilize only one of these pathways |CITS: [1906065]|. A few exceptions include |FRAME: TAX-44252|, in which variants (II) and (III) seem to coexist |CITS: [BARTLETT85]|, and |FRAME: TAX-1718|, in which variant (I) and (III) coexist |CITS: [1906065]|.

Lysine is one of the 10 essential amino acids that mammals are unable to synthesize, and must therefore acquire in their diets.

<b>About This Pathway</b>

The succinylase variant is the most common bacterial lysine biosynthesis pathway. It is found in many
different types of bacteria.
In this pathway, a succinate moiety is added to |FRAME: DELTA1-PIPERIDEINE-2-6-DICARBOXYLATE|,
followed by an amino group, to form <i>N</i>-succinyl-L,L-DAP.
The succinate is then removed, and an epimerase converts the resulting L,L-DAP
to <i>meso</i>-DAP. This pathway has been experimentally verified in several Gram-negative bacteria, including
|FRAME: TAX-83333|, |FRAME: TAX-71421|, |FRAME: TAX-1718|, |FRAME: TAX-210| and |FRAME: TAX-1773|,
and genes specific for this pathway have been identified in many other organisms."	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=P4-PWY"		"L-lysine and L-diaminopimelate biosynthesis"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=LYSINE-SYN"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-2942" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=DAPLYSINESYN-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-3081" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=LYSINE-AMINOAD-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5097" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-2941"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=IND-AMINO-ACID-SYN"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Amino-Acid-Biosynthesis"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5101"	"L-isoleucine biosynthesis II"	"PWY-5101"	"<b>General Background</b>

|FRAME: ILE| is almost always synthesized from |FRAME: 2-OXOBUTANOATE|. In the most common pathway,  |FRAME: 2-OXOBUTANOATE| is generated from |FRAME: L-ASPARTATE| via |FRAME: THR| (see |FRAME:PWY-3001|). The key enzyme in that pathway is |FRAME:THREDEHYDSYN-CPLX|, encoded by the |FRAME:EG10493| gene.

In addition to the standard pathway, microorganisms have developed several alternative pathways for |FRAME: ILE| biosynthesis. |FRAME: 2-OXOBUTANOATE| can be synthesized from |FRAME: GLT| via |FRAME: L-THREO-3-METHYL-ASPARTATE| (see |FRAME: PWY-5103|) |CITS: [4550817]|, from |FRAME: PYRUVATE| (this pathway) |CITS: [4607875][4808901][15292141]|, and from |FRAME: PROPIONATE| by carboxylation (see |FRAME: PWY-5104|) |CITS: [5800441][1212197][Eikmanns83a]|). In addition, there are several reports that under anaerobic conditions some anaerobic bacteria can carboxylate |FRAME: CPD-7076| to |FRAME: ILE| via |FRAME: 2-KETO-3-METHYL-VALERATE| (see |FRAME: PWY-5108|) |CITS: [5813342][6726176][6440485 ]|.

<b>About This Pathway</b>

The pathway desribed here was originally proposed in the spirochaete |FRAME: TAX-173| in 1974 |CITS: [4808901]|. Using isotope labeling data, it was shown that the pathway, which was named \"the pyruvate pathway\", started with the condensation of |FRAME: ACETYL-COA| and |FRAME: PYRUVATE| to form citramalate. At the time it wasn't clear whether the product of this initial reaction is |FRAME: CPD-31| or its stereoisomer, |FRAME:S-CITRAMALATE|. As a result, two plausible routes were proposed, depending on the stereoisomer formed. The route starting with |FRAME:S-CITRAMALATE| would proceed via |FRAME:L-THREO-3-METHYL-ASPARTATE|, while the route starting with |FRAME: CPD-31| would proceed in a manner very similar to the pathway of |FRAME:LEUSYN-PWY|. Both routes were proposed to combine at |FRAME:2-OXOBUTANOATE|, the key intermediate which is formed directly from |FRAME: THR| in the more common |FRAME: ILE| biosynthetic pathway (|FRAME:ILEUSYN-PWY|) |CITS: [4808901]|.

Subsequent work has confirmed the presence of the pyruvate pathway in other |FRAME:TAX-171| strains |CITS: [6404889]| as well as in many species of archaea |CITS: [Eikmanns83][Ekiel84]|, but did not determine the exact route employed by the organisms. In 1999 an |FRAME: CPLX-7022| was purified from |FRAME: TAX-2190|, and shown to catalyze the formation of |FRAME: CPD-31| |CITS: [9864346]|. In 2004 a similar enzyme was isolated from |FRAME: TAX-189518|. These authors were also able to show that |FRAME: 2-METHYLMALEATE| is the substrate for the following reaction. By cloning and overexpressing the enzymes |FRAME:CPLX-7020 | and |FRAME: CPLX-7021|, which catalyze the comparable steps in |FRAME: LEU| biosynthesis (see |FRAME: LEUSYN-PWY|), the authors were able to demonstrate the conversion of |FRAME: 2-METHYLMALEATE| to |FRAME: 2-OXOBUTANOATE|, confirming that this is indeed the route
employed by |FRAME:TAX-171| strains for |FRAME: ILE| biosynthesis. Despite the sharing of several enzymes between the biosynthetic pathways of |FRAME: LEU| and |FRAME: ILE| in these organisms, these pathways are not co-regulated, due to the difference in the enzymes catalyzing the first reaction. |FRAME:CPLX-7019| expression is not regulated by |FRAME: LEU|, but is sensitive to |FRAME: ILE| concentrations |CITS: [15292141]|.

Even though the pathway has not been characterized as well in archaebacteria, the presence and nature of several key enzymes from |FRAME: TAX-2190| suggests that this is most likely the |FRAME: ILE| biosynthestic pathway employed by methanogens |CITS: [15292141][17449626]|. The pathway has been subsequently detected in non-methanogenic archaea |CITS: [17400748]| as well as in the Delta-proteobacterium |FRAME: TAX-35554| |CITS: [18245290]|. The CimA protein from |FRAME: TAX-35554| constituted the first characterized member of a phylogenetically distinct clade of citramalate synthases. Based on the distribution of homologs of that protein, the pathway has been predicted to have a much wider occurrence than previously thought, and may exist in Delta-proteobacteria, Alpha-proteobacteria, Cyanobacteria, Deinococci, Clostridia, Actinobacteria, Sphingobacteria, Chlorobia, and the Chloroflex, as well as the |FRAME: TAX-183968| class of the archaea |CITS: [18245290]|."				"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=ISOLEUCINE-SYN"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5104" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-3001" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5108" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5101" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5103" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=ILEUSYN-PWY"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=IND-AMINO-ACID-SYN"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Amino-Acid-Biosynthesis"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=ILEUSYN-PWY"	"L-isoleucine biosynthesis I (from threonine)"	"ILEUSYN-PWY"	"The pathway of |FRAME: ILE| biosynthesis from |FRAME: THR| is a five-step pathway that shares its last four steps with the pathway of |FRAME: VAL| biosynthesis. These entwined pathways are part of the |FRAME:BRANCHED-CHAIN-AA-SYN-PWY|, that generates not only |FRAME: ILE| and |FRAME: VAL|, but also |FRAME: LEU|.

As a consequence of having several of its component enzymes involved in the synthesis of three different amino acids, the pathway of isoleucine biosynthesis is subject to regulation by all three amino acids. The first enzyme in the pathway, |FRAME: THREDEHYDSYN-CPLX|, is downregulated by isoleucine and leucine, but is upregulated by valine. The following pathway step, catalyzed by |FRAME: ACETOLACTSYNI-CPLX| (AHAS I) and |FRAME: ACETOLACTSYNIII-CPLX| (AHAS III), is inhibited by all three amino acids. This apparent paradox of valine stimulation of step one followed by valine inhibition of step two is a product of the preference of AHAS III for processing of the isoleucine precursor |FRAME: 2-OXOBUTANOATE| rather than the valine precursor |FRAME: PYRUVATE|. When valine is abundant in the cell, both AHAS
enzymes are inhibited, blocking valine production and potentially disrupting isoleucine synthesis as well. However, the stimulation of |FRAME: THREDEHYDSYN-CPLX| generates a substantial pool of |FRAME: 2-OXOBUTANOATE|. Combined with the high affinity of AHAS III for this compound, this allows the isoleucine synthesis to continue despite inhibition caused by the parallel valine synthesis pathway.

Enteric bacteria such as |FRAME: TAX-511145| and |FRAME: TAX-90371| have been shown to possess two types of threonine dehydratases - a catabolic enzyme, which is induced by threonine (see |FRAME: THREDEHYDCAT-CPLX|), and a consistitutively-produced biosynthetic enzyme (|FRAME: THREDEHYDSYN-CPLX|) |CITS: [13405870]|. Both enzymes convert threonine to |FRAME:2-OXOBUTANOATE|, but differ in their regulation and expression.

Biosynthetic threonine dehydratases were also described in several soil bacteria |CITS: [16743051]|. A survey of 75 soil isolates capable of growth on L-threonine revealed a group of three organisms that possessed substantial L-threonine dehydratase activity, to the exclusion of any other threonine-catabolyzing enzyme |CITS: [5076220]|.  The group consisted of |FRAME:ORG-5895| and two |FRAME:TAX-1696| isolates. The enzyme from |FRAME:ORG-5895| was partially purified, and was found to be of the biosynthetic type on the criteria that its formation was consitutive, it was susceptible to inhibition by |FRAME:ILE|, |FRAME:VAL| protected against denaturation and was a positive effector and antagonist of isoleucine, and neither AMP nor ADP acted as effectors |CITS: [16743051]|. Interestingly, even though the enzyme was of the biosynthetic type, the researchers found that much of the threonine in these organisms was converted to |FRAME:PROPIONATE| in a catabolic pathway identical to that described in |FRAME:PWY-5437|. Thus, the biosynthetic enzyme was recruited to a catabolic pathway.

A biosynthetic threonine dehydratase was also reported in |FRAME:TAX-615| |CITS: [355220]|."	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-3001" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=THREOCAT-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=BRANCHED-CHAIN-AA-SYN-PWY"			"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=ISOLEUCINE-SYN"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5104" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-3001" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5108" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5101" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5103" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=ILEUSYN-PWY"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=IND-AMINO-ACID-SYN"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Amino-Acid-Biosynthesis"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-3001"	"superpathway of L-isoleucine biosynthesis I"	"PWY-3001"	"<b>General Background</b>

|FRAME: ILE| is almost always synthesized from |FRAME: 2-OXOBUTANOATE|. In the most
common pathway,  |FRAME: 2-OXOBUTANOATE| is generated from |FRAME: L-ASPARTATE| via
|FRAME: THR| (this pathway).
The key enzyme in this pathway is |FRAME:THREDEHYDSYN-CPLX|, encoded by the |FRAME:EG10493| gene.

In addition to the standard pathway, microorganisms have developed several alternative pathways for
|FRAME: ILE| biosynthesis. |FRAME: 2-OXOBUTANOATE| can be synthesized from |FRAME: GLT| via |FRAME: L-THREO-3-METHYL-ASPARTATE| (see |FRAME: PWY-5103|) |CITS: [4550817]|, from |FRAME: PYRUVATE| (see |FRAME:PWY-5101|) |CITS: [4607875][4808901][15292141]|, and by carboxylation of |FRAME: PROPIONATE| (see |FRAME: PWY-5104|) |CITS: [5800441][1212197][Eikmanns83a]|).
In addition, there are several reports that some anaerobic bacteria can carboxylate |FRAME: CPD-7076| to |FRAME: ILE| via |FRAME: 2-KETO-3-METHYL-VALERATE| (see |FRAME: PWY-5108|) |CITS: [5813342][6726176][6440485 ]|."		"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=ILEUSYN-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=HOMOSER-THRESYN-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY66-5"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=IND-AMINO-ACID-SYN" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Pathways"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Amino-Acid-Biosynthesis" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=NIL&object=Generalized-Reactions"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5103"	"L-isoleucine biosynthesis III"	"PWY-5103"	"<b>General Background</b>

|FRAME: ILE| is almost always synthesized from |FRAME: 2-OXOBUTANOATE|. In the most
common pathway,  |FRAME: 2-OXOBUTANOATE| is generated from |FRAME: L-ASPARTATE| via
|FRAME: THR| (see |FRAME:PWY-3001|).
The key enzyme in that pathway is |FRAME:THREDEHYDSYN-CPLX|, encoded by the |FRAME:EG10493| gene.

In addition to the standard pathway, microorganisms have developed several alternative pathways for
|FRAME: ILE| biosynthesis. |FRAME: 2-OXOBUTANOATE| can be synthesized from |FRAME: GLT| via |FRAME: L-THREO-3-METHYL-ASPARTATE| (this pathway) |CITS: [4550817]|, from |FRAME: PYRUVATE| (see |FRAME:PWY-5101|) |CITS: [4607875][4808901][15292141]|, and from |FRAME: PROPIONATE| by carboxylation (see |FRAME: PWY-5104|) |CITS: [5800441][1212197][Eikmanns83a]|).
In addition, there are several reports that under anaerobic conditions some anaerobic bacteria can carboxylate
|FRAME: CPD-7076| to |FRAME: ILE| via |FRAME: 2-KETO-3-METHYL-VALERATE| (see |FRAME: PWY-5108|) |CITS: [5813342][6726176][6440485]|.

<b>About This Pathway</b>

This pathway was first described in 1962 by Abramsky et al, who observed that in |FRAME: TAX-566546|
|FRAME:L-THREO-3-METHYL-ASPARTATE| was exclusively converted to |FRAME: ILE| |CITS: [13859068]|.
The authors suggested a pathway in which |FRAME: L-THREO-3-METHYL-ASPARTATE| is transaminated to
|FRAME: METHYLOXALO-ACETATE| (based on earlier reports by |CITS: [13766613]|), followed by decarboxylation
to  |FRAME: 2-OXOBUTANOATE|, which is then used for the biosynthesis of |FRAME: ILE| in the
\"conventional\" manner.  The proposed pathway was substantiated by a second paper published
by the same group  |CITS: [14342322]|. However, the biological significance of this pathway was not clear,
as it was not known whether |FRAME:L-THREO-3-METHYL-ASPARTATE| occurs naturally in |FRAME: TAX-566546|.

In 1972 Phillips et al have demonstrated that a different strain of |FRAME:TAX-562| (|FRAME: ORG-5900|, ATCC 8739)
was able to synthesize |FRAME: ILE| from |FRAME: GLT|. The authors were able to demonstrate activity
in crude extracts of several enzymes, including the key enzyme |FRAME:CPLX-7027|, which converts |FRAME:GLT|
to |FRAME:L-THREO-3-METHYL-ASPARTATE|, as well as |FRAME: MONOMER-11907| |CITS: [4550817]|.

Please note that the last 4 steps in this pathway are identical to the \"common\" |FRAME: ILE| biosynthetic pathway.
For information about |FRAME: TAX-83333| enzymes catalyzing these steps, see the pathway |FRAME:PWY-3001|."				"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=ISOLEUCINE-SYN"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5104" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-3001" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5108" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5101" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5103" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=ILEUSYN-PWY"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=IND-AMINO-ACID-SYN"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Amino-Acid-Biosynthesis"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5104"	"L-isoleucine biosynthesis IV"	"PWY-5104"	"<b>General Background</b>

|FRAME: ILE| is almost always synthesized from |FRAME: 2-OXOBUTANOATE|. In the most
common pathway,  |FRAME: 2-OXOBUTANOATE| is generated from |FRAME: L-ASPARTATE| via
|FRAME: THR| (see |FRAME:PWY-3001|).
The key enzyme in that pathway is |FRAME:THREDEHYDSYN-CPLX|, encoded by the |FRAME:EG10493| gene.

In addition to the standard pathway, microorganisms have developed several alternative pathways for
|FRAME: ILE| biosynthesis.  |FRAME: 2-OXOBUTANOATE| can be synthesized from |FRAME: GLT| via |FRAME: L-THREO-3-METHYL-ASPARTATE| (see |FRAME: PWY-5103|) |CITS: [4550817]|, from |FRAME: PYRUVATE| (see |FRAME:PWY-5101|) |CITS: [4607875][4808901][15292141]|, and from |FRAME: PROPIONATE| by carboxylation (this pathway) |CITS: [5800441] [1212197][Eikmanns83a]|).
In addition, there are several reports that under anaerobic conditions some anaerobic bacteria can carboxylate
|FRAME: CPD-7076| to |FRAME: ILE| via |FRAME: 2-KETO-3-METHYL-VALERATE| (see |FRAME: PWY-5108|) |CITS: [5813342][6726176][6440485 ]|.

<b>About This Pathway</b>

This pathway was first suggested by Buchanan, who in 1969 discovered the key enzyme,
|FRAME: CPLX-7028|, in cell extracts from the photosynthetic bacterium |FRAME: TAX-1047|
|CITS: [5800441]|.
This enzyme catalyzes a ferredoxin-dependent reductive carboxylation of |FRAME: PROPIONYL-COA| to
|FRAME: 2-OXOBUTANOATE|. Buchanan found that at least in |FRAME: TAX-1047| the resulting
|FRAME: 2-OXOBUTANOATE| is processed to |FRAME: ILE| by enzymes involved in the \"common\"
|FRAME: ILE| biosynthesis pathway. He was also able to show the same enzymatic activity in the non-photosynthetic
bacteria |FRAME: TAX-1501| and |FRAME: TAX-876| |CITS: [5800441]|.
An independent report of the pathway in another |FRAME:TAX-1485| sp., |FRAME: TAX-1509|, has also
been published |CITS: [6726176]|.

A few years later Sauer et al published a report that documented the incorporation of labeled
|FRAME:PROPIONATE| into |FRAME:ILE| by mixed cultures of rumen microorganisms |CITS:[1212197]|.
These authors also found that the |FRAME:PROPIONATE| was converted to |FRAME:2-OXOBUTANOATE |
by reductive carboxylation.

A third study supporting this pathway was published in 1983 by Eikmanns et al |CITS: [Eikmanns83a]|. This study
reported that several methanogenic archaea, including |FRAME: TAX-145262|, |FRAME: TAX-39441| and |FRAME: TAX-2208|,
incorporated assimilated |FRAME:PROPIONATE| almost exclusively into |FRAME: ILE|. The process was inhibited
by several |FRAME: ILE| biosynthesis intermediates, including |FRAME:CPD-7076|, |FRAME:2-OXOBUTANOATE|
and |FRAME: ILE|.



"				"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=ISOLEUCINE-SYN"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5104" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-3001" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5108" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5101" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5103" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=ILEUSYN-PWY"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=IND-AMINO-ACID-SYN"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Amino-Acid-Biosynthesis"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=HISTSYN-PWY"	"L-histidine biosynthesis"	"HISTSYN-PWY"	"The genes necessary for histidine biosynthesis have been identified in many bacteria, fungi, plants,
and archaea. The pathway in all of these organisms is identical, with small differences in some of
the enzymes used. Histidine is an essential amino acid, and is not synthesized by mammals.

A few differences between different organisms concern whether the enzymes are mono- or bifunctional. One such case is the enzyme |FRAME: EC-3.1.3.15|. Some organisms, including  |FRAME: TAX-83333|, |FRAME: TAX-90371| and |FRAME: TAX-727|, have a bifunctional enzyme, with the C-terminal domain exhibiting |FRAME:IMIDPHOSDEHYD-ENZRXN| (EC 4.2.1.19) activity. These enzymes belong to the DDDD phosphohydrolase/phosphotransferase superfamily. Other organisms have separate monofunctional enzymes catalyzing these two reactions. Monofunctional histidinol-phosphate phosphatases belong to either the PHP (polymerase and histidinol phosphatase) superfamily, as in the case of |FRAME: TAX-1423|, |FRAME: TAX-4932| and |FRAME: TAX-300852| |CITS: [14993698]|, or to the DDDD superfamily, as in the case of the archaeon |FRAME: TAX-342948| NA1 |CITS: [18223080]|.

Another such case concerns the conversion of |FRAME:PHOSPHORIBULOSYL-FORMIMINO-AICAR-P| (BBM III) to |FRAME:D-ERYTHRO-IMIDAZOLE-GLYCEROL-P| (IGP) and |FRAME:AICAR| (AICAR), which is catalyzed by |FRAME: EC-4.3.2.10|. This process requires two catalytic functions, including the transfer of an amide from |FRAME: GLN| and a cyclization reaction. In prokaryotes, these two catalytic activities are encoded by two genes whose products form a complex. In yeast and plants, this conversion is catalyzed by a single bifunctional enzyme.

In all organisms operating the pathway, the enzyme catalyzing the first step is feedback-inhibited  by |FRAME: HIS|. In plants, the entire pathway is located inside the chloroplast |CITS: [16547652]|."	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PRPP-PWY"			"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=HISTIDINE-SYN"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=HISTSYN-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5029"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=IND-AMINO-ACID-SYN"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Amino-Acid-Biosynthesis"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5505"	"L-glutamate and L-glutamine biosynthesis"	"PWY-5505"	"<b>Please note:</b> This collection of reactions does not represent the metabolism of a single organism.
Rather, it is assembled from a variety of organisms.  Its purpose is to provide an overview of the ways
that organisms can biosynthesize glutamate and glutamine.

The amino acid glutamate is a both constituent of proteins and a biosynthetic precursor. Many 
pathways and reactions involving glutamate as a precursor are shown on the MetaCyc compound page 
for |FRAME: GLT|.  Glutamine is also a constituent of proteins and is the amino group donor for many
biosynthetic reactions, as shown on the MetaCyc compound page for |FRAME: GLN|.
It also serves as a storage form of ammonia.    

In microorganisms, glutamate dehydrogenase, glutamine synthetase (GS), and glutamate synthase
(glutamine &alpha;-oxoglutarate amidotransferase, GOGAT) are used for ammonia assimilation.
Some of these organisms may use only glutamate dehydrogenase, or only glutamine
synthetase/glutamate synthase (GS/GOGAT), while others use either route, depending upon growth
conditions (|CITS: [GOTTSCHALK1986]| and in |CITS: [17020556] [14555464]|).
Mammals use glutamate dehydrogenase and glutamine synthetase in nitrogen metabolism.
In plants, GS/GOGAT functions in ammonia assimilation.  A role for glutamate dehydrogenase in
glutamate biosynthesis in plants is unclear |CITS: [17114271]|.

"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY66-5"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=IND-AMINO-ACID-SYN" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Pathways"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Amino-Acid-Biosynthesis" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=NIL&object=Generalized-Reactions"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=ARGSYNBSUB-PWY"	"L-arginine biosynthesis II (acetyl cycle)"	"ARGSYNBSUB-PWY"	"<b>General Background</b>

Arginine biosynthesis is notable for its complexity and variability at the genetic level, and by its connection with several other pathways, such as pyrimidine and polyamine biosynthesis, and certain degradative pathways. The initial steps of the arginine biosynthetic pathways proceed via <i>N</i>-acetylated intermediates. The presumed reason for this is that the acetylation prevents the spontaneous cyclization of glutamate derivatives, which leads to proline biosynthesis, thus keeping the two pathways separate |CITS: [12633501]|. A variation of the pathway found in some archaebacteria and hyperthermophilic bacteria utilizes a dedicated carrier protein to protect the intermediates instead of acetylation.

Several alternative arginine biosynthetic pathways have evolved in bacteria:

In |FRAME:ARGSYN-PWY|, which is not very common, the key intermediate |FRAME:ACETYL-GLU| (NAG) is formed by the enzyme |FRAME: EC-2.3.1.1|. A second key intermediate downstream, |FRAME:N-ALPHA-ACETYLORNITHINE|, is hydrolyzed by the enzyme |FRAME: EC-3.5.1.16|, releasing acetate, and forming the arginine precursor |FRAME:L-ORNITHINE|.

In |FRAME:ARGSYNBSUB-PWY|), which is found in most of the prokaryotic and eukaryotic microbes investigated up to now, the two reactions mentioned above are linked: the acetyl group which is removed from |FRAME:N-ALPHA-ACETYLORNITHINE| is recycled onto glutamate, regenerating  |FRAME:ACETYL-GLU| (NAG).
This recycling is performed by the enzyme |FRAME: EC-2.3.1.35|. This pathway is considered more evolved, since the overall reaction is energetically more favorable |CITS: [3534538]|.

The variant |FRAME: PWY-5154| is found in several eubacteria. While in the two pathways mentioned above |FRAME:N-ALPHA-ACETYLORNITHINE| is deacetylate to |FRAME:L-ORNITHINE|, which is subsequntly transcarbamoylated to form |FRAME: L-CITRULLINE|, in this variant |FRAME:N-ALPHA-ACETYLORNITHINE| is not deacetylated. Instead, it is
transcarbamoylated directly by the enzyme |FRAME: EC-2.1.3.9|, resulting in |FRAME: CPD-7224|. The enzyme |FRAME:ACETYLORNDEACET-CPLX| can accept |FRAME: CPD-7224| as a substrate, and deacetylates it into |FRAME: L-CITRULLINE| |CITS: [16585758]|.

The variant |FRAME: PWY-7400|, which has been described in the archaebacterium |FRAME: TAX-2285|, involves early intermediates that are protected not by acetylation but by a carrier protein (the LysW |FRAME: LysW|), which participates in the biosynthesis of both |FRAME: ARG| and |FRAME: LEU| in these organsims |CITS: [23434852]|.

<b>About This Pathway</b>

The cyclic pathway for arginine biosynthesis has been demonstrated in many organisms, including the prokaryotes |FRAME:TAX-186817|, pseudomonads, cyanobacteria, photosynthetic bacteria and archaebacteria, as well as eukaryotic organisms such as |FRAME:TAX-4932|, |FRAME:TAX-5140| sp., and |FRAME:TAX-3052| sp.

Organisms that employ this pathway possess the <i>argJ</i> gene, which encodes the enzyme ornithine acetyltransferase (OAT). OAT catalyzes the transfer of the acetyl group from <i>N</i>-&alpha;-acetyl-ornithine to glutamate,  generating ornithine and <i>N</i>-acetyl-glutamate (NAG). Since the latter is the substrate for another enzyme in this pathway, <i>N</i>-acetyl-glutamate kinase (encoded by <i>argB</i>), which catalyzes a previous step, this reaction effectively converts the otherwise linear pathway to a cyclical pathway  |CITS: [JGM138-125][8025667]|.
While most of the NAG in these organisms is generated by OAT, some of it is still generated by <i>N</i>-acetyl-ornithine synthase (NAGS, EC 2.3.1.1, encoded by <i>argA</i>), which fulfils an anaplerotic (replenishment of pathway intermediates) role to replenish NAG that is lost due to degradation or cell division |CITS: [12633501]|.

In some bacteria, such as <i>Bacillus</i> sp. |CITS: [8473852 ]|, <i>Nisseria gonorrhoeae</i> |CITS: [1339419]|, |FRAME:TAX-2337| |CITS: [10931207]| and in yeast (|FRAME:TAX-4932|) |CITS: [9428669]|, OAT can have a dual enzymic function. In these organisms, either <i>N</i>-acetylornithine or acetyl-CoA can be used as acetyl donors for formation of NAG.  <i>argJ</i> genes from such organisms can complement both <i>argE</i> and <i>argA</i> mutations in |FRAME:TAX-562|. However, these organisms still possess separate NAGS enzymes encoded by <i>argA</i> genes. The biological role of duplicate NAGS activity in these organisms remains to be elucidated |CITS: [12633501]|.

<b>Additional yeast-specific info from the |FRAME:TAX-4930| Genome Database:</b>

The first five steps of arginine biosynthesis in <i>S. cerevisiae</i> take place in the mitochondrion
|CITS: [11553611][Hinnebusch]|. This part of the pathway is known as the acetylated derivatives cycle because the
acetyl group that is added to L-glutamate in the first step of the pathway is recycled via <i>N</i>-acetylglutamate
generated in the fifth step.
The enzymes that catalyze the second and third steps are encoded by a single gene (ARG5,6) that is translated
into a pre-protein which is imported into mitochondria and cleaved there to yield two enzymes, <i>N</i>-acetylglutamate
kinase and <i>N</i>-acetylglutamyl-phosphate reductase |CITS: [1649049]|.
These enzymes form a complex with each other and with <i>N</i>-acetylglutamate synthase, the first enzyme in the
pathway, which may have implications for regulation of their activity |CITS: [11553611]|.
The mitochondrial steps of the arginine biosynthesis pathway result in the formation of ornithine, which is exported
to the cytoplasm by the transporter Ort1p |CITS: [8798783]|. In the cytoplasm, L-ornithine is converted to
L-arginine in three reactions mediated by ornithine carbamoyltransferase, arginosuccinate synthase, and
argininosuccinate lyase.  Transcription of genes of the arginine biosynthetic pathway, as well as of other amino
acid biosynthetic pathways, is activated by the transcription factor Gcn4p under conditions of amino acid
starvation |CITS: [11390663][Hinnebusch]|. Transcription of ARG1, ARG3, ARG5,6, and ARG8 is also
repressed in the presence of arginine by the ArgR/Mcm1p complex, which consists of Arg80p, Arg81p, Arg82p,
and Mcm1p |CITS: [14563547]|. The transcriptional activator Gcn4p interacts with subunits of the ArgR/Mcm1p
repressor, allowing for fine-tuning of transcriptional control in response to arginine availability |CITS: [15289616]|."				"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=ARGININE-SYN"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-4983" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7400" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=ARGSYNBSUB-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5154" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=ARGSYN-PWY"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=IND-AMINO-ACID-SYN"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Amino-Acid-Biosynthesis"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7400"	"L-arginine biosynthesis IV (archaebacteria)"	"PWY-7400"	"<b>General Background</b>

Arginine biosynthesis is notable for its complexity and variability at the genetic level, and by its connection with several other pathways, such as pyrimidine and polyamine biosynthesis, and certain degradative pathways. The initial steps of the arginine biosynthetic pathways proceed via <i>N</i>-acetylated intermediates. The presumed reason for this is that the acetylation prevents the spontaneous cyclization of glutamate derivatives, which leads to proline biosynthesis, thus keeping the two pathways separate |CITS: [12633501]|. A variation of the pathway found in some archaebacteria and hyperthermophilic bacteria utilizes a dedicated carrier protein to protect the intermediates instead of acetylation.

Several alternative arginine biosynthetic pathways have evolved in bacteria:

In |FRAME:ARGSYN-PWY|, which is not very common, the key intermediate |FRAME:ACETYL-GLU| (NAG) is formed by the enzyme |FRAME: EC-2.3.1.1|. A second key intermediate downstream, |FRAME:N-ALPHA-ACETYLORNITHINE|, is hydrolyzed by the enzyme |FRAME: EC-3.5.1.16|, releasing acetate, and forming the arginine precursor |FRAME:L-ORNITHINE|.

In |FRAME:ARGSYNBSUB-PWY|), which is found in most of the prokaryotic and eukaryotic microbes investigated up to now, the two reactions mentioned above are linked: the acetyl group which is removed from |FRAME:N-ALPHA-ACETYLORNITHINE| is recycled onto glutamate, regenerating  |FRAME:ACETYL-GLU| (NAG).
This recycling is performed by the enzyme |FRAME: EC-2.3.1.35|. This pathway is considered more evolved, since the overall reaction is energetically more favorable |CITS: [3534538]|.

The variant |FRAME: PWY-5154| is found in several eubacteria. While in the two pathways mentioned above |FRAME:N-ALPHA-ACETYLORNITHINE| is deacetylate to |FRAME:L-ORNITHINE|, which is subsequntly transcarbamoylated to form |FRAME: L-CITRULLINE|, in this variant |FRAME:N-ALPHA-ACETYLORNITHINE| is not deacetylated. Instead, it is
transcarbamoylated directly by the enzyme |FRAME: EC-2.1.3.9|, resulting in |FRAME: CPD-7224|. The enzyme |FRAME:ACETYLORNDEACET-CPLX| can accept |FRAME: CPD-7224| as a substrate, and deacetylates it into |FRAME: L-CITRULLINE| |CITS: [16585758]|.

The variant |FRAME: PWY-7400|, which has been described in the archaebacterium |FRAME: TAX-2285|, involves early intermediates that are protected not by acetylation but by a carrier protein (the LysW |FRAME: LysW|), which participates in the biosynthesis of both |FRAME: ARG| and |FRAME: LEU| in these organsims |CITS: [23434852]|.

<b>About This Pathway</b>

The linear pathway of arginine biosynthesis has been described in several organisms including the <i>Enterobacteriaceae |CITS: [3534538]|</i>, the |FRAME:TAX-641| |CITS: [10692366]|, and the Gram-negative bacterium |FRAME:TAX-34|
|CITS: [ 9829957]|. The pathway in these organisms starts with the acetylation of the amino moiety of |FRAME: GLT|
catalyzed by ArgA, ArgJ or both, yielding |FRAME:ACETYL-GLU| (NAG).

Some archaeal species, such as |FRAME: TAX-2284|, which are known to produce |FRAME: ARG|, do not have either ArgA and ArgJ orthologs. Instead, these organisms use the |FRAME: G-17812|-encoded ligase to bind |FRAME: GLT| to a dedicated |FRAME: LysW \"carrier protein\"| encoded by the <i>lysW</i> gene. The carrier protein, as well as the next 4 enzymes in the pathway, are bifunctional and participate in both |FRAME: ARG| and |FRAME: LEU| biosynthesis in these organisms (see |FRAME: PWY-3081|).

The C-terminal part of the carrier protein is acidic and is easily recognized by the subsequent enzymes, all of which have a basic environment around their active sites. In this way the subsequent transformations leading to |FRAME: L-ORNITHINE| occur while the amino acid is attached to LysW |CITS: [19620981]|. Once formed, the ornithine is removed from the carrier protein by a dedicated enzyme encoded by the |FRAME: G-17816| gene |CITS: [23434852]|."				"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=ARGININE-SYN"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-4983" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-7400" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=ARGSYNBSUB-PWY" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5154" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=ARGSYN-PWY"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=IND-AMINO-ACID-SYN"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Amino-Acid-Biosynthesis"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=ARGSYN-PWY"	"L-arginine biosynthesis I (via L-ornithine)"	"ARGSYN-PWY"	"<b>General Background</b>

Arginine biosynthesis is notable for its complexity and variability at the genetic level, and by its connection with several other pathways, such as pyrimidine and polyamine biosynthesis, and certain degradative pathways. The initial steps of the arginine biosynthetic pathways proceed via <i>N</i>-acetylated intermediates. The presumed reason for this is that the acetylation prevents the spontaneous cyclization of glutamate derivatives, which leads to proline biosynthesis, thus keeping the two pathways separate |CITS: [12633501]|. A variation of the pathway found in some archaebacteria and hyperthermophilic bacteria utilizes a dedicated carrier protein to protect the intermediates instead of acetylation.

Several alternative arginine biosynthetic pathways have evolved in bacteria:

In |FRAME:ARGSYN-PWY|, which is not very common, the key intermediate |FRAME:ACETYL-GLU| (NAG) is formed by the enzyme |FRAME: EC-2.3.1.1|. A second key intermediate downstream, |FRAME:N-ALPHA-ACETYLORNITHINE|, is hydrolyzed by the enzyme |FRAME: EC-3.5.1.16|, releasing acetate, and forming the arginine precursor |FRAME:L-ORNITHINE|.

In |FRAME:ARGSYNBSUB-PWY|), which is found in most of the prokaryotic and eukaryotic microbes investigated up to now, the two reactions mentioned above are linked: the acetyl group which is removed from |FRAME:N-ALPHA-ACETYLORNITHINE| is recycled onto glutamate, regenerating  |FRAME:ACETYL-GLU| (NAG).
This recycling is performed by the enzyme |FRAME: EC-2.3.1.35|. This pathway is considered more evolved, since the overall reaction is energetically more favorable |CITS: [3534538]|.

The variant |FRAME: PWY-5154| is found in several eubacteria. While in the two pathways mentioned above |FRAME:N-ALPHA-ACETYLORNITHINE| is deacetylate to |FRAME:L-ORNITHINE|, which is subsequntly transcarbamoylated to form |FRAME: L-CITRULLINE|, in this variant |FRAME:N-ALPHA-ACETYLORNITHINE| is not deacetylated. Instead, it is
transcarbamoylated directly by the enzyme |FRAME: EC-2.1.3.9|, resulting in |FRAME: CPD-7224|. The enzyme |FRAME:ACETYLORNDEACET-CPLX| can accept |FRAME: CPD-7224| as a substrate, and deacetylates it into |FRAME: L-CITRULLINE| |CITS: [16585758]|.

The variant |FRAME: PWY-7400|, which has been described in the archaebacterium |FRAME: TAX-2285|, involves early intermediates that are protected not by acetylation but by a carrier protein (the LysW |FRAME: LysW|), which participates in the biosynthesis of both |FRAME: ARG| and |FRAME: LEU| in these organsims |CITS: [23434852]|.

<b>About This Pathway</b>

This linear variant of the arginine biosynthesis pathway has been reported from the <i>Enterobacteriaceae |CITS: [3534538]|</i>, the |FRAME:TAX-641| |CITS: [10692366]|, and the Gram-negative bacterium |FRAME:TAX-34| |CITS: [ 9829957]|. The pathway was also described in the archaeon |FRAME:TAX-2287| |CITS: [vandecasteele90]|, but in most likelihood that organism possesses a different variant of the pathway (see |FRAME: PWY-7400|).

In this pathway  glutamate is acetylated to <i>N</i>-acetyl-glutamate (NAG) by the enzyme NAG synthase, encoded by the <i>argA</i> gene. The acetyl donor for this reaction is  acetyl-CoA. NAG is then converted in several enzymatic steps to <i>N</i>-acetyl-ornithine. The acetyl group is removed in the form of acetate by the enzyme acetylornithine deacetylase, encoded by the <i>argE</i> gene. Ornithine is then combined with carbamoyl phosphate to form citrulline, which is converted in two steps to L-arginine." "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Pathways"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Amino-Acid-Biosynthesis" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=NIL&object=Generalized-Reactions"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY0-1061"	"superpathway of L-alanine biosynthesis"	"PWY0-1061"	"|FRAME: L-ALPHA-ALANINE| is an essential component of protein and peptidoglycan. The later also contains about three molecules of D-alanine  for every L-alanine. Only about 10 percent of the total alanine synthesized flows into peptidoglycan.

At least three pathways (|FRAME: ALANINE-VALINESYN-PWY|, |FRAME: ALANINE-SYN2-PWY|, and |FRAME: PWY0-1021|) contribute to the synthesis of alanine. Alanine biosynthesis I is established only by existence of the relevant enzymes. Its contribution to alanine synthesis remains speculative because alanine auxotrophs have not yet been isolated. Because alanine but not valine represses AvtA, its primary purpose is probably synthesis of L-alanine |CITS: [396446]||CITS: [7040341]|. Existence of the Alanine biosyntheis II  pathways rests on the evidence that lutamate-pyruvate 
aminotransferase acitivity is found in crude cell extracts; the enzymes has not been purified nor have mutant alleles of its designated encoding gene (alaB) been isolated  |CITS: [396446]|, |CITS: [4146872]|.  The conversion can also be mediated as a side reaction of alanine racemase |CITS: [9832621]| . The alanine biosyntheis III pathway, mediated by cysteine desulfurase activity  is required to donate sulfane sulfur for the synthesis of Fe-S clusters, thiamine, thionucleosides in tRNAs, biotin, lipoic acid, and molybdopterin |CITS: [12382038]| probably contributes only a minor amount of the cell's alanine requirement, as judged by the cell's total requirement for sulfane sulfur.

"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=THRESYN-PWY"	"superpathway of L-threonine biosynthesis"	"THRESYN-PWY"	"The overall superpathway of threonine biosynthesis as shown here covers the entire process of converting the central energy metabolism molecule |FRAME: OXALACETIC_ACID| into |FRAME: THR|.

This pathway is regulated at multiple points by its end product, both via enzyme inhibition and attenuation. Attenuation in response to |FRAME: ILE| and |FRAME: THR| represses the second, fourth, fifth, and sixth steps in this pathway. In addition, the enzymatic activity of |FRAME: EC-1.1.1.3| is inhibited by |FRAME: THR|, regulating flux through the second and fourth steps in the pathway.

In |FRAME: TAX-562| three enzymes carry out the second step and two enzymes carry out the fourth step, reflecting the many downstream products that depend on those reaction steps.

More thoroughg regulatory relationships affecting these pathway steps is provided in |FRAME: P4-PWY|." "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=IND-AMINO-ACID-SYN"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=NIL&object=Generalized-Reactions" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Amino-Acid-Biosynthesis"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-6897"	"thiamine salvage II"	"PWY-6897"	"<b>General Background</b>

|FRAME: THIAMINE-PYROPHOSPHATE \"Thiamine diphosphate\"|, also known as vitamin B1, is known to play a fundamental role in energy metabolism. It is an essential cofactor for a variety of enzymes such as |FRAME: TRANSKETOI-CPLX transketolase|, |FRAME: PYRUVATEDEH-CPLX \"pyruvate dehydrogenase\"|, |FRAME: CPLX3O-118 \"pyruvate decarboxylase\"|, and |FRAME: CPLX66-42 \"&alpha;-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase\"| |CITS:[15326535]|. Its discovery followed from the original early research on the anti-beriberi factor found in rice bran. Beriberi, a neurological disease, was particularly prevalent in Asia, where the refining of rice resulted in the removal of the thiamine-containing husk |CITS: [Begley96]|.
Thiamine is synthesized <i>de novo</i> by microorganisms, plants and some lower eukaryotes (e.g. |FRAME: TAX-5820|), but not by higher eukaryotes, which must obtain it through their diet.

<b>About This Pathway</b>

Since the <i>de novo</i> biosynthesis of |FRAME: THIAMINE-PYROPHOSPHATE| is a very complex process, many organisms possess various salvage pathways thart enable them to rescue thiamine fragments obtained from the environment. This pathway describes the salvage of two thiamine-degradation compounds, |FRAME: THZ| and |FRAME: HMP| (HMP).

The key enzyme of the pathway is |FRAME: CPLX-8351| (|FRAME: BSU38300|), an enzyme  that phosphorylates the degradation product |FRAME: THZ|, turning it into the phosphorylated form that it a part of the <i>de novo</i> biosynthetic pathway.

HMP is processed by |FRAME: BSU11710-MONOMER| (|FRAME: BSU11710|), a bifunctional enzyme that also takes part in the biosynthetic pathway. The enzyme phosphorylates HMP into |FRAME: AMINO-HYDROXYMETHYL-METHYL-PYR-P|, already an intermediate of the biosynthetic pathway, and continues to add another phosphate, resulting in |FRAME: AMINO-HYDROXYMETHYL-METHYLPYRIMIDINE-PP|, the other substrate of |FRAME: BSU38290-MONOMER|.

The rest of the pathway is identical to the biosynthetic pathway: |FRAME: BSU38290-MONOMER| catalyzes the coupling of the thiazole and pyrimidine moieties, while |FRAME: BSU05900-MONOMER| adds another phosphate group, generating the active form |FRAME: THIAMINE-PYROPHOSPHATE|." // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Thiamine-Biosynthesis"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=NIL&object=Generalized-Reactions" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5180"	"toluene degradation I (aerobic) (<I>via</I> <i>o</I>-cresol)"	"PWY-5180"	"<b>General Background</b>

|FRAME: TOLUENE Toluene| is widely used as an industrial additive and solvent. Toluene and related aromatic compounds can be degraded by bacteria, and have been studied in the metabolically versatile genus |FRAME:TAX-286| and closely related genera. These studies have been directed toward bioremediation of environmental pollutants by metabolic engineering, and the development of syntrophic bacterial consortia  (reviewed in |CITS: [15492931]|). Aerobic pathways of toluene degradation have been identified in various species that involve different initial monooxygenase, or hydroxylating dioxygenase reactions. Several of these pathways converge in the formation of |FRAME: CPD-111| (2,3-dihydroxytoluenel) |CITS: [1892384]|. This compound is a substrate for ring cleavage enzymes, the products of which are metabolized via a common <i>meta</i> fission pathway, resulting in the formation of compounds of central metabolism (see this pathway and MetaCyc pathways |FRAME: TOLUENE-DEG-3-OH-PWY| and |FRAME: TOLUENE-DEG-DIOL-PWY|).   

<b>About This Pathway</b>

A degradative plasmid, TOM, containing an operon for the inducible toluene <i>ortho</i>-monooxygenase pathway has been identified in |FRAME: TAX-292| G4. The operon, <i>tomA012345</i>, encodes toluene <i>ortho</i>-monooxygenase and catechol 2,3-dioxygenase, which allow this organism to grow on toluene and related compounds as sole carbon and energy source |CITS: [7538275]|, and in |CITS: [11751810]|. This pathway for toluene degradation via |FRAME: CPD-111| in |FRAME: TAX-292| (previously known as <i>Pseudomonas cepacia</i>) is shown here.

In this pathway, toluene is sequentially hydroxylated by the |FRAME: CPLX-6483| system. The first hydroxylation is at the <i>ortho</i> position yielding |FRAME: CPD-109| (2-hydroxytoluene) as an intermediate, and the second is at the <i>meta</i> position yielding |FRAME: CPD-111| |CITS: [7578004]|.  

Ring fission of |FRAME: CPD-111| is catalyzed by catechol 2,3-dioxygenase to produce |FRAME: 2H6OH2-4DIENOATE|. This compound is hydrolyzed to |FRAME: OXOPENTENOATE|, or its tautomeric dienol form |FRAME: CPD-6761|. This tautomerization occurs spontaneously in aqueous solution |CITS: [15301547]|. It is not known which tautomeric form is produced by the hydrolase, and which form is used by the hydratase of |FRAME: TAX-292|. However, it has been suggested that the |FRAME:TAX-303| hydratase uses the dienol form as a substrate |CITS: [2681159]|, and there is evidence that the |FRAME:TAX-562| hydratase also uses the dienol form as substrate, producing a ketonized intermediate in the reaction mechanism |CITS: [9492273]|.

The enzymes catalyzing the last three reactions in this pathway, as well as the intermediates, were not directly demonstrated in |FRAME: TAX-292|. However, their existence in this organism is inferred by work in <i>Pseudomonas</i> |CITS: [8063106]|. The products of the pathway are pyruvate, which enters central metabolism, and acetaldehyde, which may be converted by acylating aldehyde dehydrogenase to acetyl-CoA, a central metabolite |CITS: [8063106][8419288]|." "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=AROMATIC-COMPOUNDS-DEGRADATION"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=NIL&object=Generalized-Reactions" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Degradation"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY-5182"	"toluene degradation II (aerobic) (via 4-methylcatechol)"	"PWY-5182"	"Toluene is widely used as an industrial additive and solvent. Toluene and related aromatic compounds can be degraded by bacteria, and have been studied in the metabolically versatile genus |FRAME:TAX-286| and closely related genera.  These studies have been directed toward bioremediation of environmental pollutants by metabolic engineering, and the development of syntrophic bacterial consortia  (reviewed in |CITS: [15492931]|).  Aerobic pathways of toluene degradation have been identified in various species that involve different initial monooxygenase, or hydroxylating dioxygenase reactions.  Several of these pathways converge in the formation of 2,3-dihydroxytoluene (3-methylcatechol) |CITS: [1892384]|.  This compound is a substrate for ring cleavage enzymes, the products of which are metabolized via a common <i>meta</i> fission pathway, resulting in the formation of compounds of central metabolism (see this pathway and MetaCyc pathways |FRAME: TOLUENE-DEG-2-OH-PWY| and |FRAME: TOLUENE-DEG-DIOL-PWY|).   

Toluene degradation in |FRAME: TAX-329 <i>Ralstonia pickettii</i> (previously known as <i>Pseudomonas pickettii</i> and <i>Burkholderia pickettii</i>)\"| is controlled by a chroosomal regulon |CITS: [10671442]|. The initial hydroxylation reactions are catalyzed by toluene 3-monooxygenase, followed by <i>meta</i> cleavage of the benzene ring by catechol 2,3-dioxygenase, and subsequent degradation via the <i>meta</i> cleavage pathway (see |FRAME:P183-PWY|) |CITS: [8206853]|.   

There is disagreement in the literature over the hydroxylation reactions of the first enzyme of this pathway. Initial reports suggested that the first hydroxylation is at the <i>meta</i> position yielding <i>m</i>-cresol (3-hydroxytoluene) as an intermediate, and the second yields 2,3-dihydroxytoluene (3-methylcatechol) pathway |CITS: [8206853]|.  However, later work suggested that toluene 3-monooxygenase is a predominantly <i>para</i> cleaving enzyme.  Its initial products were shown in that study to be 90% <i>p</i>-cresol, and 10% <i>m</i>-cresol.  <i>p</i>-Cresol was further hydroxylated to 4-methylcatechol |CITS: [15126473]|. Although further metabolism of 4-methylcatechol was not studied in that report, it has been shown to be a substrate of catechol 2,3-dioxygenase in <i>Ralstonia pickettii</i> |CITS: [1856161]|.

Ring fission of 2,3-dihydroxytoluene is catalyzed by catechol 2,3-dioxygenase to produce <i>cis,cis</i>-2-hydroxy-6-oxohepta-2,4-dienoate.  This compound is hydrolyzed to 2-oxopent-4-enoate, or its tautomeric dienol form <i>cis</i>-2-hydroxypenta-2,4-dienoate.  This tautomerization occurs spontaneously in aqueous solution |CITS: [15301547]|.  It is not known which tautomeric form is produced by the hydrolase, and which form is used by the hydratase of <i>R. pickettii</i> in this pathway.  However, it has been suggested that the |FRAME:TAX-303| hydratase uses the dienol form as a substrate |CITS: [2681159]|, and there is evidence that the |FRAME:TAX-562| hydratase also uses the dienol form as substrate, producing a ketonized intermediate in the reaction mechanism  |CITS: [9492273]|.  The products of the pathway are pyruvate, which enters central metabolism, and acetaldehyde, which may be converted by acylating aldehyde dehydrogenase to acetyl-CoA, a central metabolite, as suggested by work in <i>Pseudomonas</i> |CITS: [8063106], [8419288]|." "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=TCA-GLYOX-BYPASS"	"superpathway of glyoxylate bypass and TCA"	"TCA-GLYOX-BYPASS"	"This superpathway integrates the common prokaryotic TCA cycle with the glyoxylate shunt, a variation that bypasses the steps of the TCA cycle in which carbon is lost in the form of |FRAME: CARBON-DIOXIDE|.


The |FRAME: TCA \"TCA cycle\"| is a catabolic pathway that generates energy and reducing power as well as precursors for biosynthesis. The TCA cycle is very common, and a variation of it exists in practically all aerobic living organisms |CITS: [16746397][16746585][16747930]|.

The input to the cycle is |FRAME: ACETYL-COA|, which is produced by the |FRAME: PYRUVATEDEH-CPLX \"pyruvate dehydrogenase complex\"| from pyruvate, the product of the ubiquitous glycolysis pathway, but is also generated by the degradation of fats and proteins and by the fermentation of many feedstocks.

In every turn the TCA cycle converts one molecule of |FRAME: ACETYL-COA| into two |FRAME: CARBON-DIOXIDE| molecules, reduces a total of four molecules of either |FRAME: NAD|, |FRAME: NADP|, or |FRAME: Quinones quinone| to |FRAME: NADH|, |FRAME: NADPH| and |FRAME: Reduced-Quinones quinol|, respectively, and phosphorylates one molecule of GDP to GTP.

The reduced molecules of NADH/NADPH/quinol that are formed by the TCA cycle serve as electron donors for oxidative phosphorylation (see for example |FRAME: PWY-3781|). In that process the electrons flow to a terminal acceptor, powering on their way proton pumps that trasport protons across the cytoplasmic or mitochondrial membranes, generating a proton motive force (PMF). As the protons return to their original location, they power ATPase enzymes that phosphorylate ADP molecules to ATP. The total energy gained from the complete breakdown of one molecule of glucose by glycolysis, the TCA cycle, and oxidative phosphorylation equals about 30 ATP molecules in eukaryotes.

This superpathway also includes the |FRAME: GLYOXYLATE-BYPASS|, which bypasses those steps in the TCA cycle that lead to a loss of |FRAME:CARBON-DIOXIDE|, eliminating the loss of carbon. The glyoxylate cycle operates in bacteria and some eukaryotic organisms. In |FRAME:TAX-562| the bypass is active when growth on 2 carbon compounds requires conservation of 4 carbon TCA intermediates, and is repressed during growth on glucose |CITS: [6378912][6389540][6329757][2512996]|. In plants the cycle is invovled in the metabolism of storage oils during germination of seeds |CITS:[Brownleade97]|. The cycle also operates in developing eggs of nematodes, where it converts triacylglycerols to carbohydrates |CITS: [627278]|."	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=GLYCOLYSIS-TCA-GLYOX-BYPASS"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=TCA" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY0-845"	"superpathway of pyridoxal 5'-phosphate biosynthesis and salvage"	"PWY0-845"	"
This superpathway shows the various ways that |FRAME:TAX-562| can obtain pyridoxal 5'-phosphate, a coenzyme for many 
enzymes that participate in amino  acid and glycogen  metabolism. It can be synthesized de novo from 
erythrose-4-phosphate, glyceraldehyde-3-phoshpate, and pyruvate |CITS: [12896974], [9696782]|. 
It can also be obtained via salvage pathways from certain precursors, pyridoxal, pyroxidine and pyridoxamine, that 
might be available in the environment |CITS: [323431], [9537380], [8764513]|." "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=IND-AMINO-ACID-SYN"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=NIL&object=Generalized-Reactions" // "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Amino-Acid-Biosynthesis"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY0-781"	"aspartate superpathway"	"PWY0-781"	"This superpathway integrates the biosynthesis of several compounds that are derived from the central metabolite |FRAME: OXALACETIC_ACID|, an intermediate of the |FRAME:TCA \"TCA cycle\"|, including the amino acids |FRAME: L-ASPARTATE|, |FRAME: LYS|, |FRAME: THR|, and |FRAME: MET|, as well as the main methyl-group carrier |FRAME: S-ADENOSYLMETHIONINE| and the proton/electron carrier |FRAME: NAD|. The specific pathways shown here are those used by the bacterium |FRAME: TAX-562|.

The pathway starts by the reversible transamination of |FRAME:OXALACETIC_ACID| to |FRAME: L-ASPARTATE|, which is catalyzed by |FRAME: EC-2.6.1.1|, providing a link between carbohydrate and amino acid metabolism. |FRAME:OXALACETIC_ACID Oxaloacetate|, which is consumed in this pathway, is replenished from the |FRAME:TCA \"TCA cycle\"|, by |FRAME: EC-6.4.1.1|, and in some bacteria also by |FRAME: EC-4.1.1.31| |CITS: [Gottschalk1986]|.

To start |FRAME: NAD| biosynthesis, |FRAME: L-ASPARTATE| is oxidized by |FRAME: EC-1.4.3.16|, the first enzyme dedicated to <i>de novo</i> |FRAME: NAD| biosynthesis in some bacteria. The enzyme can use either |FRAME: OXYGEN-MOLECULE| or |FRAME: FUM| as electron acceptor, enabling it to function under both aerobic and anaerobic conditions |CITS: [11863440]|. |FRAME: NAD| biosynthesis proceeds via |FRAME: QUINOLINATE|, |FRAME: NICOTINATE_NUCLEOTIDE|, and |FRAME: DEAMIDO-NAD|, which is aminated to |FRAME: NAD| (see pathway |FRAME: PYRIDNUCSYN-PWY|)

|FRAME: L-ASPARTATE| can also by converted in two steps to |FRAME: L-ASPARTATE-SEMIALDEHYDE|, where the pathway branches further. One branch leads toward |FRAME: LYS| biosynthesis, while the other continues towards the biosynthesis of |FRAME: THR|, |FRAME: MET|, and |FRAME: S-ADENOSYLMETHIONINE| |CITS: [14929228]|.

Because the conversion of |FRAME: L-ASPARTATE| to |FRAME: L-ASPARTATE-SEMIALDEHYDE| is common to many downstream biosynthetic pathways, |FRAME: TAX-562| has three different enzymes that initialize it (|FRAME: ASPKINIHOMOSERDEHYDROGI-CPLX \"aspartate kinase I\"|, |FRAME: ASPKINIIHOMOSERDEHYDROGII-CPLX \"aspartate kinase II\"|, and |FRAME: ASPKINIII-CPLX \"aspartate kinase III\"|), which are controlled by the available supply of |FRAME: THR|, |FRAME: MET| and |FRAME: LYS|, respectively |CITS: [4148765]|.
The L-lysine pathway shown here belongs to the diaminopimelate (DAP) group of Lysine pathways, and is known as the succinylase variant (see |FRAME: DAPLYSINESYN-PWY|, as it involves succinylated intermediates.

The rest of the |FRAME: L-ASPARTATE-SEMIALDEHYDE| is converted to |FRAME: HOMO-SER| by |FRAME: EC-1.1.1.3|. Once again, |FRAME: TAX-562| has two different enzymes catalyzing this reaction, which are controlled by the availability of |FRAME: THR| and |FRAME: MET|, respectively |CITS: [4551091][4889171]|.
|FRAME: HOMO-SER| can be isomerized to |FRAME: THR| in two steps that involved phosphorylation and de-phosphorylation |CITS: [11368768]|, or alternatively can lead to the formation of |FRAME: MET| in a 4-step pathway. 

For |FRAME: MET| biosynthesis, homoserine is first activated by <i>O</i>-succinylation, and the product is combined with |FRAME: CYS| to form cystathionine. This compound is cleaved to homocysteine, which is subsequently methylated to produce methionine. The last reaction is catalyzed in |FRAME: TAX-562| by two different enzymes, |FRAME: EC-2.1.1.13| and |FRAME: EC-2.1.1.14|. Both enzymes use |FRAME: 5-METHYL-THF-GLU-N| as the methyl donor. However, the former requires cobalamin (vitamin B<sub>12</sub>), while the latter does not |CITS: [1339288]|.

Once |FRAME: MET| is formed, a single enzyme, the ATP-dependent |FRAME: EC-2.5.1.6|, can convert it to |FRAME: S-ADENOSYLMETHIONINE| |CITS: [6251075]|." "HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=PWY66-5"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=Pathways"	"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=NIL&object=Generalized-Reactions"
"HTTPS://biocyc.org/META/NEW-IMAGE?type=PATHWAY&object=MET-SAM-PWY"	"superpathway of <i>S</i>-adenosyl-L-methionine biosynthesis"	"MET-SAM-PWY"	"This superpathway integrates the biosynthesis of the amino acids |FRAME: HOMO-SER| and |FRAME: MET| from |FRAME: L-ASPARTATE|, and the single step conversion of |FRAME: MET| to |FRAME: S-ADENOSYLMETHIONINE|. The sub-pathways used for construction of this superpathway are those used by the bacterium |FRAME: TAX-562|.

|FRAME: MET| (met) is one of the proteinogenic amino acids, but is also required for a number of important cellular functions, including the initiation of protein synthesis, the methylation of DNA, rRNA and xenobiotics, and the biosynthesis of cysteine, phospholipids and polyamines.
In all metzoa |FRAME: MET| is an essential amino acid (an indispensable amino acid that cannot be synthesized <i>de novo</i>) and must be supplied in the diet.

In the pathway shown here, |FRAME: MET| is synthesized using organic sulfur through transsulfuration of <i>O</i>-acylated homoserine with |FRAME: CYS| to form |FRAME: L-CYSTATHIONINE|. Cystathionine is then cleaved to |FRAME: HOMO-CYS|, which is methylated to methionine |CITS: [3309561]|.
The methylation of |FRAME: HOMO-CYS| to |FRAME: MET| is catalyzed by either a cobalamin-independent enzyme (|FRAME: EC-2.1.1.13 \"EC 2.1.1.13\"|) or a cobalamin-dependent enzyme (|FRAME: EC-2.1.1.14 \"EC 2.1.1.14\"|), depending upon the species or growth conditions |CITS: [9409150][12948640]|.

The <i>O</i>-acyl group of homoserine is an acetyl group in fungi, yeast, and most Gram-positive bacteria (see |FRAME: HSERMETANA-PWY|) and a succinyl group (as shown here) in enteric bacteria and some other Gram-negative bacteria, such as |FRAME: TAX-287| and |FRAME:TAX-303| (|CITS: [3309561][9409150][10482527]|).

Once |FRAME: MET| is formed, a single enzyme, the ATP-dependent |FRAME: EC-2.5.1.6|, can convert it to |FRAME: S-ADENOSYLMETHIONINE| (SAM) |CITS: [6251075]|. SAM is the principal biological methyl donor in transmethylation reactions, and is also used as a sulfur donor in transsulfuration reactions, as an aminopropyl group donor in polyamine biosynthesis, and as a cofactor of many enzymes that use radical chemistry by generating a |FRAME: CPD-15400|."
